column2: LEAD: JEROME KERN'S ''Sally'' was a major musical success in 1920, running for almost two seasons and establishing Marilyn Miller as one of Broadway's most popular stars. In contrast to other Kern hits, the show is seldom revived. For that reason, one might suppose that the New Amsterdam Theater Company is performing a service by presenting the quasi-concert version that began a five-performance engagement Wednesday at the New Academy Theater.

LEAD: With a winning smile and a friendly wave to her admirers, the Duchess of York, known to most of the world as ''Fergie,'' made her first official visit to New York City last night for a fund-raising performance of Andrew Lloyd Weber's ''The Phantom of the Opera'' benefitting three charities.
LEAD: Mats Wilander outlasted Stefan Edberg, the defending champion, 6-0, 6-7, 6-3, 3-6, 6-1, today to move into the men's final of the Australian Open Tennis Championships.

LEAD: UPDATE on Dominick's, the pint-size, wildly popular Italian institution on Arthur Avenue in the Bronx: At 3 P.M. on a Sunday, customers were lined up in the foyer while inside gleeful diners, packed tighter than a jar of Italian peppers, were digging into oval platters of homemade lasagna, stuffed shells, ziti in red sauce, bresaola, pork chops and more.

LEAD: A day after its $4.2 billion takeover bid for the insurer Farmers Group Inc. was rejected, a subsidiary of Britain-based B.A.T. Industries indicated it might be willing to raise its offer. Henry Frigon, president of Batus Inc., based in Louisville, Ky., urged Farmers' directors to meet with B.A.T.

LEAD: The Government extended its 13-year-old state of emergency for six months today, saying it needed to deal with threats from rebels. Parliament was told that South African-backed Mozambique National Resistance rebels were responsible for 101 incidents from July 12 to Jan. 4, including murders, abductions and the burning and ransacking of villages.
LEAD: From September to December every year, the United Nations stages its annual extravaganza at Turtle Bay.

LEAD: There are a few people left at the Pentagon who still think it's possible to turn the place around on a dime, or preferably a nickel.

LEAD: Art Monk practiced with the Washington Redskins today for the first time in more than six weeks as the team began preparations for the Super Bowl.

LEAD: ''PROMISED LAND'' tries hard to win you over but finally wears you down with its sincerity. Michael Hoffman, the writer and director, seems determined to inject freshness into the old story about graduating seniors who discover life is hard after high school, but he transforms his best ideas and images into bludgeons.

LEAD: Dominic Adams walking past a mound of snow that had been trucked to a downtown park. The imported snow was to have been used in a snow-sculpture contest scheduled to be part of the city's winter festival this weekend. However, officials decided to cancel event because of unusually warm weather. (NYT/Joe

LEAD: EVER since Larry Holmes agreed to take $3.1 million for taking Mike Tyson's punches, he has been a different Larry Holmes, a hermit in a stylish sweatsuit. He trained in his own quiet gym in Easton, Pa. He hardly talked to sportswriters. He didn't arrive in Atlantic City until 48 hours before he will try to dethrone Tyson as the world heavyweight champion.

LEAD: Sam St. Laurent, a goaltender the Devils traded to Detroit two summers ago, helped drop New Jersey below the .500 mark for the first time this season as he made 27 saves tonight for the Red Wings, who beat the Devils, 3-2. Brent Ashton's second goal of the game, scored 3 minutes 37 seconds into overtime, was the difference.

LEAD: An article from Washington on Wednesday cited a study showing that Pat Robertson's Presidential campaign paid more than $4 million to three consulting companies in the first nine months of 1987. The article noted that under Federal law, consultants in turn can hire subcontractors in a way that lets a candidate avoid disclosing precisely how the money is spent.

LEAD: LOOKED at one way, George Balanchine's ''Jewels'' could be called a three-act abstract ballet in which each act evokes qualities associated with a particular jewel. Looked at another way, it could be argued that ''Jewels'' is not a three-act ballet at all, but three one-act ballets, for each of its parts is self-contained and has music by a different composer.

LEAD: It's that time of year in the suburbs. The doorbell rings. You answer. At first you don't see anything. You look down and it's a lovely little girl with a million-dollar smile and maybe a ponytail to break your heart. You smile back - relieved it's not a religious pamphleteer, or even worse, a guy selling meat out of his trunk - and already you have made the fatal mistake.

LEAD: AMERICAN dance has been formed and shaped by choreographers who broke from tradition to follow their own lights. In the case of Danny Buraczeski, whose jazz dance pieces are being performed by his company this weekend at the Joyce Theater, the break was twofold. Mr. Buraczeski, who began dancing as a Japanese major at Bucknell University and went on to Broadway show-dancing, chose to devote himself to choreographing jazz dance, a form that has seldom been taken so seriously.

LEAD: FEW jazz legends have a more exotic mystique than Django Reinhardt, the Belgian-born gypsy guitarist and banjo player who led the legendary Parisian ensemble known as the Quintet of the Hot Club of France in the 1930's and 40's. By the time of his death in 1953, at age 43, he was recognized as one of the three or four most important jazz guitarists in history, and his influence has reverberated from Les Paul, one of his great champions in the 1940's, to Willie Nelson in his nostalgic mode.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: HE has a year of collegiate eligibility left, but Craig (Ironhead) Heyward, the Pittsburgh running back who was the nation's second-leading rusher last season, has apparently given up on college and plans to seek a pro career. According to The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, Heyward did poorly in his courses last fall, has not been going to classes at all this term and has told friends he wants to turn pro.

LEAD: THE safety pin has had nothing if not an interesting existence. It started off keeping diapers together; in a few old-fashioned families it still serves that purpose. Then came the punk movement, which turned this humble clasp into a symbol of rebellion.
LEAD: Connally on the Block

LEAD: ITEM: Just a few weeks after Richard D. Bernard learned that his job as manager of merchandise marketing at NBC would be eliminated last May, he was given a shot at another position in the company. Mr. Bernard chose instead to take his chances as an unemployed job hunter. ''I wasn't so sure that being a survivor was any better than being let go with a severance package,'' he said.
LEAD: Poland Extends An Official Hand To Rebel Artists Once Held At Arm's Length

LEAD: JUST AS SKIRT lengths and shapes go in and out of style, so too do body types. When the reedy, angular physique of models in the 1960's and 70's was replaced by a more curvaceous ideal, many fashion pundits declared that, at last, womanly women were attractive again. But the new ideal, shown off in the tight and skimpy spring clothes that crowded the runways late last fall, seems even more demanding than the old one.
LEAD: EVERY time I go back for a visit to England I realize how good potatoes can be.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Henry Tulgan of Pittsfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ronna Lynn Tulgan, to Thomas Winslow Ostheimer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Ostheimer of York, Me.
LEAD: IN Montreal, as elsewhere, large museums with a broad variety of programs and large-scale exhibitions receive lots of attention, but specialized small museums are all too often passed by.

LEAD: A new and potentially disruptive dispute has risen over an announcement Friday by the San Diego Yacht Club that it would sail a multihull yacht against New Zealand's monohull challenger in the America's Cup next fall.
LEAD: Butch Reynolds outdueled Antonio McKay for the victory in the 400-meter dash, and Marcus O'Sullivan continued his winning form in the mile tonight in the Kodak Invitational indoor meet.

LEAD: Wallis Bleecker Dunckel, the president of Bankers Trust Company from 1960 to 1966, died Thursday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Easton, Conn.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo will use a panel of top legal aides to decide if a special state prosecutor should be appointed in what has been described as a racial and sexual attack on a teen-age girl, a spokesman said today.

LEAD: Although senators routinely speak of offering amendments, reservations or understandings to the Soviet-American treaty on intermediate-range nuclear missiles, staff members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee say these terms are outmoded.
LEAD: ON that always anxious night before the end of winter vacation, our 10-year-old son, Josh, sat on the edge of the bed, legs swinging.
LEAD: DEFINITION OF disease is a tricky business.

LEAD: EACH TIME I GO home to see my parents at their house near Poughkeepsie, N.Y., my brother, a schizophrenic for almost nine years now, comes to visit from the halfway house where he lives nearby. He owns a car that my parents help him to maintain, and his food and washing are taken care of by the halfway house.

LEAD: I WAS the only single woman left among my friends until three years ago. I remember that time well, because while my friends were altering their existence for a lifetime partnership, I was preparing for what I thought would be a life alone.

LEAD: UNTIL 1986, most people had never heard of superconductivity. But for 75 years scientists have known that certain materials lose all resistance in conducting electricity under conditions of extreme cold. Such temperatures can be achieved only by cooling with liquid helium, which is quite expensive and difficult to use.

LEAD: Vanya Maria Persico and Lawrence Jeffrey Perez, staff members of the New York State Assembly, plan to marry in July, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Persico of Albany and San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, have announced.

LEAD: The Israeli Army, concerned about reports of excessive brutality and beatings of Palestinians by Israeli soldiers, said today it would take steps to increase supervision of soldiers in the field.

LEAD: AT the first day of hearings on whether Governor Evan Mecham should be impeached, it was quickly apparent that his critics had a good deal of ammunition. But it was also clear that Mr. Mecham's greatest sin may not have been corruption or deceit, but that he had embarrassed Arizona.

LEAD: The thud of artillery and the crackle of gunfire filled Jalalabad today, a day after two terrorist bombs killed 17 mourners during the funeral of Abdul Ghaffar Khan, the pacifist leader of the Pathan people.

LEAD: James Atlas describes well the Chicago I knew as an undergraduate (''Chicago's Grumpy Guru: Best-Selling Professor Allan Bloom,'' Jan. 3). I studied with Allan Bloom and other members of the Committee on Social Thought. It was an invigorating education that continuously forced us to consider what it means to be a human being and a member of civil society.

LEAD: SHE won a gold medal at the 1984 Olympic Winter Games, and if all goes well, Debbie Armstrong, will win another in Calgary next month. At least she'll have a chance. Armstrong, who has been hampered by injuries since the 1984 Games, was one of five women named yesterday to the United States women's Olympic ski team.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about AIDS education, discussing the prevalence of AIDS in the Bronx, characterized an estimate incorrectly. Dr. Peter Gillette, an assistant professor of medicine at the State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn, indeed said ''30 percent of the kids'' in the South Bronx test positive for the AIDS virus.

LEAD: The police stepped up psychological pressure today on an armed group barricaded in a log house in an effort to arrest some of the members in connection with the bombing of a Mormon Church chapel.

LEAD: CHECK indoor plant collection for presence of mealybugs, white flies, aphids and spider mites; control if found. Use water-soluble fertilizer sparingly; indoor plants are semi-dormant during the winter months since light levels are low. Keep up with seed and nursery catalogue orders; plan the garden for this spring and summer.

LEAD: FAME can be fleeting, but the National Football Foundation does its part to keep the names of former stars fresh at its College Football Hall of Fame in Kings Island, Ohio. In the process, its annual inductions can provide fresh ammunition for trivia buffs.
LEAD: To The Editor:

LEAD: The engagement of Katherine M. Lyons, a daughter of Jane C. Lyons of Irvington, N.Y., and the late Robert K. Lyons, to Robert C. Michele has been announced by the future bride's mother. Mr. Michele is the son of Dr. Evelyn W. Michele of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Dr. Charles T. Michele. An October wedding is planned.
LEAD: The name of the writer of an article on Jan. 10 on Nebraska farm real estate was misspelled. The correct spelling is Dick Herman.
LEAD: AMERICA FORGETS HER POETS.

LEAD: LIVING IN NEW YORK you forget about driving. It's one of the great luxuries of New York that a car is absolutely superfluous there. Unless you dedicate your life to parking, you can't keep the thing at the curb, and unless you are Croesus, you can't afford garage space.

LEAD: BASEBALL CLINIC Bobby Valentine, manager of the Texas Rangers, is to be one of seven speakers at a baseball clinic from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. Saturday in the Physical Education Center on the West Hartford campus of the University of Hartford.

LEAD: Naum S. Meiman, the 76-year-old mathematician who is among the last of the prominent Soviet dissidents denied exit visas, has been told that Soviet officials have decided to allow him to emigrate. Mr. Meiman reported Friday evening that he had received a telephone call from the French writer Simone Veil, who has taken an interest in his 14-year struggle to emigrate.

LEAD: 'Intellectuals should make themselves heard by putting forward their perceptions of what is right. Then let the politicians worry about what is possible.' Henry A. Kissinger speaking as one of 76 Nobel laureates summoned by President Francois Mitterrand of France to discuss the problems of the 21st century.

LEAD: TOMORROWrrxh, the 100th Congress will convene for its second session, and Ronald Reagan will go to Capitol Hill to deliver to the assembled legislators the State of Union Message for his final year in office. The expectation, encouraged by the comments of senior White House officials, is for few new initiatives.

LEAD: Sharlene A. McEvoy asked what happened to ''Our Town'' as it appeared in Thornton Wilder's 1938 play. Her answer was that it was ''ravaged by hordes of greedy developers'' and changed to ''their town.'' My answer is a little different. It is 50 years later and ''our town'' has changed quite a bit.

LEAD: JULIENNE MARIE SCANLON, who was known only as Julienne Marie when she played leads in musicals on Broadway in the 1960's and early 70's, has renewed her singing career after a 10-year retirement with an act made up of songs that were sung in musicals by ''the other woman,'' the second female leads.

LEAD: A BOOK was published last month that contained 39 military proclamations issued during coups and attempted coups since the last civilian president of Argentina completed his term 60 years ago. Had the book been delayed, the list would have been longer. Last week, there was yet another army revolt and, while it failed, it produced the customary grandiose pronouncements.

LEAD: BLOOD HUNT. By Neil M. Gunn. (Walker, $15.95.) Though this book, first published in Britain in 1952, includes a murderer on the run, a wronged woman and a revenge-obsessed policeman, it is not really a mystery or a thriller. It is, rather, a charming, old-fashioned novel of life in a remote section of the Scottish Highlands right after World War II.
LEAD: THE idea, the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission said, was to ''improve the image'' of the cabbies, ''professionalize'' them and ''respond to consumer complaints.''
LEAD: A PROPOSAL by Mayor Biagio DiLieto to tear down the New Haven Veterans Memorial Coliseum and use the site for a shopping mall has raised fears that the arena will not be replaced.

LEAD: LACK of adequate snow cover will probably cause the postponement of the 10th Annual International Sled Dog Races that were to have taken place at Saranac Lake, N.Y., next Friday, Saturday and Sunday. The new dates would be Feb. 27 and 28.

LEAD: The Enrico Fermi II nuclear power plant went into commercial operation today, 14 years late and about $4 billion over its budget.

LEAD: To the Editor: This past fall we spent an enjoyable two weeks in Paris. We particularly delighted in the quality of the French cuisine; not only the subtleties and nuances of fragrance and taste but also its beauty of presentation, the elegance of restaurant decor and the impeccable service. However, into the midst of this culinary splendor, our privacy and senses were assaulted on numerous occasions by smokers, often seated in close proximity.
LEAD: To the Editor: It is not surprising to see a question on Cyprus appear in the Q. & A. column (Travel, Jan. 3).

Rabbi Perry Rank officiated. The bride, the director of research and planning at the New York Telephone Company, graduated from Cornell University and received a master's degree in communications from George Washington University.

LEAD: TO those who own or use a snowthrower, happiness is trouble-free operation. Although knowing how to operate a snowthrower safely and skillfully is important, smooth sailing throughout the snow season depends largely on performing manufacturer-recommended maintenance thoroughly and on time. Complete maintenance information is usually printed in the owner's manual furnished with the snowthrower or available from the manufacturer.

LEAD: IN the latter half of the 1930's a gang of killers appeared in Western Europe whose accumulated crimes - considering their impact on history - are probably unequaled in the annals of murder. They were agents of the Soviet secret police - then called the N.K.V.D., now the K.G.B. - operating in a special unit dedicated to terrorism.

LEAD: WHOEVER FIRST SAID ''I'D rather be lucky than good'' was on to something, of course. In music, it does appear as if careers often rise and fall at the spin of the wheel. A conductor in Rio de Janeiro is hissed off the podium, a young cellist named Arturo Toscanini jumps in as his replacement and a musical legend is set in motion.

LEAD: Starting July 1, New Jersey's tax on gasoline will rise to 10.5 cents a gallon, from 8 cents, following Governor Kean's signing this week of a law to help finance a seven-year $5.7 billion highway construction program.

LEAD: JAWOLE WILLA JO ZOLLAR has had a consistent and innovative interest in mining tradition and creating new ritual, most notably with her Urban Bush Women company and with Edwina Lee Tyler and Tiye Giraud, composers and musicians who share her passionate involvement. In ''Song of Lawino,'' which opened Thursday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, the three women have joined Valeria Vasilevski, the experimentalist director and writer, for an evening of incomparably rich and powerful theater.
LEAD: To the Editor: My husband and I are irritated by the ''ranks lower than the others'' rating that Paul Chutkow gave the Crazy Horse Saloon (''Paris Is Still Kicking,'' Travel, Jan. 3).

LEAD: 'DANCIN' FEET' There is nothing static about either the name or the contents of the North Shore Dance Theater's latest production. It is called ''Dancin' Feet'' and that is what members of the energetic young, Huntington-based jazz dance company, under the direction of Sandi Bloomberg, a former Rockette, and Toni Wortman employ today at the Harborfields Public Library.

LEAD: A GROWING number of teen-age runaways in Westchester are in reality homeless youths who are abandoning bleak motel rooms and trying to return to their own communities, according to the county Youth Board. Its latest report also describes how young males who lack education and training are deliberately putting themselves in jail and says that nearly 100 percent of homeless teen-age women in the county become pregnant.
LEAD: Beyond public attitudes, the police and the courts could do much to build confidence in the criminal justice system with specific reforms.

LEAD: An elderly man plunged to his death from the top balcony of the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon during an intermission of the Metropolitan Opera's performance of ''Macbeth.''

LEAD: A few years back local slogan makers decided to dub Dallas the Time of Your Life City. It's not clear exactly what that was supposed to mean, but its hint of French Quarter-style merriment rang hollow as an inducement to visit Dallas.

LEAD: ''AN AMERICAN JOURNALIST WAS absolutely infuriated with all the drama that was coming over here from England - angry that the theater was being so dominated by the British, when America had a perfectly good drama of its own. That was in 1832,'' says British-born Julian Webber, who is directing the revival of David Belasco's 1905 melodrama, ''The Girl of the Golden West,'' opening Friday at the Soho Repertory Theater.
LEAD: ROBERT PAYNE thinks of the Super Bowl as literally the biggest thing ever to hit this city.
LEAD: MORE PEOPLE NOW live farther from urban centers than at any time in recent years.

LEAD: JEFFREY ESSMANN, a character comedian whose fine-tuned sensibility places him in the tradition of Ruth Draper, Lily Tomlin and Danitra Vance, is a performer whose pursuit of comic truth embraces all ages and freely crosses sexual boundaries. Mr. Essmann is also something of a literary daredevil, for his most ambitious pieces assume some historical knowledge and steer away from pat comic formulas.
LEAD: Milton H. Adler, a former assistant attorney general in New York, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

LEAD: Israeli-Occupied West Bank, Jan. 22 - ''Greetings to the children of the stones,'' intoned the voice from the minaret of the lone mosque in this little Palestinian village. ''Greetings to the uprising.''

LEAD: GEORGE BUSH'S role in the Iran-contra affair has come back to haunt him at a critical juncture in his Presidential campaign. The problem isn't so much what Mr. Bush has said he knew about the affair as what he has said he didn't know: that it was an arms-for-hostages swap, from which funds were diverted to the contras.

LEAD: Showing an artist in 1986, 1987 and now in 1988, as the CDS Gallery (13 East 75th Street) has done with the painter Peter Booth, is often an indication that an artist is being pushed too hard. But Booth lives in Australia, far from the pressures of New York, he has a career of work behind him, and prior to 1986, he had never had a solo show in the United States.

LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eastern Regional basketball tournament at Byrne Meadowlands Arena March 24 and March 26 will allocate tickets by lottery.
LEAD: Some people can take it, but can't, or won't, dish it out.

LEAD: IN his wispy voice, Mike Tyson was talking about how ''Larry Holmes was a great and courageous champion in his time. I just wanted to let him know his time is over.'' And let the world know that Mike Tyson's time is now. But until the heavyweight champion fights Michael Spinks, his time will be clouded by the presence of the one heavyweight with the style that might confuse him, that might even conquer him.

LEAD: When downtown zoning in New Canaan, Conn., allowed for three-story structures, most builders limited themselves to one. But that was when the Fairfield County town was still manufacturing shoes. Now, with a growing docksider population and new, two-story zoning, many of those buildings are getting an extra floor.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joel H. Gosler of Jersey City have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie Lynn Gosler to Alan Howard Freudenstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Freudenstein of Teaneck, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

Nightmarish experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania.

LEAD: A NEW JERSEY executive, eager to participate in a joint venture, ''needed to get his hands on some funds, fast,'' said the executive's financial planner, Paul S. Brienes, president of Paul Stewart Associates in Princeton, N.J. After assessing his client's portfolio, Mr. Brienes tapped the executive's life insurance policy for a loan.

LEAD: FROM my office in an old North Shore mansion, as I sip my lukewarm coffee and aim my little heater at my frozen feet, I watch a mallard in the pond below that appears to be walking on water.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert White of Medford, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Lisa Sue White to Dr. Barry Stephen Paul, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Paul of New Rochelle, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in April.

LEAD: ARRIVING in Antigua, Guatemala, is like falling into a time warp and ending up in 16th- or 17th-century Spain. Colonial-style mansions line the landscape, shrouded by eight-foot walls that hide pools, gardens brimming with multitudes of flowers and, beyond, elaborate hand-carved woodwork.
LEAD: TRAVEL easterly through the Bahamas and you come to Crooked and Acklins Islands, fragrant with cascarilla bark, the base for Campari.
LEAD: HE came as close as a quarterback can come - second and goal on the Vikings' 1-yard line, fourth quarter, 4 points behind, needing a touchdown to lead his team to the Super Bowl.
LEAD: Erna Weill, a sculptor who lives in Teaneck, N.J., has been troubled for some time by the sight of families living out in the open.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Q. Our 30-year-old house has cedar shakes on the outside. To my knowledge, these shakes have never been painted or treated in any way. Should we leave them as is, or should they be treated in some way?

LEAD: The Soviet poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko continues to display a knack for sensing when changes in the Kremlin's view of the past are about to affect the future. In a poem that he wrote and read around Moscow last summer, but which has only recently turned up in the United States, Mr. Yevtushenko expressed admiration of Nikolai I.

LEAD: Nizar Jwaideh, director of public affairs for the Washington mission of the Arab League and editor of the magazine Arab Perspectives, died Wednesday of pancreatic cancer at George Washington University Hospital in Washington, D.C. He was 55 years old.

LEAD: The mammoth neon cactus and life-size fiberglass cows that guard the Hilltop Steak House here may soon become familiar emblems around the world as the owners work out a plan to franchise the restaurant.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Jason R. Einbinder of Lincroft, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Dana Einbinder to Aaron Michael Brenner, the son of Dr. Robert P. Brenner of Los Angeles and Dr. Johanna Brenner of Portland, Ore. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: WHEN Soviet authorities announced earlier this month that new legal safeguards were being introduced to protect the rights of psychiatric patients, human rights advocates were pleased but skeptical. The Soviet Union has continued to use mental wards as holding tanks for nonconformists and the politically suspect, despite years of world protest.

LEAD: The Democratic Presidential candidates, searching for ways of moving a still highly volatile and uncertain Iowa electorate, stepped up their attacks on one another today in a series of forums held just 16 days before the state's Presidential caucuses.

LEAD: THE coming Congressional vote on renewing aid to the Nicaraguan rebels and the demands made by a frayed regional peace treaty have combined to make the next two weeks perhaps the most decisive of the many turning points in Central America's current turbulent passage.

LEAD: Back in November, at the Larry Holmes Training Center in Easton, Pa., the man after whom the facility was named was standing before the speed bag, talking - riffing, really - as his hands beat a steady rhythm on the small bag.
LEAD: ONCE AT A BORDER: ASPECTS OF STRAVINSKY With Igor Stravinsky, Robert Craft, others. Directed by Tony Palmer. 1981. Kultur. 166 minutes (2 cassettes). $69.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ON Jan. 9, a phone call was received at the Medical Communications Center in East Meadow. Man: ''The baby is turning blue!'' Medical technician: ''An ambulance is on the way.'' Woman: ''She's turning blue!'' Technician: ''Listen carefully. Lay the baby flat on her back. Lift the chin, slightly back.

LEAD: Casanova's Anticlimax Casanova, the great lover, talker, intriguer, came to a sad end as librarian to a count in Bohemia, where he complained away his last 13 years. This is from ''Casanova: A New Perspective,'' by J. Rives Childs (Giniger/Paragon House).
LEAD: Fred Quartlebaum, a reserve guard, sank two free throws with 10 seconds to play today to break a tie and give Fordham a 63-61 Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference victory over Fairfield.

LEAD: Gary Hart's top campaign aides instructed at least one supporter to ''raise and conceal hundreds of thousands of dollars in illegal contributions,'' The Orange County (Calif.) Register reported in a copyright article yesterday.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Neil Smith of Greensboro, N.C., of the engagement of their daughter Lisa Karen Smith to Warren Seth Waters, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Waters of Clifton, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla. A May wedding is planned. The future bride is a senior at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro.

LEAD: ''WHO IS PEARL HARBOR?'' SALLY White asks in Woody Allen's ''Radio Days.'' Sally's big break as a radio actress has been abruptly terminated by the announcement that the Japanese have attacked the United States naval base on Oahu. One minute before air time, Sally's debut performance has been canceled to make way for a special news broadcast.
LEAD: Columbia University yesterday announced the 66 newspaper editors, executives and others who will make up the jury to nominate entries for this year's Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. E. Newton Cutler Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., and Edgartown, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Allison Waring Cutler to Francis E. Fox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Fox of Ardmore, Pa. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: AN ambulance speeds down a narrow street in Irvington and stops beside a teen-ager lying in the road, severely injured after being thrown from her car in a collision. As ambulance volunteers prepare the girl to be taken to a hospital, a silent group watches intently. One films the incident from atop a truck, one holds a microphone, and a third studies the drama on a television monitor.
LEAD: New York State has agreed to buy 16,796 acres of land to add to the state forest preserve in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David E. Krieger of Spring Valley, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Jodi F. Krieger to Gary Alan Kittrell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Kittrell of Brooklyn. Ms. Krieger and her fiance expect to graduate in May from the Brooklyn Law School. She is an alumna of the State University at Binghamton, N.Y.

LEAD: MANY ensembles take on the complete cycle of Beethoven Quartets as an early challenge in their collective careers, but not so the Tokyo String Quartet. It took well more than 15 years of international concertizing before the Tokyo felt ready to tackle this most demanding of musical enterprises. That was in the summer of 1986, and since then the quartet has repeated the cycle a number of times, always to great critical and audience acclaim.

LEAD: Oil production at Prudhoe Bay on Alaska's North Slope is polluting the fragile tundra and has resulted in hundreds of violations of environmental regulations, three environmental organizations have charged.

LEAD: Q. Our 30-year-old house has cedar shakes on the outside. To my knowledge, these shakes have never been painted or treated in any way. Should we leave them as is, or should they be treated in some way?
LEAD: An article on Jan. 10 about a Gallup poll on the 10 men most admired by Americans misstated the year in which the list was first compiled. It was 1946.

LEAD: Mayor Marion Barry was standing bare-chested in his office, surrounded by polished mahogany, inscribed brass plaques and tables piled high with the wordage of urban government, his stocking feet planted a good half-inch deep in the baby blue pile of the wall-to-wall carpet. An aide stood by, proffering a freshly starched tuxedo shirt.

LEAD: LOOKING for a millionaire under 40 who owns a sailboat? Or a New England high school coach? Their names and millions of others are readily available from three Westchester list brokers, who specialize in renting out names.

LEAD: SINCE AIDS began its cruel assault, the insurance industry and homosexual rights advocates have been locked in a rancorous debate over the testing of insurance applicants for antibodies to the disease. But the groups are finding common ground on two issues: regulatory AIDS guidelines designed to keep discrimination out of the underwriting business, and health insurance pools for so-called uninsurable people, such as those who test positive for the virus.

LEAD: A last-minute change in the New York City Council's bill for public financing of city election campaigns could be a boon to some current officeholders, including the Council majority leader, Peter F. Vallone.

LEAD: ''I'D SAY WE'RE ONE OF THE world's smallest manufacturers of electric guitars,'' says Jolyon Dantzig, who with his partner, Frank Untermyer (above), operates Hamer Guitars in Arlington Heights, Ill. Specialists in custom-made instruments for professional musicians, Hamer does regular business with rockers like The Police, Judas Priest, Billy Idol and Steve Stevens.

LEAD: If William Simon does become taipan of a trans-Pacific trading company, he will be able to develop such extraordinary opportunities for small American companies that he will silence his detractors (''William Simon's Pacific Overtures,'' by L. J. Davis, Dec. 27).

LEAD: A cargo craft carrying food, fuel and mail docked today with the Mir space station, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency. The Russians periodically send cargo to the space station, where two Soviet astronauts are one month into a yearlong mission.

LEAD: CARLOS KLEIBER, who made his Metropolitan Opera debut on Friday evening as conductor of the season's eighth ''La Boheme,'' arrived on a wave of excited expectation that had to make one wary. Before he even lifted the baton, the 57-year-old German musician was treated to the kind of heady ovation that many conductors do not receive after their finest performances.

LEAD: ''Whose Town Is It, Anyway?'' was interesting and many of Sharlene A. McEvoy's statements were right on the money. The problem seems obvious to me in her statement that ''we have watched our beloved small towns being ravaged.'' Hers is a plea for political action, for when one ''watches,'' the inevitable happens: the course of least resistance results in results not always to the liking of the watcher.

Saturday as soloist with the Chappaqua Orchestra at Horace Greeley High School.

LEAD: His eye took in a quarter-million-dollar painting, fabulous antiques and imposing mementos of fame and power, but as he looked across the possessions of a lifetime Friday, John B. Connally Jr. found himself musing about a 12-gauge shotgun he won at the Grand National Quail Shoot in Enid, Okla., in 1967.

LEAD: The growers of Maine's famed wild blueberries, fearing large losses to their $50 million-a-year crop this summer because of an outbreak of the span worm, have persuaded the State Pesticides Control Board to make a rule change that will let them use a pesticide against the bloom-eating worm.

LEAD: The article, ''New State Law in Licensing Fishermen Stirs Debate'' [ Dec. 27 ] does not adequately describe the provisions of the new law and erroneously states that all New York State residents fishing in state waters must obtain a $100 license.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: IT WAS NOT THE AMERICANS BUT the British who largely invented television, as the new public-TV series ''Television'' makes clear. And so, there may be a certain poetic justice in the fact that this eight-part retrospective of the medium, which makes its hourlong debut tomorrow night at 8 on Channel 13, is based on a British series that ran three years ago in England but was never shown in this country.

LEAD: On Friday they had a meeting to articulate the soul-searching that went on during the silent bus ride home from Thursday's loss, their third in a row. Tonight, they skipped their morning practice, regrouped at game time, and plowed their way to a 3-2 victory against Edmonton.

LEAD: IT seemed last week that Government experts were suddenly discovering what any grocery store owner or police officer in the inner city had known long ago: the problems of street crime and drugs are inevitably intertwined.

LEAD: The Navy's new Trident 2 submarine missile has failed for the first time in nine test launchings, officials have reported.

LEAD: THE year has begun with a tug-of-war over auto rental companies' coverage for collision damage. On New Year's Day, the Hertz Corporation placed a greater burden on those choosing not to pay Hertz for this coverage. Within days, a large insurance organization responded, saying that it was insuring holders of certain credit cards against this and any other new risks the auto rental companies might hold the customer responsible for.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Milton Ritholz of Bellmore, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Michelle Ritholz to Gary Bernstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Bernstein of Searingtown, L.I. Miss Ritholz is a special assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York. Her fiance is an associate in the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Throughout his career, Irving Berlin has been creating precedents and today another will be launched. LEAD: The United States has funneled tens of millions of dollars to religious-affiliated schools and hospitals around the world under a little-known program administered by the Agency for International Development, The program, American Schools and Hospitals Abroad, has since 1971 quietly financed Jewish, Catholic and Protestant schools and hospitals in Africa, Latin America, Asia and the Middle East.

LEAD: THAT clever satirist, Tom Lehrer, once explained in song the mental processes involved in subtraction: ''If you are over 35 and went to a private school, . . '' and so on. Where and when you learned your subject is also important for bridge players.

His 31-unit building at 604 Riverside Drive is opposite the entrance at 138th Street to the planned Riverbank
LEAD: Zairian police forces arrested a prominent opposition figure in the capital of the African nation during a violent confrontation last Sunday, according to the State Department.

LEAD: GEORGE BUSH WAS IN TROUBLE; Pat Robertson had said the Vice President didn't know the difference between a missile and a warhead, and for an instant, which is a very long time on television, the Vice President appeared confused. Missile? Warhead? He really didn't seem to know the difference. One thought of Gerald Ford in 1976, when he said that Eastern Europe was not under Soviet domination.

Though she and her all-American husband have a cute little girl and a lovely apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, when Cullen goes to sleep at night she dreams of Rondua, a land of strange beasts and quests and hidden dangers that could be straight out of C.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Hellman of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Yvette Dawn Hellman, to Gary David Ansel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Darrell Ansel of Minnetonka, Minn. The couple plan to marry in May.
LEAD: JOHN DRYDEN AND HIS WORLD By James Anderson Winn. Illustrated. 651 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

LEAD: INCREASES in addicts lured by cheaper, stronger and more widely available heroin and in the spread of AIDS through intravenous drug use have given new impetus to opening more methadone clinics around the state, officials say.

LEAD: THE Museum of Cartoon Art's castle was already cracking when this reviewer first saw it almost a decade ago. Now, the concrete edifice, which is on Comly Avenue in Rye Brook, has plastic protecting part of an outside wall and wood beams shoring up its curving colonnade. These and other temporary measures cost $30,000, said the museum's curator, Sherman Krisher, who added that ''the building is collapsing faster than we can raise money for the radical surgery that it needs.

LEAD: As the tiny, bespectacled woman made her way into the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn, an audience of 1,200 rose in admiration and curiosity, their Kodaks and Polaroids flashing. Downstairs, in the fellowship hall, an overflow crowd of several hundred watched on closed-circuit television.
LEAD: Reggie Theus scored 22 points and the Sacramento Kings blew a 15-point lead before rallying for a 97-94 victory over the Knicks tonight.

LEAD: THE first novel by Jorge Amado was published in the United States in 1945 and more than a dozen others by the Brazilian author have been published here since. While Mr. Amado is one of the most popular foreign authors elsewhere in the world, his sales in the United States have never begun to match his international reputation.

LEAD: For what is believed to be the first time, the companies that made and sold lead pigment for paint used in houses around the country for most of this century have been sued on behalf of children poisoned by the lead.

LEAD: A RECENT issue of a national news magazine brought some surprising news to my attention: It isn't enough to eat and rest well, avoid drugs and alcohol and see my doctor regularly to lead the proper pregnant life. Now, halfway into my third pregnancy, I learn that I should be playing ''educational'' tapes for my developing fetus to hear and presumably gain greater intelligence from.
LEAD: Steffi Graf became the Australian Open women's champion for the first time today. Now she can concentrate on winning the elusive Grand Slam.

LEAD: THE state has acquired a five-bedroom home here as the start of an $11 million program to reduce, from 835 to 500, the number of patients at the overcrowded Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital in Morris County.

LEAD: FOOTBALL North 21, South 7: Chris Chandler of Washington and Don McPherson of Syracuse each passed for a touchdown to lead the North in the 39th Senior Bowl yesterday. Chandler led a 99-yard scoring drive in the first period, hitting Willie Anderson of U.C.L.A. for a 36-yard touchdown.

LEAD: IT isn't often that the same game gets both a brilliancy prize and a prize for excellence in the end game, but Michael Rohde showed, in the 1987 United States Championship, that such a feat is not impossible.
LEAD: ''This country faces a great problem with entrenched management. If shareholders don't stand up for their rights, we are going to be a third-rate power.''

LEAD: Mrs. A. David Gurewitsch of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter Maria Anna Gurewitsch to Jacques Brand, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Felix Brand of New York and Brussels. The couple plan to marry in June.

LEAD: With a crucial vote less than two weeks away, there is a growing reluctance in Congress to approve new military aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, even among some members of Congress who are key to the Administration's strategy.

LEAD: LENINGRAD'S KIROV BALLET RECENTLY concluded a two-month season in Paris that included the first full-length version of ''Le Corsaire'' seen in the West since this initially French work was staged in Russia in the 19th century. So fascinating and entertaining was this venture that one even felt impelled to go back to the ballet's literary inspiration - namely, the long poem Byron wrote in 1814 and entitled ''The Corsair.

LEAD: LEGALIZED gambling in New Jersey has generated more than $4 billion in state revenues over the last 17 years, but there is a growing sense of alarm about its social effects.

LEAD: IN THE BEGINNING, AS FAR back in my family as anyone could go, was my great-grandmother, and her name was Annunziata. In the next generation, it would be my grandmother's name, in the generation after that (in its Anglicized form, Nancy) it would be my aunt's first name and my mother's middle name, and in the generation after that, my sister's middle name as well.
LEAD: ONE of the most contentious pieces of legislation that Congress will face when it convenes a new session tomorrow is a bill to raise the minimum hourly wage, which has been $3.35 since 1981.

LEAD: Public restrooms in this coastal city are called ''pre-treatment facilities.'' An office in City Hall is decorated with a poster of a toilet headlined ''The Origin.'' And every September, thousands of people are drawn to this city's foggy shoreline for the ''Flush With Pride'' festival.

LEAD: IN PARIS, THERE HAS LATELY BEEN more good art than almost anyone can keep up with. Momentarily, there will be much more. To those who remember how long and slow was the recovery of the great city from the effects of World War II, there is an element of wild exhilaration about the current exhibition schedule.

LEAD: THE vocal misadventure of Senator Joseph Biden, in which the then, but now former, Presidential aspirant recaptured - unfortunately, verbatim - Neil Kinnock's musings about the proletarian characteristics of his British ancestors, reveals a common peril for public figures.

LEAD: THE New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection has, since October, been putting eight-ounce plastic vials containing self-addressed and color-coded postcards into Raritan Bay and New York Harbor.

LEAD: The 13th annual ''Music From Japan'' series, under direction of Naoyuki Miura, begins at 5 P.M. today at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue at 70th Street Tickets for the concert and a reception afterward are $10. Information: (212) 517-2742.

LEAD: THE LOCKED ROOM: The New York Trilogy, Volume Three, by Paul Auster. (Penguin, $5.95.) In the latest of Paul Auster's self-reflexive, metafictional whodunits, a biographer turns detective and sets out to solve the literary and linguistic mysteries surrounding the disappearance of a friend. Last year our reviewer, Stephen Schiff, said he had found the author's previous two novels annoyingly austere, but added that in ''The Locked Room,'' his ''philosophical asides now sound heartfelt instead of stentorian and his descents into semiological Angst feel genuinely anguished and near.

LEAD: DR. OTIS R. BOWEN, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and other top officials in the department want Congress to repeal a law that limits most elderly people's earnings to $8,400 a year. For those 65 to 69 years old, the law reduces benefits by $1 for every $2 of earnings above that amount, until, when earnings top $20,000, no benefit is paid at all.
LEAD: HE entered my life last July in a bowl of Depression glass, covered with a light blue embroidered hand towel. He was naked, pinkish-purple, all mouth and decidedly not cute.

LEAD: IT has been my observation that Long Island has changed fundamentally in recent decades, and that we, by which I mean all those concerned about public issues in our region, have not yet fully come to terms with those changes and what they mean for the future.

LEAD: A GROUP of fishermen, some of whom have been fishing peacefully for more than 50 years off East Island in Glen Cove, are appealing a decision by a State Supreme Court justice that they are trespassing and must stop.

LEAD: INrrxh Israel's occupied territories, fighting was sporadic last week, but military law was firmer than ever. As the Palestinian protests entered their seventh week, soldiers were carrying out a new policy of force in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Palestinians and foreign relief workers said hundreds of people were brutally beaten, some in street clashes and some in house-to-house searches, as the Army tried to break a general strike.

LEAD: THE MacWorld Expo, a computer trade show and conference held here earlier this month, signaled the success of Apple Computer Inc.'s transformation from a renegade manufacturer of hobbyists' computers to supplier of information systems to the most powerful corporations in America.

LEAD: A lot of next week's music will come in twos, with four duos competing for attention Sunday alone. Bradshaw and Buono, the pianists, offer new music (by Elizabeth Bell), a recent piece (by the late Vincent Persichetti) and more traditional repertory by Schubert, Rachmaninoff and Liszt - all at 2 this afternoon at Alice Tully Hall.

LEAD: JAMES CLAUDE WRIGHT JR., the Speaker of the House, is perfectly happy to bask in the glow of a historic moment, but he is not one to waste time on social small talk. So when he arrived at the White House for the state dinner last month honoring Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Texan was determined to catch the ear of a ranking Soviet official and promote his views of the Central American peace process.

Sometimes what they accomplish amounts to colonialist plunder. But at times their wanderlust produces unexpected insights.

He wasn't getting rid of masterpieces, merely ''deaccessioning'' a few works the museum no longer needed.

LEAD: BREAKFAST MAY BE THE FIRST meal of the day, but lately it has seemed last in our affections. The crackle and spatter of eggs, bacon and sausage on the griddle have become a casualty of hectic schedules and the latest diet plan. Breakfast seems to have lost its esthetic and psychological properties - warm, sustaining food shared by the family early in the day's labor - to become, at best, an injection of nutrients.

LEAD: THE name, in two-foot-high bronze letters, on the portico of the Pantheon is that of Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa. He was the general, admiral and son-in-law of Augustus, the emperor who in 27 B.C. built the complex of baths, water gardens - and the temple that has survived. The name newly inscribed in black and gold on the 18th-century house facing the Pantheon is Burghy.

LEAD: ''When a Maya woman puts on her huipil she emerges through the neckhole symbolically in the axis of the world. The designs of the universe radiate from her head extending over the sleeves and bodice,'' Walter F. Morris Jr. writes in LIVING MAYA (Abrams, $40). During 14 years of research, this American anthropologist found parallels between the diamond patterning woven into intricately brocaded blouses of contemporary Mayas in Chiapas, Mexico, and the fabric designs depicted 1,200 years ago in the art of their ancestors, the Classic Mayas.

LEAD: WHEN FORTUNE MAGAZINE hired Charles Sheeler to paint a series of pictures for its December, 1940, issue celebrating the glories of American technology they found just the man for the job. Sheeler had by then become known for his paintings and photographs of cities and machines. For Fortune, the artist created steely, crisp images of an airplane propeller, a steam locomotive's wheels, a turbine engine, an electric transmission tower - pictures that treated the bits and pieces of technology as if they were icons of a new, bracing religion.
