Milles did not bring a forest of antique sculptures filling his living room to Cranbrook in order to use them as teaching aids for his students. When I was in his home with a group of students in 1944, Milles told us, ''These are my resource books, my library.

LEAD: DIPPING and bobbing in their awkward way, the flock of shimmering green parrots swept into the bare guanacaste tree where they cacklingly congratulated themselves on their abrupt landing. All beak and feet, large parrots are poor airmen who seem ridiculously relieved to arrive anywhere at all. The noisy comedians of

LEAD: LOWER tax rates, the Reagan Adminstration long maintained, would not only encourage people to work harder but would also make them more honest. If less was taken by various tax collectors, the argument ran, fewer people would risk evasion, and significant numbers of moonlighters, barterers and other members of the ''underground'' economy would be lured into fiscal rectitude.

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY'S armories are generally elaborate structures, often with 200-foot-wide drill halls and unusual architectural character. But as the need for armories has declined since their heyday at the turn of the century, several have been demolished and it has been hard to find alternative uses for the others.
LEAD: Kenny Wilson scored 21 points and Mark Plansky added 20 tonight as Villanova defeated Seton Hall, 69-63, in a Big East Conference game.

LEAD: No! There are many players on the PGA Tour who possess both the talent and qualities needed to attain star status. It is rather that viewers are subjected to media coverage that focuses on past achievers and achievements. Jack Nicklaus attracts much too much camera time, even when he's playing 7 over par.

LEAD: IN the good old summertime of 1984, the most popular song on the charts was ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' Now, it's the winter of 1988, and by the close of the Olympic Games next month, the national anthem may seem like a golden oldie.

LEAD: Only a week after winning an important diplomatic victory at the summit meeting of Central American leaders, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra is facing an unexpected challenge from within his Sandinista regime.

LEAD: To the Editor: The eloquent description provided by Mr. Kostelanetz is like a bit of madeleine for those of us who have shared the delights of which he speaks. Unintentionally, however, he gives too short shrift to the attractions of Kungstradgarden, the green oasis in downtown Stockholm.
LEAD: From their living rooms, about 80 former Redskin and Bronco players will share in next Sunday's Super Bowl winnings, adding from $9,000 to $18,000 apiece to their postseason swag.
LEAD: ON DEC. 18, New York City officials turned over the last five vacant apartment buildings on the Grand Concourse to private developers for rehabilitation into badly needed housing for the Bronx.
LEAD: AT Winterfest, the annual plays-in-progress series at Yale Rep, the accent this year is on comedy.
LEAD: THE other day, I took my wife's car to the garage for a periodic checkup. Six hours later and $436.61 poorer, I had the ransomed car back home.
LEAD: VENICE AT NIGHT. THE PAINTER DEGAS.

LEAD: ANCIENT CARTHAGE - A city of immense wealth where commerce and culture flourished - left a legacy of some of antiquity's most compelling mosaics, 17 of which are on view at the American Museum of Natural History through May 1.

LEAD: The representative of the Arab League and three other Arab diplomats met with a senior State Department official today to complain about what they considered inadequate United States pressure on Israel to halt the violence against Palestinians in Jerusalem, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

LEAD: RACISM crawled out from under a rock of silence and onto the network airwaves once again last week. Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder's comments to a Washington television news reporter for a report about the progress of blacks in society revealed a mind married to a number of dangerous stereotypes.

LEAD: Henck Arron, who is to be the Vice President and Prime Minister of Suriname, speaking at a news conference Friday in Paramaribo. With him was Ramsewak Shankar, the President-elect. Their inauguration tomorrow will return the South American country to civilian rule after eight years of military rule.
LEAD: QUEST FOR AN ISLAND Vassily Aksyonov. 246 pp. New York: PAJ Publications/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

LEAD: The harvest of statistics from 1987 continued. A steep, 16.2 percent plunge in housing starts in December got the most attention. That put housing construction for all of 1987 at 1.62 million units, the lowest since 1982 and down 10 percent from 1986. Much of the December decline was in apartment construction, which has lagged since tax laws changed last year.

LEAD: A five-year investigation has uncovered bribery and corruption that cost the Uzbek Republic at least $6.5 billion and involved high-ranking officials, including the son-in-law of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today.

LEAD: IT is easier to cry ''Save the wetlands!'' than it is to figure out what a wetland is - or so one can conclude from the debate that has swirled around New York State's efforts in the last several years to designate freshwater wetlands on Staten Island.
LEAD: PRESSURE on the pocketbook, the type both the public and elected officials respond to, began building last week behind the need to change the state's automobile insurance system.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kalberer, of Providence and Wakefield, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Lawton Kalberer to James Gerard Turino, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerard Turino of Alpine, N.J, and East Hampton, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Rev. Al Sharpton, a Brooklyn minister, orbited on the periphery of civil rights and political circles for years before his leadership of recent demonstrations against racism brought him the high visibility he admittedly enjoys. But the spotlight got a little warm last week after New York Newsday reported that Mr.

LEAD: St. Anthony of Jersey City and St. Nicholas of Tolentine from the Bronx, two of the top high school basketball teams in the country, will be on the same program one more time this season. Unfortunately, they won't be playing each other.
LEAD: At the Gramercy Park Hotel in Manhattan yesterday, Susan Lucia Falk and Kurt Antony Corso were married by the Rev. Mary Alice Brown of the Unity Church of Christ in Teaneck, N.J.

LEAD: The engagement of Dr. Joanne Leslie to Dr. Jonathan Ames, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Ames of Tucson, Ariz., and Nantucket, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alan Leslie of Jackson Heights, Queens. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: For the last three days, Connecticut players studied the scouting report that focused on how to contain Greg (Boo) Harvey and Michael Porter, St. John's stunning backcourt combination. The secret: cut off the drive, keep them out of the paint, give them the outside shot and encourage the 3-point shot.
LEAD: Southern Bride is a new magazine from Pace Communications, Greensboro, N.C., that will serve the nuptially inclined in 17 Southern states and the District of Columbia.

LEAD: After years of fascination with Japanese management, some American executives are confronting it from a new perspective - as employees of the Japanese enterprises that are multiplying in the United States.

LEAD: EACH of the five episodes of ''Murder of a Moderate Man'' - beginning tonight at 10 on Channel 31 and running through Friday - begins with the same dreamlike sequence. A distinguished looking man in a white robe is being greeted at an airport. A small girl hands him flowers. A hand holding a gun suddenly appears, horrifying the man's supporters.

LEAD: Carl J. Portale is returning to European Travel and Life magazine and his old job as its publisher. He left the magazine, which he had helped found, after Rupert Murdoch acquired it last year. Since then, the 48-year-old Mr. Portale helped Tiffany & Company put out a one-shot magazine marking its 150th anniversary.

LEAD: In its second major excursion into the United States in just over a year, the Campeau Corporation of Canada last night began a $4.2 billion offer for Federated Department Stores Inc., the owner of Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Filene's.
LEAD: Iran has informed Lebanon that all foreign hostages held by extremists loyal to Teheran will be released once the war in the Persian Gulf ends, Lebanese Government officials said this week.

LEAD: THE Fine Arts Quartet is an American ensemble with a decided Central European tint. In its program at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night, one heard a rounded rather than a finely cut edge to phrasing and timbre. At its worst, the Fine Arts sounds fuzzy to the point of imprecision; yet there is a depth to the group's sound and a relaxed, welcoming quality to the music itself.
LEAD: Brian Orser, the reigning world champion, won his eighth consecutive Canadian figure skating championship Saturday night, but not in the way he expected.

LEAD: ONCE it was known as a sleepy Navy town near the Mexican border, the best place in California to get a tattoo. But now San Diego awaits the circus maximus of sports, Super Bowl week. And when the thousands of visitors depart after the Denver Broncos and the Washington Redskins determine the Super Bowl XXII champion Sunday, an estimated $140 million will have been spent during the circus max in this sparkling harbor city that the American Football League discovered.

LEAD: An increase in the number of racial and anti-Semitic incidents on campuses is forcing soul-searching at many of the nation's institutions of higher learning, according to educators at a conference on racism.
LEAD: The death of a singing coach who plunged from an upper balcony to the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera House was a suicide, the New York City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.
LEAD: BRITISH-owned Ammirati & Puris has won the GE/RCA consumer electronics business. Its $20 million in billings make it the biggest account in the agency's 14-year history.

LEAD: One week after elections marred by widespread irregularities and charges of fraud, Haiti's government-appointed electoral council today declared Leslie F. Manigat, a 57-year-old former political science professor, as the country's next president.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: They started with a creaky mimeograph machine and an aroused Governor, and they grew into a political institution.

LEAD: The Abu Nidal terrorist network for at least four years maintained an important financial operation in Warsaw that traded arms and consumer goods to raise funds for terrorist acts, according to a classified State Department report on the group's operations.
LEAD: Clayton K. Yeutter will be the first United States Trade Representative to visit China. He will leave for Beijing Jan. 31 to sign a pact governing trade in the sensitive sector of textiles.

LEAD: THE lawyers for Texaco Inc., after a victory in a key battle in bankruptcy court last Friday, are gearing up for a new round of legal wrangling this week, this time over a disclosure statement that is intended to provide the details on how the company plans to restructure.

LEAD: A SHORT while ago when the waning moon was a brilliant sliver above the heaving Atlantic, I was driving along the outer beach of Martha's Vineyard island an hour and a half before dawn wondering when the three quick cups of black coffee I had quaffed would begin to rouse me from my torpor.
LEAD: Less than 10 months from now, the winner of the Presidential election, exhausted by the campaign, will face an assignment almost as cruel as the campaign itself.
LEAD: West Germany's economy is expected to grow between 1.5 percent and 2 percent this year, compared with 1.7 percent growth in 1987, the Economics Minister, Martin Bangemann, said today.
LEAD: The contra supply plane that crashed in southern Nicaragua on Saturday was hit twice by Soviet-made surface-to-air missiles, foreign reporters taken to the scene today were told.
LEAD: Dominique Wilkins scored 31 points but the Atlanta Hawks had to withstand a fourth-quarter rally to defeat the New Jersey Nets, 118-111, today.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Washington article on Saturday about illegal aliens misstated the status of a proposal to extend a May 4 deadline for applying for legal status. The Immigration and Naturalization Service is considering, but has not formally announced, action that would allow aliens who have made known their intention to apply by May 4 to submit the necessary documentation later; they could do so as long as they could show that the delay was caused by reasons beyond their control.

LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 25, 1988: MONDAY Acme Electric Consol Freightways Archer-Daniels-Midland Foster Wheeler Armstrong World Indus Lubrizol Corp Black & Decker Phila Elec Co TUESDAY Ball Corp Interstate Pwr Becton, Dickinson & Co Interstate Securities Black Hills Corp NUI Corp Borden Inc Norwest Corp Cilcorp Inc Phila Suburban Corp Duke Power Santa Fe Southern Pacific EDO Corp UGI Corp Fedders Corp USX Corp Glenfed Inc WEDNESDAY AMP Inc Oneida Ltd Alltel Corp Philips Indus Amer

LEAD: President J. R. Jayewardene is to travel to New Delhi Monday to discuss the possibilities of a mutual-assistance treaty between Sri Lanka and India and the phased withdrawal of 38,000 Indian troops who were sent to support a plan for ending the Tamil insurgency here.

LEAD: They were a ray of hope in the dark days following the Oct. 19 collapse of the stock market: signaling a vote of confidence in the financial markets, corporations big and small announced large buybacks of their shares, telling investors that they stood ready to buy their companies' stock even if no one else would.

LEAD: For the second successive season, Christian Lacroix has opened the couture showings here on an exuberant note. He is always high-spirited and his clothes always merry. Because the season at hand is spring and summer, usually a lighthearted time for fashion, he has been inspired to new heights of gaiety.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Luke Holland had plenty of room to spare as he deftly kept his balance and guided his bicycle over an obstacle, in this case another bicycle, during a jump in the playground at Washington Square Park. (NYT/Vic DeLucia)
LEAD: An obscure Federal court case here has compelled the Defense Department to disclose a minor secret that has implications for sensitive issues in American foreign policy.
LEAD: One year ago today, Yvonne McCain and her children finally left the ranks of the homeless.
LEAD: Two planes collided Saturday over this Los Angeles suburb, and two men aboard one plane were killed when it crashed, the authorities said. The other plane landed safely.
LEAD: When older Japanese worry about the fate of their country, they tend to think about young people like Hirokazu Kishida.
LEAD: David Deutsch, chairman of David Deutsch Associates, took time out from his busy vacation schedule in sunny Florida to call New York about his agency's new assignments.

LEAD: Edward Perkins, the American Ambassador, attending a funeral yesterday in Soweto for Percy Peter Qoboza, a black newspaper editor who was one of South Africa's most respected journalists. About 5,000 mourners of all races attended the four-hour service. (Reuters)

LEAD: Warning that the price of failure will be a suspension of its debt payments abroad, Argentina has begun searching for new loans to help cover this year's interest payments on its $54 billion foreign debt, the third largest in Latin America after Brazil and Mexico.
LEAD: Stephen and Lois Plumlee of Sarasota, Fla., deliberately sent their contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund after the holidays.

LEAD: Western Europe's unemployment picture, which has been exceedingly grim for several years, is expected to grow even grimmer over the next few months as a result of the dollar's plunge, which has made American goods more competitive with European products.

LEAD: At the present time the credit markets are leaning in the direction of lower interest rates, as traders and investors seem to be anticipating weak economic data in the first several months of 1988.

LEAD: TSUYOSHI TSUTSUMI played solo cello pieces by Japanese composers at the Asia Society late Saturday afternoon. Five of the six have been written in the past three years and one especially for this concert.
LEAD: With the sounding of conch shells, revelers wrapped up a yearlong celebration of Hawaii's 1,000-year-old native culture.
LEAD: This desperately poor nation on the southeastern coast of Africa is playing out a tragic drama whose chapters are scrawled in blood. A 12-year-old conflict is strangling Mozambique.

LEAD: SOMEONE once said of of Gabriel Faure's music that it behaved like a cat - discreet, graceful, with a sense of great adventure but at the end, always landing on its feet no matter how high or dangerous the fall. His chaste little Pavane - as performed by the orchestra and singers of the Montreal Symphony on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall - was an instructive microcosm of Faure's quiet risk-taking.
LEAD: Mike Gottfried, the Pitt football coach, said today he would meet with Craig Heyward Monday to discuss the all-America tailback's relationship with Bruce Allen, a sports agent.
LEAD: Louis Licari can't tell you whether it's true blondes have more fun. But he can answer that other question asked in the old Clairol hair color commercials, ''Does she or doesn't she?''

LEAD: As its name suggests, the Royal and Ancient Golf Club, which was established in St. Andrews, Scotland, in 1754, is steeped in tradition, much of it reflected in the club's priceless collection of paintings, prints and historic relics.
LEAD: As an antidote to the October Wall Street collapse, the Harvard Business Review will include cartoons in a revamping that will make its debut with the January-February issue.

LEAD: Nearly a month after the expiration of a state-imposed deadline, a small company in New York City has yet to comply with an order to empty its plant of an enormous inventory of radium-226, a dangerously radioactive material that was once widely used in treating cancer.
LEAD: Ramon Gaulke, president of USA Weekend, the Gannett Company supplement that appears in 293 newspapers with a circulation of 14.6 million, reports that there is something in the wind.
LEAD: Every few days for the last several months, another Southern politician has endorsed Senator Albert Gore Jr. for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

LEAD: A leader of Reform Judaism in the United States yesterday urged Israel to end its policy of beating Arabs to quell violence in the West Bank and Gaza, calling the practice ''an offense to the Jewish spirit'' that ''betrays the Zionist dream.''

LEAD: On the morning after Haiti's widely criticized presidential election, Leslie F. Manigat, an energetic former professor of political science, strode through his crowded campaign headquarters smiling broadly and waving one hand high in a victory sign.

LEAD: Leonard Stern, the chairman of Hartz Mountain Industries and owner of The Village Voice, said yesterday that he would offer to buy The New York Post without its real estate if economic agreements could be struck with the newspaper's labor unions.

LEAD: The 10th Annual International Sled Dog Races, which were scheduled to be held at Saranac Lake, N.Y., next weekend, will now take place Feb. 27-28, according to Peter Lesser, executive director of the community's chamber of commerce.

LEAD: ONE of the enduring myths of athletics is that eating protein will enhance one's performance. Since protein is composed of amino acids, some advocates take the notion one step further: loading up on certain amino acids will improve strength, promote muscle building and increase performance.
LEAD: Pat Cash was hoping to turn the Australian Open into a national celebration, but Mats Wilander spoiled the party.

LEAD: For nearly 15 years, Justin McCarthy has operated a refuge for hundreds of unwanted cats, dogs and barnyard animals at his 67-acre farm here. Now he is accused of abusing the animals he pledged to care for until their ''happy, natural death.''
LEAD: Georgetown limped into Syracuse this afternoon without a victory in its last three games, punchless on offense and close to falling hopelessly behind in the Big East race.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Matina S. Horner has announced that she will resign the presidency of Radcliffe College, a post she has held since 1972, to pursue her research into social change and women's issues.
LEAD: Fernando Ferrer at his inauguration yesterday. He had been interim Borough President since April, replacing Stanley Simon. Page B3. (NYT/Sara Krulwich)
LEAD: Question: Years ago, before the T-formation became standard, the single-wing formation was the most popular one in the National Football League. Which pro team was the last one to give it up?

LEAD: Suddenly, ''Good Morning, Vietnam'' is a smash hit, and Robin Williams was coping with this information as might be expected. The star of the film said he was appropriately delighted. He added that he was understandably grateful. And, as he paced his suite in the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan, he spoke rather earnestly of America's fascination with the

LEAD: President Reagan's State of the Union Message will be broadcast live at 9 o'clock tonight on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on C-Span, the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network.
LEAD: Congress Reconvenes

LEAD: For ABC, the good news about its Super Bowl telecast is that the teams feature two prominent and distinct quarterbacks: John Elway, the Yuppie-looking scrambler, and Doug Williams, the drop-back passer and the first black quarterback to start a Super Bowl.
LEAD: * Comstock Group Inc., Danbury, Conn., an engineering and construction company, elected Joseph G. Munisteri president, chief executive and a director.

LEAD: In a special arrangement that may violate Federal election laws, two Presidential campaigns obtained copies of a list of Iowa caucus participants and other voters from the state's Democratic Party and in exchange each campaign got its supporters to contribute $10,000 to the party.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Prospects are considered slim that President Reagan's call for lower capital gains taxes will go anywhere in the Democratic-controlled Congress in the forseeable future.
LEAD: ''No one's attempting to hide it.

LEAD: Quietly, with virtually no publicity, a number of doctors have begun offering a way out for women who are pregnant with more fetuses than they want or can carry safely: They are aborting some of the fetuses while allowing the rest to proceed to birth.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has told the General Services Administration that a $25 billion project to replace the Government's antiquated telephone system has been compromised by a growing contract controversy.
LEAD: Anthony Todd hit a 10-foot jumper with two seconds left today as Nevada-Las Vegas rallied from a 12-point deficit to defeat previously unbeaten Temple, 59-58.

LEAD: The million-gallon oil spill floating down the Ohio River from the Pittsburgh area has reached Cincinnati, and intake valves that draw water from the river for about 850,000 people have been closed.

LEAD: He came of age suffering the indignities of being on a poor team and fearful of losing a career at 21 because of a freakish accident. But an improved team and the mastery of modern medicine are beginning to erase the bad memories for the New Jersey Devils' Pat Verbeek.

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods Dec. Wednesday G.N.P. Fourth Quarter Thursday Personal Income Dec. Friday

LEAD: THE Tsai Fung Dance Company aims for the integration of contemporary and traditional dance forms. But the pieces that were the most compelling in a program presented on Friday at Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, were those that seemed the purest.

LEAD: After a lull of several years, Brazil is re-emerging as a major supplier of weapons to the Middle East. The Persian Gulf war has given a major impetus to Brazilian arms makers and they are competing with the big powers with increasing success.

LEAD: With the House convening today, Representative Tom McMillen plans to go before his colleagues to explain that he misinformed them when he described an ''internal, high-level'' Japanese Government memo that turned out to be bogus.
LEAD: Australia is preparing for the celebration of its bicentennial on Tuesday with a characteristic mixture of flamboyance and self-doubt.
LEAD: The owner of a bakery in Brooklyn was shot to death in his office yesterday after three masked and armed men entered the shop, the police said.

LEAD: IT is not until the final act of ''The Cherry Orchard'' that the malevolent thud of an ax signals the destruction of a family's ancestral estate and, with it, the traumatic uprooting of a dozen late-19th-century Russian lives. But in Peter Brook's production of Chekhov's play, the landscape seems to have been cleared before Act I begins.
LEAD: ''THE greatest Elway play?''

LEAD: The designation in Washington of the Martin Marietta Corporation to operate a billion-dollar computer complex as an important part of President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative may suggest that a ''Star Wars'' missile defense is just around the corner.

LEAD: Phil Baechler, a 39-year-old athlete from Yakima, Wash., wanted to spend more time with his newborn son, Travis. But Baechler had a crowded schedule: he had a full-time job as a copy editor, and he was a competitive runner.

LEAD: Tonight, Thornton A. Wilson, who is 66, intends to ''have fun'' at his retirement party at a Seattle hotel where he will be toasted by 500 friends and international business associates. They are flying in to celebrate his 17 years of guiding the Boeing Company out of the ''Boeing Bust'' of 1970 to its position today as the world's largest aerospace company, with revenues of $16.3 billion in 1986.
LEAD: There are two generalizations about bridge enthusiasts that seem valid.

LEAD: Jay Haas, one of the consistent but not spectacular players on the PGA Tour for the last dozen years, played just that way today - managing steady but not spectacular golf - to win the 29th annual Bob Hope Chrysler Classic by two shots over David Edwards.

LEAD: Acting under the threat of trade reprisals by the United States, Brazil has relaxed some protection of its fast-growing computer industry by authorizing commercialization of an American-made software program.

LEAD: When Billy Ray Bates was signed by the Portland Trail Blazers out of the Continental Basketball Association in 1980, his acrobatic slam dunks and spinning moves to the basket made him an instant crowd favorite and earned him a nickname: The Great Legend of the Northwest.

LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company and New York State, trying to put the stalemate on the Shoreham nuclear power plant behind them, have intensified negotiations that could close Shoreham but allow Lilco to remain an independent, investor-owned utility.

Construction of new housing for the poor has come to a virtual halt. The result has been a decline in home ownership (for the first time since World War

LEAD: For its ninth acquisition in North America, Britain's Shandwick P.L.C., a public relations concern, has made its first move into Canada, buying PIR (Public and Industrial Relations of Canada) Communications. Shandwick is putting up $2.9 million in cash, with the payout over four years not to exceed $9.2 million.
LEAD: EMPEROR OF THE AIR. By Ethan Canin. 179 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95.
LEAD: Officials in this predominantly white Chicago suburb have been wrangling in recent days over a black church's efforts to move into town.
LEAD: An 82-year-old man was fatally stabbed and his wife was injured during a robbery Saturday in their apartment, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: More than 20 Palestinian militants have been arrested in Jordan, according to the Government there and a radical Palestinian group, amid signs that several Arab Governments are concerned that the unrest in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip may spill over into their territory.

LEAD: The new Israeli policy of beating Palestinians to stop the protests in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip has spurred relatively little official debate here, but brought mounting worries over Israel's image abroad.

LEAD: AT times, actions spoke louder than words and dancing was more vivid than scenic effects in the program that Dancecompass offered Saturday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y. At other times, choreography was subservient to gimmickry.

LEAD: Washington goes back to work today with the usual State of the Union pomp but also with hearings, starting this morning, on what might be Ronald Reagan's most important legacy: agreement on arms control with the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Senator Joseph R. Biden, Jr., previewing a likely Democratic strategy for dealing with the new missile accord the Senate will begin considering on Monday, said today that he plans to attach ''conditions'' to the accord that would define a broad arms control agenda for the United States.

LEAD: One off-duty police officer was stabbed in the face in a struggle with a car thief in the South Bronx, and another off-duty officer was shot during a dispute with a motorist in Brooklyn last night, the police said.

LEAD: On Monday, when the Republic of Suriname inaugurates a new, freely elected Government headed by President Ramsewak Shankar, there will also be a small festivity here in the tenth floor offices of van Kloberg & Associates, which styles itself as an international consulting firm.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Until the Eastman Kodak Company agreed Friday to spend $5.1 billion to acquire Sterling Drug Inc., it had been pursuing a diversification strategy that could best be described as busy but dainty.
LEAD: A man sought in a series of abductions was killed along with one of his hostages today in a gun battle with the police. A second suspect was wounded.

LEAD: Roy Blount Jr. has rafted down the Amazon River, taking a brief swim that ended abruptly when he realized piranhas had wiggled into his bathing suit and were nibbling at his upper thigh - an unpleasant experience that nonetheless enabled him to write an account of the trip that began with the lead of a lifetime: ''Wild fish tore my flesh.

LEAD: As part of its broad investigation of the October stock market collapse, the Securities and Exchange Commission is studying the extent to which companies may have announced stock buyback plans without actually intending to buy the stock.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Parker Pen Company, whose management, after a leveraged buyout, has halted its downward skid, is in high spirits as it approaches its 100th anniversary this year.

LEAD: In an effort to polish the image of India's Government-controlled airlines and prepare for an anticipated surge in tourists and traffic, a band of ambitious technocrats and officials is beginning a sweeping overhaul of two big carriers.
LEAD: The struggle to maintain decorum in the Capitol has pitted its custodians against the fashion industry, specifically: the new mid-thigh-length culotte suits being featured for spring.
LEAD: A looming Federal deadline has set off intense competition among private agencies that retrieve kidneys and other organs for transplanting.

LEAD: Just six months after the State Legislature passed a set of ethics bills hailed as among the most important reform measures in New York's history, the issue of legislative ethics has again begun to dominate debate here.
LEAD: The badly burned body of a child, possibly 4 years old, was found in a plastic bag in a vacant lot in Harlem by a passer-by yesterday morning, the police said.
LEAD: Three Democratic Presidential candidates are running almost even with two weeks left until Iowa's precinct caucuses, according to a poll published yesterday in The Des Moines Sunday Register.

LEAD: Offering an image of the Bronx as ''the front line, the proving ground of urban America,'' Fernando Ferrer took his first oath of office yesterday as the elected Borough President of the Bronx.

LEAD: Negotiations between representatives of Mike Tyson and Michael Spinks broke down over the weekend, making the prospect of a fight between Tyson, the undisputed heavyweight champion, and Spinks in the near future seem unlikely.
LEAD: A television commercial promoting tourism in the Garden State employs the slogan, ''New Jersey and you, perfect together.''
LEAD: Treasury financing looms large in the credit markets this week.

LEAD: A state court has agreed to hear an appeal by the Union Carbide Corporation of an interim award of $270 million to the victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas leak, a news agency report said. But the court declined to stay proceedings in a $3 billion damage suit filed by the Indian Government against Carbide, the United News of

LEAD: The brightly lighted hall with its metal folding chairs was a far cry from the dim, smoky clubs where Robert Sanford played before his illness. And his selection of music was dictated by the fact that his left hand, damaged by chemotherapy, is virtually useless these days, and by his blindness, which limits his keyboard bravado.
LEAD: The Midwest Stock Exchange said this week that it plans to list 700 additional stocks for trading.
LEAD: An express train derailed early today in the mountains of southern China, and 90 people were killed and 66 others seriously injured, the official New China News Agency reported.
LEAD: Paul J. Babbitt Sr., the father of former Gov. Bruce Babbitt, a Democratic Presidential candidate, died today. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: Orders for American-made machine tools surged 76.7 percent in December from the previous month, to $242.5 million, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.

LEAD: In his spacious 46th-floor office, C. Edward Acker, chairman and chief executive of the Pan Am Corporation, and Martin R. Shugrue, the vice chairman, were going over airline schedules and seat sales last Thursday morning. They were trying their best, it seemed, to keep their minds off a far more pressing matter.

LEAD: It remains to be seen whether Joyce Brown's release from the hospital to a residential program puts a happy ending to the story of a homeless woman's fight against involuntary psychiatric treatment. Beyond law, her case dramatizes the failure of a policy - deinstitutionalization, the emptying of state mental hospitals during the 1970's.
LEAD: President Ortega says that during his trip to Spain this week, he will ask the Madrid Government to become active in Central American peace efforts.

LEAD: On this one point, the Government's investigators are already agreed: Donald Rochon, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was a victim of often brutal racial harassment by his white colleagues.
LEAD: St. Anthony of Jersey City, ranked as the top high school team in the country by USA Today, easily improved its record to 13-1 yesterday with a 60-47 victory over All Hallows of the Bronx.

LEAD: The outside members of the board of the E. F. Hutton Group will receive more than $2.5 million in fees as a result of the brokerage firm's merger with Shearson Lehman Brothers, according to Hutton officials. One director, Peter V. Ueberroth, will receive nearly $1 million.

LEAD: A Louisiana real estate broker wanted to know what Paul Simon would do if Soviet missiles were launched at America. A California woman, noting that her mother had prayed after winning a seat on the town council, asked if Michael S. Dukakis would do so in the Oval Office.
LEAD: Ann Rork Light, who was a silent film actress, died here Saturday at the Vanderbilt University Hospital. She was 79 years old and was being treated for emphysema and lung cancer.

LEAD: SKIING Swiss Get 1-2 Sweep: Daniel Mahrer led a 1-2 Swiss sweep yesterday in the men's World Cup downhill at Leukerbad, Switzerland. Mahrer scored his second victory of the season with a surge of speed near the bottom of the course, sweeping through an icy curve and finish slope to win in 2 minutes 17.53 seconds.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A cast of larger-than-life characters that makes grown people go ''Oink'' and others shout ''Ole!'' is invading San Diego.
LEAD: Dr. Charles Glen King, a nutritionist who co-discovered vitamin C, died of heart failure yesterday at West Chester (Pa.) Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Kennett Square, Pa.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL REPORT Unemployment in Western Europe is expected to get worse as a result of the dollar's drop, which has made American goods more competitive with European products. The situation is already grim, with Europe's jobless rate at 11 percent. No net new jobs have been created in Europe since 1980.

LEAD: After struggling through a first session characterized by confrontations with the White House on the budget and foreign affairs, the 100th Congress will return Monday facing a broad range of unfinished business that must be crowded into a legislative calendar shortened by the 1988 elections.

LEAD: Cynthia Rebecca Zarin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael S. Zarin of Great Neck, L.I., and Wellfleet, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Seccareccia, the son of Michael F. Seccareccia of Pawtucket, R.I., and the late Grace Partridge Seccareccia. Rabbi Eugene J. Lipsey officiated at the Woman's Club of Great Neck.

LEAD: Reports that the Rev. Al Sharpton may have been a Federal informant have caused deep consternation among black New Yorkers who had been forging an alliance, sometimes uneasy, to address concerns ranging from the public schools to racially motivated violence.
LEAD: The words rasped through the afternoon air with no-nonsense authority:

LEAD: Dori Ann Hanswirth, an associate in the New York law firm of Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent & Lehrer, and Joseph Nathan Lamport, an associate in the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, were married yesterday at Estherwood in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis officiated.

LEAD: Arab foreign ministers today pledged moral and financial support to Palestinians who for nearly two months have been violently protesting the Israeli occupation of the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.

LEAD: Demonstrators marching yesterday from Hyde Park to the Queen Elizabeth II Conference Center in Westminster, where an international conference on AIDS is scheduled to begin tomorrow. The marchers called for more spending on AIDS research and care, anti-discrimination laws and free AIDS drugs. (AP)

LEAD: CBS, looking for an edge in the heated Saturday morning children's television competition, is trying an unusual and potentially problematic programming ploy, developing a weekly cartoon series based on the trademark character of a national pizza chain.

LEAD: Beverly N. Lancaster received his given name from a clerk in a rural Kansas hospital who mistook the British boy's name, Bevley, for the misspelling of the more common girl's name. During the Depression, his parents did not have $2 to change his birth certificate.
LEAD: The Martin Agency in Richmond, a subsidiary of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, is going to be doing the advertising for CSX/Sea-Land Intermodal, a recently created business unit of the CSX Corporation.
LEAD: A DC-6 cargo plane on a supply mission to contra guerrillas crashed inside Nicaragua Saturday night, apparently killing 11 Nicaraguan crewmen and cargo handlers.
LEAD: Always try to give the customer ''a little more than expected'' was the credo of Ida Steinberg, a Hungarian immigrant who opened a small grocery store in Montreal in 1917.
LEAD: A 2-year-old girl was raped early yesterday in Queens, and an Astoria man was arrested and charged with the attack, the police said.

LEAD: THE situation at the Orion Pictures Corporation is certainly a curious one. Two of the wealthiest men in the media industry have gradually been buying up stock in the relatively small motion picture and television company. Its recent films include ''Platoon,'' ''Robocop,'' ''No Way Out'' and ''Throw Momma From the Train,'' and its television series include ''Cagney and Lacey.
LEAD: With a scrappiness symptomatic of a tightening race, the seven Democratic candidates for President squared off here today over the trade imbalance and the Federal deficit.

LEAD: A gaggle of girls and boys from the St. Joan of Arc School in Jackson Heights, Queens, crowd the Glendale Bakery every day, eyeing and buying sweets and sandwiches. But in recent weeks the children have not lingered long after school.

LEAD: William J. Tausch, 52, a former executive vice president at Lintas: Campbell-Ewald, where he once headed the Chevrolet account, is joining the Newspaper Advertising Bureau as vice president, automotive marketing, and manager of the Detroit office. He replaces Valentine Corradi, who has retired.

LEAD: ''The Last Emperor,'' a panoramic history of modern China, won four Golden Globe Awards, including best dramatic motion picture, on Saturday night while Sally Kirkland, who played an emigre actress in ''Anna,'' and Michael Douglas, a ruthless trader in ''Wall Street,'' took top honors for actors in dramas.

LEAD: William Henry Curry, associate conductor of the Indianapolis Symphony, has been named this year's winner of the Leopold Stokowski Conducting Competition.

LEAD: A former top adviser to the Panamanian military ruler, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, said yesterday that he would provide details on the general's involvement in drug and arms smuggling, corruption and money laundering, unless the general removed himself from politics.

LEAD: The chairman of the Cubs told a Chicago City Council hearing yesterday that the club would consider leaving Chicago if the city did not allow night baseball games at Wrigley Field. The chairman, John Madigan, appeared before the council's committee on energy and environmental protection. The panel is considering a proposal to install lights at Wrigley Field.

LEAD: As more than 50 police officers watched, a man described as a low-level drug dealer was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison for the murder of a rookie police officer in a gun battle in Queens.

LEAD: Bennett E. Bidwell and Robert A. Lutz have both gained the title of president, along with some added responsibilities, at the Chrysler Corporation's Chrysler Motors subsidiary. Their job changes followed the resignation last week of Harold K. Sperlich, the unit's president since 1985.

LEAD: Coach Ron Lapointe of the Quebec Nordiques and Terry Carkner, a defenseman for the club, were suspended for five and 10 games, respectively, for leaving the bench during a third-period fight in a game against the Montreal Canadiens on Sunday night. Lapointe also was fined $1,000 and the team was fined $10,000.

LEAD: Jerome Lane had 17 points and 17 rebounds, and halted the game for a half-hour with a backboard-shattering slam dunk tonight as Pittsburgh routed Providence, 90-56, in a Big East Conference game.

LEAD: On Oct. 19, John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, was at the center of one of the worst financial panics of the 20th century. These days, he is reliving that period as he defends the performance of the Big Board's specialists in the wake of a recent report.

LEAD: Three days after Kirk Gibson and six other players were awarded a second shot at becoming free agents because of collusion among the club owners, the Yankees announced yesterday that they would not pursue Gibson in the open market.

LEAD: Several weeks ago Michael Deaver, the former Presidential adviser, in need of money to pay his legal bills, held a tag sale of his office furnishings. Last weekend John Connally, a former Governor of Texas in need of money to pay an army of creditors, consigned his worldly goods to auction. Mr. Deaver got about $100,000 from his sale.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: After a two-year battle over a court desegregation order that has left Yonkers a divided city, local officials and the plaintiffs yesterday agreed on a plan to build low-income housing in mostly white neighborhoods.

LEAD: AS reports of cocaine-related deaths steadily accumulate, doctors are gaining a sharper awareness of the dangers of the drug. Increasingly, the doctors realize they must add cocaine abuse to their checklist of considerations when they are confronted with certain medical emergencies - in infants as well as adults.
LEAD: The United Automobile Workers Union last week opened a campaign to organize workers at the second-largest union-free Japanese automobile plant in the United States.

LEAD: A Panamanian's Threat A former Panama official threatened to tell of illegal acts by the military ruler unless he left politics. Page A3. 'Flapper' Star Dies at 85 Colleen Moore, the silent movie star who personified the ''flapper,'' has died in California. Page B6. Ex-Official Helps Inquiry A former top Queens Democrat, convicted of corruption, has been aiding an inquiry on the judiciary.
LEAD: American wine producers have reached a voluntary agreement to reduce levels of urethane in table and dessert wines, the Food and Drug Administration announced today.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Rupert Murdoch may continue to own The New York Post at least until late March, in effect extending a March 6 deadline he had faced.

LEAD: When operators lost control of the Unit 2 reactor at Three Mile Island on March 28, 1979, it was widely feared that Pennsylvania, or even the United States, might be bathed in radioactive material. This did not happen. The reactor had evidently remained intact.

LEAD: Wearing high boots and carrying long poles and burlap bags, lawenforcement officers invaded homes, shops and offices in Arizona and eight other states earlier this month, seizing hundreds of rattlesnakes and exotic crawling desert creatures.
LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, campaigning in New York yesterday, called for ''healing'' and ''focusing on common ground'' in the wake of a recent rise in racial tensions in the city.

LEAD: Before we are inundated by the inevitable flood of articles and television specials commemorating the tumultuous events of 20 years ago, any Americans who still call themselves liberals would do well to remember that 1968 was a year of unmitigated disaster for their cause. It marked the end of New Deal, Fair Deal, New Frontier and Great Society liberalism.

LEAD: Whatever you call it - chic, cachet or ''chien,'' that odd French expression - it is something Frenchwomen just seem to have. It's an indefinable quality, a knack for putting oneself together, that results in an enviably stylish look.

LEAD: President Reagan's influence is continuing to recede as the 1988 election year commences, and the nation's political mood is one of drift and uncertainty, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

LEAD: Former Senator Gary Hart and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachussetts went on the offensive tonight against theis rivals for the Democratic Presidenthal nomination and against each other, turning a debate that began cordially into another forum for sparring among the Democratic candidates.

LEAD: A couple who saw a line of stranded motorists near their home invited them in for the night and ended up serving breakfast today to 63 new friends, including a missionary from Japan and a couple from England, ''It's been quite fun - it's a lovely group of people,'' said Nickie Jones, 23 years old, of London.

LEAD: One man was shot and killed and four others were wounded last night in a hail of gunfire during a dispute over illegal drugs on East 28th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues, the police said.

LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday reported fourth-quarter net income of $23 million, or 17 cents a share. In the period a year earlier, the giant chemical company reported a net loss of $495 million, reflecting an after-tax charge of $473 million from the company's repurchase of shares during a takeover battle with the GAF
LEAD: Citibank does not plan to participate in a Treasury-backed program designed to relieve Mexico's debt burden, John S. Reed, Citicorp's chairman, said in an interview yesterday.

LEAD: Gevaert N.V., a Belgian maker of photographic products, announced today that it would lead a group of investors in an attempt to buy most of the new shares issued last week by Societe Generale de Belgique.

LEAD: IN Marrakesh, and elsewhere in southern Morocco, Gnawa musicians play for all-night, outdoor rituals with dancing, singing and spirit possession. A young master Gnawa musician, Hassan Hakmoun, brought a solo version of the music to the Ethnic Folk Arts Center (179 Varick Street) on Sunday, as part of its Music Around the Mediterranean series.
LEAD: Samuel Riley Pierce Jr., the only member of President Reagan's original Cabinet still in office, says he has survived by doing his job quietly and effectively.

LEAD: For seven years the Hertz Corporation charged motorists and insurance companies higher prices to repair cars damaged in accidents than it actually paid, the company said yesterday.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are expected to announce Tuesday that they will donate designs and manufacturing technology for advanced computer chips to Sematech, the new consortium formed by many of the nation's leading computer and semiconductor companies.

LEAD: AMERICAN and Japanese scientists have independently discovered a new high-temperature superconductor that differs dramatically from the family of materials that set off a flood of research over the last year.
LEAD: Johnny Gee, who pitched for the Pittsburgh Pirates and the New York Giants in the 1940's and played basketball with the Syracuse Nationals, died Saturday. He was 72 years old.
LEAD: Edna M. Telep of Yardley, Pa., recalls fondly how she grew up in New York City and ''benefited from the surroundings and the excellent education,'' all of it free.
LEAD: A graph in Business Day last Tuesday, with an article about businesses' reluctance to build new factories, bore an incorrect label. It represented gross spending on machinery and factories.

LEAD: THE Reagan Administration's program to persuade elderly Americans to join prepaid health plans is gaining momentum, but nearly 20 percent of the health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, that signed up for the program have dropped out, displacing 80,000 people.
LEAD: IN a growing effort to learn more about animal behavior, researchers are constructing ecologically complex swamps, aviaries and cages that try to make captive animals feel more at home.

LEAD: Molly Berns, an honorary chairwoman of the New York Heart Association for which she had been a principal fund raiser for many years, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: BOB BERMAN was a 19-year-old rookie for the Washington Senators when he was sent into the game in the bottom of the ninth to catch Walter Johnson. It was June 12, 1918, 70 years ago this summer, in Sportsman's Park, St. Louis.

LEAD: The International Federation of Advertising Agencies will install Norval B. Stephens Jr., a veteran advertising man, as its managing director next Monday.

LEAD: Cars jammed the Golden Gate Bridge today as a strike by bus drivers who normally haul 27,000 passengers a day forced commuters to form car pools, ride ferries and seek other ways of getting to work. About 300 Golden Gate Transit drivers and telephone operators walked off the job early Saturday after negotiators remained deadlocked beyond a Friday midnight strike deadline.

LEAD: In a 5-to-3 decision, the Supreme Court ruled today that criminal trial judges may bar defense witnesses from testifying in order to punish attorneys for failing to disclose the witnesses' identities soon enough. The Court said the judges could take the action regardless of whether the defendants were at fault.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on the Law page last Friday about the Texas Supreme Court described appointments to that court incorrectly. Jack Hightower and Lloyd Doggett are Democrats running for seats on the court; they were not appointed to it by Gov. Bill Clements.

LEAD: A West German concern has signed an agreement with the Soviet Union to use Russian satellites for space experiments. The company, Kayser Threde, is to conduct three experiments on board the Soviet Foton spacecraft between 1989 and 1992, according to the Soviet news agency Tass. The news agency gave no details, but said the company was developing a laser device to measure environmental pollution from space.
LEAD: Borrowing from sculptors, scientists have developed a new technique that reveals the microscopic cracks that form as rocks or buildings collapse under pressure.

LEAD: ''They've risen on us, we didn't rise on them,'' Yehuda Genyan, a tailor, was saying today of the Palestinian protesters. ''They walk around here like kings, but a Jew goes to pray at the wall and he gets stabbed.''
LEAD: President Reagan said tonight he would remain a vigorous, aggressive President ''right to the finish line'' of his Administration a year from now.

LEAD: An unusual partnership won an unusual event Sunday in the Hague in the Netherlands. Zia Mahmood, the globe-trotting Pakistani star who is seldom at his London home, teamed with Eric Rodwell of West Lafayette, Ind., a reigning world champion, to snatch a victory in the Statenbank World Top Tournament, which has a good claim to be considered the world's strongest annual event.
LEAD: An explosion and fire trapped more than 125 men in a coal mine in northern Mexico today, and authorities said at least 10 had died.

LEAD: ''What's bugging me is that you seem to get access to early drafts of intelligence. I don't even get a final copy.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz to Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. [ A18:4. ]

LEAD: The Emmis Broadcasting Corporation and Quantum Media Inc. are among several companies interested in acquiring the six stations of NBC Radio, according to industry executives familiar with the negotiations.

LEAD: While saying ''we don't think we have a problem at this time,'' Bill France Jr., the president of Nascar, announced yesterday a drug testing program for Winston Cup Series stock car racing drivers. The policy, which goes into effect immediately, would incorporate ''reasonable suspicion'' as the basis for testing drivers, mechanics, crew members and Nascar officials.

LEAD: Iran is hesitating to mount a long-forecast winter offensive against Iraq in the seven-year-old Persian Gulf war, Western and Iraqi officials say, and apparently is concentrating instead on diplomatic efforts to break up a broad coalition of pro-Iraqi Arab nations.

LEAD: While most skiing magazines cover only skiing, here comes a magazine called Snow Country that will also report on off-season activities in its monthly issues.
LEAD: JIMMY (THE GREEK) SNYDER may be gone, but he is far from forgotten at CBS Sports, or among viewers.

LEAD: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration scientists who earlier studied the loss of ozone over the South Pole are now turning their attention to the North Pole, the Federal agency announced today.

LEAD: Normally, Andrew Daly, a junior at Ridgewood High School, would not pay attention to a bunch of parents arguing over whether to show an AIDS video at school. ''Not a chance,'' said Andrew. Except one day he looked up and realized his mother was one of the video's leading opponents.

LEAD: Engineers using new methods to test engine parts of the space shuttle have found unexpected structural variations that could affect the resumption of flights if they prove to be problems, space agency spokesmen said today.

LEAD: The USX Corporation announced yesterday that its board had elected Charles A. Corry, a leading company strategist, as president of the giant steel and energy concern.

LEAD: A day after he was designated President-elect by a Government-appointed electoral council, Leslie F. Manigat tried today to quell renewed charges of fraud and to turn toward the future with a pledge that he would strive to build ''a society of social justice.''

LEAD: Auxiliary Bishop Agustin A. Roman of Miami, the Cuban-born prelate who played a major role in the peaceful ending of two prison riots by Cuban inmates, charged today that the Justice Department had not lived up to the spirit of the agreement that brought about the solution to the uprisings.

LEAD: The 82-year-old opera fan who fell to his death Saturday from an upper balcony of the Metropolitan Opera House during an intermission of Verdi's ''Macbeth'' had indicated that he was severely depressed or contemplating suicide.
LEAD: Thomas P. Hackett Jr., chief of psychiatry at Massachusetts General Hospital, died of a heart attack Saturday while horseback riding. He was 59 years old and lived in Newton, Mass.
LEAD: The Devils have been slipping and sliding on the ice lately and falling in the standings.

LEAD: Two California companies are making plates to repair the skulls of German Siamese twins separated last September, and the plates will be inserted as soon as they are finished, according to officials at Johns Hopkins Hospital.

LEAD: State officials today certified that more than 300,000 Arizonans had signed petitions demanding Gov. Evan Mecham's recall. The Governor will be told officially Tuesday that he has five days to resign or agree to run in an election to recall him from office.

LEAD: Billboard Publications, the newest subsidiary of Affiliated Publications Inc., said that it had signed an agreement to acquire The Hollywood Reporter, the trade publication. The 57-year-old daily, with a circulation of about 20,000, is owned by Hollywood Reporter Industries, which is owned by Tichi Wilkerson Kassal.

LEAD: A former Queens Democratic Party official convicted on corruption charges, Richard L. Rubin, has secretly been cooperating with a state agency investigating political corruption and patronage in the Queens judiciary, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.
LEAD: Stock prices surged in heavy trading yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average recaptured much of last week's loss, climbing 42.94 points, or 2.3 percent, to 1,946.45.

LEAD: Susan Eisenhower was 9 years old when the man she calls ''granddad'' left the White House. Now 36 and head of the Eisenhower World Affairs Institute, she is presiding over activities commemorating the 30th anniversary of the United States-Soviet exchange agreement.

LEAD: Precious metal futures were battered yesterday on reports of substantial sales of gold by South Africa and the Soviet Union, the two largest suppliers of bullion. Meanwhile, copper prices tumbled as more analysts said the yearlong rally in copper prices appeared to be sputtering out.
LEAD: Thousands of aborigines from around the country met here tonight in what their organizers said could well be the largest gathering of this ancient people in its 40,000-year history.

LEAD: Colleen Moore, the star of the silent screen who personified the ''flapper'' of the 1920's, died of cancer yesterday at her ranch near Paso Robles, Calif. She was 85 years old. Miss Moore appeared in about 100 films beginning in 1917 and ending with one of her comparatively few talking pictures, ''The Scarlet Letter,'' in 1937.

LEAD: Charles M. Heidel said today that he would resign as president and chief operating officer of the Detroit Edison Company.
LEAD: Vice President Bush and Dan Rather, the CBS News anchor, shouted at each other in a 10-minute interview about the Iran-contra affair on live national television last night.

LEAD: HILL, HOLLIDAY, CONNORS, COSMOPULOS of Boston has won Pitney Bowes Inc.'s account, which includes the corporate advertising and most of work for the company's business systems. LEAD: ROOSEVELT AND DE GAULLE. Allies in Conflict: A Personal Memoir. By Raoul Aglion. 237 pages. Illustrated.

LEAD: Two members of a former Los Angeles social and business club, the Billionaire Boys Club, were convicted in Redwood City today of murdering the father of one of the defendants in a plot to obtain his assets.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo said today that $100 million from the state pension system would be made available for loans to small businesses at below-market interest rates.

LEAD: A Polish Government spokesman said today that Warsaw acted this month on American information to expel a Palestinian businessman reported to be a close associate of Abu Nidal, the Palestinian terrorist leader.

LEAD: Corning Glass Works today reported a 72 percent rise in profits in the fourth quarter and a record profit for 1987, thanks to one-time gains in the tax and accounting areas and the addition of an extra week into the financial figuring.

LEAD: Herbert Schmertz, whose combative responses to critics of the Mobil Corporation and the oil industry made him the nation's best-known corporate public relations executive during the 1970's, is said to be preparing to leave the company to set up his own business.

LEAD: During negotiations last weekend for a Mike Tyson-Michael Spinks match in June, Bill Cayton, Tyson's co-manager, told Butch Lewis, Spinks's promoter, that if he walked out on the discussions not to bother to come back. Lewis left in spite of the warning.
LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission has become involved in a case of alleged art fraud that a commission attorney, calls ''a first'' for the agency.

The morning rush hour was marked by a peaceful demonstration at the bridge by representatives of the 300 bus drivers of the Golden Gate Transit District.

LEAD: Who set up whom in the now infamous CBS Evening News shootout between Vice President Bush and Dan Rather Monday night? LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: William F. Larkin, a lawyer and former member of the New York State Assembly, died of lung cancer Sunday at Cabrini Hospice of Cabrini Medical Center. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: A special New York State prosecutor said yesterday that there were no grounds to bring criminal charges against Brooklyn District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman or any of her prosecutors concerning a dispute over whether a complainant was mistreated at a sexual misconduct trial.
LEAD: A PERSON could be forgiven for thinking that polenta, the Italian version of cornmeal mush, has just become a hot new item for American food lovers. A person would be wrong.
LEAD: To his players' amusement and the consternation of would-be spies, Coach Joe Gibbs has ordered the Redskins to switch uniform numbers every day while practicing for Super Bowl XXII.

LEAD: If ours were a parliamentary system, the Reagan Government would have fallen 14 months ago. When the Democrats recaptured the Senate in 1986, it reflected a surprising loss of confidence. Then, almost immediately, came the Iran-contra bombshells. President Reagan's popularity sank like a stone, from 67 percent to 46 percent in a month, and it's barely more than that today.

LEAD: HORSE RACING Nice Core Wins by a Neck: Nice Core raced near the leaders early, went to the front once into the stretch and held on gamely to win by a neck in the $31,000 allowance feature yesterday at Aqueduct. Special Message, one of the outsiders in the field of 12, was the runner-up. Nice Core carried 112 pounds under Carlos Correa for a mile and an eighth on the fast but dull racing strip in 1:54 to win his first race this year.

LEAD: The Detroit Tigers have offered Kirk Gibson a one-year contract extension with a no-trade clause, according to Greg Shea, a team spokesman, who refused to specify details of the offer. LEAD: HE has been the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year, he has been an All-Star six times, he has been in drug rehabilitation twice and he is 33 years old, so Walter Davis, the career scoring leader for the Phoenix Suns, figured it was about time to think about the future. Yesterday, he said he planned to retire after the 1988-89 season and to devote his time to a youth drug-abuse treatment center he is founding in Phoenix.

LEAD: SOUTHERN ARIZONA. To an Easterner who had never traveled to this corner of the United States before, the image Tucson and its vicinity brought to mind was of vast, dusty plains, an expanse broken only by the profile of a straggly cactus. But, in fact, the natural beauty of this section of the Grand Canyon State is startlingly diverse; day trips from Tucson will take the traveler from the lush coolness of a mountain canyon to the raw beauty of a forest of saguaro cactuses.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today dissolved the government of the southern state of Tamil Nadu, acting two days after violent brawling on the floor of the State Assembly had to be broken up by the police.

LEAD: POUFS ARE FAST BECOMING passe for evening, but the bouncy or puffed skirt is beginning to be big news for day. Some of the most forward of the new spring styles, while fairly simple above the waist, wind up in skirts that look as though a passing breeze could tilt them this way and that. Sometimes, the effect is achieved with a petticoat or two propping up a fullish skirt.

LEAD: Benno Moiseiwitsch (1890-1963) started recording in 1916, and thus he lived through several revolutions in the recording industry, from acoustic to electric, to LP, to stereo. That fall, he said, there would be a ''colored'' family in the parish for the first time - ''colored'' was the polite term for blacks in those days - and ''colored'' children in the parish school.

LEAD: TAKE a walk down Main Street of any town born a century or more ago and you will find evidence of the fascination for house plants during the Victorian era. Horticultural hobbies were such an intrinsic part of 19th-century life that the architecture reflected this penchant for plants.

LEAD: Four senior correction officers at Sing Sing have been demoted and transferred after an investigation late last year indicated that they were ineffective in stopping drug smuggling by guards, gambling and sex between inmates and female guards, the commissioner of New York State corrections said yesterday.

LEAD: Sinead O'Connor sings sweetly on her debut album, ''The Lion and the Cobra'' (Chrysalis 41612; LP, cassette and CD). But not very often. She's more likely to howl or snarl, to make her voice rasp or crack, to summon the gnarled embellishments of Celtic songs or the open-throated wail of arena-rock.

LEAD: ''GO ahead and turn the knob all the way to the right, then all the way back,'' said Mark Levinson, as he twirled a burnished aluminum dial. The soprano voice coming from two sets of stereo speakers shot to singularly clear high-range notes. He adjusted five other knobs, muting some sounds and bringing life to others.

LEAD: WHEN the furnace shuts down or will not start, puzzled homeowners often panic. But you will be doing yourself and utility personnel a favor, particularly in storms or cold snaps when service crews are strained, by trying to restart the furnace yourself.

LEAD: Opponents of aid to the Nicaraguan rebels will begin airing four television and radio advertisements in 17 targeted Congressional districts represented by House members or Senators who are undecided or wavering in their support of contra assistance.

LEAD: Drug traffickers in Colombia demonstrated a new level of ruthless audacity last week with the kidnapping and murder of Carlos Hoyos, Colombia's Attorney General. LEAD: New York farmers grew more apples, grapes, sour cherries, cabbage and sweet corn in 1987 than the year before, but fewer pears, sweet cherries and onions, according to a series of year-end farm reports issued this week, They also received less money for their fruit and vegetable crops last year, $308 million, compared with $324 million in 1986, a drop of 5 percent, the State Agricultural Statistics Service said.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Carlin of Bryn Mawr, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Paris Ariane Carlin to Johan H. W. Christofferson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lars H. Christofferson of Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: WHILE takeovers and restructurings may enrich common stockholders, owners of corporate bonds in many cases are left reeling from losses. That has been particularly true in recent months for holders of debt convertible into corporate shares. These bonds are generally sold at lower than prevailing interest rates because investors get a kicker: a chance to share in any appreciation of the common stock.

LEAD: How do we know what we know? In THE RING OF TRUTH: An Inquiry Into How We Know What We Know (Random House, $24.95), an immensely pretty book crafted as a companion volume to a public television series of that name on scientific inquiry, Philip and Phylis Morrison, master teachers both - he at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, she in classrooms for all ages - go a long way toward telling us.

LEAD: The Cuomo administration, reversing an earlier stand, will let New York City distribute clean needles to hundreds of drug addicts as part of an experiment to reduce the spread of AIDS, officials familiar with the administration's thinking said today.
LEAD: The Polish Government announced sweeping price increases tonight, including a rise in retail food prices averaging 40 percent.

LEAD: THE Juilliard School ended its weeklong ''Focus'' series, devoted to interactions between American vernacular music and the art music we call ''classical,'' with Charles Ives's ''Holidays Symphony'' Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall. The performance, under Paul Zukofsky, was worthwhile: a reminder that there is broad music of deep feeling woven throughout this piece, which has been played rather infrequently since its overexposure in the years of the Ives centennial and the nation's bicentennial.

S. Lewis; they stepped through a doorway in the back of a closet and abruptly entered a room that was another world.

LEAD: IN the past, there was a type of investment property that the city's assessors called ''sleepers.'' These were the buildings that the were suspected of being underassessed. But since there was no recent sale with which to confirm market value, and no income and expense data unless owners cared to protest an assessment they considered too high, assessors could greatly underestimate their true value.

LEAD: Music keeps chang-ing venue. From church and palace, it moved to the public concert hall as its chief abode. Then the parlor piano and later the phonograph and radio brought music into the living room. And now it seems that music is on the move again, in more than one way. These days, much of it is heard in cars.

LEAD: I am an admirer of Joyce Carol Oates and of Henry A. Kissinger, and also of Mikhail Baryshnikov, Alexander Solzhenitsyn, Yevgeny Yevtushenko. Imagine if an American leader and spouse were to give a dinner in the Soviet Union for their favorite Russian intellectuals. The Soviet Government would have to pull many of them from Gorky, from Siberia, from phony psychiatric facilities, from exile, from defection.

LEAD: Turkeys and Then Some IF it's a gaggle of geese and a flock of sheep, what do you call a group of turkeys? (You can have fun with that one for a while.) Whatever you call them, a whole lot of turkeys are gobbling away at the Connetquot River State Park in Oakdale. The 3,500-acre park is home to about 50 to 60 wild 20-pound turkeys, although, as a New York State park ranger, Gary Lawton, said, ''These turkeys aren't really so wild - they're somewhat tame because they're so used to seeing people in the park.

LEAD: ABRAHAM Joel Tobias hasn't had a show since the mid-1930's, but he has made several murals. The earliest, done for the post office in Clarendon, Ark., is dated 1942; the most recent is a fresco, ''History of Science,'' that the artist worked on from 1960 to 1975 but for some reason left incomplete.

LEAD: IT'S cold, and it's going to be a rough day on the beach. I can tell as soon as I look out the window. The snow is blowing so hard that I can scarcely see the crest of the dunes, 100 yards away. A lone deer walks stiffly through the beach grass, and a marsh hawk fights the winds. Nine mourning doves line up on my porch railing; with feathers fluffed up to trap air and preserve heat, they look like tiny hens.
LEAD: A jury today sentenced Carl Isaacs to die in the electric chair for the 1973 murders of six members of a family.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Seeler of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Evelyn Harrison Seeler to John F. McKay 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McKay Jr. of Hempstead, L.I. The wedding is to be in September. Miss Seeler, an associate in the New York law firm of Rosenberg & Estis, graduated from the Kew-Forest School and cum laude from the University of Richmond.
LEAD: Lauren Rebecca Molloy and Mario Buccellati plan to marry in March, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. John Haywood Molloy of Newburgh, N.Y., have announced.

LEAD: An article tucked away in a recent Billboard magazine and filed for future reference reports that Australia, which already provided a modest sum (slightly more than $50,000) in such support in 1985, is considering a significant expansion in public subsidies for rock music. The debate in that country apparently revolves around such questions as who should administer the funds, whether they are better provided for international touring bands or for mid- or entry-level groups, and so forth.

LEAD: WHEN Citicorp recently announced layoffs in its North American investment bank, including many in the mortgage-backed securities department, some people wondered whether the cutbacks signaled an industry contraction that could mean less money for residential mortgages - and ultimately higher rates.
LEAD: In an effort to persuade Congress to defeat President Reagan's request for new aid to the contras, the Sandinista Government has mounted a campaign of good deeds.
LEAD: The Broncos will, 34-17. EDWARD RANDALL New York
LEAD: ON Feb. 20, the model of a modular home built in the Victorian style is to be unveiled on Peck's Lane in Newtown, a first step in a new era for prefabricated housing in Connecticut.
LEAD: KENNETH O. DECKO has been president of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, the largest business group in the state, for 17 years.

LEAD: RECORD crops of nuts, especially walnuts and almonds, were harvested this fall in California, according to the Department of Agriculture. This volume is good news for consumers. Wholesale prices for walnuts are below last year's levels and almond production was more than double last year with prices also lower.

LEAD: After an eight-month interagency inquiry, the United States has decided to ask Iraq for tens of millions of dollars to compensate the families of those killed in the Iraqi attack on the guided missile frigate Stark, State Department and Pentagon officials say.
LEAD: Alaska's largest commuter airline has been temporarily shut down by the Federal Aviation Administration because of safety problems.

LEAD: I read, with great interest, the article on ''A Private Owner for Public Housing'' [ Jan. 10 ] . Although I think that private ownership of public housing has possibilities, I would have preferred to see public housing sold to tenants of the buildings rather than to a private company.

LEAD: The marriage of Freda Diane Adler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Adler of Ridgefield, Conn., to Jesse London, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin London of New York, took place last evening at the Westbury Hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg officiated.
LEAD: ''From our point of view, there were five main targets. The American Embassy was one of them.'' Col. Do Tan Phong, a Vietcong commander in the Tet offensive in 1968. [ 1:2. ]
LEAD: Fireworks exploded over San Diego Marina Friday night and fans crowded vendors' stands outside the stadium yesterday. (NYT/Barton Silverman)
LEAD: PROPERTY-TAX relief, low-income housing and a new school-aid formula are expected to top the agenda when the General Assembly convenes Wednesday.
LEAD: A man who killed two people to cover up his forgeries of historical documents must spend the rest of his life in prison, the Utah Board of Pardons decided Friday.

LEAD: Bridgewater $131,700 178 Leghorn Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; remodeled kitchen, deck, full basement; taxes $1,318. Denville $255,000 68 Kitchell Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old ranch; wall-to-wall carpeting, C/A, family room; taxes $2,400.
LEAD: ORCHESTRAL concerts will be bountiful this week, beginning Tuesday evening when the noted Soviet emigre maestro, Rudolf Barshai, will be the guest conductor for the Hartford Symphony.

LEAD: The engagement of Mary Catherine Moffett to Christie Max Williams, a son of Ann L. Williams of Los Angeles and Robert C. Williams of Spencerville, Ontario, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William W. Moffett of Mystic, Conn. A May wedding is planned.
