LEAD: THE National Fish and Wildlife Foundation is helping to implement the North American Waterfowl Management Plan, an ambitious and much-needed cooperative agreement that this country and Canada signed in 1986 but for which no funds were allocated.

LEAD: As investigators have looked into the role of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in the Wedtech affair and in a never-built Iraqi pipeline project that now appears to involve hints of bribery, the name E. Robert Wallach has come up repeatedly.

LEAD: To the Editor; May I add to your colorful Jan. 14 article on the ''The Blizzard of 1888'' exhibition at the New-York Historical Society? The Latin American press back then carried a front-page article headlined, ''New York Under the Snow'' by Jose Marti, the Cuban revolutionary poet, educator, writer of children's stories, art and literary critic, and journalist.

LEAD: WITH the current Long Wharf Theater revival of one of A. R. Gurney Jr.'s early works, the 1970 ''Scenes From American Life,'' and the opening Off Broadway of his latest produced play, ''Another Antigone,'' at Playwrights Horizons, chroniclers of Mr. Gurney's career have a rare chance to see the playwright in perspective, and to contrast his past and present concerns.
LEAD: PEOPLE who run an office out of a home may no longer find it worthwhile to take allowable deductions on the office when preparing income tax returns this spring.
LEAD: THE CONSOLATION OF NATURE And Other Stories. By Valerie Martin. 147 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.
LEAD: PLASTIC garbage cans are a boon to those of us who work nights and sleep days.

LEAD: Q. I have a chair whose frame is made of white plastic that has discolored to an uneven beige. Yet a painted metal brace is still white. Is there any way to clean or bleach the plastic, or is there a white paint I can apply?

LEAD: Minority students were more likely than whites to be suspended or placed in classes for the handicapped and were less likely to graduate from the public schools in the 1986-87 school year, according to a survey whose results were issued Friday by the Department of Education.
LEAD: NOW hear this. Jack Kent Cooke is speaking, and no greater love has anyone else for the sound of his own voice.

LEAD: The Santa Fe Opera will present the United States premiere of Krzystof Penderecki's opera ''The Black Mask'' during its 1988 season, which begins July 1 and ends Aug. 27, the company's director, John Crosby, has announced. The opera is one of six that will be given during the 37-performance series.

LEAD: Dave Studdard, Broncos' offensive tackle, versus Dexter Manley, Redskins' defensive end - Manley is coming on after a sluggish season during which he had 8 1/2 sacks. However, if he keeps his composure, he is the quickest and most dangerous pass rusher in this game, and he can disrupt an offense. Studdard is not as skilled as Manley.

LEAD: The date is Jan 31, 2038. At 8 o'clock tonight, Carnegie Hall will be the scene of a special concert of rediscovered music - music that has not been played for three decades. There will, however, be no orchestra - not enough people play the violin, or the cello, or the oboe, anymore. All of the instruments will be played on a new computer, programmed for the occasion: the Bach 9000, which sounds more like an old-fashioned symphony orchestra than the real thing.

LEAD: IN the dialect spoken in Alsace, flammekueche means ''cooked in the flames''; the French flambee has a similar meaning. Whatever it's called, tarte flambee is to northern Alsace what pizza is to southern Italy.

LEAD: YES, critics agreed, ''Carry Me Back to Old Virginia'' - Virginia's official state song - is indeed steeped in sentiment and history. But in today's world, they argued, it is basically a slur on blacks and an unwelcome reminder of slavery.

LEAD: SHORTLY before Stan Lundine took office as Lieutenant Governor of New York in January 1987, he consulted the man who had held the job longer than anyone else: Malcolm Wilson, No. 2 to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller for 15 years. Surprisingly, Mr. Wilson's advice was exactly the opposite of what Mr. Lundine had hoped for.
LEAD: RESPECTED SIR By Naguib Mahfouz. Translated by Rasheed El-Enany. 154 pp. New York: Quartet Books/ Salem House Publishers. $13.95.

LEAD: The engagement of Jennifer Grant Slingluff to Patrick Malone Robinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Miller Robinson Jr. of Nashville, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Haines Slingluff Jr. of Rumson, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: To the Editor: One thing travel agents and travel articles fail to mention is that the Alice Springs and Ayers Rock areas in central Australia are ''the fly capitals of the world.'' Seeking moisture, they attack the mouth and eyes.

LEAD: LIKE some ancient ritual fire dance, shadowy figures dart hither and yon, bearing blazing torches. One man jabs the air with a great glob of fire; another rolls a flaming mass in rapid swirls; still others breathe life into their burning bubbles.

LEAD: LUKAS FOSS's now 15-year-old Meet the Moderns series is changing. In recent years offered in pairs of programs, one at the Brooklyn Philharmonic's home base of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the other at Cooper Union, the series - this season, at least - has abandoned Brooklyn and now consists of five single concerts in Manhattan, three at Cooper Union, one at Town Hall and one at Merkin Concert
LEAD: A coalition for the homeless is banking on a survey of Pennsylvania's homeless to give officials a better idea of who needs help and what help is needed.
LEAD: AN Irish bald eagle? Hardly. But how did it get to a field near Killarney, Ireland, where it was found exhausted and almost starved last Nov. 18?

LEAD: ON the Super Bowl sidelines, coaches have always projected a variety of images. Vince Lombardi, as tough as his tombstone teeth. Don Shula, as solid as his Mount Rushmore jaw. Chuck Noll, as cool as his icy eyes. Tom Landry, as unflappable as his snap-brim hat. Bill Walsh, as organized as the game plan on his clipboard.

LEAD: If American Express did corporate ''Do you know me?'' ads, CPC International Inc. would be a natural choice. Most everyone knows Mazola corn oil, Hellmann's mayonnaise, Skippy peanut butter, Thomas's English muffins and its other products. But CPC itself? It seemed to have made a high science of keeping a low profile.

LEAD: BLACK HISTORY MONTH The Greenburgh Library's celebration of Black History Month begins this week with a talk by Terrie M. Williams, who grew up in Mount Vernon and is now a vice president of Essence Magazine Inc. She will speak about ''Making It to the Top: A Black Woman's Journey'' at 7:45 P.M.

LEAD: The Dog in the Poet When he was almost 40 and severely depressed, the poet Rilke fell in love with a young concert pianist. The lifting of his spirits prompted some almost hysterically enthusiastic love letters, like this one from ''Rilke and Benvenuta: An Intimate Correspondence'' (Fromm).
LEAD: DOMESTIC REVOLUTIONS A Social History of American Family Life. By Steven Mintz and Susan Kellogg. Illustrated. 316 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.

LEAD: Three years ago former workers at a nuclear plant here told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that plant managers repeatedly falsified radiation readings, thus hiding evidence of problems that would otherwise have forced an expensive shutdown.

LEAD: REPRESENTATIVE James J. Florio of Runnemede, who lost to Thomas H. Kean in the 1981 gubernatorial election - and who has indicated he may run again next year -said that President Reagan's praise in his State of the Union speech for Mr. Kean's education efforts was ironic.

LEAD: Darrell Green, Redskins' cornerback, vs. Ricky Nattiel, Broncos' wide receiver - Green is one of the two or three best cornerbacks in the league, with exceptional speed and an ability to be physical despite his small size. Nattiel, a 5-foot-9-inch, 180-pound rookie, caught 31 passes for an average 20.3 yards during the season.

LEAD: Vice President Bush holds a commanding lead in the South in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination while the Democratic contest is unsettled, according to a poll released yesterday.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 32 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Sterling Jonas of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Gail Jonas, to Harry Isadore Goldberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Goldberg of Savannah, Ga. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: I would like to add to William Safire's collection of ''summative dribble-offs'' such as et cetera, blah, blah, blah and whatever (On Language: ''I am Appalled,'' Dec. 20). Among folks who work in computer science, artificial intelligence and cognitive science, the term mumble has become a mildly self-deprecatory way to terminate a thought that has gotten beyond the control of its thinker.

LEAD: John Elway is capable of winning the game almost by himself, and with Denver's running game he may have to. Washington will find a way to contain Elway somewhat. Final score: Washington 37, Denver 24. ROBERT FABRIKANT New York

LEAD: WINTER vacation: a time for family to sit together by the fire. My 63-year-old husband wants to learn to ski. I want to do some cross-country skiing. My stepson-in-law wants to ski. My stepdaughter, four months pregnant, wants to ski; the obstetrician says don't go down hill. My 17-year-old wants to ski.

LEAD: EARLY IN ''THE UNBEARABLE Lightness of Being,'' Daniel Day Lewis stares at women. Tomas, the character he portrays, is a Czechoslovak brain surgeon whose easeful life will soon be wrenched apart - by undesired love, by the Russian military invasion of Prague in 1968 - but for now he has a look Don Juan might envy.
LEAD: WHEN Maurie Fisher and June Breton Fisher organized their first ''floating golf tournament'' five years ago, it prompted a lot of tongue-in-cheek questions.

LEAD: I recall reading in an old book that the world was rushed into production in six days, after which a complete rest was felt to be necessary. Presumably, the work was considered perfect at the time. Or maybe the result fell so short of expectation that the whole show was simply allowed to stand, flaws and all, to be rethought another day.

LEAD: DESPITE the Chernobyl accident in 1986, in which 31 people died after a reactor exploded, the Soviet Union has clung to its ambitious plans for developing nuclear power. By the turn of the century, Soviet officials hope to double - to more than 20 percent - the percentage of electricity generated by nuclear reactors.

LEAD: Harry Reichenbaum, a lawyer who specialized in negligence and medical malpractice cases, died of a heart attack Monday at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx. He was 63 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

LEAD: President Mubarak of Egypt has been here this week urging the Reagan Administration to get actively involved in the search for Arab-Israeli peace. He had a central message, delivered with passion.

LEAD: FOR THE PAST decade, the most persistent culinary enthusiasm in America has been for Italian food. Witness the continuing proliferation of Italian restaurants.

LEAD: NEXT month, the 95 members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will reconvene in their Geneva headquarters to begin the second year of negotiations on revisions of world trade rules. Watched with a good deal of fanfare in the fall of 1986 in Punta del Este, Uruguay, these negotiations are scheduled to end in 1990.

LEAD: A SERIES of concerts organized last winter at the historic St. James Episcopal Church in North Salem drew such an enthusiastic response that a new cycle of ''Music at St. James'' has been arranged for the final Sundays of January, February and March - with the first concert beginning this afternoon.

LEAD: A June wedding is planned by Dr. Ricki Ellyn Steinberg, a senior resident in pediatrics at Beth Israel Hospital, and Dr. Dean Cory Mitchell, a senior resident in internal medicine at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. LEAD: STEVE, 10 months old, pushed Emily, 14 months old, across the living-room floor on her three-wheeler. Ricky, 9 months old, played with a hat. Their foster mother sat on the floor, occasionally reaching out to hug or pat one of the children. ''A house full of kids - just what I always wanted,'' she said, laughing as Ricky hid behind the hat.
LEAD: The ''Garbage Crisis'' has been in the headlines for the past year, and it now appears possible that this unsolved problem will eventually ruin the natural beauty of Westchester County.

LEAD: A WHILE ago, a friend at odds with his colleagues told of a dream in which they were feeding him glass. This writer, at an offbeat exhibition recently, recalled her visceral reaction to his story when she confronted a pile of broken glass contained within a circular rim. Glass at its rawest -jagged, brittle, uncivilized by shaping and capable of hurting - rarely shows up in galleries where glass is the theme.

LEAD: Yes or no: Continue aid to the contra rebels in Nicaragua, or finally cut them off? For the last seven years, the Reagan Administration has by hook and, almost literally, crook, kept the aid flowing. This week Congress will vote on the newest proposal, for $36 million in aid, including $3.6 million in military aid.

LEAD: When Georgetown, Conn., was placed on the National Register of Historic Places last March, it was recommended as ''a community which today resembles the rural industrial village of 19th-century Utopian ideology.'' The mill of the Gilbert and Bennett Company, founded in 1818, forms the center of the unincorporated village near Norwalk.

LEAD: FIRST OFF, I OWE AN apology to Mikhail Gorbachev, author of ''Perestroika,'' whose book tour recently included a stop in Washington. (Why first off? Why not just first? Because I am being determinedly colloquial, and it's better than the awkward firstly.) With a loud ''Ah-hah!'', I quoted an anonymous refusenik catching the Soviet General Secretary using a Russian word that was kind of an insult to President Reagan.

LEAD: Calvin Ayres wants to be the first black police officer in Lufkin, an East Texas town of 30,000 people about 150 miles from here. But first he has to pass the police entrance examination, and therein lies a problem.

LEAD: THE program note for George Balanchine's ballet ''Stravinsky Violin Concerto'' remarks that the choreographer used the same score in 1941 for an earlier ballet, ''under the title 'Balustrade,' with beautiful costumes and scenery by the late Pavel Tchelitchev.''

LEAD: An illegal gambling ring that handled about $500 million in bets on sporting events was the target of raids on seven apartments in Manhattan last night that resulted in the arrests of 20 people, the police reported.

LEAD: TRACK and field's governing body, the International Amateur Athletic Association, has toughened its anti-drug rules while calling for Americans to ''cure'' their legal barriers to random testing.

LEAD: Joe Gibbs is arguably the best coach in football. John Elway is unquestionably the best quarterback in football. This Super Bowl will be decided by these two men. In the World Series, the on-field leadership of Don Baylor outmatched the off-field leadership of Whitey Herzog. Super Bowls, like World Series, are won or lost on the field, not in the locker room.

LEAD: THREE YEARS ago, when I suggested an article to the editors of this magazine on ''the human cost of AIDS,'' most reporting on the epidemic was scientific in nature and people with AIDS were often portrayed as faceless victims. By profiling a man with AIDS and his volunteer counselor from Gay Men's Health Crisis, I proposed to show the devastating impact AIDS was having on a few individual lives.

LEAD: Weeping women, in traditional mourning robes, kneeling along the funeral route of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo. The body of the 77-year-old leader, who died on Jan. 13, was taken to his country estate outside Taipei. The remains of his father, Gen. Chaing Kai-shek, are in a mausoleum nearby.

LEAD: For Gaston Leroux, author of the novel ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' there was no doubt that his Phantom existed, that he was a man assuming the appearance ''of a spectral shade.'' The tangibility of the Phantom - what might be called Leroux's Law -is preserved through all the disparate dramatizations, from Lon Chaney's hollow-eyed, death's-head version in the 1925 silent film to Claude Rains's more sedate 1943 cinematic impersonation to Brian De Palma's rock-toned modernization, ''The Phantom of the Paradise.

LEAD: IN my small suburban town, a group of children are shared freely by a group of mothers who happen to be friends. The friendships began with the children, but they have grown more quickly than the toddlers who used to crawl on our laps and upset coffee cups when we were full-time mothers. All of us have jobs outside our homes now, with a variety of titles, hours, responsibilities and pressures.

LEAD: TITCH. By Chaim Bermant. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) Chaim Bermant's brief eighth novel closely resembles the oft-told tale of the American Jew who comes of age during World War II, discovering in wartime his Americanness as well as his ambivalence about his Jewish identity. The differences in ''Titch'' are that its bookish Jewish youth, the repository of his immigrant family's ambitions, is British; that the locale is neither the Bronx, Brooklyn nor Newark but Manchester; and that the forbidden fruits are rashers and the granddaughters of baronets.

LEAD: The economy's growth rate for the final quarter of 1987 was deceptively robust. Gross national product rose at an annual rate of 4.2 percent during the quarter, but most of the increased output piled up as unsold inventory, which is likely to be a drag on the economy in the immediate future. The economy grew at an inflation-adjusted rate of 3.7 percent for all of 1987, the fifth year of expansion.

LEAD: A jury in Federal District Court on Friday found Clarence Mitchell 3d, a former State Senator, guilty of conspiracy and obstructing a grand jury investigation into his connection with a convicted Baltimore drug dealer.

LEAD: As the Pigeon River winds through the Great Smoky Mountains in North Carolina, its waters are clear and filled with bass and trout. But about 40 miles before crossing into Tennessee, the river turns the color of coffee, and the only fish found in it are bottom dwellers like carp and bullhead.

LEAD: IN April my daughter and I were in a car accident. We were driving to my parents' house in Pennyslvania; it was rush hour on a three-lane interstate highway. I was in the right lane. The 18-wheeler to my left didn't see me. He pulled abruptly into my lane and hit my car, sending me spinning in front of him, where he hit me a second time.

LEAD: The painting of two blond-haired children on the outside of what was once the Mother Goose Nursery School is faded now. The small desks and chairs and brightly colored pictures are no longer inside.

LEAD: Miss Minnesota-U.S.A. was arrested on a gross misdemeanor theft charge after a security guard at a department store here told police she was shoplifting, City Attorney Marsh Halberg said today.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: Six-Month Event

LEAD: OUT ON THE RIM. By Ross Thomas. (Mysterious Press, $17.95.) Here's one solution to that panicky, last-ditch scramble at the airport for the perfect book to read on the plane. Ross Thomas's nimble international thriller will get you to Washington, Malibu, Manila, Hong Kong and even - with a few backup books like his earlier ''Briarpatch'' and ''Cold War Swap'' - to the Philippines.

LEAD: At 3 o'clock in the morning of Jan. 31, 1968, North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces launched a wave of simultaneous attacks on South Vietnamese and American forces in major cities, towns and military bases throughout South Vietnam.

LEAD: IT MAY SEEM WILDLY FUTURISTIC, but the whole idea actually recalls Noah's Ark. Biosphere II, a completely enclosed, 2.25-acre, self-supporting ecosystem designed to accommodate plant, animal and human life, has been in the works since 1984 near Tucson, Ariz. Supporters see the project as a hedge against the eventual extinction of life on Earth (aka, Biosphere I), as well as a step toward colonization of the Moon and Mars.

LEAD: To what extent can an ex-hibition sum up an entire civilization? Every generation has its own answer to that, but some of the answers haven't worn too well. Once upon a time the huge, baggy, ''comprehensive,'' all-star national survey was in high favor. Governments loved them, and in a time of relative inactivity in the museum world the public often loved them, too.

LEAD: To the Editor: Readers interested in Susan Lumsden's article ''Marbled Paper From Florence'' (Travel, Dec. 13) have an opportunity to learn of the process as applied to another material - slate. The first exhibit dealing with this process as used on slate is on view at the Vermont Historical Society Museum in Montpelier through April 30.
LEAD: The principal of Trumbull High School wants seniors to make their final exam a sobriety test.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: AT exactly 3:33 P.M. on Jan. 16, 1987, in the midst of a week punctuated by power outages, cold fronts and a wave of snowstorms, my daughter, Julia, forced her way kicking and screaming into the world.

LEAD: Helen Fahnestock Michalis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Fahnestock Michalis of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to Michael Hayden Bonebrake, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Bonebrake of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal

LEAD: Patricia E. Harris, the executive director of the New York City Art Commission and an assistant to Mayor Koch, and Mark D. Lebow, a lawyer who is the chairman of the City Civil Service Commission, were married last evening at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Richard J. Jacobs officiated.

LEAD: WHILE storm clouds and spare parts still cause most flight delays, a growing number of late planes are the result of crowded airports. Yet avoiding airport congestion can be as simple as bypassing congested airports. Most major American cities have mid-sized airports in and around them that are served by major airlines but are less busy than the city's main facility.
LEAD: AFTER some great years, the financial-services industry in the state is showing signs of slowing down.

LEAD: THE HISTORY OF A ROOM IS A scrapbook of lives; the evolution of its decor, a record of evolving tastes and fashions. The room shown here was originally the newspaper publisher Joseph Pulitzer's bedroom. Tucked away on the upper floor of an old New York house, Pulitzer's private quarters were grand, his bedroom measuring 32 by 36 feet, with 16-foot-high ceilings.

LEAD: A former RKO movie theater is being converted into nine storefronts on Broadway at 232d Street in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx. The 14,500-square-foot building, which David Magier purchased last August for $1.4 million, was built in the 1920's and for the past 20 years has been used as a bingo parlor.

LEAD: It is an excellent idea to take your spouse or another person to the doctor with you, especially if surgery is on the agenda. The subtle mental dysfunction discussed in Morton Hunt's article must not cloud what lawyers and physicians recognize as informed consent to undergo a surgical procedure. Relevant questions should be asked and note should be made of the risks of the intervention, possible complications and the expected benefits.

LEAD: Fred Couples opened today's third round of the Phoenix Open with an eagle 2 on the first hole, then sank a 40-foot birdie putt on the second. That was a strong enough start to get the attention of Davis Love 3d.

LEAD: THERE will be a curfew in Washington this evening. It is self-imposed and will begin at approximately 5 P.M. The streets will be deserted, the delicatessen shelves emptied and most restaurants, drugstore and supermarket chains shuttered early.

LEAD: 'Anybody that suggests aboriginal people have a lot to celebrate this year as a result of the last 200 years hasn't taken much note of history.' - Gerry Hand, Australia's Minister for Abroriginal Affairs, announcing that he would boycott the bicentennial festivities.
LEAD: Secret Weapon: Horseradishes
LEAD: TWO decades ago bridge was a recreation of the capitalist countries, spurned by the communist world as a bourgeois pursuit that promotes gambling. But times have changed.

LEAD: ON the east side of Manhattan, from 96th Street north, empty lots still outnumber condominiums, boarded-up windows are more common than ''For Sale'' signs and trash far exceeds brass. Nonetheless, people who live there are worried that the neighborhood is getting trendy.
LEAD: THE Montrealer was a classic train.
LEAD: ''FAST GIRLS,'' the American Stage Company's new comedy, is about sex and the single woman in the age of AIDS anxiety.

LEAD: EVEN talking about it, Mary Jean Tully gets exceedingly annoyed. She isn't the self-pitying type, but on certain social occasions, she does wonder, ''Why, oh, why me?'' And it doesn't help much to know that the same thing happens to a lot of other people, and that these people often have the very same thought.

LEAD: To demonstrate more than a dime's worth of policy difference between himself and George Bush, Bob Dole must find an issue on which he can take a more hawkish stance - without appearing to be disloyal to Ronald Reagan.

LEAD: Elizabeth Mehren, a reporter in New York for The Los Angeles Times, and Fox Butterfield, a reporter for The New York Times, were married yesterday in Park City, Utah. Hal Taylor, the Mayor of Park City, officiated at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Mathews.

LEAD: The marriage of Laura Best Yorke, a daughter of Lane Harvey Yorke of New York and Aaron Jones Yorke 4th of New York and Southampton, L.I., to Thomas Peter Kikis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter T. Kikis of New York and Nassau, the Bahamas, took place yesterday at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York.

LEAD: For the sixth time, Willie Jasper Darden has broken a date with death. The United States Supreme Court last week blocked the execution of the Florida prison inmate, who was scheduled to be electrocuted this week for the 1973 murder of a Lakeland merchant, pending his latest appeal, which will be heard after the Court reconvenes next month.

LEAD: His lyric tenor filling the room, Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn offered a ballad about love.

LEAD: An American jailed and charged with anti-Government activities after his small plane was shot down last month was released to a United States Senate candidate and a group of lawyers today and flown to Los Angeles.

LEAD: I USED to create fantasies of how I would be when I reached a certain age. I even created the appropriate rocking chair and the porch where I would sit and view life passing by; where I would receive my children and tell tales of my past to numerous grandchildren, who would delight in my company; where friends would gather to reminisce happily about our long-ago adventures; where I would feel at peace - wise, loving and loved.

LEAD: IT was his first day back at work after the longest layoff of his career, and for Wayne Gretzky it was a busy, if ultimately unsatisfying, night Friday in Edmonton. He set up all four Oiler goals in a game against Calgary, but the Flames got five, spoiling Gretzky's return after a 13-game absence.

LEAD: Year after year, Super Bowl football games have been anything but super. In the last five years, in order, the Washington Redskins have won by 10 points, the Los Angeles Raiders by 29, the San Francisco 49ers by 22, the Chicago Bears by 36 and the Giants by 19.

LEAD: THE New Jersey Council of Churches has taken a hard look behind the state's low unemployment figures and found disquieting evidence that putting people to work is no longer enough to make the American Dream a reality for many citizens.
LEAD: PUTTING ON A HAT CAN BE A ceremonious act, an elegant gesture in the ritual of dressing. That's no news to the spruce
LEAD: THE spending bill Congress passed last month included $2.2 million to continue environmental studies of Long Island Sound and the surrounding shoreline.

LEAD: Valerie Prescott Kindred, a geologist for Shell Oil in Houston, and Scott Cameron Walker, a telecommunications analyst for International Business Machines in Boulder, Colo., plan to be married in April. Their engagement has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. G. Estabrook Kindred of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Skytop, Pa.

LEAD: Nancy Lawrence Clark and Richard John Angerer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Angerer of Lansing, N.Y., plan to marry in August, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Clark of Cooperstown, N.Y., and St. Simons Island, Ga., have announced.

LEAD: The marriage of Dr. Phyllis Schmiedeberg to Scott M. Sherman took place yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York. Acting Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, who is also the supervising judge of the Civil Court in Manhattan, officiated.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond John Wean Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Rebecca Wean, to Robert Scott Stilin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Stilin of Mellen, Wis. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: EIGHT years after legislation was first proposed, Long Island, along with the rest of New York State, is embarking on an 18-month trial that will permit audiovisual equipment in courtrooms. Beginning tomorrow, at the crophones will be allowed in criminal and civil court proceedings, including trials that the press wishes to cover.

LEAD: COLOR in photography has become the equivalent of sugar in the diet and is every bit as addictive. This may explain not only the fad for colorizing old movies but also the jolt that comes from seeing those that have escaped the treatment.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene V. Amoroso of Houston have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Jean Amoroso to David Elisha Walker, a son of Mrs. Bayard Walker of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Walker. The couple plan to marry in August.

LEAD: An item in Sports People last Sunday misidentified the former University of Michigan All-America running back who will be inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame next December. He is Bob Chappuis.

LEAD: ''NOISES OFF'' is a knee-slappingly funny comedy about the behind-scenes doings of a live theatrical production called ''Nothing On.'' At Theater Three, where this delightful show by the British playwright Michael Frayn is currently playing, ''Noises Off'' is productions this theater has come up with in several seasons.

LEAD: President Reagan said today that while the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua had made limited concessions toward greater democracy, continued military pressure by the contras was necessary to continue that progress.

LEAD: A TIME FOR GIANTS: Politics of the American High Command in World War II. By D. Clayton James with Anne Sharp Wells. (Franklin Watts, $19.95.) A distinguished historian and the author of the well-received three-volume biography ''The Years of MacArthur'' here focuses attention on the careers of 18 top American military leaders.
LEAD: Dr. Jonah D. Kosovsky, an assistant attending physician in Mount Sinai Medical Center's department of medicine, died of cancer last Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 61 years old.

LEAD: Press the first button on the private telephone at Gracie Mansion and you'll automatically be connected with a special woman in Mayor Koch's life. ''I have very special access,'' she said. Nearly every day at 6 A.M., the Mayor picks her up for a 40-minute workout on a treadmills in a downtown gym.

LEAD: EVER since George Halas sat on an automobile running board at the Hupmobile agency in Canton, Ohio during the 1920 founding of the National Football League, coaches have talked about their teams having to ''make the big plays.'' But nobody ever made more big plays quicker in a big game than Doug Williams did yesterday in the Washington Redskins' 42-10 triumph over the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XX

LEAD: Colleen Walker was sitting in a tent two summers ago, describing in detail her every golf shot to reporters at the Mastercard International Pro-Am. She was recounting her final round, explaining how for the first time she had placed second in a Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour event.

LEAD: Pamela and David Maier are expecting their first child in six months. Besides choosing a name for their new baby, the Maiers face another difficult decision: If it's a boy, should he be circumcised?

LEAD: The General Services Administration knew that competitors for Government telephone contracts had improperly obtained secret bid information about the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, but the agency allowed them to bid on the contracts anyway, according to two agency employees.

LEAD: The Knicks, one game past the midway point of the National Basketball Association season following their overtime loss in Chicago Saturday night, have baffled coaches, scouts and fans with their inconsistent play.

LEAD: Wallace Groves, whose Wall Street career ended in the 1930's when he was convicted for mail fraud and who then went on to develop the city of Freeport in the Bahamas into a major resort and gambling area, died Saturday at Doctors Hospital in Miami, six days after suffering a stroke. He was 86 years old.

LEAD: JOE ELY delivered twanging, stomping, full-tilt rock-and-roll at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street, on Friday night. For a decade, Mr. Ely has been singing and writing songs that match basic rock to lyrics that delight in wordplay and imagery. In the 1970's, he put together a band that reflected his Lubbock, Tex., background, mixing Mexican accordion, soul saxophone and country steel guitar with guitar-driven rockabilly; on his 1984 album ''Hi-Res,'' he also flirted with computers and synthesizers.

LEAD: The Delta knitwear factory would simply be closed down, the article said, because environmental officials were tired of waiting for the company's management to put in chimney filters that stop soot.
LEAD: Donald L. Rogers, president of the Association of Bank Holding Companies, died Jan. 18 of colon cancer at his home in Washington. He was 59.
LEAD: Ever so quietly, senior officials of the International Olympic Committee are still working on resolving the issue of North Korea's participation in the Seoul Olympics later this year.

LEAD: THE keyboardist and composer Wayne Horvitz and the guitarist and composer James (Blood) Ulmer unveiled two entirely different approaches to music at the Bottom Line Saturday night. For his records, Mr. Horvitz, who sounds as happy swinging through be-bop as throwing notes around with the saxophonist John Zorn, constructs perfect musical miniatures.

LEAD: When Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian financier, began his attack from the south, Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest holding company, was forced to seek help from a neighbor to the north.

LEAD: Stephen P. Schwartz, 53, will have a sensitive job as the person in charge of two midrange office systems -System/36 and System/38 - that have been lagging in rugged competition with minicomputers from other companies. Mr. Schwartz will head the I.B.M. Application Business Systems, which will be responsible for System/3X products.

LEAD: The rules governing many corporate takeovers are about to change dramatically, all with the stroke of a pen in Wilmington, Del. The state's Governor, Michael N. Castle, is expected to sign tomorrow a bill that makes unfriendly takeovers harder.

LEAD: Washington's defensive schemes, which imprisoned John Elway's skills, and the use of the size advantage of its offensive line were the key elements in the Redskins' Super Bowl rout of the Denver Broncos.

LEAD: It is hard to know what to expect of Pat Robertson in Iowa, where his unorthodox Presidential candidacy, like the more conventional campaigns of his rivals, will get its first major test Feb. 8.
LEAD: * James M. Kimmelman has joined Greenstone & Rabasca South, Boca Raton, Fla., as executive vice president and general manager.

LEAD: The narrow streets and small wooden homes look at first like any other Japanese neighborhood. But here and there, telltale signs appear - a sticker on a door with a tiny Korean flag, bolts of brightly colored Korean silk hanging in a shop window, posters of red-cheeked girls in Korean traditional dress, the kimchi pots of spicy pickled cabbage on display in the central market.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Education will be spared a 2.5 percent spending cut that the Koch administration plans to impose on all other city agencies, city and education officials said yesterday.
LEAD: It did not come to pass, but many cable television subscribers in Manhattan spent part of yesterday contemplating Super Bowl Sunday without the Super Bowl.
LEAD: With the retirement this spring of Robert Shaw from the post of music director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, an era will end in this city's cultural life.

LEAD: FOR people who follow developments in the electric utility industry, the announcement on Thursday by the beleaguered Public Service Company of New Hampshire that it had filed for bankruptcy protection came as no surprise.
LEAD: Thousands of people lined up today outside the new St. Lucie County Sports Complex to buy tickets for the Mets' spring training games.

LEAD: President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, left Jordan today to return to Washington after a day of talks with King Hussein. American and Jordanian officials refused to comment on the talks beyond saying they focused on the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
LEAD: The rafters stayed in place, but another kind of ceiling was lifted at clubs across New York City over the weekend.

LEAD: Nuclear plants that were abandoned before completion or finished at excessive cost will cost the nation's economy as much as $100 billion, according to utility experts. The penalty for this technological wrong turn will be shared by residential and business electric customers, Federal taxpayers and, increasingly, utility stockholders and bondholders.
LEAD: A photographer for a national magazine recently approached Kathleen Wood with a request: find a Presidential nominating caucus that will take place in a one-room schoolhouse.

LEAD: Reprise was the theme sought by all three metropolitan-area Patrick Division teams over the weekend, as each attempted to generate something resembling a winning streak.

LEAD: A NEW promotion campaign for CBS-TV breaks today on the network, and if the hopes of Gene F. Jankowski, president of the Broadcast Group, are realized it will help bring a younger audience to the network that attracts the oldest.
LEAD: The International Monetary Fund, long criticized for insensitivity to the consequences of its demands for austerity in debtor countries, is trying a new approach.

LEAD: To honor the 90th birthday of the composer Vittorio Rieti, the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble is to give a concert devoted to his work at 8 P.M. on Wednesday at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

LEAD: Two film makers and a video artist are the recipients of this year's Maya Deren Awards, sponsored by the American Film Institute. The three - Bruce Conner, Yvonne Rainer and Bill Viola - will each receive a $5,000 cash award. J. Hoberman, a film critic for The Village Voice, is to receive a citation for contributions to independent film and video.

LEAD: For more than two years, top officials debated whether giving clean needles to New York City drug addicts would do more good or harm in a city that is home to half the nation's heroin addicts and that expects to bear the worst damage from the rising AIDS epidemic.
LEAD: The inaugural concert on Feb. 4 of a new symphony orchestra has stirred up greater interest and expectation here than any other cultural event in recent times.

LEAD: A police spokesman, who asked not to be identified, said an undetermined number of arrests were made tonight stemming from the Super Bowl XXII celebration. The spokesman cited incidents of looting, window breaking and fighting. No official arrest estimates were available because of the large number of people in the area, the spokesman said.

LEAD: An article on Dec. 17 about newspaper editors' views on the character of Gary Hart misstated the year in which Richard M. Nixon ran for the Presidency against George McGovern. It was 1972; his rival in 1968 was Hubert H. Humphrey.

LEAD: In a mansion that was home to barons of a bygone era, more than 100 government officials, academics, foundation executives and civic leaders met here this weekend to debate New York City's social and economic future in the wake of last fall's Wall Street collapse.

LEAD: The Neuroscientific Corporation had the right names associated with it to be a hot new stock issue. By selling shares to the public, the tiny manufacturer of medical equipment hoped to transfer a device developed in the laboratories of Rockefeller University into practical and immediate use in the nation's hospitals.

LEAD: The Democratic Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts said today that it had apologized to Senator Paul Simon, a rival, over a Dukakis staff member's attempt to ''volunteer'' at a Simon campaign office.

LEAD: Shaken by the murder of the country's Attorney General last Monday, many influential Colombians have begun arguing that this country is paying too high a price for combating powerful drug traffickers.
LEAD: The Washington Redskins' starters were about to be introduced today before Super Bowl XXII when Don Breaux, who coaches the running backs, walked over to Timmy Smith, his prize rookie.

LEAD: An exhibition that opened yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art explores social and political themes in American printed art from the 1960's to the present, using 144 prints and 36 books by 108 individual artists and 16 collectives. The printed works are organized into six categories: governments and leaders; race and culture; gender; nuclear power and ecology; war and revolution; economics, class struggle and the American Dream.

LEAD: Looking grander than it has in a generation, Grand Central Terminal will mark its 75th anniversary tomorrow with a clear Beaux-Arts victory over decades of neglect and abuse but without its fabled title, ''Gateway to a Continent.''

LEAD: Sanford N. McDonnell, the chairman and chief executive of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, said he would retire in March. Mr. McDonnell, 65 years old, has headed the company since 1980. LEAD: In a company whose upper ranks have long been an exclusive male bastion, Ellen M. Hancock stands out. Not only is Mrs. Hancock the highest-ranking woman to be an I.B.M. operating officer, but she may also hold one of the company's toughest jobs.

LEAD: A Brooklyn man taken into police custody after threatening neighbors in his apartment building died in an ambulance en route to the hospital on Saturday, the police said, and it is unclear what caused his death.

LEAD: Somewhere far away, the Super Bowl parties were reaching their climax and two weeks of analysis were near their end. But inside this hotel ballroom where about 1,000 people sat, Super Bowl XXII was nothing more than a point of reference.

LEAD: Joseph J. Coffey Sr., a co-founder of Local 804, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, died Saturday at City Hospital Center at Elmhurst, in Queens, after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Woodside, Queens.

LEAD: At Wagner College, the undergraduate enrollment is about 1,500, the longest walk from a dormitory to a classroom takes five minutes, and students still pay a quarter for a round-trip ride on the Staten Island Ferry.
LEAD: ALTHOUGH the young choreographers who took part in the Choreographers Showcase on Friday night at the Robert Yohn Dance Loft had ideas, their kinetic images did not always embody those ideas.

LEAD: Sandy Lyle of Scotland almost committed the cardinal sin of missing his tee time this morning. But he capped a big comeback when he won the Phoenix Open by beating Fred Couples on the third hole of a playoff. He won with a bogey 5 after Couples drove into a pond on the left of the 18th fairway for the second time in less than an hour.

LEAD: The Social Democratic Party voted today to merge with the Liberal Party in the latest effort by Britain's centrists to break the dominance of the governing Conservatives and opposition Laborites.

LEAD: The White House Chief of Staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., said today that President Reagan had no intention of asking Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to resign because he is under investigation for his involvement in an Iraqi pipeline project.

LEAD: In his State of the Union Message, President Reagan urged Congress to rally behind family values. Meanwhile, hard-pressed American families are finding out the truth of December's grim statistics: Total housing starts dropped 18 percent below November. Apartments are what home-starved city families need; families already combing the streets for vacancies know that apartment- house starts dropped a mammoth 33 percent.

LEAD: The end to the legal battle over desegregating Yonkers' neighborhoods left the city with a bitterly divided government and a large bloc of voters renouncing the very officials they elected just three months ago.
LEAD: The Wall Street Journal was so pleased about the 16-page I.B.M. advertising insert it carried Friday that it heralded its coming with both print and radio ads.

LEAD: The commission working to restructure New York City's government has been told by its legal experts that it must devise a radically new form of government - one that abolishes the powerful Board of Estimate and distributes its authority elsewhere.

LEAD: When Steve Chen, one of the nation's leading supercomputer engineers, left Cray Research Inc. in a dispute last year, it was only hours before Carl J. Conti called. As I.B.M.'s chief of mainframe computer development, Mr. Conti, 50, seized an opportunity to move I.B.M. into the only major computer field where it currently has no offerings.
LEAD: Some four million Ecuadoreans voted today for a successor to President Leon Febres Cordero from a record field of 10 candidates backed by 17 different parties.
LEAD: Avalanches in the Italian Alps killed three people and stranded others this weekend, the authorities said today.

LEAD: THE start ramp is steep. The first three gates look like a forest of slim trees that have been placed directly in your path. ''Ready . . . Go!'' the starter says, and you push off. Your heart is in your mouth and your legs are trembling as you breathe hard and aim straight at that first gate.
LEAD: Not too far from the ancient walls, a modern dish antenna is aimed as if in supplication to the heavens above the Holy Land, eavesdropping on America's nightly news images of Israel.
LEAD: Rex Chapman's 3-point play with 1 minute 18 seconds remaining sparked Kentucky to a 78-69 victory today over Notre Dame.

LEAD: The management restructuring that the International Business Machines Corporation announced last week is intended to bring the responsibility for decision-making closer to the company's operations. The move will give the five general managers who will run the new major units much greater visibility in the world's largest computer maker.

LEAD: A 290-pound pet tiger, riding in the back seat of a car on its way to a public appearance, was slightly injured in a traffic accident last week but is now back home with its owner. The cat's owner, Edwin Corders, remained at its side last Thursday for the seven hours it spent at a veterinary clinic here.

LEAD: On the basketball court, Bob Gaeta has always been a gunner. He lived and died by the jump shot.

Minutes before, dozens of young men and women carrying red, white and blue balloons formed the Stars and Stripes to Alpert's performance of ''America the Beautiful.

LEAD: The Nets have often been a troubled franchise since they came into being in 1967 as the New Jersey Americans in the American Basketball Association. But at the midpoint of this National Basketball Association season, they have a 9-32 record after beating the Detroit Pistons Saturday night.

LEAD: Star of the Game: Doug Williams of the Redskins getting ready to hand off in the first quarter. Beleaguered Bronco: Redskins' Dexter Manley grabbing John Elway, Broncos' quarterback, in the second quarter. Getting Away: Redskins' Timmy Smith eluding a Denver defender at the goal line for a touchdown in the second quarter.

LEAD: THE television movie ''Weekend War'' is less impressive as a drama exercise than for what it reflects, probably accurately, about widespread public perceptions of United States Government policies in Central America. Especially since the Iran-contra hearings, the overall picture is riddled with covert maneuverings, evasions and, to put it gingerly, disinformation.

LEAD: When President Reagan was first elected in 1980, the Heritage Foundation had waiting for him a long agenda of actions he could take in dealing with environmental problems. The recommendations reflected the foundation's conservative perspective. National environmental groups, whose views were generally in direct opposition to those of the foundation, wrung their hands.

LEAD: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, has been cleared of any charges of legal or ethical misconduct after a yearlong series of investigations into his financial relationship with Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street speculator.

LEAD: Something there is about a Bond Street or a Rodeo Drive or a Rue du Faubourg St.-Honore that makes the head spin and the fingers itch and the ribs feel the scorch of a red-hot wallet. ''Buy me,'' the glories in the shops proclaim, ''and you'll get a leg up on life.''
LEAD: Surgeons transplanted a heart into an 18-day-old boy born with a fatal defect and said today the infant was in critical but stable condition.

LEAD: The rate of growth of the nation's economy slowed in January, lagging behind December in production and employment, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, scheduled to be released today.
LEAD: ''Because that's where the money is,'' Willie Sutton supposedly said when asked why he robbed banks.

LEAD: * Brooklyn Union Gas Co. named Robert V. Delaney senior vice president and chief administrative officer, Craig G. Matthews senior vice president and chief financial officer, and Helmut W. Peter senior vice president and chief engineer.

LEAD: An essay in The Journal of the American Medical Association describing a young physician's decision to inject a lethal dose of morphine into a terminally ill patient has drawn a flood of letters from doctors calling the action unethical and illegal.

LEAD: Surrogate Renee Roth, are you and the city's other surrogates paying attention? It's hard to imagine a stronger claim on it than the just-disclosed ''sting'' operation in which court representatives were secretly videotaped stealing cash and valuables from the apartments of people they thought were dead.

LEAD: A leading Japanese university plans to build the first high school for Japanese students in the United States on the campus of Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y.

LEAD: IT was almost exactly 20 years ago that the revue ''Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris'' opened in New York at the Village Gate and introduced a young generation of theatergoers to the dramatic songs of the Belgian singer and poet, who died 11 years later at age 49. Arriving when the antiwar movement was in full flower and Bob Dylan's folk-rock diatribes had brought a caustic realism to American pop, Brel's songs of love, death, war and the homeland also spoke to the moment, though in a different vocabulary.
LEAD: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, figures the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers owes him -$1,994.46 to be precise.

LEAD: Hold that memo! That stack of while-your-were-out telephone messages! That snippet from a draft of the State of the Union Message. Those who would shred their White House paperwork have to face the preservationists of the Reagan tenancy.
LEAD: Mounted in a prominent spot in the offices of one of Washington's major law-enforcement agencies is a blown-up formal photo of a man in his 30's, neatly dressed, hair parted in the middle.

LEAD: LIZZIE OLESKER plunged into the supposed trivialities of life and Alyson Pou rose above them in a program of performance art presented by the Danspace Project on Friday at St. Mark's Church. In ''House Work,'' Ms. Olesker conjured up three generations of women and paid a glance to a fourth, in the guise of a young sociology student engaged in a Marxist-feminist interpretation of housework.

LEAD: Iowa's largest newspaper, The Des Moines Register, endorsed Bob Dole and Paul Simon today in the state's Feb. 8 Presidential caucuses. The Register normally does not endorse candidates before the caucuses.

LEAD: SCHUBERT at age 15 reminds us of a legatee who, bursting with new-found wealth, puzzles over how to spend it. Thus Saturday's Schubertiade concert at the 92d Street Y - the third in this year's series of eight - overwhelmed us with Schubert's spirit even when the invention seemed squandered and misdirected.

LEAD: Little noticed in President Reagan's State of the Union Message was his endorsement of further trade help for the Caribbean Basin. Under 1983 legislation 22 Caribbean countries benefit from tariff-free access to the United States market.

LEAD: George H. Conrades, 48, is described by Myron Kerstetter, an analyst at Gartner Securities, as soft-spoken, personable and a tough manager. He will run the group that I.B.M. calls Personal Systems, embracing the company's personal computer divisions and its typewriters, displays and other low-end products that have previously been run under different corporate units.

LEAD: Carsten Vala, a student at Williams College, sun bathing on the campus in Williamstown, Mass., yesterday as the temperature rose above the 50 degree mark. Unseasonably warm weather prevailed over most of the East while frigid air sent the temperature below zero in parts of the Plains. (AP)

LEAD: The Illinois Legislature and Gov. James Thompson have set an inglorious example of what not to do about AIDS. Ignoring the advice of their own and other public health authorities, they enacted a law last year that compels everyone getting married in Illinois to be tested for the AIDS virus. The classic results of this stubborn folly would be ludicrous were it not for the nuisance and dismay inflicted on so many people.

LEAD: An illegal gambling ring that handled about $500 million in bets on sporting events - including $5 million on the Super Bowl - was the target of raids on seven apartments in Manhattan Saturday night that resulted in the arrests of 20 people, the police reported.

LEAD: JAMES P. CORCORAN is on a mission. To Mr. Corcoran, the Superintendent of Insurance of New York State, a key segment of the insurance industry lacks important rules, and as a result, the possibility of an insurance crisis looms.
LEAD: THE EXCELLENT EMPIRE. The Fall of Rome and the Triumph of the Church.

LEAD: FOR Mikhail Bulgakov, turning Russia's peasantry and proletariat into a ruling class was not unlike an operation turning a mongrel cur into a human being. You may dress him up to look the part, but initially his behavior will remain rude, crude and socially unacceptable.
LEAD: Volkswagen dealers are raising Cain in Washington because of reports that their imports from Brazil could be hit by trade sanctions President Reagan is now weighing against that country.

LEAD: Patrick A. Toole, 50, takes command of I.B.M. Technology Products, with responsibility for semiconductors and packaging for systems. Mr. Toole previously ran the Information Systems Technology Group.
LEAD: The reports of Phil Donahue's death at the hands of Oprah Winfrey have been grossly exaggerated.
LEAD: On rare occasions a player can usefully adopt at the bridge table a technique developed in a daily non-bridge occupation.
LEAD: In 10 minutes, the headmaster of Deerfield Academy would be breaking the news to many of his 560 boys. ''A few will hiss or boo,'' Robert E. Kaufmann predicted.

LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board has approved the proposed merger of the Shawmut Corporation of Boston and the Hartford National Corporation of Hartford. Shareholders of the two banks overwhelmingly approved the merger last November. The combined bank, to be called the Shawmut National Corporation, will have assets of about $25 billion.

LEAD: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor whose bid to take over the Singer Company has been accepted by company executives, said yesterday that he had obtained about $505 million in financing for his offer.

LEAD: BECAUSE every cast of a ballet inevitably brings something personal to it, ballet lovers constantly return to certain works just to see how they will look with a particular set of dancers. Recent performances of the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater featured some interesting interpretations.

LEAD: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. said that it had secured a $3.2 billion line of credit from a consortium of banks to finance its unsolicited bid for Farmers Group Inc. Last month Farmers, a Los Angeles-based insurance group, rejected a $4.2 billion bid from the British tobacco conglomerate. B.A.T., based in London, said Saturday that it would finance the deal - worth $60 a share - through debt and cash.

LEAD: Gifts of all sizes, large and small, from $1 to $110,000, continue to flow in to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The 76th annual appeal, which opened after Thanksgiving, runs through February.
LEAD: The drive by many of the nation's largest banks to expand through acquisitions may come to a near standstill for several years because of a proposal by the Federal Reserve Board.

LEAD: For more than a year, Vice President Bush has been groping for a way to prevent the Iran-contra matter, the Administration's worst foreign policy disaster, from becoming his own political albatross.

LEAD: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation joined forces yesterday with the Reichmann family of Canada to fight a bid for control of the large rail, oil and real estate company by the head of the Henley Group.

LEAD: The Federal Government is releasing five times as many Cubans from prison each month as it did before uprisings at two prisons last year focused attention on the Cubans' efforts to remain in this country, according to a report today in The Atlanta Journal and Constitution.
LEAD: The most exciting Super Bowl in history may have been played in the second quarter of today's game here.
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board's proposal to increase its bank capital requirements is based on the concept that certain loans and other assets held by banks carry a higher risk than others.

LEAD: An Episcopal Church official said yesterday that the decision of the Newark Diocese to bless homosexual couples ''has set off a lot of sparks'' and has placed the issue of homosexuality high on the church's agenda.

LEAD: THE age in which a pregnant woman was regarded as a delicate flower to be secluded until her baby was born passed long ago, but questions remain about just how active she should be. Increasingly, doctors are advising patients to exercise and stay fit if they wish; some even urge sedentary patients to begin an exercise program after becoming pregnant.
LEAD: Dr. Leon Menaker, a charter member of the Lincoln Institute for Psychotherapy in Manhattan, died of liver cancer Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

LEAD: While economists vainly looked for signs last week that the Federal Reserve had eased monetary policy, interest rates in the credit markets fell sharply on the assumption that the Fed would ratify those declines by pushing short-term interest rates lower.

LEAD: After meeting in this Alpine ski resort, the Prime Ministers of Greece and Turkey announced what they said was an important agreement today to help bring peace and cooperation to their traditionally hostile countries.

LEAD: Israelis and U.S. TV Israelis wince and debate as they watch American TV news film of the recent Palestinian demonstrations in the occupied territories. Page A8. Paying for Nuclear Energy The nation will pay as much as $100 billion for abandoned nuclear plants or those finished at excessive cost, utility experts say.

LEAD: This has always been a city that has defined itself by the ways it differs from other cities: a cool, managerial island of businesslike calm amid the ferment of urban America.
LEAD: HUNTING in the bitter cold of mid-winter does not necessarily require indifference to discomfort. In fact, such stoicism may be beyond most of us. But it can be both productive and instructive.
LEAD: At least four Palestinian youths were reported shot and wounded by Israeli soldiers today in continuing civil unrest, and a Jewish settler was severely burned by a gasoline bomb.

LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange's specialists failed to respond to nearly two-thirds of the trading messages they received through the intermarket trading system during the October market collapse, according to an internal report prepared by the exchange.

LEAD: American Brands Inc. announced yesterday that it would buy E-II Holdings Inc. in a deal valued at $2.7 billion, ending a tangled month-long takeover fight that began when E-II made an offer for American Brands.
LEAD: Neoax Inc. said yesterday that it had increased its offer for the IU International Corporation by $1 a share, to $20 a share, or about $548 million.

LEAD: By late Sunday afternoon, the streets of this city were eerily deserted as all those Washingtonians who had not been able to make their way to Jack Murphy Stadium in San Diego headed for television sets and Super Bowl parties.

LEAD: Thomas J. Conlin, a retired colonel in the Army, died Wednesday at the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in East Patchogue, L.I., after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Bellport, L.I.

LEAD: For years, The Wall Street Journal - with its huge circulation and staff and its soaring advertising revenues - has been the envy of newspaper publishers and editors throughout the land.

LEAD: FOR the second consecutive year, a hunting, fishing and outdoor sports show will be held at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. The Dodge National Sportsmen's Show will run Feb. 4-7.

LEAD: The Redskins' victory in Super Bowl XXII brought thousands of fans into the streets to celebrate tonight, some of them rabid followers and some of them foreigners with an attitude of pleased befuddlement.
LEAD: A 48-year-old man was fatally stabbed in a dispute with two younger men yesterday after he assaulted their mother on a Queens subway train, the police said.

LEAD: When the House considers new aid for the Nicaraguan contras this week, the package from the White House will carry a price tag of $36.25 million for four months, a figure the Administration argues is relatively modest.

LEAD: Georgi M. Malenkov, who was a leading political figure in the Soviet Union after the death of Stalin but who was ousted in a Kremlin power struggle and sent into political oblivion, died last month, a Soviet official said yesterday. He was 86 years old. Malenkov was Prime Minister for two years and, for a short time, head of the Communist Party.

LEAD: Union printers have overwhelmingly rejected a proposed contract with The Chicago Tribune and will continue their 31-month strike against the newspaper, union officials say. The contract would have brought lifetime annuities of $500 a month to most of the striking printers, but it also would have meant that only a small minority would have kept their jobs.

LEAD: Q. My house is heated by steam and one radiator makes a banging sound when it is on. What causes this, and can eliminate it? A. As the steam in a radiator dissipates, it condenses into water and runs through the radiator valve to the boiler for reheating. If the water cannot run out easily and meets the incoming steam, a knocking sound sometimes results.

AT first glance, the mid-1970's seems like the least inventive phase in the career of Andrzej Wajda, the brilliant, prolific Polish director. His trilogy from the 50's, ending with the masterly ''Ashes and Diamonds,'' assessed the emotional cost of World War II. In 1976, he would tear down Stalinist icons in ''Man of Marble.'' But earlier in the decade, films such as ''A Wedding'' and ''Land of Promise,'' both set in the 19th century, seemed to signal, if not a retreat from the political wars, at least an escape from the pressure of recent events. ''Land of Promise,'' the 1975 film that will have its first commercial run in New York at Cinema Village today and tomorrow, offers only a visual rest from contemporary battle. It has all the indirection you would expect of a defiant film maker whose work must pass Government censors and film boards (for years they rejected the idea for ''Man of Marble''), all the accomplishment of one adept at portraying the personal drama of history.

JAMES WOODS is more frequently seen eating on-camera than just about any other actor, but he's so edgy and thin that there's nothing voluptuous about this behavior. If anything, it's borderline rude. So are Mr. Woods's smoking and his wisecracking; so is virtually everything else he does. Combine this taunting manner with the fierce, obsessive dedication Mr. Woods brings to almost any role and you have the makings of a perfect Elmore Leonard character, which Mr. Woods is bound to play some day. In the meantime, he has arrived as the detective hero of ''Cop,'' based on James Ellroy's crime novel ''Blood on the Moon.'' In ''Cop,'' which opens today at Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters, Mr. Woods plays the extremely hard-boiled Detective Sgt. Lloyd Hopkins, who is led by the long arm of coincidence onto the trail of a mass murderer. The character is a reasonable embodiment of certain detective-movie conventions, but the plot leaves a lot to be desired, especially since it devotes no more than 30 seconds' thought to the killer's motive or his history.

LEAD: AARON COPLAND began his Symphony No. 3 in 1944 when the outcome of World War II was still in doubt, and finished it two years later in a time of national euphoria. Like other Copland works of the 1940's (''A Lincoln Portrait,'' for instance), it spoke in an optimistic, oratorical style that caught the upbeat mood of the times.

LEAD: Most of the important news stories journalists deal with are sad or dreary. People are killed, hijacked, swindled. Nations go to war, or spend their energies and fortunes preparing for it. Earthquakes, explosions, plagues. Everybody is always saying something nasty about somebody else. That's the way things are in the world - or that is how it comes out by the time we are finished slicing it up into words or pictures.

LEAD: IT'S a long way from a Harvard ethnobiologist's thoughtful account of his search for exotic Haitian medicinal potions to a film with the advertising slogan ''Don't bury me . . . I'm not dead!'' But in fact these two sides of ''The Serpent and the Rainbow'' aren't as different as they sound. Wade Davis's fascinating 1985 book is much more an adventure story than a scientific tract, and the film is the work of Wes Craven, whose horror credits (''A Nightmare on Elm Street,'' ''The Hills Have Eyes'') give an incomplete impression of his talents.

LEAD: Historians on a panel assigned to examine President Kurt Waldheim's wartime record said today that they might have to extend their work because of a disputed document said to have been discovered in Yugoslavia.
LEAD: Gary Hart's Presidential campaign has asked the Federal Election Commission for a ruling on whether it can use 1988 campaign contributions to repay debts from the 1984 race.

LEAD: A picture caption on Jan. 11 about the participation of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in a forum at Miami Shores, Fla., misidentified the sponsor. It was the Forum of North Dade, a nonpolitical organization, not the Democratic Party.

LEAD: For a moment on Wednesday, dreaded seriousness took the floor at the Alternative Museum. Stuart Dempster, the trombonist, wandered out from off stage, playing his plastic didjeridu -a long tube, derived from the Australian aboriginal wooden instrument of the same name, which, when blown into, makes buzzing sounds.
LEAD: In a reorganization intended to put pressure on its unions, the Texas Air Corporation said yesterday that it would take the profitable Eastern shuttle away from its Eastern Airlines subsidiary.

LEAD: Stepping up the level of confrontation in the final days of the Iowa caucuses, Senator Paul Simon's campaign manager today called on Representative Richard A. Gephardt to suspend television advertising here until his campaign had filed a report on his finances with the Federal Election Commission.
LEAD: It's an interesting proposition: They keep the records; the records help lenders decide if you're a good credit risk; and for $35 a year you can keep tabs on the record keepers.

LEAD: After a second day of heated discussion, a panel of specialists concluded today that payment to surrogate mothers for bearing a child should be prohibited when it involves a loss of parental rights.
LEAD: The Florida Legislature has approved a bill calling for major changes in medical malpractice laws, including a limit on the amount of money that may be awarded in malpractice lawsuits.

LEAD: Among National Basketball Association coaches, Gene Shue stands fourth in career victories with 767, only 171 behind the 938 of the leader, Red Auerbach. But in defeats, Shue heads the list. And on Thursday night in Los Angeles he became the first N.B.A. coach to lose 800 games when his Clippers fell to the Lakers, 117-86.

LEAD: United States District Court Judge Charles L. Brieant is expected to rule early next week on whether Texaco Inc. may continue mailing its bankruptcy reorganization plan to shareholders. Judge Brieant heard arguments from shareholders opposed to the plan but has made no decision on their request to halt the mailing, which began on Wednesday.

LEAD: The Horn & Hardart Company, based in Las Vegas, Nev., said that it had agreed to acquire International King's Table Inc., which operates King's Table Buffet restaurants in California, Oregon, Washington and other Western states. Horn & Hardart, which already owns 19.9 percent of King's Table, will make a cash offer to purchase a minimum of 31.1 percent and up to all common shares oustanding for $20.25 in cash, or a total indicated price of $58.7 million.

LEAD: Overkill is our style. ''Everything to excess,'' we reply to the Athenians' ''Everything in moderation.'' The spirit of the day, until Wall Street turned into Sucker's Alley, was expressed in the Yuppie's Creed: ''I want it all, and I want it now.''

LEAD: Consumer debt rose by $4.5 billion in December, the biggest monthly gain in three months, the Federal Reserve said yesterday. The December increase placed total consumer debt at $612.57 billion, up 6 percent from the end of 1986.

LEAD: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military ruler of Panama, in effect sold his government to drug traffickers for millions of dollars in bribes and turned Panama into a capital of international cocaine smuggling, the Justice Department charged in two indictments made public today.

LEAD: After months of painful anonymity, Representative Richard A. Gephardt is beginning to show the telltale sign that proves he considers himself a front-runner. He is denying that he is ahead in next Monday's Iowa Democratic Presidential caucuses.

LEAD: About 2,000 residents, law-enforcement officials and politicians gathered this evening to rally against the possible parole of a man convicted of killing two police officers in 1963. About 30 police cars from municipalities throughout Essex and Bergen Counties lined the street in front of the municipal complex.

LEAD: President Reagan mocked Congress recently for tucking dozens of frivolous expenditures into the catch-all 1988 budget bills. Shortly he will send back all the items that he says he would cross out if he had a line-item veto, and ask that they be canceled. That, he suggests, will test whether Congress really thinks the Government should subsidize such things as cranberry, crawfish and wildflower research.

The principals are David Carroll and Philip Casnoff as Soviet and American chess masters and Judy Kuhn as the woman in love first with the Russian and then with the American.

LEAD: Between the eighth and ninth rounds of Marlon Starling's title defense against Fujio Ozaki tonight, Starling's promoter, Cedric Kushner, stepped out of the Convention Center crowd and yelled at the champion.

LEAD: Adults who want to select the best in children's books may refer to ''Children's Books 1987: 100 Books for Reading and Sharing,'' a list available at branches of the New York Public Library. The guide, published annually since 1911 by the library's Office of Children's Services, costs $2 and cites books that are recommended by children's libraries.

LEAD: As the state and the Long Island Lighting Company intensify talks to end their battle over the Shoreham nuclear power plant, Lilco's opponents on the Island are beginning to voice doubts that a negotiated settlement will be politically acceptable.

LEAD: The clarinet explains Mozart as well as any other instrument. LEAD: As the 46-year-old mother of a healthy 6-month-old daughter (and a 19-year-old son), I read Melvin Konner's article ''Childbearing and Age'' with considerable interest (Body and Mind, Dec. 27). While I do not dispute the reality of his statistics on the decreasing chances of conception with advancing age, it must be said that, despite atrophying organs and waning hormonal levels, the life force can be more generous to older women than mere statistics might lead us to believe.

LEAD: MAINSTREAM jazz - now essentially bebop - may be the most deceptive of all the kinds of music played under the name of jazz. LEAD: John Kolius has needed the time to slow down. Little has been heard in the last year from the skipper who carried the New York Yacht Club's banner to Australia for the 1986-87 America's Cup series.
