East Islip $178,000 127 Marilyn Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, new eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,500.
LEAD: Hundreds of police officers and soldiers used tear gas to disperse mourners and marching students at the funeral of a black youth leader today.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:
LEAD: A chart last Sunday with an article on the Nova Pharmaceutical Corporation misidentified the market where the company's stock is traded. The shares are traded over-the-counter.

LEAD: WHEN the Olympic athletes from 57 nations parade Saturday during the opening ceremony of the 15th Winter Games, one of the Canadian team members will be Andy Moog, the same Andy Moog who was an established goaltender for the Edmonton Oilers of the National Hockey League. And more than any other athlete in Calgary, he will be taking the first step to Olympic reality.

LEAD: THE presentation of dances-in-progress is always a tricky business. Unfinished, they defy reasonable critical analysis, and most tend to exist in a kind of limbo between inspiration and execution. The three pieces presented by the Jose Limon Dance Company in a gala showcase on Thursday at the Joyce Theater were no exception.

LEAD: A measure that has been signed into law by President Reagan gives Alaska's 85,000 Eskimos, Indians and Aleuts a fighting chance to keep native lands and other wealth in native hands, several of their leaders say.

LEAD: THE CARDINAL Starring Tom Tryon (in photo), Romy Schneider, Carol Lynley, Jill Haworth, Ossie Davis, John Huston, Burgess Meredith, Robert Morse, Raf Vallone, Josef Meinrad. Produced and directed by Otto Preminger. 1963. Video Treasures. 175 minutes. $9.98.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Jennifer Louise Eastwick and David Lawrence Allen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Allen of Westbury, L.I., plan to marry in June, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Warren W. Eastwick of Pittstown, N.Y., and Ludlow, Vt., have announced.

LEAD: WHEN Procter & Gamble decided five years ago to build a manufacturing plant, the plans included so much electronic monitoring equipment that executives at headquarters, 500 miles away, would have been able to check the plant's exact output at any time.
LEAD: Supplies and Services For the Wedding

LEAD: The indictment of Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, in the United States on drug charges has stiffened his resistance and makes the likelihood of his peaceful departure from power more remote, Panamanian civilians, military officers and foreign diplomats say.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo this week stepped up his campaign against the salaries at public authorities, calling them excessive and demanding that the authorities bring them under control.

LEAD: Clinton, Conn. $155,000 12 Evergreen Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; wall-to-wall carpeting, living-room fireplace; taxes $1,258. Guilford, Conn. $197,500 1821 Little Meadows Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; skylights, solar water heat, 2.8 acres, taxes $1,965.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Allan Bloom's book is a pretentious account of his own nostalgia for the days when white-male authority went unquestioned. Such yearnings are the standard litany of extreme conservatism.

LEAD: An Amtrak train carrying 190 passengers ran a red signal and collided with a Burlington Northern freight Thursday, slightly injuring 13 people, the authorities said. The accident occurred about 15 minutes after the passenger train had left Omaha for Chicago.

LEAD: ANN CARLSON had people dance like - and with - animals on Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Her ''Animals'' was an eloquent five-part work that examined differences between people and animals, yet affirmed the kinship of all beings.
LEAD: Laura Louise Foster, a botanical artist, died last Sunday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital after a brief illness. She was 70 years old and lived in Falls Village, Conn.

LEAD: In an unusually caustic attack on some members of the State Legislature, Mayor Koch yesterday released a barrage of statistics that he said showed how the city would be hurt by a state proposal to supplement the pensions of retired city and state workers.
LEAD: A former Common Pleas Court judge was convicted today of one of two Federal extortion counts. He is the third Philadelphia judge convicted of corruption in six months.

LEAD: The International Boxing Federation has decided to limit today's title fight in England between the middleweight champion, Frank Tate, and Tony Sibson to 12 rounds instead of the 15 the I.B.F. ususally insists on for a championship fight. In doing so, the I.B.F. appeared to be bowing to the safety concerns of British boxing authorities, who refused to sanction the fight at 15 rounds and called on the I.B.F.

LEAD: I read with interest James Sterngold's article ''Too Far, Too Fast'' (Jan. 10), about John Gutfreund, chairman and chief executive of Salomon Brothers. Though I have had a minimal business relationship with Salomon Brothers in the last 10 years, my experience requires that I comment on the article.

LEAD: Carolyn Marree Conant and Michael Wyatt Hiley, a son of Mrs. Robert Langford of Morristown, N.J., and David B. Hiley of Katonah, N.Y., plan to marry in July, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Martin C. Conant of New Providence, N.J., have announced.

LEAD: His name appears, at one moment, to be Jean Kippelstein - already a sign of a mixed identity - even though his classmates knew him as Jean Bonnet, teasing him for being a ''bonnet de nuit,'' a nightcap. The historical fact is that he was neither Kippelstein nor Bonnet. His real name was Hans Helmut Michel, and he was born in Frankfurt, Germany, on June 6, 1930.

LEAD: Carrick DeHart scored 16 points in a second-half run today as the University of California-Santa Barbara erased an 11-point deficit and upset No. 2 Nevada-Las Vegas, 71-66. It was the second time this year the unranked Gauchos had upset their Pacific Coast Athletic Association rivals.

LEAD: It was nice to see our hero, Olympian skier Pirmin Zurbriggen, in The New York Times Magazine (''On the Edge of Greatness,'' by Trip Gabriel, Dec. 27). But what does Mr. Gabriel mean by calling him a ''Goody Two-shoes'' or a ''lollipop''? What is wrong with being shy, religious and modest? Pirmin Zurbriggen does not have to tell anyone he's good.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 7 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.50.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, an evil wizard and a mouse. 2 2 OUTBREAK, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $4.95.) Tracking down a deadly disease that ophthalmologists pass on to their patients.

LEAD: THE campus of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., is studded with buildings named for members of Congress who channeled billions of dollars into it. Among them is the Clinical Center, a 540-bed research hospital, named for Warren G. Magnuson, a Democratic Senator from Washington for more than three decades.

LEAD: WHEN the Cuomo Administration decided last week to let New York City give clean needles to drug addicts, it may have seemed like a bold new step to stem the spread of AIDS. But in the days that followed, the experimental program drew criticism and questions from a wide range of drug abuse experts who said the project will be plagued by problems.

LEAD: THE New Jersey Supreme Court last week undid most of the decision that a lower court judge reached in the case of Baby M, and it has declared that, contract or no contract, the woman who gave birth to her is her legal mother. But the new decision leaves Baby M, now Melissa Elizabeth Stern, where the earlier one did - with her biological father.

LEAD: FEW subjects are more ripe for satire than the so-called ''new age'' movement with its assorted gurus, nuts and charlatans all spouting different brands of transcendental mumbo jumbo. Jeff and Julie Olmsted, the songwriter-performers who created ''Jeff and Jewel's New Age Blues Revue,'' which plays at Don't Tell Mama on Thursdays through the end of the month, have done their homework in researching a field that encompasses phenomena as different as Werner Erhard's EST training seminars and Shirley MacLaine's thoughts on reincarnation.
LEAD: A report last Sunday about the engagement of Julia McKay van Roden to Andrew Howard Lerman misidentified Miss van Roden's mother. She is Amy McKay Biddle.

LEAD: Thanks to six years of a booming economy, Governor Kean has been able to initiate a number of programs in education, environmental cleanup and trasportation, and in his latest budget proposal last week he continued to target new spending in those areas.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The uses of MOzart are manifold. For example, last week I discovered that the Haffner Serenade is good for frayed nerves while you're waiting to be pulled out of a ditch. No cause for alarm - it's all part of winter driving in the Berkshires, but it explains why, under certain conditions, a good sound system in a car gives as much comfort as a good heater.

LEAD: GOD'S WATER CARRIERS. By Manes Sperber. Translated by Joachim Neugroschel. Foreword by Elie Wiesel. (Holmes & Meier, $24.50.) In ''God's Water Carriers,'' Manes Sperber (1905-84) describes a time during his youth when, questioning God and beginning a lifelong debate over his faith, he climbed a barn roof in his shtetl in Poland to hurl stones into space, in the hope of challenging the God he was certain waited behind the ''trapdoor'' in the sky.
LEAD: General Noriega forestalled American retaliation for years by playing Federal agencies off against one another and against other countries, American officials said.

LEAD: CHARLES KILLIAN slept last month in a friend's abandoned car behind an auto parts store on Route 25A in Rocky Point. It had no heat and offered little protection from the bitter cold. But until he found work, he said, it would have to do.
LEAD: Back in the 60's, Woody Her-man was asked if the big bands would ever come back. His answer was blunt: ''No.''

LEAD: Convent Station $312,000 13 Weathervane Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old contemporary; porch, central air-conditioning, 2-car attached garage; taxes $3,087. South Orange $278,000 279 Beech Spring Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 44-year-old Tudor; fireplace, den, eat-in kitchen; taxes $4,318.

LEAD: Of all the proposed pinches in Mayor Koch's gloomy spending plan for the next fiscal year, the one that he and other New Yorkers may feel the most, at least psychologically, is his decision not to hire nearly 2,000 police officers.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The marriage of Maureen Elizabeth Ferguson, a daughter of Helen E. Ferguson of New York and the late Charles A. Ferguson, to Thomas Daniel Steiner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. S. Daniel Steiner of Glen Arbor, Mich., and Longboat Key, Fla., took place yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Stockbridge, Mass.

LEAD: A Washington article by The Associated Press on Jan. 24 about oil production at Prudhoe Bay in Alaska reported charges by three environmental groups that the tundra there was being polluted. The article said the American Petroleum Institute had declined to comment until it could see the report from the environmental groups.

LEAD: TO fill the gap between two musical hits - ''42d Street,'' which recently closed an extended engagement, and ''La Cage aux Folles,'' next month's attraction - ''The Student Prince'' has been lugged into the Darien Dinner Theater for a spell.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: TAMING volatility in the stock market appears to be the order of the day.
LEAD: Mike Vreeswyk scored 21 points for Temple today as the Owls defeated Rutgers, 84-53. The Scarlet Knights set a school record by losing their 13th consecutive game.

LEAD: THE circle around Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega tightened last week, but Panama's military leader gave no indication that he is yet willing to relinquish control of his country. On Thursday, United States grand juries in Miami and Tampa, Fla., indicted General Noriega and 15 other people on charges of drug trafficking and racketeering.

LEAD: Q. I live in a new town house condominium that has an outdoor wood deck made of pressure-treated 2-by-4's. The decking has turned green with mildew, and the builder has suggested using a K2 spot remover to clean it. Is this the way to correct the problem?
LEAD: Anthony M. Frank, a successful California executive who came to the United States as a child when his parents fled Nazi Germany, figures he owes America something.
LEAD: THE TRUE GEN An Intimate Portrait of Ernest Hemingway by Those Who Knew Him. By Denis Brian. Illustrated. 356 pp. New York: Grove Press. $19.95.

LEAD: I'VE BEEN MEETING FORMER students of mine lately: one on the A train, one in Zabar's, another at a street fair. They are shy about it at first - scrutinizing me, trying to find the someone they knew behind the years, the changes. ''You're Professor Lyons, aren't you?'' one asked, and I stuttered a bit, because the last time this happened, I said ''I was,'' meaning ''without the title now'' though I am still Lyons.
LEAD: ''WE DO make quite a team,'' the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. remarks to Malcolm X at the end of a hypothetical meeting in a Harlem hotel room.

LEAD: THE first simple chords of Beethoven's ''Les Adieux'' Sonata at Alice Tully Hall Friday night let us know about Thomas Lorango's intelligence and sympathy for the piano literature. Each voice had its own life and each was joined together by Mr. Lorango's natural feel for the tensions of movement. This sensitive, almost private, feeling for music carried over into the finale of Schumann's Fantasy and the three Intermezzos from Brahms's Opus 119.

LEAD: ''Something had to snap. If it didn't happen in October, it would have happened soon thereafter. The immediate cause of the break was incidental.'' - Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, in Congressional testimony about regulating the markets.

LEAD: A JOKE around this capital city has President Joaquim A. Chissano, Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan out for a sightseeing drive in Washington. President Reagan instructs the driver to keep turning right. Seeing that the car is going in circles, Mr. Gorbachev takes over. He tells the driver to keep turning left.

LEAD: Senator Daniel K. Inouye apparently is a sensitive kind of guy. The Hawaii Democrat said last week that he was ''hurt and angered'' when critics accused him of ''sneaking'' a measure through Congress that channeled $8 million to a campaign contributor's pet project. The $8 million, attached to a huge spending bill that was rushed through Congress in December, was to support the Jewish education of North African refugees in France.

LEAD: LOVE songs are normally an inevitable part of a cabaret singer's repertory, but Marlene Ver Planck has built her entire program at Dannys' Skylight Room (346 West 46th Street) on songs that trace the ups and downs of a love affair.

LEAD: Whoever said they were enslaved? Shed no tears over these freewheeling, free-spending, free-spirited guys. They never had it so good. Some of their salaries practically rivaled the Treasury balance. LARRY L. KUNTZ Brooklyn

LEAD: Carol Vogel states that Mrs. Gutfreund's ''style now is to hold Sunday night suppers offering a Texan menu of fried chicken and monkey bread.'' Since when has fried chicken and monkey bread, of all things, been considered ''Texan''? THE REV. DAVID H. MARION-DAVIS Houston

LEAD: Q. I live in a new town house condominium that has an outdoor wood deck made of pressure-treated 2-by-4's. The decking has turned green with mildew, and the builder has suggested using a K2 spot remover to clean it. Is this the way to correct the problem?

LEAD: Europeans took a long time assimilating their discovery of the New World. It was almost a century before artists, in representing the New World, broke away from Eurocentric preconceptions and classical or medieval styles. Initial attempts at realism may not have been great art, but they left a revealing historical record of one civilization's encounter with another.

LEAD: LAST spring the United States Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the Indiana Control Share Acquistion Statute, which limits company takeover activity in that state. This statute requires certain hostile bidders to obtain the approval of the disinterested stockholders - the bidder or management - in order for the takeover bidder's shares to have voting power.

LEAD: In his first meeting with a North Korean official since North Korea announced it would not participate in the 1988 Seoul Summer Olympics unless it is a co-host, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, warned that time was growing short for North Korea to participate in any form.

LEAD: My congratulations to James Sterngold for having written the article about John Gutfreund with a straight face. Here we have a sensitive report of the philosophical self-discoveries of an imposing man who denies himself millions of bonus dollars and only draws a million; who acknowledges disastrous misjudgments while promising to get it right next time; who enjoys the trust of the

LEAD: ONCE again, Edwin Meese 3d is under fire. And once again, Washington is wondering how long the Attorney General, the nation's highest law enforcement officer, can keep on surmounting accusations of impropriety and misjudgment.

LEAD: WAL-MART STORES, the nation's third-largest retail chain, held a major voter registration drive in late January in its 650 stores in 12 of the Southern states that will be participating in the March 8 ''Super Tuesday'' Presidential primary. The remainder of the chain's 1,114 outlets in the Southwest and Midwest will hold voter registration campaigns in September, in time to enable new registrants to vote in the November

LEAD: Last Sunday, in his essay ''Can TV Be Taken Seriously?'', John J. O'Connor neglected to mention that the British-made ''South Bank Show,'' currently being saluted in the Museum of Broadcasting's ''New York World Television Festival,'' is also available on the Bravo cable service; it is presenting the cultural series on Thursday evenings at 10.

LEAD: LAST week, the Reagan Administration published its new regulations ending Federal funds for any family-planning clinic that counsels women about abortions or refers them to abortion providers. But whether the rules will ever be enforced remains very much in question.
LEAD: WOMANSWORD What Japanese Words Say About Women. By Kittredge Cherry. Illustrated. 151 pp. New York: Kodansha International. Paper, $13.95.

LEAD: The engagement of Christine Robertson Leness to David Lawton Boudreau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Boudreau of Plymouth, Minn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John G. Leness of New York and Quogue, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AFTER 10 years of applying the spurs to reluctant bureaucrats, a horse-loving, horse-owning schoolteacher from Oakland in Bergen County has won the right to build a world-class horse-show arena for New Jersey.

LEAD: BATTERED by foreign gains in manufacturing and high technology, American companies are increasingly favoring cooperation over competition, as they band together in order to survive. Taking a hint from the Japanese, endangered industries are forming research consortiums to pool limited supplies of talent, money and managerial skill.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Catherine Baum Cox and Daniel Jacob Blumenthal, a son of Mrs. Albert H. Blumenthal of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Blumenthal, plan to marry in the fall, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Alvin E. Cox of Newport News, Va., have announced.

LEAD: In the middle of an analytical article on John Gutfreund, you inserted a full page on his wife, Susan, and her ''high living.'' What in the world has her living style to do with the way her husband runs Salomon? Wasn't the Gutfreund story designed to give us insights into the excesses of Wall Street, not Givenchy?

LEAD: 1919: The Year Our World Began. By William K. Klingaman. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $27.95.) The year 1919, by any yardstick, was an eventful one, and the historian William K. Klingaman persuasively demonstrates that it began with hope, ended in despair and shaped the 20th century. Consider these highlights: With hostilities ended in the Great War, Woodrow Wilson spends several months in Paris working on a treaty; by year's end, his dream of a League of Nations is shattered.

LEAD: A SALES program is under way in the Towers on the Park condominium at the northwest corner of Central Park, at the edge of Harlem, and it is demonstrating a new concept in producing high-rise housing with government assistance for people of moderate to middle income.
LEAD: ''AT Equity Library Theater, the actor is our focus,'' declared George Wojtasik, the theater's producing director.

LEAD: Renee Yvette Chenault, a television moderator and a producer for the New Jersey Network, a group of four PBS stations, and Michael Thaddeus Crawford, a copy editor at The Wall Street Journal, plan to be married March 19. Their engagement has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs.

LEAD: TAKING a giant step away from the traditional theatrical fare it produces so well, Long Island Stage is presenting John Wallowitch and Bertram Ross in a cabaret act called ''Back on the Town.'' This elegant and intimate show is a sophisticated musical routine during which these two urbane and talented men woo their audience with renditions of such rarely heard delights as Irving Berling's ''Cohen Owes Me $97.

LEAD: Thomas Babbitt Lamb, an inventor and industrial designer, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the Carolton Manor convalescent home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 91 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

LEAD: The engagement of Marye Esther Buckley to John Patrick Moran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. The couple plan to marry in

LEAD: The major artistic creation of the Philippines today is a passion play in which a simple widow challenges a dictator she believes killed her husband, and leads her nation to freedom. In its second act, the widow, as president, faces down a series of violent challenges, clinging perilously to power as the forces of darkness struggle to reassert themselves.

LEAD: 'WALLENBERG AT 75' Harvey Rosenfeld, the author of ''Raoul Wallenberg: Angel of Rescue,'' will give a talk in Hartford tomorrow about the Swedish businessman who ran an underground from Germany to England during World War II and saved many Jews from the Holocaust, The talk is titled ''Raoul Wallenberg at 75: The Unresolved Question.

LEAD: FRANTIC, unpredictable, turbulent and - out of nowhere - harmonious, Cecil Taylor's music mirrors urban life in all its hyperactive sprawl. The pianist brought a new quintet to a packed Knitting Factory Thursday through last night; his Bosendorfer concert grand was squeezed onto the tiny stage along with Thurman Barker's drums and vibraphone and William Parker's bass.

LEAD: Scene from Juvenile Awareness Program at East Jersey State Prison, which brings in juvenile deliquents to see and hear inmates describe, in harsh, often abusive language, life behind bars. Such life is producing tensions at Bergen County's 25-year-old Jail Annex, top. 'Scared Straight' article, Page 18.

LEAD: THIS will be another week of competing events. Today alone, there is a dance program at 2 P.M., a violin recital at 2:30, five solo or chamber concerts at 3 and seven recitals with 4 o'clock starts.
LEAD: A PICKUP truck belonging to a unit owner is continually parked in a New Jersey condominium parking lot in violation of house rules that permit only passenger cars.

LEAD: THE PROBLEM HAS ALWAYS been what to do with them. One Minnesota plant turns them into a re-usable rubber compound. And, of course, they make good rope swings. There are an estimated 2 billion discarded tires in this country; about 40 million - the world's largest pile (above) - are near Westley, Calif.

LEAD: President Reagan lost a crucial funding vote last Wednesday on the contra war. Only a vote was lost, not a country. Yet the White House is sure to blame Congress if the Sandinistas fail to live up to the Central American peace plan. But it is Mr. Reagan, not Congress, who is responsible for the breakdown of U.S.

LEAD: At St. James's Episcopal Church in Manhattan yesterday, Barbara Suzanne Christman, the daughter of Clyde Salle Christman and Suzanne Carter Christman of Yakima, Wash., was married to William Preston Hutchings. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. H. Ford Hutchings of Tucker's Town, Bermuda, and New York.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: America's urban centers are hemorrhaging jobs, while ''outer cities'' are flourishing in places like White Plains, Boston's Route 128 corridor or the area around Chicago's O'Hare Airport. In some such places, jobs now go begging, even while a few miles away, inner-city residents beg for jobs.

LEAD: Seymour Simon's series of children's books on the planets, the sun and the stars reminds you of the old joke about childhood being too good to be wasted on kids. What do these books lack that a good adult book should have? The latest, URANUS (Morrow Junior Books, $12.95. Ages 4 to 8), like its companions, is beautiful, evocative, neat, simple, informative.
LEAD: ' Of course, we can't return their lives, but this is a very noble deed. '

LEAD: Though best known in his lifetime for having invented an invaluable antiseptic, Dr. Albert C. Barnes (1872-1951) had an auxiliary reputation as a major art collector and the founder of a private educational facility in the suburbs of Philadelphia. In its turn, that facility had also a double reputation.

LEAD: INSTALLING a prefabricated disappearing stairway as an attic entrance is worth considering if a larger or more convenient opening is needed. The task is simple for two people (an assistant is necessary to help maneuver the staircase), provided that the opening for the stairway can be cut so that its long sides are parallel with the existing ceiling joists, and that the roof is supported by rafters, not trusses.
LEAD: REMEMBER when your mother warned you to be careful what you wished for because you just might get it?

LEAD: Carmen Polo de Franco, the Spanish dictator's widow, who was considered a significant influence on some of the repressive policies of his 36-year rule, died today in her Madrid apartment. She was 87 years old.

LEAD: WHAT is it that separates the ''pros'' from the amateurs in photography? To many minds, it's a matter of equipment. Professional photographers, according to this theory, have access to a special breed of cameras, lenses, flash units and the like. Using pro-level equipment, they are able to take pro-level pictures.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump has built a business empire on his name. He calls his company the Trump Organization. Its home is Trump Tower. His fanciest condominium project bears the name Trump Parc. He owns casinos in Atlantic City called Trump Plaza and Trump's Castle.

LEAD: The Soviet Union, by virtue of its traditional pre-eminence in international hockey rather than its recent performances, remains the favorite to capture the gold medal. However, the development of competitive teams by the rest of the Olympic contingent has rendered the Russians vulnerable to more challengers than ever before.

LEAD: THE Philharmonia Virtuosi took January off, but February finds the ensemble back in concert action on this and the following two Sundays. Today at 3 P.M., Cyprien Katsaris is the featured soloist at the State University of New York at Purchase, with the brilliant French pianist tackling two great concertos, the Liszt A major and Beethoven's Third.

LEAD: A state transportation official has promised to speed up repair plans for a stretch of road that accounted for almost half the car accidents and injuries last year on the Whitestone Expressway in Queens.

Kellie of Brooklyn, have announced.

LEAD: Russell Baker's amusing essay ''High-Flying Confusion'' (Sunday Observer, Jan. 10), on how journalists confess error, recalls an anecdote told about John Foster Dulles, a prominent lawyer who was Secretary of State in the Eisenhower Administration. Mr. Dulles was once asked whether he had ever been wrong.

LEAD: Life is too short, you realize after dropping in on ''Dance on Film, Dancin' in the Movies,'' a wonderfully eclectic series that continues at Film Forum 2 through Feb. l8. Does anybody nowadays have time to sample everything from big-band musicals to ''The Red Shoes,'' Merce Cunningham and the Bolshoi?
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A 55-YEAR-OLD Yonkers landmark, the Herald Statesman Building on Larkin Plaza, is being renovated into offices for two major tenants who are expected to bolster the local economy.
LEAD: Even the most loyal St. John's fan should have been able to predict this one.

LEAD: WINTERS' TALES: Stories and Observations for the Unusual. By Jonathan Winters. (Random House, $13.95.) Included in the publicity material sent to reviewers along with ''Winters' Tales'' is a quotation from Jonathan Winters's most famous fan. ''Jonathan showed me,'' Robin Williams writes, ''that anything is possible - one of the few people able to make me laugh from my soul.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James K. Breene Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Warren, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Julie Brodie Breene to William Townsend Ziebold Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ziebold of Charleston, W.Va., and Hot Springs, Va. The couple plan to marry in September.

LEAD: An August wedding is planned by Wendy Joy Engel and Adam Seth Cohen, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Engel of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., have announced. Mr. Cohen is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Cohen of Hewlett Harbor.

LEAD: With a softened ideology and assertions of battlefield prowess, Iran's principal exiled opposition movement, crushed during the Islamic revolution, is seeking to project itself as a new force in this region's conflicts.

LEAD: Mr.and Mrs. Harold S Share of Hudson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Vicki Ellen Share, to Micahel Eric Fleiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel M. Fleiss of Plainview, L.I. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: Squeeze on Water

LEAD: Susan Spangler Hart and Matthew Paul Smith, teachers at the Collegiate School, plan to be married March 19. The Rev. and Mrs. Sinclair Danforth Hart of Williamstown, Mass., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Smith of Brooklyn. Miss Hart graduated from Amherst College.

LEAD: A Sports of The Times column last Sunday about the old boy network in professional football gave an incorrect figure for the number of assistant coaches in the National Football League. There are 282, of whom 41 are black.
LEAD: BOATERS on Long Island Sound and its major estuaries are probably going to find the Coast Guard far less accessible next summer as a result of Congressional budget cuts.

LEAD: Congressional action to preserve a free market is now more necessary than ever, since Delaware, the nation's second-smallest state, adopted legislation to sharply restrict contested mergers. The measure, signed by Delaware's Governor last week, will affect companies around the country.

LEAD: Administrators and teachers in New York City's day-care centers are leaving their jobs for positions with higher salaries and better working conditions and the quality of care at the centers is suffering, according to participants in a symposium yesterday in Manhattan.

LEAD: Allan Bloom gave quite a revealing interview to James Atlas - particularly when he likened himself to a rock star in his excitement over his success as an author (''Chicago's Grumpy Guru,'' Jan. 3). ''It's like being declared . . . a rock star. All this energy passing through you. . . '' Could it be that this is how Mick Jagger feels when he is ''tarting it up on stage.

LEAD: WHILE residents of the east side of Yonkers protest a Federal Court order to build 200 low-income housing units on the mainly white side of town, residents of the west side are fighting a condominium development proposed for their neighborhood because they say it would displace low-income minority families.

LEAD: AS I glided through Bellport last fall on my bike, I got a glimpse of a white frame 19th-century charmer. It was called the Old Inlet Inn. Was this a find? Would the food live up to the exterior charm?

LEAD: With the weather outside somewhat frosty, a welcome warning trend has settled into several theaters. ''Distant Harmony,'' at the Carnegie Hall Cinema (Seventh Avenue at 57th Street), gives us Luciano Pavarotti conquering and being conquered by China, during his 1986 tour with the cast of ''La Boheme.

LEAD: Two of New York City's largest teaching hospitals - Beth Israel Medical Center and New York Hospital -plan to expand their treatment of AIDS patients as part of a major expansion of hospital-based AIDS care this year.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene T. Lyons of Arlington, Va., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Marie Lyons, to Robert Patrick Callahan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Callahan Jr. of Norfolk, Va. The couple plan to marry in April.

LEAD: Barclay Plager, a former National Hockey League defenseman for the St. Louis Blues who later coached the team, died of brain cancer today. He was 46 years old and was an assistant coach with the Blues at the time of his death.
LEAD: Federal prosecutors have detailed the kickbacks and coverups that were conceived and directed over 16 years by Lee Alexander, the former Mayor of Syracuse.

LEAD: The engagement of Dr. Carolyn Mary Scerbo to Dr. William George Kaelin Jr., a son of Nancy P. Kaelin and Mr. Kaelin, both of Fairfield, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Scerbo of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: The White House today criticized Senate Democratic leaders for threatening to delay approval of the new Soviet-American treaty banning ground-launched medium- and shorter-range missiles after negotiations between the Senators and the Administration on a key issue appeared to collapse Friday.
LEAD: A producer has testified that Victor Lasky, a conservative author, was portrayed fairly in her ABC News television documentary on the McCarthy era.

LEAD: Iowa's Democratic chairman today defended her party's complicated Presidential caucus process and criticized news organizations that she said would report inaccurate results Monday night in a search for simplicity.
LEAD: Cliff Robinson scored 16 points and blocked 9 shots to lead Connecticut over Georgetown tonight, 66-59.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William Munoz of Freehold, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Ann Munoz, to Dr. Andrew James Lerrick, a son of Mrs. Robert Lerrick of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Dr. Lerrick. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, today called the move by the players to decertify their union as their bargaining agent ''a strategem'' to step up pressure on the owners.

LEAD: Bravo to those quoted in the article ''Incest Victims Get Sympathy but Little Help'' [ Jan. 10 ] for having the courage to say what so many clinicians feel about our system of helping, be it legal or institutional. The system does not work.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Harold K. Wolfson of New York and White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter Dale Honey Wolfson to Dr. William M. Reiff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Reiff of Chicago. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Jan. 17 article ''Animal Rights Group Assails Egg Farm'' omits a crucial fact about factory farming: Since the hens that are crammed together in tiny cages could easily succumb to infectious illness, their feed is heavily dosed with antibiotics.
LEAD: Prof. Vernon McClean's Opinion Page article on racism in language (Jan. 24) seems peculiarly misdirected. It also makes some arguments based on etymological errors.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AN EXPANSIVE GREEN-house that overlooks Manhattan in Alfred Hitchcock's 1948 movie ''Rope'' so inspired Jon Weiser, president of Charivari Men's, that he obtained a production still to show Shigeru Uchida, the Japan-based interior designer who had begun to renovate Weiser's new apartment. To Uchida, the views were intriguing and the space vast by Japanese standards.

LEAD: Norman W. Stewart and Dr. Ann Roberts Stewart of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Hilton Head Island, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cecily Ann Stewart to Dr. James Frederick Whiting, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick D. Whiting of Binghamton, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in June.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Summer Night Starring Mariangela Melato and Michele Placido. Directed by Lina Wertmuller. 1983. International Video Entertainment. 94 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.

Manigat, the new President of Haiti, believes he is going to have a chance to test his ideas of national development. But first, Mr. Manigat, who is to be inaugurated today, must ease the resentment over the blatantly rigged Jan.
LEAD: My response to the question - Are free agents free again in baseball? - is: Is anyone free? MICHAEL HASDAY Scarsdale, N.Y.

LEAD: THE United States Postal Service is in the midst of issuing seven commemorative stamps in two weeks. Leading the way is a block of four that depicts domestic cats, two statehood issues and the 11th in the Black Heritage series.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. David L. Marshall of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lea Marshall to Douglas Bavier Strong, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Strong Jr. of Fairport, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in October.

LEAD: THE Office of Management and Budget has provoked debate in the scientific community by suggesting that the laboratories of the National Institutes of Health be converted to a private research center, financed by government, industry and foundations.

LEAD: The West Germans' faith in nuclear energy, never too strong and even shakier since the Chernobyl disaster, has been further battered in recent weeks by a barrage of revelations about embezzlement, bribery and illegal shipments of nuclear wastes in the industry.

LEAD: Why can't George Bush simply come clean on his participation in the arms-for-hostages decision? Why does he respond by attacking the press for daring to ask the question, or by hiding behind his confidential relationship with the President, or by claiming that he's already answered everything?

LEAD: The Citizens Committee for New York City has chosen three prominent New Yorkers and five neighborhood organizations to receive its annual awards for ''enhancing the quality of life in New York City.''
LEAD: To the Editor: People who think their money will guarantee luxurious accommodations, familiar foods and paved highways in a poor, struggling country should stay home.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The General Services Administration has reprimanded a Federal policeman who gave refuge in a snowstorm to a homeless man who has been living on the steps of the Federal courthouse here for much of the last eight years.

LEAD: From the 900-year-old walls that once marked the northern boundary of Cairo stretch the remains of a city many tourists never see. Graceful minarets still punctuate its horizon like exclamation points, while in the narrow streets below, men in turbans and striped robes sell onions, garlic and lemons from donkey-drawn carts.

LEAD: Owain Hughes, a Welsh geologist, made a significant discovery recently. While rehabilitating a New York City landmark at 597 Broadway in SoHo, Mr. Hughes, who left Oxford University to mine real estate, found a white-marble facade beneath decades of accumulated grime. His training had almost failed him.

LEAD: POLITICS A Work in Constructive Social Theory. By Roberto Mangabeira Unger. New York: Cambridge University Press. Social Theory: Its Situation and Its Task. A Critical Introduction to Politics. 256 pp. Cloth, $39.50. Paper, $12.95. False Necessity: Anti-Necessitarian Social Theory in the Service of Radical Democracy.

LEAD: Heavy Metal in a Quiet Room IT was hard to tell who was having more fun at the Nassau Coliseum recently, the 17,000 screaming teen-agers in the arena, who were boogying away to the heavy-metal sound of the rock band Whitesnake, or Rose Liss in the basement, who was ''up a couple of dollars'' in a deuces-wild seven-card-stud poker game.

LEAD: TRAVELERS watching their pounds, francs or lire - and the dollar buys fewer of each these days -might consider buying a package deal to Europe. A weeklong package in Paris, London or Rome can represent a substantial saving over standard prices because airlines and tour companies get discounts by negotiating for large blocks of rooms.

LEAD: I DIDN'T cry when my grandfather died. This man had taken me in, loved me and did the job his son couldn't do, but when he died I didn't cry. His death wasn't a sad death or a shocking death. It was a long time coming: he was a long time going. We called it senility back then. But for those last five years, he had been in steady decline.
LEAD: HE GOT HUNGRY AND FORGOT HIS MANNERS A Fable. By Jimmy Breslin. 275 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $17.95.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration plans a full-scale show of military force in and around South Korea next fall to deter possible North Korean terrorism or attack during the Olympic Games in Seoul, Administration officials say.
LEAD: The Patten Corporation, a large development company based in Vermont, has agreed to drop its $1 million lawsuit against Hartford, Me., a small town in Maine's western mountains.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Peter McE. Buchanan of New York and Quechee, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Willets Buchanan to Gary Raymond Pfister, a son of Sally D. Pfister of South Roanoke, Va., and Dr. Richard C. Pfister of Newton, Mass. A July wedding is planned.
LEAD: It is a rite of dawn on the banks of the Amazon: fishermen briskly tossing their haul on the piers, ready for market.
LEAD: The engagement of Marguerite Karter to Howard Rory Elisofon has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Karter of New York. An April 30 wedding is planned.

LEAD: IN the early years of the Winter Olympics, the most successful athletes were mainly skiers and skaters from the northern European belt of Norway, Sweden and Finland. Then the Soviet Union joined the Olympic movement and started winning winter medals. Then East Germany did the same.

LEAD: Browsing through the romanticism exhibit at the New York Public Library on 42d Street, watching visitors pore over original manuscripts by Wordsworth, Coleridge, Shelley, Keats and Blake or gaze at paintings by Turner, Constable, Samuel Palmer and others, I wondered what has happened to romanticism, how it has weathered since Wordsworth.
LEAD: ON winter weekends, I like to make meals that will warm people after an active day in the cold outdoors. Old-fashioned food - thick soups, stews and pot roast - is what I enjoy most.

LEAD: The article ''After School, They're at School'' on Jan. 3 has, I believe, some misinformation. To my knowledge, the oldest program, Clasp, is located in Great Neck. The second oldest program is the North Bellmore After-School Center Inc., which was incorporated in October 1979 and started in September 1980 at the Saw Mill Road School by Marilyn Deiner.

''My mother called me up from the car dealership where she was working, and told me Newcombe's car had broken down,'' Mr.

LEAD: THE House vote against aid to the contras reflects another sharp swing in Washington's attitude toward Central America, leaving the region wondering what will come next. No one pretends really to know.

LEAD: THEY'RE out there somewhere; they must be. But who are they and where are they? Do they look like everyone else? Have they advanced degrees in science, math and languages? Do they occasionally have temper tantrums? Have they ever been heard to mutter, or even to come right out with, words like ''heck,'' ''darn,'' or ''oh, fudge?

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Courtney Andrew Nelson of Wells, Vt., and Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Shelby Forrester Nelson to Dr. Jon H. de la Harpe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman A. de la Harpe of Cape Town. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: As free as the polluted air that we inhale each day is! NICHOLAS D. DECURTIS New York

LEAD: Not So Gay Paree Not all the Americans in Paris haunted cafes and dance halls. Here is The New Yorker's Janet Flanner describing Edith Wharton's sober expatriation. She is quoted in ''Women of the Left Bank: Paris, 1900-1940,'' by Shari Benstock (University of Texas).

LEAD: William Shakespeare must have just returned from jury duty when he wrote, ''The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers.'' He might especially have had in mind the selection of civil juries in the New York State Supreme Court, a process that makes suicide seem user friendly.

LEAD: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York, Deborah Glaser, the daughter of Susan Heath of New York and David Glaser of Springfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian Jerome Henry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Henry of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Adrian van Kaam performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The Ohio Ballet, which opens a week's season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue) Monday, has the look and feel of a well-tuned single instrument. Celebrating its 20th anniversary this year, the company is the creation of Heinz Poll, its director and chief choreographer, and Thomas Skelton, the lighting designer; and it bears the imprint of an informed and articulated artistic vision.

LEAD: A record set called ''New York Cabaret Music'' (Atlantic LP 81817-1, six disks; CD 81817-2) is both more and less than that title might suggest. There has been cabaret music of one sort or another in New York for decades, but this collection deals primarily with the 1950's. Even more specifically, it reflects the tastes and interests, personal and business, of the Ertegun Brothers, as indicated by its subtitle, ''The Erteguns' New York.

LEAD: SOME of Connecticut's lawmakers sounded like weather forecasters last week after Governor O'Neill unveiled his $6.3 billion budget proposal for the next fiscal year and recommended spending $73.8 million of the state's five-year old budget reserve, more commonly known as the ''rainy day fund.''
LEAD: THE SHELL SEEKERS By Rosamunde Pilcher. 530 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $19.95.

LEAD: A shortage of health care workers and inadequate state financing have prompted two of Maine's largest home health care agencies to stop accepting new patients under a state program designed to lessen the reliance of the elderly and the handicapped on nursing homes.

LEAD: A female deputy sheriff was properly denied a promotion to sergeant that would have placed her in an all-male wing of the Oneida County Jail, the Court of Appeals, New York's highest court, ruled this week.

LEAD: Q. I live in a new town house condominium that has an outdoor wood deck made of pressure-treated 2-by-4's. The decking has turned green with mildew, and the builder has suggested using a K2 spot remover to clean it. Is this the way to correct the problem?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An Army laboratory in Hawaii has identified remains returned to the United States by Vietnam last September as those of Maj. Michael J. Bosiljevac of Omaha, an Air Force officer who disappeared on a flight over North Vietnam more than 15 years ago. He was the 146th American whose remains, having been returned by Hanoi since the Vietnam War, were subsequently identified by the Central Identification Laboratory in Honolulu.

LEAD: The line between en-tertainment and news will be stretched a smidgen thinner beginning tonight, when Fox's fledgling network launches a weekly series called ''America's Most Wanted,'' described by its producers as ''a televised manhunt'' intended to enlist the public's help in the capture of fugitives.

LEAD: BARRY HANNIGAN came up with a dandy program for his piano recital Thursday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. The music consisted of two of the most admired, large-scale piano scores of the mid-1970's, both experimental and involving whistling and vocalizations from the performer, yet both looking forward to today's accessible post-modernism.

LEAD: They live in a quiet residential neighborhood in San Francisco, a professional couple in their late 30's, with two adopted daughters, 5 and 2 years old. ''Our kids play with the neighbors' kids,'' said one of the parents. ''We swap recipes and borrow tools from the people next door. We're just another family.
LEAD: IRISH TO ENTERTAIN

LEAD: Since the Presidential campaign began, Gerald M. Boyd has been covering Vice President Bush while Bernard Weinraub covered Senator Bob Dole. Last week they switched assignments to report how the campaigns compared in style and substance.
LEAD: The commander of United States forces in Latin America has said that the Nicaraguan rebels are on the verge of a three-way split that will erode and possibly destroy their military strength.
LEAD: WEEKEND by Marlene Fanta Shyer. Warner Books. 316 pages. Paperback, $3.95.

LEAD: FRANK TAYLOR pulled his car over to the side of the road, climbed out and scurried up the hill. He aimed his camera at the aging brown Shaker sawmill, took some pictures, and returned to the car.
LEAD: TELEVISING the Olympics is only slightly less complicated than staging them.

LEAD: Poland's authorities are struggling to close a festering wound at the nation's prestigious Academy of Sciences, where members published an unusual open letter charging that inroads of political control crushed work in the academy's social science institutes.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A clash between the rights of employees suffering from AIDS and those of noninfected co-workers could pose a growing problem for employers, according to a survey of attitudes toward people who have the disease.

LEAD: Rabbi and Mrs. Jonathan Eichhorn of Kingston, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Lynn Eichhorn, to Russell Alan Hinz, a son of Chief Warrant Officer Dale Hinz, U.S.A., of Mount Holly, N.J., and Lolita Eiden of Milwaukee. The wedding is to be May 29. Miss Eichhorn is a graduate of the State University at Albany, where she is studying for a master's degree in public administration.

LEAD: A report last Sunday on fiscal issues before the General Assembly gave an incorrect figure for the amount of money to be taken from the 1986-87 budget surplus and state corporate tax and used for local property tax relief in the 1988-89 fiscal year. The amount is $42 million. The article also misstated an increase to that fund being sought by the Connecticut Conference of
LEAD: Free? Look what Jack Clark and Kirk Gibson just got for salaries! Seems expensive to me. RICHARD COWIT Farmingville, L.I.

LEAD: At St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church in Ridgewood, N.J., Leslie James Payne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Payne Jr. of Ridgewood, was married yesterday to Edward J. Gerrity 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerrity Jr. of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Richard B. Andersen, the rector, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE final chapter in a five-year dispute between Suffolk County officials and local residents over the fate of the aging Sagg Bridge, which has spanned Sagaponack Pond for 65 years, is being written.

LEAD: IN THE LIBRARY OF A 23-ROOM apartment on Fifth Avenue, four blocks from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a rug that was once in the emperor's quarters in Beijing's Forbidden Palace. Somehow, during the turbulent years following the Opium War of 1839-42, the rug was removed from the palace and, some decades later, found its way into the hands of an American pilot who had brought a single-engine plane to China, offering his air-freight services to opium traffickers.

LEAD: Steve Jones has never broken par 72 on Pebble Beach Golf Links in the half-dozen rounds he has played here. But he said he will need to do just that on Sunday to have a chance to win the A.T.&T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am. The 6-foot-4-inch pro from Phoenix, who has yet to win in four years and three tournaments on the PGA Tour, took a three-shot lead today through three rounds of the event that used to be the Bing Crosby Pro

LEAD: WHILE the gurus of fashion contemplate the next direction of the hemline (can a hem go sideways?), the current crop of wildly diverging lengths has created some interesting contrasts to hold our attention.

LEAD: EVEN after construction crews completed work two years ago on Riveredge, an office complex in Florham Park, N.J., plenty of work remained for Edward Blake and Donald Rotwein, who served as the project's architects.

LEAD: There are many here who refer to this week as ''the end of the world.'' The candidates will stop talking to animals and will fly East. The reporters will stop caring that Iowa is the Jell-O-eating capital of the country, and will stop buying products of the new political tourist industry, like ''Ski Iowa'' T-shirts and ''Weak-End in Des Moines'' lingerie.

LEAD: WHAT memories are supposed to be triggered, one muses, crossing the threshold of Memories Cafe in Stamford? Perhaps it is the live music heard nightly from 8:30 to about 11:30 that is intended to induce them.
LEAD: Lying on a crude kitchen table, the body of perhaps the youngest victim of Nicaragua's civil conflict lay swaddled in white inside a dank mud shack today.

LEAD: WHEN large employers sponsor voter registration drives for their workers, the number of new registrants can be as large as the voting population of an entire small town. The Nationwide Insurance Companies, with 14 regional offices, has registered or reregistered an average of 3,000 voters a year since 1984.

LEAD: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., B. Billings Day, a daughter of Mrs. Vincent C. Banker of Locust Valley and Richard W. Day of New York, was married yesterday to Bradford Delano Smith, a son of Mrs. Frank Y. Larkin of Greenwich, Conn., and David S. Smith of Washington.
LEAD: A truck believed to be carrying explosives was reported stolen in Queens yesterday, and the police appealed for help in finding it.

LEAD: Choosing a clean sweep rather than a renovation of the 10-acre industrial complex, Arthur Collins and James R. Psaki began demolition last November of a former Electrolux factory in Old Greenwich, Conn. Next month construction will begin on a mixed-use development to take its place. The $75 million project on Forest Avenue will include a four-story office building, scheduled for completion in the fall of 1989, as well as 167 low-rise condominium units and a recreation center.

LEAD: HERE in Scarsdale we manage to keep in touch with the world, and when I learned that they had had nearly 12 inches of snow in Washington, it gave me an excuse to call William. Even though I am nearly 20 times his age, there is a bond between us - his mother, my daughter. He answered the phone himself.

LEAD: Now it begins. Vice president Bush and Dan Rather were only prelude. Tomorrow night, television gets down to the real stuff. Who will win the Iowa caucuses? The candidates with the most votes, you say? Strictly speaking, that's true, but on television that's only part of the story. The other part has to do with perception.

LEAD: WE are about at the half-way mark of winter and I have been accused of counting time, even days, too much, as though I were not a great fan of the season. A few weeks ago, I was, in best Pollyanna fashion, buoying up a neighbor who was doggedly scraping ice from his car's windshield. I said, cheerily, ''Hey, less than two months until spring.

LEAD: Renaldo Nehemiah is angry. Not at his longtime archrival, Greg Foster, who won the hurdles Friday night in the Panasonic Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden. Not at the others who beat him in that race as he finished next to last. Not at the public, which wants to know what has happened to the old Renaldo

LEAD: After meeting with President Nicolae Ceausescu for nearly three hours today, a visiting United States official said he had found the Rumanian leader unwilling to listen to American concerns about Rumania's human rights policies.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''Calming the Jitters About Tipping on Cruises'' (Practical Traveler, Nov. 1) was timely. Some crew members on our recent Royal Caribbean Cruise Line cruise seemed to receive virtually no monetary remuneration, only uniforms, bed and board. With such an arrangement, company loyalty is minimal, and the caveat regarding personal effects (stressed by the cruise line) becomes more significant.

Showered with applause, flowers and teddy bears after their long programs, they had become America's ice-skating darlings, leaving the impression they were more a team than sometimes cutthroat competitors in a national championship.

LEAD: The Federal ethics trial of Lyn Nofziger, now entering its fifth week, has provided a revealing glimpse at the ready access to high Reagan Administration officials that was granted to former aides who return as lobbyists.

LEAD: Illinois officials and the lawyers for Gary Dotson, a convicted rapist who was freed after Cathleen Crowell Webb recanted her accusation, are turning to a new genetic testing procedure in an effort to determine Mr. Dotson's guilt or innocence.
LEAD: SECOND SIGHT By Mary Tannen. 259 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.
LEAD: FOR more than 27 years, a three- acre slab of concrete, surrounded by barbed wire, has been a silent witness at Fort Dix, N.J., to the deadly potential of nuclear arms.
LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would reject any Congressional alternative for aid to the Nicaraguan rebels ''that is little more than a disguise for surrender and abandonment.''
LEAD: A Federal drug agent was pronounced dead today, a day after he was shot in an ambush by drug traffickers. Another agent and two suspects died in the shooting.

LEAD: BY SILENCE BETRAYED Sexual Abuse of Children in America. By John Crewdson. 267 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: A proposed city ordinance to require people checking into hotels, motels and inns to show an identification card bearing a photograph is being supported by local officials, but criticized by hotel industry organizations.

LEAD: In the 28 years since Frank Lloyd Wright's death, his associates, who have tried to keep the flame of his reputation burning, have often done more to damage his name than to enhance it. Under the rubric of Taliesin Associated Architects (named for the architect's famous houses in Spring Green, Wis., and Scottsdale, Ariz.) they have produced new buildings that are generally mediocre imitations of the great architect's late work.
LEAD: AMERICA can't compete.

LEAD: The New Jersey Chamber of Commerce's annual visit here is a political as much as a business event, starting with the chartered train from Trenton on which politicians walk the aisles, renewing acquaintances and talking up their campaigns.

LEAD: The political party that has headed every Malaysian Government since independence in 1957 was ruled illegal last week by a Malaysian judge because some of its branches were improperly registered. The unexpected ruling is likely to pose political, legal and possibly financial problems for Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and the party, the United Malays National Organization.
LEAD: F. Vernon Foster, a New York stockbroker for more than 70 years, died of complications following a blood infection last Sunday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The engagement of Jean Dashiell Griffith to Robert Dixon Hopkins has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Alexander Griffith of Ruxton, Md. The couple plan to wed March 19. Miss Griffith, a graduate of the Garrison Forest School and Towson State University, is an employment counselor for Nancy Adams Personnel in Baltimore.

LEAD: When Billy Dee Williams took over last week for James Earl Jones in ''Fences,'' the Pulitzer Prize-winning play at the 46th Street Theater, it was a little like an athlete being asked, on short notice, to take over for Babe Ruth - or Josh Gibson. Mr. Jones won a Tony award for his towering portrayal of Troy Maxson, the Josh Gibson-like ex-Negro League slugger caught in a vise of frustration and limitation with members of his own family.
LEAD: It was more than a question that Marvin Schecter posed. It was a scenario that he painted.

LEAD: Many first-rate recordings of Beethoven's complete trios have become available in recent years, and to these may now be added the cycle by the Borodin Trio, containing the basic six (the three of Op. 1, the two of Op. 70 and Op. 97), two sets of variations and several rarely heard early works. All are available on a set of four Chandos compact disks (CHAN 8352/3/4/5; also on

LEAD: A MONTH after unanimously rejecting a $55 million complex of stores and condominiums, the White Plains Common Council last week approved a pared-down version that had been revised to answer neighbors' complaints.

LEAD: Before the Revolution of 1917, Russian artists were already experimenting with radical visual vocabularies based on abstraction and geometric forms. The pioneers of Suprematism and later Constructivism further championed a new marriage of ''art and life.'' After the Revolution, artists such as Alexander Rodchenko, Vladimir Mayakovsky, Liubov Popova and El Lissitzky actively participated in advertising the virtues of their new society.
LEAD: RATS are not a big problem in Takoma Park, Md., but when the city moved to help homeowners who were occasionally troubled by them, it found no easy solution.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Barcelona'' by Paul Delaney (Travel, Dec. 20) is an example of the tendency of many writers to describe exorbitantly expensive hotels and restaurants, thus giving a misleading picture to potential travelers.
LEAD: To the Editor:

Like John Gunther's ''Inside . . .'' series, John Ardagh's book about Germany may be of some use to those readers who have absolutely no idea at all about the subject being dealt with. Like Gunther, Mr.

LEAD: PROPOSALS to upgrade the helicopter landing pad on Dune Road in Southampton Village, halted by environmental objections for several months because the expansion would involve filling in wetlands, may now face a legal challenge by an adjoining property owner.

LEAD: It was a curious scene that Monday morning last week in the main hall of the Haskell Free Library. On one side of the thin, black line sat a Canadian judge; five Canadian witnesses for the prosecution; a Canadian attorney and George Terwilliger 3d, the United States Attorney for Vermont, who was there to question the witnesses.

LEAD: IN the 18th century in England's Cornwall, tin smelters would stand around a basin of the silvery liquid as a huge block of wood dropped into it and sent up a fountain of molten metal. The impact of the wood made the tin boil off impurities. Sparks flew and the heat was intense, but according to a contemporary historian, the workers scarcely noticed the bright specks of tin flying about them.
LEAD: IN the closing months of 1987, the people of the United States had 58 hours of shared anguish.

LEAD: In a major policy declaration, Chancellor Helmut Kohl today formally spurned the idea of eliminating short-range nuclear missiles from Europe but demanded negotiations that would reduce to equal ceilings the number of such weapons held by NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
LEAD: THERE'S a female rite of passage even more traumatic than the first date, and I recently came through it with flying colors. I dined alone, for the first time, with my future mother-in-law.

LEAD: FOUNDED in 1975, the Australian Chamber Orchestra maintains an active schedule at home in Sydney, plays elsewhere in Australia and has toured Asia and Europe. But its current 16-city swing through the United States is its first in this hemisphere. A part of the Australian bicentennial celebrations, the tour brought the orchestra Friday night to the Metropolitan Museum of
LEAD: Re: ''L.I.R.R. Main Line to Enter Electric Age,'' Jan. 17:

LEAD: Nietzsche Thought he put his finger on it with his distinction between Apollonian and Dionysian personalities. Other thinkers have divided us into such antagonistic camps as Yogis and Commissars, Hedgehogs and Foxes, Yea-sayers and Nay-sayers, Saved and Unsaved. Wagner detected a sharp difference between Day People and Night People.

LEAD: The article ''Computers: A Necessary Insidiousness'' [ Opinion Page, Jan. 17 ] renders a distinct disservice to your readers. Especially in the over-30 generation, there's enough nervousness about these marvelous machines without adding to it by maligning them, even if facetiously. Worse yet, to tell all sorts of untruths about them!

LEAD: I'M an incurable romantic. I question couples on how they met. Their fairy-tale wedding albums are the end of the story. Similar to the wedding gown, the volume is boxed and wrapped for eternity. And as a history published three or four decades ago, it is a quaintly dated reference.

LEAD: IN a move that could have a significant impact on Nassau County government, a businessman is asking the State Supreme Court to rule on what he contends is County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta's ''manipulation'' of the county budget to ''mislead the people of Nassau County.''
LEAD: When Matthew V. Storin decided to take a job as editor of a weekly newspaper in this little coastal town, some of his friends thought he was crazy.

LEAD: More than two years after starting an extensive screening program for infection with the AIDS virus, the Defense Department has tested nearly four million people and has identified 5,890 who carry the deadly virus.
LEAD: NASCAR officials in Daytona Beach, Fla. suspended Tim Richmond indefinitely yesterday after he tested positive for a substance prohibited under the stock car sanctioning body's policy.
LEAD: Wait until October. While George Steinbrenner and Billy Martin are toasting each other on a world-championship season, just ask Jack Clark. KARA YORIC Kinnelon, N.J.

LEAD: Skiing Slalom to Pelletier: Monique Pelletier, a member of the United States Ski Team's National Training Group, outdueled Tamara McKinney and other more experienced skiers yesterday to win the women's giant slalom at the United States Alpine championships in Copper Mountain, Colo. McKinney, in her first competition of the season, finished a respectable third, behind Pelletier and runner-up Heidi Voelker.
LEAD: An article and a caption on Jan. 31 misidentified a community group in East Harlem. It is the Union Settlement Association, not the East Harlem Settlement House.

LEAD: The three long tales that make up THE BRIDGE OF LOST DESIRE by Samuel R. Delany (Arbor House, $17.95) display one of science fiction's finest writers at the top of his form. This book is an addition to Mr. Delany's unique Neveryon series, which slyly builds on archeological speculation to body forth a world at the very beginning of civilization in which such important events as the change-over from hieroglyphs to alphabet have occurred within the life spans of the characters.

LEAD: The surreal setting of Joshua Johnson's ''Little Girl in Pink With a Goblet Filled With Strawberries'' adds drama to this folk portrait of a small child identified as Emma Van Name, which dates from about 1805. The painting, attributed to one of the nation's first black artists, was sold at Sotheby's last weekend for $660,000 - more than 14 times the previous record at auction for this artist - a price that represents a growing awareness of Johnson's importance.

LEAD: IN Waterloo, a town that has lost 12,000 manfacturing jobs in the last decade, the John Deere foundry and tractor plant has recalled 500 workers since November. In Albia, a rural crossroads where the farm crisis drove one bank and at least three shops out of business, a small pipe-making company plans to open a factory that will employ 100 people.
LEAD: THE Pioneer warehouse complex, on Flatbush Avenue at the foot of Livingston Street in Brooklyn, has been a familiar sight for more than 75 years.

LEAD: New York State Attorney General Robert Abrams, who was appointed by Governor Cuomo last month as special prosecutor in the Tawana Brawley case, has expressed frustration over the continuing refusal of Miss Brawley's lawyer, Alton H. Maddox Jr., to cooperate in any way.

LEAD: Sparta Brook will share attention with the Hudson River in a colony of 20 houses being built in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Mitchell Hochberg, the co-developer, promises a backyard babbler for 12 of them and a Tappan Zee view for seven. The project, called The Orchard, will also retain some of the apple trees that once dominated the 30-acre hilltop off Scarborough Road.

LEAD: ''Stardust'' is but a memory at the Biltmore Theater, though it still embellishes the marquee at 261 West 47th Street that once spoke of ''Barefoot in the Park'' and ''Hair.'' Since its last musical closed in May, the police say the theater has been used as a drug shooting gallery. On Feb. 16, it will be auctioned off at the Hotel

LEAD: Ruth La Ferla's article ''Under Cover'' (Men's style, Jan. 17), does not reflect the opinion of the many who feel that gray(ing) temples on a man are attractive and evoke an air of distinction and success (and there is no greater aphrodisiac than success).
LEAD: Flood victims on the roof of a house in Petropolis, where five days of heavy rain left at least 58 dead.

LEAD: IN a highly visible advertising campaign, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has been holding itself out as the bank that stresses its ''relationship'' with its clients above all else. ''We don't promote M.&A. deals just to generate fees,'' heralds one ad that proudly shows an empty tombstone - symbolic of a takeover deal that wasn't done, presumably because it wasn't in the client's interest.

LEAD: HER name hung over Denver last month like the smog, and it almost did not seem to matter how badly any of America's best female figure skaters beat up on each other in the national championships. The significant other, thousands of miles to the east, lurked in spirit, nonetheless. Katarina Witt. Of course.

LEAD: May I propose an inter-esting experiment: turn on your record machine and play - in either order you choose -Wilhelm Furtwangler's Bayreuth recording of the Beethoven Ninth Symphony (1951) and Roger Norrington conducting the same piece with the London Classical Players (1987).

LEAD: THE story of the Holy Family's flight into Egypt is not one of the Bible's cliffhangers - St. Matthew devotes but three or four verses to it. Nevertheless, the tale becomes endearing and often quite dramatic, as it is told in the print show that is one of the two current attractions at the Davison Art Center at Wesleyan

LEAD: INDOORS sow seed of geranium, petunia, salvia, begonia, impatiens, eustoma, portulaca and coleus. It is too early to sow vegetable seed indoors especially tomatoes, peppers, melons, eggplants; wait until March. Pot paperwhite narcissus bulbs in pebbles, but discard any of these tender bulbs that have already bloomed; they cannot be forced again.
LEAD: SOMETIMES IT SEEMS I am being drawn by a cartoonist. How else can I explain my being in this supermarket with an impulse to ask the manager to recommend a soap for my dishpan hands?

LEAD: The Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Ruthann Mary Pritchard, an associate at the First Boston Corporation, and Howard Alan Silverstein, a general partner in Goldman, Sachs & Company, both in New York. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Thomas J. Gibbons, who was Philadelphia's first Police Commissioner under the City Charter that was adopted in the early 1950's, died here Friday after a brief illness. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: If Kevin McReynolds loses his salary arbitration case with the Mets, he will join Julio Cruz as the only three-time losers in the 13-year history of the system. People on both sides of the arbitration table have speculated that McReynolds will indeed lose because they think he submitted too high a number, $1.15 million.
LEAD: VINCENT J. SCULLY is the Sterling Professor of Art History at Yale. He has been teaching art and architecture history since 1947.

LEAD: SOME IS WHERE the money is. NBC will not be moving to New Jersey. Thanks to Mayor Koch, it's going to stay at Rockefeller Center for at least another 35 years. ''The peacock can have both brains and beauty,'' the Mayor said last December as NBC accepted his offer.
LEAD: FACED with a chronic shortage of speech-language therapists, Connecticut public schools are turning to parents, paraprofessionals, teachers and computers for help.

LEAD: Alaska's largest commuter airline, whose recent troubles range from a crash that killed 18 people to an errant flight into Soviet air space, may be the victim of its own success, a Federal official says.

LEAD: A young Soviet soldier who defected to the guerrilla forces in Afghanistan has appealed in an open letter to other Soviet soldiers to resist the war there, according to a human rights organization in New York.

LEAD: To the Editor: I read with great interest your coverage on travel-study in England - Cambridge and Oxford (Travel, Jan. 10). In fact, the bit on Corpus Christi, Cambridge, brought smiles to me because some years ago I myself was a student at Corpus Christi College, Oxford, with Dr. E. J. Wolff's University of Detroit program there, and as part of our program we visited our sister school in Cambridge.

LEAD: Joan Craig, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Craig of Moorestown, N.J., and Peter Michael Ruggiero, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Ruggiero of Elmont, L.I., were married yesterday at the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Raymond Finn, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A FRIEND stopping off in Miami to break up a New York to Buenos Aires trip inquired if there was anything to do in Miami for two days besides the beach. He didn't mean Miami Beach, of course. Everyone knew that was dead, he said, a kind of Far Rockaway with palm trees, and not too many of those.

LEAD: At least seven Singaporeans have died in the last six weeks after kidney transplant operations at a hospital in southern China, according to their families and Singaporean Health Ministry officials.
LEAD: Abercrombie & Kent/Continental Waterways, 1420 Kensington Road, Oak Brook. Ill. 60521 (312-954-2944; 800-323-7308).

LEAD: LASER printers are getting better, smaller, faster and slightly less expensive. That makes them more attractive than ever as replacements for the dot matrix or daisy wheel printers now in the office.
LEAD: FOUR eastern Connecticut hospitals, all facing a shortage of beds partly because of population increases, are working out an agreement to share space.
LEAD: A HOW-TO BOOK PROMISES to create ''a more beautiful you'' in 21 days. Twenty-one days? It seems like an eternity. The book, by the way, was written in 1972.
LEAD: A retired executive from Manhattan contributed 647 shares of Bancorp Hawaii stock, worth $30,570.75 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LEAD: At St. Andrew's the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, Carmen Maria Fial, the daughter of Walter F. Fial of Baltimore and the late Carmen S. Fial, was married yesterday to Hans-Jurgen Sund, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Sund of Osterode, West Germany. The Rev. Edward J. Kiernan performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The battle has raged for decades - is recorded music a valid substitute for live performance before an audience? The extremes have ranged from listeners and musicians who felt recordings were at best misleading to those like Glenn Gould who retreated to the recording studio and forswore live performance entirely.

LEAD: I WAS so taken in by the events of Oct. 17, Black Monday, that I actually read past the first page of the daily business section now and keep the car radio set to news so I can keep track of the ups and downs of the stock market.
LEAD: THE Dwight-Englewood School here is teaching students that ethical issues have a practical application in everyday life outside of textbooks.

LEAD: To the Editor: In Betsy Wade's ''Going to China? What to Expect'' (Practical Traveler, Sept. 13), many valuable and valid hints for comfortable travel in China were given. I would like to give one additional hint. The old adage, ''When in Rome, do as the Romans do,'' might wisely be updated to ''When on a Pacific Delight tour in China, do as the Pacific Delighters do.

LEAD: At the Plymouth Congregational Church in Minneapolis, Elizabeth Whitney Burton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Burton of Deep-haven, Minn., was married yesterday to Bruce Alan Ericson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Ericson of Snyder, N.Y. The Rev. Carla Bailey performed the ceremony.

LEAD: What did Martin Heidegger think about the Nazis, and when did he think it? Debate over the German philosopher's Nazi past was rekindled in France recently with the publication of a new book, ''Heidegger and Nazism,'' by a former student, Victor Farias. Mr. Farias produces evidence that Heidegger, whose thinking has had widespread influence on postwar intellectual life in France, was no mere dabbler in Hitlerian politics, as his apologists maintained after the war.

LEAD: At Calvary Episcopal Church in Stonington, Conn., Elizabeth Blair Eddy and Andrew Cary Heublein were married yesterday by the Rev. John Donnelly. The bride is the daughter of Comdr. William P. Eddy, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Eddy of North Stonington, Conn. A graduate of the Loomis Chaffee School, she attended Randolph-Macon Woman's College.

LEAD: A nationwide manhunt set off by the karate-style kick slaying of a young business executive on a Manhattan street ended Friday night with the capture of a 20-year-old part-time New York stagehand as he stepped off an airliner in San Francisco.

LEAD: Amy Robin Fier, an associate in the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson in Washington, and Baruch Gitlin, a second-year student at the Georgetown University Law Center, plan to marry in April. Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Fier of New York have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr.
