LEAD: The intrusion was the sort of blurred moment, of off-the-street barrages of rocks and bullets, when the seeds of middle-class vendetta are being sewn amid the spirited villagers of the Palestinian protest.
LEAD: GOVERNOR Kean's leading economic adviser says that a glowing forecast for 1988, issued just two weeks ago, may have been overly optimistic.
LEAD: THE MAGIC SCHOOL BUS INSIDE THE EARTH By Joanna Cole. Illustrated by Bruce Degen. 40 pp. New York: Scholastic. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 8)

LEAD: FEDERAL and local narcotics agencies are at odds over whether there has been an increase in the availability in New Jersey of a cocaine-based drug known to medical experts as basuco and to addicts as ''bazooka.''
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Professor McClean's effort to attribute to ''white racism'' 500 years of English usage, wherein the word ''black'' has come to have a derogatory or sinister meaning, is absurd.

LEAD: FOR weeks, a battle has been raging in Angola that could have repercussions throughout southern Africa. The battle is for Cuito Cuanavale, the strategic town in southern Angola; the warring forces have been fighting for control of the region for more than a decade. On the defending side are the troops of the Angolan Government, backed by Cubans and Soviet advisors; on the offensive, the UNITA forces of Jonas Savimbi, the guerrilla leader, receiving 5-million-a-year in American military aid, stiffened by a South African army of at least 5,000, perhaps as many as 7,000 men.

LEAD: WHEN we prepare for a long driving trip, one of our tasks is picking a taped book to play on our cassette deck during the hours spent on monotonous interstates. We call an 800 number and rent one because a six-hour tape is an expensive purchase. If it's a book we discover we like, it can then be bought for our shelves at home.
LEAD: CALCULATED RISKS A Century of Arms Control, Why It Has Failed, and How It Can Be Made to Work. By Bruce D. Berkowitz. 221 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.
LEAD: SEVEN months ago, New Jersey's health-care community received a challenge: to develop innovative and unique approaches to the state's most pressing health-care problems.
LEAD: Chalk up another point for inevitability: tourists have set foot on the South Pole.

LEAD: The American Medical Association says only a court order could force it to disclose the identity of a physician who wrote an essay about injecting a terminally ill patient with a lethal dose of morphine.
LEAD: Bimbo Coles scored a career-high 51 points today, including a 3-point goal that started a decisive Virginia Tech run in the second overtime as the Hokies defeated Southern Mississippi, 141-133.
LEAD: Eleven of the 13 Presidential candidates crisscrossed Iowa today in pursuit of the uncommitted, the undecided and the persuadable as the campaign here drew to a close.

LEAD: The upheaval in the Israeli-occupied territories has brought both anxiety and exhilaration to Jordan, as Jordanians and Palestinians wonder where the events are leading them and how they will change the delicate alliance they have forged in this country in the last 40 years.

LEAD: SINCE the birth of Israel nearly 40 years ago, the Arab-Israeli conflict has fallen into a circular pattern. Statesmen try to move ahead, push some distance but finally fail. Amid diplomatic stagnation, warfare erupts. Then the combat ends, having loosened some of the old positions, providing a period of diplomatic fluidity.

LEAD: When speculation that Gov. Evan Mecham might resign started rising last October, Secretary of State Rose Mofford telephoned a good friend in Flagstaff and said, ''Good morning, this is Governor Mofford.''

LEAD: With an eight-gallon purchase of unleaded gasoline, Mobil Oil service stations around the country have been giving motorists drinking glasses decorated with the logo of a football team in leaded enamel.

LEAD: One thing a horseplayer can be sure of is that when his horse falls back from first to sixth turning for home, it is not going to win. Today at Gulfstream Park, though, that is exactly what Beauty Cream did en route to a half-length victory in the $200,000 Orchid Handicap.
LEAD: TENSIONS in Bergen County's 25-year-old Jail Annex are difficult to manage, says Sheriff Robert R. Herb, and unless changes are made, he contends, violence will continue and injuries increase.
LEAD: THE MEMOIR OF MARCO PARENTI A Life in Medici Florence. By Mark Phillips. 283 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $40.

LEAD: State Senator Michael B. Mitchell and his brother, former State Senator Clarence Mitchell 3d, were sentenced Friday to two and a half years in prison each for taking payoffs to block an investigation of the Wedtech Corporation.

LEAD: When you see your best friend acting in a way that will ruin his life, do you pretend not to see? Do you insist to others that it is really not so bad as it looks? Do you tell yourself that it is his business, not yours?

LEAD: FOR all the bipartisan praise heaped upon Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, the Senate's 97-to-0 confirmation of his nomination last week ushered in a period of uncertainty about the Supreme Court's direction.
LEAD: A delegation from the Hollywood film industry returned from the Soviet Union this week with three signed agreements for joint ventures.

LEAD: A New York City real-estate trade group said last week that despite recent criticism of several ambitious development projects, a public opinion poll it commissioned has found a reservoir of support among residents for commercial and residential development.

LEAD: A Soviet official said today that Moscow is ready to support a United Nations Security Council resolution that would impose an arms embargo on Iran for failing to accept a cease-fire in its war with Iraq.

LEAD: Woonsocket has fallen heir to a parcel of land in New England that may be worth up to $500,000. But the Boston-based company that advised the city of its inheritance has declined to say where the land is.

LEAD: Viktor I. Mironenko's son, Dima, turned 14 a month ago, and like most Soviet teen-agers he now faces an important decision. Will he join Komsomol, the huge youth arm of the Communist Party and the route to power and prestige for generations of Communists, including Mikhail S. Gorbachev?

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Rowland Clifford of Cornwall, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Rowland Clifford, to John Tittmann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barclay Tittmann of Concord, Mass. A July wedding is planned. Miss Clifford, a graduate of the Northfield Mount Hermon School and Connecticut College, is studying for a master's degree in international relations at the University of Chicago.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Strickler of Killingworth, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Allen Strickler to Jonathan Seth Cole, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray L. Cole of Wayne, N.J. An August wedding is planned. Miss Strickler, until recently a book sales coordinator at Publisher's International Marketing Services in New York, graduated from Choate Rosemary Hall and Skidmore College.

LEAD: Announcement of the engagement of Pamela Grace Dorman to Stuart Krichevsky has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Dorman of Dix Hills, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

At right, Deborah Donahue in thekitchen of her new house in the Whalebone Woods section of East Hampton.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BRITAIN'S STEADILY growing prosperity,'' boasted Nigel Lawson, the British Treasury Minister, ''is not some short-lived boom, which could come to a juddering halt at any moment.'' Only a year before, the leader of Britain's Labor Party, Neil Kinnock, expressed the hope that America's policy toward Nicaragua would be ''brought to a juddering halt.
LEAD: George Britt, a former newspaperman, author and teacher, died Thursday at the Meadow Lakes retirement complex in Hightstown, N.J., where he lived. He was 92 years old.

LEAD: FRANCES LEAR didn't know anything about headlines or deadlines. But she was convinced that she had an idea. Two years ago, armed with a huge settlement from her divorce from the television producer Norman Lear, she started work on a magazine for women over 40.

LEAD: BEHIND THE SCENES In Which the Author Talks About Ronald and Nancy Reagan . . . and Himself. By Michael K. Deaver with Mickey Herskowitz. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: The regulatory waters are still being roiled by the October market collapse. The S.E.C. staff urged curbs on stock index futures trading, saying the technique aggravated the dive of Oct. 19. Among other things, the 900- page report recommended that margins on futures be raised from the current 10 percent.
LEAD: A bad scare, and a little embarrassment about surrendering a four-goal lead, prompted the Islanders to come up with two more goals and defeat the visiting Sabres.
LEAD: The Army says it can build a laboratory in Utah to experiment with defenses against germ warfare without posing a threat to the public or environment.
LEAD: Trading Pinstripes For Chef's Toque

LEAD: To the Editor: Two hundred and sixty dollars for dinner for four in Spain? Have travel writers no conception that many ordinary travelers choose Spain (and Portugal and Morocco and some others) because it is one of the less expensive places to visit? If the writer of a ''What's Doing in'' must indulge himself in expensive restaurants, let him do it in a special category placed between ''Hotels'' and ''Restaurants.
LEAD: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

LEAD: ''I'm so sick and tired of the great, galloping hordes of candidates criss-crossing the state and burrowing into every nook and cranny, every home. Every time you turn around you crash into one of them. Enough, enough!'' Betty Dumbaugh of Storm Lake, Iowa, who plans to stay home on caucus night.

LEAD: LONDON may be dreary and drizzly in winter but it tingles with the excitement of concerts and theater and things to do. Question: Can an American enjoy an inexpensive holiday there with the dollar so sick? Answer: Yes, but you have to work at it.

LEAD: WHEN Mariarosa Cartolano, a New York lawyer, recently purchased her first car, a 1987 Chrysler Le Baron, she was prepared to find high prices in the dealer's showroom. What she wasn't prepared for was the size of the insurance bill: $4,000 a year, or about 25 percent of the cost of the car itself.

LEAD: IF the New York City Board of Estimate is dismantled, as some legal experts were proposing last week, there could be an ironic result. A challenge to the board that originated in a desire for a more representative city government could so upset the city's system of checks and balances as to give more power to an already powerful mayor.

LEAD: IT'S far too early to tell whether voter turnout for the 1988 Presidential election will be greater than the 53.1 percent of eligible voters who turned out for the 1984 Presidential election. But if it is, a number of businesses will be able take some of the credit.

LEAD: The marriage of Toni Lynn Schachter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin I. Schachter of Freeport,L.I., and Copake Lake, N.Y., to Seth Perry Bernstein a son of Laurel Culter of New York and Wilton, Conn., and Stanley D. Bernstein of Nutley, N.J., took place last evening at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I.
LEAD: Martha Williams French and Anthony Peter Fusco, actors in New York, plan to marry in June, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. James M. French of San Francisco, have announced.

LEAD: Toward the end of Steven Spielberg's ''Empire of the Sun,'' there's a haunting sequence in which 13-year-old Jim Graham (Christian Bale), who has survived four years in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp outside Shanghai, witnesses the first American air raid on the adjacent Japanese airfield.

LEAD: WHEN A NEW acquaintance told me not long ago that he runs five miles every day, I felt jealous and ashamed (I jog only three miles, three times a week) and vowed to step up my program. Only later, and with some effort, did I remind myself that I jog as much as current medical opinion says is needed to keep my heart and lungs fit.

LEAD: A 1960'S REVIVAL IS gusting through rock. Musicians and critics are jostling one another to praise the human scale and anything-goes spirit of 1960's rock; college radio stations can play hours of recent music in which the hoarse vocals and garage-band production are virtually indistinguishable from the ''Nuggets'' collections (on Rhino Records) of half-forgotten 1960's singles.

LEAD: When it began, it was a pristine dream, the clear crystal palace of the Olympics. Now the palace does not shine so brightly. Memories of the Olympics still bring a warmth to my soul and a smile to my face. The Olympics, however, did not live up to my ideal.
LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S largest city has become a test site for a new Federal effort aimed at breaking the welfare cycle among teen-age mothers.

LEAD: BLACK HISTORY MONTH Although officially it began last week, Black History Month really gets into gear this week as museums and libraries throughout the Island study the past, celebrate the present and look into the future. For example, ''Out of Africa,'' a traveling photographic exhibition from the Smithsonian Institution that traces the rich cultural heritage of West Africa, is at the African-American Museum in Hempstead, 110 North Franklin Street, through February.

LEAD: IT has been more than a decade since the age of narcissism was identified as such by Christopher Lasch. Tom Wolfe's proto-Yuppies, the ''me generation,'' appeared at about the same time. What was formerly deplored is now accepted, even applauded.

LEAD: NOW that our last child will be leaving home for college and our net worth is down approximately 40 percent since October's Black Monday, I have finally realized my dream - a magnificent new kitchen. Just a few thousand dollars more than the original purchase price of our house in 1970, the room has brought me all the obvious anticipated pleasures.

LEAD: ABOUT 40 years ago, as a young grandmaster, the syndicated chess columnist Larry Evans jocularly broached his idea that the easiest way to win a game was to pick the ripe moment for a transition to an ending where the opponent could be bamboozled. It was not quite all in fun either - he won loads of games ''transitioning'' his opponents.
LEAD: THE Bee Battle of Mexico has started, and the bees have won the first encounter without wasting a sting.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: GUESTS were invited to create fantasy headdresses for the Christian Dior dinner Thursday at the New York Public Library for the opening of the exhibition ''Splendid Plumage.'' Chignons sprouted pheasant feathers, curls supported ostrich plumes and one bold spirit wore a bird's nest filled with eggs.
LEAD: VERDI A Life in the Theatre. By Charles Osborne. Illustrated. 360 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.
LEAD: LOVERS are preparing for the romantic highlight of the year, Valentine's Day.

LEAD: THE oldest ''rule'' in bridge, far older than the game itself, has been under attack for a quarter of a century. It's now in decline, but is likely, like Charles II, to be an unconscionable time dying.

LEAD: The choice of San Pedro Bay near Los Angeles as the site for the next America's Cup match is a move by the San Diego Yacht Club to gain a tactical advantage, Bruce Farr, designer of New Zealand's yacht challenger, said yesterday.

LEAD: If it was distressing to be a professor during the 1960's, it was equally distressing to be a student. Instead of sharing Professor Bloom's youthful experience of walking through the gates into a world in which intellectual endeavor was taken seriously, the student was plunged into a society ruled by demagoguery of the most extreme kind, in which slogans were substituted for ideas, and even attending class was sometimes a risky business.
LEAD: The McClean article represents another tiresome assault on English usage by people who should know better.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: MANY developers of urban malls fail at the delicate art of attracting a successful mix of tenants. Herald Center, the vertical shopping center at 34th Street and Broadway, has been a disappointment since it opened three years ago. In lower Manhattan, dozens of retail spaces sit vacant at the South Street
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 30 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: REFLECTIONS ON HISTORY AND HISTORIANS By Theodore S. Hamerow. 267 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $25. THE NEW HISTORY AND THE OLD By Gertrude Himmelfarb. 209 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $20.

LEAD: The engagement of Elizabeth Ochs Shine to Matthew Samuel Rosenzweig, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Y. Rosenzweig of Milwaukee, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Gretchen O. Shine and Warren S. Shine, both of New York.

LEAD: OBSERVERS OF THE auto industry were not optimistic when the United Automobile Workers and General Motors sat down last July to negotiate a new three-year contract. G.M., its share of the domestic car market falling, was seeking to shrink its work force. The U.A.W., battered by layoffs, was equally intent on preserving jobs.
LEAD: FRIDAY BASEBALL

LEAD: ROY BARNES, a union labor lawyer, calls them ''union busters.'' But Patrick L. Vaccaro, the managing partner of the White Plains office of the law firm of Jackson Lewis Schnitzler & Krupman, said: ''That's a union cop-out. That's a term they use for any firm that counsels management.''

LEAD: Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for more than 31 million elderly and disabled people, should be expanded to cover much more of the cost of long-term care, including nursing homes and home health services, according to a major new study by experts at the Brookings Institution.

LEAD: LOVING LITTLE EGYPT, by Thomas McMahon. (Penguin, $6.95.) In the early days of electrical power, Thomas Alva Edison fought with Nikola Tesla over whether direct current or alternating current would be the wave of the future. In this novel by Thomas McMahon, a Harvard science professor, Edison and Tesla are on opposite sides again, in a dispute over an electronics wizard who creates a secret underground telephone network for the blind.
LEAD: An Evening With Bach

LEAD: Marcy Engel, a lawyer for Salomon Brothers, and Stuart M. Cobert, an associate in the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, plan to be married in October, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Engel of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced.

LEAD: JUST five years ago, the odds of wandering into a first-rate restaurant in greater Miami were roughly equal to your chances of finding a 16th-century Spanish doubloon in the Fontainbleau Hotel's swimming pool. Except for some gutsy Cuban haunts downtown, Miami cuisine was characterized largely by over-air-conditioned tourist places featuring humdrum chain-restaurant fare.

LEAD: The marriage of Dr. Helen Towers and Dr. Walter I. Weiss, graduates of the Royal College of Surgeons in Dublin, took place last evening at the Berkeley Court Hotel in Dublin. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg of Temple Rodelph Sholom in New York performed the ceremony.

LEAD: In every Olympic year, many Americans seem to think that our privately supported athletes are at a disadvantage compared to the Eastern bloc's state-subsidized athletes. Unfortunately, a more serious United States disadvantage is being overlooked: our Government's attitude toward bidding for and staging international events.
LEAD: The Rangers will have just 14 hours to savor what they accomplished here tonight, and most of that time will be spent worrying about longterm implications.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The engagement of Beth Cari Langerman to Joseph Stephan Friedma,the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Friedman of Wayland, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. David W Langerman of West Nyack, N.U., and Boca Raton, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: I thoroughly enjoyed Holcomb B. Noble's article ''A Joyful Noise'' (About Men, Dec. 27), about singing in a male chorus. It recalled an experience I had in early 1944 in Belfast, Northern Ireland, where I was on furlough for three days.
LEAD: AS he walked into the Beverly Hills Hotel one day in January 1984, Stuart Karl surely felt on top of the world.

LEAD: Rupert Murdoch announced yesterday that he had agreed to sell The New York Post to Peter S. Kalikow, a New York City real-estate entrepreneur. But the $37 million sale is contingent upon significant concessions from The Post's labor unions, and Mr. Kalikow has given no guarantee that the newspaper will be kept open in any case.

LEAD: In Division I college basketball, everyone has a story. The paths to the big time are winding. The tales are often legendary. David Wagner of Iona has a story, one that is unique in a unique world.
LEAD: Nearly 100 days ago, Lisa Steinberg was fatally beaten in her family's Greenwich Village apartment. Not only could it happen again to someone else, it has.

LEAD: The United States has suggested 18 specific steps that the Japanese Government and industries could take to increase imports of American-made semiconductors, and the two sides will discuss the issue this week, a Japanese official said.
LEAD: In pulpits all over Iowa this Sunday morning, the word went forth that Christians had a duty to fulfill, at once sacred and civic, in Monday's caucuses.
LEAD: ALTHOUGH the excuses offered by waterfowlers who fail to shoot their limit of birds are as plentiful as pinfeathers on a young duck, I have one that is, I believe, without precedent.

LEAD: THREE of the four composers on Sunday afternoon's program by the Boston Composers String Quartet have roots in either jazz or rock-and-roll; yet there was probably no one moment during this Weill Recital Hall event when either element spoke out directly. The pull of popular culture in all these pieces was, I think, more fundamental than imitation blues, synthesized bop chords or syncopation.

LEAD: A visit to this nearly deserted Army post is a journey back in time, mostly to the grim, early days of World War II. Since then, Fort Chaffee has been a training camp for American soldiers, jail for German prisoners of war, reception area for Vietnamese refugees and holding camp for Cuban expatriates.

LEAD: Anna Mikhailovna Larina was barely 17 years old when the Bolshevik revolutionary Nikolai Ivanovich Bukharin proposed to her. By the age of 22, she was his wife, a budding economist and a mother. By 24, she was his widow, inheriting scorn and infamy.
LEAD: A man killed three people, including his father, at a family anniversary celebration before mortally wounding himself, the police said today.

LEAD: A strong earthquake occurred this morning near the far western end of the Aleutian Islands, the United States Geological Survey said. It was centered in the Pacific Ocean, about 130 miles south of Shemya Island, and was felt slightly on Shemya. The quake registered 6.1 on the Richter scale.
LEAD: OVERSEAS investors have jumped back into the Tokyo stock market.

LEAD: THE Festival Theater probably did not intend to have a mini-Kiefer Sutherland series. But after ''Promised Land,'' the new coming-of-age-in-Utah film featuring the actor, last Friday it brought in ''Crazy Moon,'' a 1986 Canadian movie in which he stars. You can't blame Mr. Sutherland for the lameness of either one.
LEAD: A 57-year-old former political science professor was sworn in today as President of Haiti, exactly two years after the Duvalier dictatorship collapsed.
LEAD: Sometimes you get a little grouchy, said Stephen Taylor Woodrow, when you hang on a museum wall for six hours a day, covered with black spray paint.

LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, based in Akron, Ohio, has named HDM, Los Angeles, to handle its Los Angeles retail broadcast advertising. The budget is estimated between $3 million and $5 million.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH William E. Phillips, the 58-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy Group, said Friday that he would relinquish his title to Kenneth Roman, 57, the chairman of the Ogilvy Group's largest operating company, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, the news did not take many people by surprise.

LEAD: ONE day not long ago I took our younger daughter, Jamie, who is 8 years old, out to the backyard to run. I set up a course and asked her to circle it several times. An active child, she'd been jogging on and off for a couple of years and began this session with a spirited stride.

LEAD: Panama's central bank reserves are nearly depleted, its trade deficit is growing and it is increasingly hard-pressed in making payments to its creditors, according to United States Government officials and private bankers.

LEAD: North Korea's demand to be a co-host of the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea, is tied to its desire for reunification with South Korea, a senior North Korean sports official said Saturday night.

LEAD: Two men believed to have been homeless were found dead on Manhattan streets during the weekend, and a third was found dead in a field on Wards Island as temperatures plunged to the lowest point in three weeks, the authorities said yesterday.
LEAD: Iowa is small, flat and remote from the great capitals of finance, government and communications. It has neither beaches nor mountains, neither battlefields nor splendid colonial houses.
LEAD: A 14-year-old girl who had gone out to buy a newspaper for her family yesterday morning was found slain a few hours later on a railroad embankment in Richmond Hill, Queens, the police said.

LEAD: A number of Broadway performers and other theater professionals are to take part in a free event on Feb. 10 at the St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street. The show, which starts at 11:30 A.M. and is open to the public on a first-come basis, is sponsored by ''Broadway Cares,'' a support and resource organization for victims of AIDS.

LEAD: Where a monument to Leonid I. Brezhnev once stood, there is now an uneven sidewalk, covered with a dusting of snow and frozen dirt. The large black Cyrillic letters that spelled out his name on a nearby metal and concrete billboard have been erased.

LEAD: In an action reflecting the growing crisis in relations between Panama and the United States, the Panamanian Government has recalled three senior diplomats, including its Ambassador to Washington, for ''urgent consultations,'' state-controlled radio stations and newspapers here said today.
LEAD: ''For me, time doesn't exist.

LEAD: IT'S plain as the whiskers on a miner's face why any fella in Cloudy Mountain would give his britches for a kiss from ''The Girl.'' Not only does she run the mining camp's only saloon, but she also runs its ''academy,'' where Joe Miller's joke book serves as a primer. (''Can February march? No. But April may.

LEAD: Federal regulators will meet on Wednesday with representatives of several California savings and loan institutions to discuss a proposal for breaking up the troubled Financial Corporation of America, a spokesman for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

LEAD: The people of Iowa, having listened for more than two years to the men who would be President, will make their choices Monday night in nominating caucuses where the margins of victory will hinge on which campaigns do the best job of getting their supporters to attend.

LEAD: ''he Federal Government has begun moving to determine the fate of 2,400 Cubans transferred last year from riot-torn prisons in Georgia and Louisiana, amid criticism of the review process and of conditions under which the Cubans are now held.

LEAD: Protesters marching in Tokyo during a demonstration calling for the return of four islands east of Hokkaido. Protesters claim that the islands, held by the Soviet Union since the end of Work War II, are Japanese territory. Portrait of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, was carrie during the march, which was sponsored by rightist groups.
LEAD: As a fourth-grader, Suzie McConnell's grammar school did not have a girls' basketball team, so she did the obvious thing.
LEAD: A Senate supporter of Bob Dole said recently: ''Bob Dole never forgives and never forgets. You know if you cross him, you've got problems.''

LEAD: The Westminster Kennel Club, which has been holding dog shows since 1877, making its show one of the oldest continuous sporting events in the country, opens a two-day run at Madison Square Garden this morning. There are 2,651 dogs representing 140 breeds or varieties, and they come from 48 states (North Dakota and Hawaii are the exceptions), the District of Columbia, Canada, Puerto Rico and

LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation complained Friday that a court order requiring interim relief payments to victims of the Bhopal gas disaster did not specify who would get the aid, the United News of India reported.
LEAD:
LEAD: * Kenneth A. Glaser joins Solin Associates as executive vice president.
LEAD: There was the unmistakable air of carnival today, as if some zany festival of democracy had erupted in this ordinarily earnest Midwestern city.

LEAD: As Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch presented their budget plans for next year recently, a listener could be forgiven for wondering if the two men lived in the same state. Despite the stock market plunge in October, Mr. Cuomo, who presented his budget to the State Legislature last month, gave an optimistic appraisal of the economy.

LEAD: The official biography of Peter S. Kalikow is a bland portrait of a New York City real-estate developer: a 45-year-old, civic-minded family man who graces the city with his buildings, gives time and money to worthy causes and has received numerous awards for his generosity and humanitarian efforts.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Yugoslav newspaperman has unearthed documents and interviewed witnesses that place Kurt Waldheim as the sole German Army officer in a small town when mass reprisal shootings and deportations of Yugoslav civilians were conducted during World War II.

LEAD: Despite its evident good sense, banning radar detectors, or ''fuzzbusters,'' has not proved popular either in Congress or in state legislatures. Only Virginia, Connecticut and the District of Columbia have adopted such a ban.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: In the last month of his life, my friend Bob Walden finally learned to love Mozart.

LEAD: Mike Moore, the Seattle pitcher who suffered 19 losses last season, has become only the seventh player in the 13-year history of salary arbi-tration to suffer a pay cut in the procedure. Moore and Jime Acker, an Atlanta pitcher, learned yesterday they had lost their cases.

LEAD: MCKIM, Mead & White are not the latest names in town, and an exhibition of this great architectural firm's work, most of which was done between the 1880's and 1910, would normally be the occasion for not much more than an appreciative nod. But this month there are not one but two exhibitions dealing with the firm's architecture, proof that McKim, Mead & White continues to possess, more than three-quarters of a century after its leading partners' deaths, nearly mythic status in New York.
LEAD: The break for the National Hockey League All-Star Game couldn't have come at a better time for the Devils, who are dispirited and hurting.

LEAD: Nearly two and a half years after a daredevil cocaine smuggler fell to his death on a driveway here when his parachute failed, a woman accused of being his accomplice is going on trial on drug charges.

LEAD: ''Les Demoiselles d'Avignon,'' the 1907 masterpiece that liberated the savage genius of Pablo Picasso and set the tone for a century of artistic discontinuity and shock, has, for a few months at least, come home. In an exhibition of around 85 works that is itself ground-breaking, the Picasso Museum has documented the evolution of this complex and convulsive painting and presented it within its artistic context for the first time.

LEAD: It took two Minnesota hockey players to discover that it is possible to play a decent game of ice hockey without ice. Brennan Olson and his brother, Scott, were rummaging around a Midwest sport shop one day in 1979 when they found an old skate with wheels attached in a straight line instead of in pairs.

LEAD: Young, middle-class, well-educated and unabashedly inspired by the Cuban revolution, Teodoro Petkoff Malec was one of the leaders of the guerrilla war begun by Venezuela's Communists in the early 1960's to overthrow the country's new democracy.
LEAD: A YOUNG man returns home.

LEAD: Brazil has mounted a major diplomatic effort to head off $105 million of trade sanctions planned by the United States in retaliation against Brazil's reluctance to buy American computer software.
LEAD: IT was so delightful, so delicious, so absolutely delovely that even Michael Jordan himself got embarrassed.
LEAD: Peter K. Nevitt, former chairman of the BankAmerilease Group, the leasing arm of the BankAmerica Corporation, has struck out on his own in a leasing venture in conjunction with the Japanese.

LEAD: Since white settlers began arriving here 150 years ago, Natal has been known for its magnificent beaches and mountains, its sugar cane and a brand of racial politics as conservative as any in South Africa. Now some of its leading citizens are promoting a plan for a multiracial government in the province, hoping that it will head off demands for black majority rule.
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation will hold the prices of its cars and trucks for the rest of the 1988 model year, Roger B. Smith, the company's chairman, promised dealers here.
LEAD: SNOW pelted car windshields and a stiff easterly wind cut through parkas one morning here recently, several hours before stores at the Aurora Mall in suburban Denver opened.
LEAD: Eighteen specialty shows were held at 12 metropolitan area sites yesterday in preparation for the Westminster Kennel Club show.
LEAD: A New York State correction officer was fatally shot by a New York City police officer last night in the Bronx in what the police said might have been an accident.

LEAD: Six days ago, the Rangers lost Chris Nilan and, with him, much of their limited muscle. On Saturday night, they lost Kelly Kisio and the scoring punch he brought. In the last week, however, they have somehow gained both momentum and ground in the Patrick Division.

LEAD: A shotgun blast was fired Saturday at the home of Evan Mecham, the impeached Governor of Arizona, and today Mr. Mecham's car dealership was vandalized in a glass-breaking spree, the police said.

LEAD: Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci and ranking American legislators called upon West Germany and other European allies today to fulfill a five-year-old alliance commitment to modernize short-range nuclear weapons.

LEAD: Aaron C. Sterling, a fund-raiser and promoter of charitable causes, died of congestive heart failure Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
LEAD: As giant banks flounder and regional banks flourish, the turmoil churning the nation's banking system is beginning to show up in the rankings of the nation's largest banking companies.
LEAD: The seminar began at 9 A.M. on a sunny Saturday morning, but there were crowds of eager, bright-eyed hopefuls lining up even earlier. Indeed, the offering seemed to many like the Holy Grail.

LEAD: The British Government won't prosecute Northern Ireland police who blocked an investigation of the police shooting in 1982 of seven unarmed men, six of whom died. Nor will the Attorney General, Sir Patrick Mayhew, publish the report of an inquiry into these shootings. Thus he seems to confirm a cover-up but won't do anything about it for reasons of ''national security.
LEAD: The adultery conviction of a female Air Force officer accused of having an affair with another officer has been set aside by the Air Force Court of Military Review, her civilian lawyer says.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week are limited to the bill market, starting with today's regular weekly sale of three-month and six-month issues totaling $12.8 billion and ending Thursday with a one-year issue of $9.25 billion.
LEAD: Larry Pleau, coach of the Binghamton Whalers of the American Hockey Leauge, was named today to replace Jack Evans as the Hartford Whalers' coach.
LEAD: South Africa's President P. W. Botha has announced plans to privatize five major state-run corporations that employ a total of 400,000 people and have combined assets of $30 billion.
LEAD: An article from Puerto Rico on Wednesday about the arrest of three American soldiers and a Panamanian on drug charges misstated the location of two military installations.

LEAD: SYLVIA KOWALCZUK'S recital at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday night addressed two problems faced by everyone who plays the harp for a living. One is to find a consistently strong repertory; the other is to create clear, unambiguous diatonic statements - melodic lines and harmonic progressions capable of penetrating the harp's rainbow of overtones.
LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

LEAD: For the second consecutive game, the Cornell University basketball team is involved in a fight, this one against Syracuse in the Carrier Dome. It starts when Greg Gilda of Cornell and Derrick Brower of Syracuse begin bumping and pushing under the basket. Punches are thrown and both are ejected, as is Derrick Coleman of

LEAD: The Composers' Showcase series will offer three programs at Alice Tully Hall this season. The series opens Feb. 29 with a Leonard Bernstein Song Celebration, performed by a wide range of artists from the worlds of classical music and Broadway. They will include Betty Comden, Adolf Green, Ben Holt, Julia Migenes and William
LEAD: A Federal drug agent was pronounced dead Saturday, a day after he was shot in an ambush by drug traffickers. Another agent and two suspects died in the shooting.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: From now on, it could cost any country that does not participate in the Summer Olympics. But not much.
LEAD: Sam Donaldson, the ABC White House correspondent who is noted for holding the President accountable for gaffes, is getting a taste of his own medicine.
LEAD: A list of credits in Weekend on Jan. 29 with a film review of ''Anguish'' misidentified the screenwriter. The film was written and directed by Bigas Luna.

LEAD: It began as a pleasant Saturday night out for Karen Toshima: dinner with a friend and a stroll through the bustling Westwood Village on the affluent West Side of Los Angeles. A short time later Miss Toshima, a 27-year-old graphic artist, lay mortally wounded on the sidewalk next to a parking meter, a bullet through her head.
LEAD: The Amoskeag Company, which controls Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., has taken a new top executive, C. Edward Midgley, from Wall Street.
LEAD: A welcome court ruling that strikes down a dissonant provision of New York City's cabaret law could encourage a jazz revival in the city.
LEAD: Carlo de Benedetti's investment company announced tonight that it would pay 4,000 Belgian francs, or $114, a share for up to 15 percent of the outstanding stock of Societe Generale de Belgique.
LEAD: American and Soviet schoolchildren are becoming acquainted here under an exchange between the Soviet Embassy school and some Washington area schools.
LEAD: State attorneys general, working collectively on consumer issues they say are ignored by Federal agencies, are emerging as an alternative national enforcement agency in an era of deregulation.

LEAD: The marriage of Barbara Furman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Furman of Manasota Key, Englewood, Fla., to Nathan David Willensky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Willensky of Atlantic Beach, L.I., took place yesterday at the Stanhope in New York. Rabbi Bernard M. Zlotowitz performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: OPEC's oil production fell sharply last month, mainly because of cutbacks by Persian Gulf exporters, including Saudi Arabia, according to the International Energy Agency.

LEAD: A young C.P.A. in Mamaroneck, N.Y., who was working late one recent bitter cold night, learned that the oil had run out in the home of an elderly couple. The man was recovering from a severe throat infection, and his wife was in bed critically ill.

LEAD: The body of a girl who had gone out to buy a newspaper for her family yesterday morning being removed from a railroad embankment in Richmond Hill. The police would not identify the girl, who they said had apparently been bludgeoned. Page B3. (NYT/Marilynn K. Yee)
LEAD: Israeli soldiers firing into a stone-throwing crowd killed three Palestinians in this tiny village today as demonstrations flared all along the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

LEAD: TOWARD the end of their Friday evening concert at the Public School 41 auditorium, the French Canadian traditional quartet La Bottine Souriante struck up a jig. Yves Lambert, who plays accordion and harmonica, began to vocalize in an argot that suggested an American mountain auctioneer singing in French in a jazzily syncopated diction.

LEAD: Results of the Iowa caucuses will be broadcast tonight by all three commercial networks, with NBC and ABC airing 30-minute news specials at 10:30 P.M. Eastern standard time, and CBS following at 11:30 (11:35 in New York City). Cable News Network will provide live coverage from Des Moines beginning at 8 P.M.
LEAD: From the day the National Basketball Association awarded Chicago the All-Star Game, the expectation was that it would be a weekend made for Michael Jordan. It was.

LEAD: Sikh militants opened fire today on a Hindu wedding party, killing the bridegroom and three other people, the police said. Four Sikh radicals arrived at the party near the town of Kapurthala, about 43 miles north of here, and began shooting AK-47 assault rifles, the police said.

LEAD: University of Rochester officials and Mary Lady Fairfax, the widow of the Australian financier Sir William Fairfax, have agreed to open an American-style graduate business school near Sydney, Australia, officials of the school said last week.
LEAD: The Market Index chart in Business Day last Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday carried incorrect values for all dates before Jan. 30. The values should have been two points higher.

LEAD: * AVX Corp., Great Neck, L.I., which manufactures electronic components, named Charles A. Dill president and chief operating officer, replacing Donald K. Thostenson, who has been named chairman of the executive committee.

LEAD: Mstislav Rostropovich, music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, will present the world premiere next month of the first piece of music written for him by a Soviet composer since he left the Soviet Union in 1974.
LEAD: QUESTION: Babe Ruth was switched from pitching to the outfield because of his ability to hit the ball even better than he pitched it. Just how good a hitter was Ruth as a pitcher?

LEAD: United Jersey Banks, Princeton, N.J., has narrowed its search for an ad agency. Still in the running are three New York shops: Geer, DuBois plus Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos and McCaffrey & McCall. The previous budget was estimated at more than $2 million.

LEAD: More Than a Fantasy The problem with fantasy sports camps is not that the average person doesn't harbor fantasies of hitting a home run to win the World Series, it's that the average person would like to sustain those fantasies.

LEAD: An article on Jan. 16 about a call for an economic boycott to protest racism in New York City misidentified the group that urged action against WABC-TV. The group is the Committee to Eliminate Media Offensive to African People.

LEAD: Two evening sessions devoted to Friedrich Durrenmatt, Feb. 20 and 22 at the 92d Street Y, have been canceled because the Swiss playwright is ill. Ticket refunds or exchanges may be obtained at the box office. Information: 427-4410.

LEAD: When the Rural Justice Center looked for a place exemplifying some of the most vexing problems of rural justice in the United States, it came here to Robeson County, which has a volatile population mix of whites, blacks and Indians, and a District Attorney who has put more people on death row than any prosecutor in the United States.

LEAD: After a three-way competition, the household products division of Miles Laboratories has assigned a Chicago agency, Zwiren & Partners, its SOS Glassworks cleaner and new-products account. The annual budget is $4.4 million.

LEAD: Steve Jones achieved the first victory of his PGA Tour career today when he sank a 20-foot birdie putt on the second hole of a playoff with Bob Tway to win the A.T.&T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.

LEAD: RICHARD BILES put steps neatly together in his choreography for the Richard Biles Dance Company, which performed Saturday night at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace. But the resultant dances were so bland that one longed for real flights of fancy.
LEAD: A strike by production workers at the Ford Motor Company's 21 plants in Britain, which started late tonight, is the first national walkout in a decade at the nation's leading car maker.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: KOREAN shamanic dance was a focus of two events over the weekend in New York City, one a seminar at Asia Society and the other a performance by Hi-ah Park on Friday night at the Open Center. The word performance is used advisedly here, for Miss Park herself stressed that the evening was a version of a shamanic ritual that was modified for the time and place.

LEAD: The soprano Dawn Upshaw will be guest soloist with the Apple Hill Chamber Players on Wednesday when the group gives the first of three monthly chamber-music concerts at Merkin Concert Hall. The ensemble, which is based in Nelson, N.H., comprises a string quartet, double bassist and two pianists.
LEAD: When his name surfaced last month in connection with a Congressional appropriation of $8 million to build schools in France for refugees from North Africa, Zev W. Wolfson was appalled.
LEAD: It is often important to make a crucial play without any revealing hesitation, and declarers often plan ahead, making the decision mentally a few tricks before the fact.

LEAD: Officials at the Lockheed Corporation confirmed during the weekend that its Aeronautical Systems Company division, which builds military air transports for the Air Force, expects to lay off 9,000 employees, mostly production workers, by next January.

LEAD: The marriage of Lynn Riley, the daughter of Mary F. Riley of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Timbes Riley, to Richard Feinson, a son of Janice Feinson of New York and Melbourne Beach, Fla., and the late Burton Feinson, took place yesterday in Bronxville at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. John M.

LEAD: Many Americans believe that the Soviet Union could overwhelm NATO defenses in a conventional war in Western Europe. They must have been surprised last week when a group of European political leaders opposed the idea that the West should build up its conventional forces before the United States ratifies the treaty banning short- and medium-range missiles.

LEAD: Disregarding the yellow flags waved by some economists, the credit markets have raced to lower yields in the belief that the Federal Reserve will try to stave off impending weakness in the economy by easing its monetary policy and reducing short-term interest rates.

LEAD: At least two people were killed and more than 100 injured Saturday night when a moderate earthquake shook Bangladesh and eastern India. The Government newspaper Dainik Bangla reported today that the deaths and most of the injuries occurred in the northeastern city of Sylhet. Walls of houses caved in around Slyhet, cracks opened up in a hospital building containing 500 beds and people ran into the streets in panic, the newspaper said.
LEAD: Floods and mud slides have killed at least 127 people in Rio de Janeiro state since Friday, a civil defense spokesman said today.

LEAD: SANDRA REAVES-PHILLIPS is a big-voiced Southern blues belter who belongs squarely in a tradition that extends from Ma Rainey through Dinah Washington. But the singer, who is appearing at the Top of the Village Gate in a show called ''Heart to Heart, My True Confessions,'' would like to be more than that.

LEAD: Ethan Canin is 27 years old, a graduate of Stanford and a fourth-year medical student at Harvard. He is also the author of the just published ''Emperor of the Air,'' a collection of nine short stories. His work has appeared in The Atlantic, Esquire and Ploughshares, and has been reprinted in ''The Best American Short Stories'' of 1985 and 1986.

LEAD: At least two youngsters were enchanted with the magical tricks of a clown performing on the lower level of Grand Central Terminal. The clown, along with mimes, musicians and other entertainers were taking part in an open house to celebrate the terminal's 75th anniversary. (NYT/Vic DeLucia)

LEAD: Demonstrators against the Roman Catholic Church's stand against homosexual activity holding a mass across from St. Patrick's Cathedral. Later, members of the group associated with the gay rights organization Dignity marched across Fifth Avenue to the front of the church, where 23 were arrested for blocking the sidewalk.

LEAD: At 6:15 A.M. yesterday, the Jersey City Chief of Police, John Fritz, walked into Police Headquarters at 8 Erie Street, went to his third-floor office and locked the door. He took his .38-caliber off-duty revolver from a safe and sometime in the next three hours, police officials said, sat down in his high-backed executive's chair and killed himself with a single shot to the right temple.

LEAD: This week's meeting of the Federal Reserve, which stands almost alone these days in managing the economy, will provide important indications of its goals for growth and interest rates and will test its resistance to political influence.

LEAD: The newest Supreme Court Justice, Anthony M. Kennedy, has hired one of Judge Robert H. Bork's former law clerks to join him when he begins work at the Court on Feb. 18. Judge Kennedy's new law clerk, Peter D. Keisler, who now works in the White House as one of six associate counsels to the President, got to know the future Justice when he was assigned to assist him with his Senate confirmation hearings in

LEAD: A decade after it began accumulating a vast stock of rundown apartment houses, New York City finds itself unable to manage them, repair them, return them to private landlords or improve the abysmal conditions for the tens of thousands of people living in them.

LEAD: The Westminster Kennel Club show will feature 2,651 dogs vying for the best-in-show title. The sporting, hound and toy breeds will be benched and judged today, starting at 9 A.M., with the groups at 8 P.M. On Tues-day, the working, terrier, non-sport-ing seven rings, from 8:30 A.M.

LEAD: THE theater of XXY Dance/ Music might have been described best as multimedia in other times, when the point of incorporating several art forms was usually to create a smoothly-transcendent blend. But ''Steady On,'' presented by XXY on Saturday at the Emanu-El Midtown Y Dance Center, would more properly be described as collagist.

LEAD: The Consumer Product Safety Commission and a Federal district judge are expected to decide soon whether to give final approval to an agreement on the future sale and production of all-terrain vehicles, which have been linked to about 900 deaths over the last five years. Under the pact, manufacturers have agreed to end production of three-wheel ATV's, but they would be allowed to continue making four-wheel models, which are considered less dangerous.
LEAD: Mayor Richard Flickinger, who guided the passage of what may have been the nation's first municipal ban on pistols, died at his home Monday after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

LEAD: Until recently Raul Gardini was viewed as the embodiment of the new Italian entrepreneur: glamorous, aggressive and ready to play a role in financial markets around the world.

LEAD: Troy Lewis of Purdue scored 14 of his 20 points in the second half today as the sixth-ranked Boilermakers beat No. 11 Michigan, 91-87, to take sole possession of first place in the Big Ten Conference.
LEAD: In an effort to reunify South Korea's divided opposition, Kim Young Sam resigned this morning as president of one of the nation's two main opposition parties.
LEAD: Burglars broke into an Episcopal church in Yonkers for the second time in a month early today and desecrated the interior.

LEAD: Next January a new cast of characters will take over at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue and there are some Washingtonians itching for the drama to begin. The capital thrives on change: new faces, new issues, new personalities, new political battles.

LEAD: Burton Wallace Marsh, the first full-time city traffic engineer in the United States, died of cardiac arrest as the result of pneumonia Thursday at the Bethesda Retirement and Nursing Center in Maryland. He was 90 years old.

LEAD: At last, tonight's the night. After watching months of campaigning, some 200,000 Iowans will assemble in gyms, firehouses and living rooms and declare for one of the six Republicans or seven Democrats running for President. And at last, three kinds of easy criticism will have to stop.

LEAD: In almost every high-profile case tried recently in the New York courts, judges have been sealing documents, holding secret hearings, curbing lawyers' out-of-court remarks or taking other actions to limit the access of news organizations and the public to sensitive information.

LEAD: PETER HIMMELMAN brought simple, unquestioning rock-and-roll to the Bottom Line last Wednesday. Fronting a four-member group of friends from his hometown of Minneapolis, Mr. Himmelman, a guitarist and songwriter, put on a sturdy, tight show that brimmed with faith in the whole rock process and in himself as a song writer.

LEAD: Rafi Nelson, a former journalist and public relations man who became the owner of a beachfront resort, died Saturday of a heart attack, the Israeli radio reported today. He was 57 years old. Mr. Nelson operated Rafi Nelson's Holiday Village, a popular resort in the tiny enclave of Taba, claimed both by Egypt and Israel.
LEAD: Equalize snaked his way through an overstuffed field of 16 to score a decisive 2 1/4-length victory over Yankee Affair in the $154,500 Canadian Turf Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

LEAD: At a time when some states are turning their prison workshops over to private managers, New York State prison officials are taking a different course: They are hunting for new products, new customers and new ways to put inmates to work.

LEAD: Ketchum Communications, Pittsburgh, has announced an executive realignment to be accomplished during a year-long transition period. Edward L. LEAD: Dumb. Deceitful. Self-defeating. The Reagan Administration set senators to sputtering when it offered up a new doctrine on treaties: Administration testimony during hearings on treaty approval need not be binding on Presidents. That doctrine, intended to protect President Reagan's Star Wars dream, prompted senatorial fury over legal treachery.

LEAD: IN an increasingly competitive battle to supply the world's airlines with new planes, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the General Electric Company are gambling on developing a new aircraft powered by a fuel-saving engine of an unusual design.
LEAD: Hazard Earl Reeves 3d, an executive in the real estate and communications industries, died of heart failure Jan. 30 in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in Monroe, Conn.

LEAD: The findings of the historians' commission about President Kurt Waldheim's war record appeared to confirm what most Austrians had feared, that an end to the punishing and divisive controversy has come no nearer.

LEAD: SALMON seems to maintain its freshness better than any other fish. Whether from Atlantic or Pacific waters, it comes to the kitchen in prime condition, provided it has been properly refrigerated.

LEAD: Despite one problem, a three-ton military satellite launched Monday succeeded in using a battery of sensors to track 15 mock enemy targets for President Reagan's anti-missile program, military officials said yesterday.

LEAD: IRONHEAD HEYWARD'S mother says that her son - she refers to him, in fact, as Craig, the name she gave him, and not by the nickname, Ironhead, which he generally answers to - is 21 years old, an adult, and ought to determine for himself what he'll do with his life.
LEAD: Salomon Brothers Inc. announced a series of high-level management changes yesterday, suggesting continued turmoil at the top of the securities giant.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: NEW YORK has a voracious appetite for music from beyond the mainstream, whether it be from Cajun Louisiana or Anatolia. This creates a performance problem. LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE troubles suffered recently by the Nashville Symphony, which was forced by financial problems to stop performing, come as the latest in an ominous series of setbacks for orchestras around the country. In the past several months, ensembles in New Orleans, San Diego, Vancouver, Denver, Detroit, Oakland, Calif., and elsewhere have been disbanded, gone on strike over wage cuts or accepted reduced salaries or shortened schedules.
LEAD: Girls come to believe that thin is beautiful as early as age 7 or even younger, according to a new report linking that attitude to a rising incidence of eating disorders in young girls.

In October, Eaton announced it would sell its military electronics business, and from that point it accounted for that segment's performance as a discontinued operation.

THERE are critics in Britain who have praised Sally Potter's ''Gold Diggers'' as ''witty,'' ''visually entrancing'' and ''an absorbing pleasure,'' and there may also be like-minded individuals on the planet Jupiter. But by any reasonable earthly standard, this thing - a 1983 oddity, sort of a feminist, deconstructionist, riddle-filled anti-musical, much of it set on the Icelandic tundra - is pure torture. Its only noteworthy attribute is the presence of Julie Christie, who embodies some sardonic notion of the archetypical unenlightened movie heroine through the ages. Like it or not, Miss Christie is infinitely better off playing such creatures straight than she is satirizing them here. ''The Gold Diggers,'' which opens today at the Thalia SoHo, begins with a black woman (Colette Laffont) and a white one (Miss Christie) outlining a vexing riddle (''Only in the darkness am I visible. You can see me but never touch me. I can speak to you but never hear you . . . who am I?''). One of them then maintains that since there are only 90 minutes to find an answer, ''Time is short.'' This is laughable, under the circumstances. The camera goes on to explore a plotless configuration of bare Arctic landscapes, mock silent-movie scenes and caricatures of masculine behavior, and never has the clock moved more slowly. There is also about a 15-minute encounter between Miss Christie and a tap-dancing mime.

LEAD: JENNIFER BARTLETT'S latest works, now at the Paula Cooper Gallery, are smart and suave and highly polished, and they cast a seductive, unsettling spell. LEAD: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, will appear at a $10,000 a couple fund-raising event Friday for the California Republican Party, state party officials said. The event will be held at the Bel-Air home of David Murdock, a real estate developer. The event is expected to draw 100 to 125 people. The Reagans are making a brief stopover before traveling to Mexico over the weekend to visit President Miguel de la Madrid.

LEAD: President Reagan's new budget lays down a comprehensive blueprint for Federal policies in the post-Reagan era, including increased spending on education and science and a dramatic expansion of his campaign for the private sector to take over Government functions.

LEAD: When Federal money flows to one department of a school or hospital, Federal law should prohibit discrimination in all parts of the institution. For years that was accepted as the clear intent of several Federal civil rights laws. Then in 1984, the Supreme Court narrowed their scope. The Senate now has restored the laws' broader reach and the House is about to follow.

LEAD: * Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $450 million of mortgage securities through a real estate mortgage investment conduit, or Remic. Divided into five tranches, the rates range from 7.30 percent to 9.25 percent. The issue is backed by conventional fixed-rate mortgages in the form of Fannie Mae mortgage-backed securities and will be offered through Bear, Stearns.

LEAD: Auto Racing Elliott Sets Mark: Bill Elliott never trailed in a record-setting victory yesterday in the opener of the Budweiser International Race of Champions series at Daytona International Speedway in Florida. LEAD: ON a Sunday in June 1986, my two teen-age daughters and I celebrated my parents' 47th wedding anniversary with them. The next day, I drove from my home in Connecticut to theirs in New York to pick up my mother and drive her to a hospital for elective surgery, a hip replacement.

LEAD: WHAT a difference three years, a little luck and a lot of hard work have made, Shorty Gladbach mused as he sat at the kitchen table in his 100-year-old yellow farmhouse, while his wife, Gerry, smiled down from her chores at the sink.

LEAD: THE classrooms where generations of Braintree students struggled with algebra and passed notes are well on their way to becoming the kitchens and bedrooms of condominiums, the result of a conversion project by Francis X. Messina, Braintree's largest developer.

LEAD: To those unfamiliar with central air-conditioning systems, steam seems the last thing to make them go. But two types of systems are powered by steam heated to more than 400 degrees. To remind building owners and co-op boards that steam can do more than provide heat, Consolidated Edison, which sells the steam it makes to generate electricity, is offering rebates until the end of the year of up to 50 percent to those that either upgrade a steam system or install a new one.

LEAD: WITH the exception of Samuel Ramey, as Banquo, new singers took over the principal roles Thursday evening in the Metropolitan Opera's troubled production of Verdi's ''Macbeth.'' After a last-minute cancellation by Shirley Verrett, Olivia Stapp took her place as Lady Macbeth, and suffice it to say that her performance was crude and melodramatic in a way that even the maniacal role cannot bear.

LEAD: The West German news magazine Der Spiegel said today that it ''regretted'' publishing a document that purportedly linked President Kurt Waldheim of Austria to war crimes. The document was declared a forgery by the Yugoslav authorities last week.

LEAD: Beginning next month, industrial plants all over the country will be required to disclose to state and local committees a flood of information on whether they are using and storing any of more than 300 ''extremely hazardous substances.''

LEAD: THE Grumman Corporation, the producer of more than 33,000 fighter planes, bombers and cargo jets, may soon be out of the airframe business. LEAD: COMPUTERS are showing up in the outplacement business in the form of sophisticated job data bases.

LEAD: TRADITIONAL WEDDINGS are glamorous spectacles, occasions to trot out the sort of finery one spies only at high official functions or in Andrew Lloyd Weber stage extravaganzas. Starched collars, stick pins and ascots - the accoutrements alone suggest a period piece, to say nothing of the clothing, a panoply ranging from morning suits to tailcoats.
LEAD: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware was alert and talking with members of his family today after surgeons corrected a fault in an artery supplying blood to his brain.

LEAD: Georgetown University has announced that it will accord ''equal treatment'' to groups of homosexual students and agreed to provide a $3,740 subsidy to such a group at its law school.

LEAD: HOW much bomb-grade plutonium is required for national security? The exact answer is secret, but the response of the Department of Energy has always been: more than we have now.

LEAD: IN the beginning was collage, pioneered as a kind of trompe l'oeil by the Cubists. Then came assemblage - or three-dimensional collage - in which found objects were transformed into Surrealist mysteries.

LEAD: The trade deficit for December was the lowest in 11 months, coming in at $12.2 billion. With imports unchanged, the improvement came from a 4.2 percent gain in exports, to a record $24.8 billion. Most predictions had been for a December deficit of at least $13 billion, and the financial markets strengthened when the report came out.

LEAD: Associated Black Charities of New York, a federation of 59 health and welfare agencies, is using the observance of Black History Month in February to honor contemporary black leaders and underscore the early beginnings of black philanthropy.
LEAD: With a sudden sweep of measures, the Greek authorities have begun a crusade against air pollution that seems to tilt at the country's intertwined obsessions: smog and the siesta.
LEAD: Eight seamen and a teen-age boy who were seized by Lebanon's main Christian militia seven weeks ago were freed today, militia figures and Lebanese officials said.
LEAD: ON VALENTINE'S day, philologists wonder: What's happening to love?

Having done in his wife - and, it seems, seven of her own husbands as well - Fay offers herself as the next Mrs. McLeavy, only she has her eye on Dennis, who also happens to be the undertaker, a bank robber and the bisexual lover of McLeavy's son
LEAD: DONNIE BRASCO My Undercover Life in the Mafia. By Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. Illustrated. 373 pp. New York: New American Library. $18.95.

LEAD: If you enjoy watching Americans win gold medals, pay close attention when full-scale competition starts Sunday in the XV Olympic Winter Games. The Americans' best chance for a gold medal in these Olympics will come in the men's 500-meter speed skating.

LEAD: When Diana Vreeland began staging her dynamic costume exhibitions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art 15 years ago, she not only narrowed the gap between fashion and art but also enhanced the perception of clothing as a field for serious study. Art museums all over this country and in Europe followed with their own fashion exhibitions, and books examining the sociological and cultural implications of clothing proliferated.

LEAD: Washington's Birthday will be observed tomorrow. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No collection or street sweeping. Government offices: Federal, state and city offices closed. Post offices: Closed, except for special delivery and Express Mail delivery.

LEAD: A careful study of the newer types of statistics, like slugging percentage and on-base average, show that Mantle, particularly the Mantle of the 1950's, was one of the most prolific and valuable baseball players of all time, a shade below Ruth, Williams and Gehrig.

LEAD: Prospective employees lined up outside the Bendix Chassis & Brake Components Division plant near St. Joseph as more than 1,000 people showed up to apply for 20 openings. About 150 new jobs will open there by next year as part of a company improvement program.

LEAD: The youth and early manhood of Jean-Honore Fragonard (1732-1806) are a joy to contemplate. He was quick, gifted, eager and adaptable. In a stocky, well-fleshed way he was very good looking. Everything went well for him, though he missed out on the classic art education that he could have got from the Academie in Paris.
LEAD: MOTHERS OF INVENTION From the Bra to the Bomb: Forgotten Women & Their Unforgettable Ideas. By Ethlie Ann Vare and Greg Ptacek. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: For six decades, ever since Louis Armstrong thrust soloists into the foreground of jazz, the vast majority of jazz performances have had the same form: theme-solos-theme. But since the 1930's, at least, some jazz musicians have been trying alternatives - narrative pieces, symphonic-scale suites and rhapsodies, free-form improvisations.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Freeman of Brielle, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jean Freeman, to Joel B. Moshin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Moshin of Brooklyn. Miss Freeman, who graduated from New York University, is a legal secretary at the New York law firm of Spengler Carlson Gubar Brodsky & Frischling.

LEAD: ALL along the Costa Brava, the stretch of coast that runs from Barcelona to the French border, Catalan bread topped with anchovies is a typical way to begin a meal at home and in restaurants. Pa amb tomaquet, slices of bread lightly toasted, rubbed with fresh tomato, then doused with one of the region's virgin olive oils, is the base.

LEAD: WHEN the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Mill moved to the South in 1971, it left more than a dozen enormous brick buildings standing vacant in Enfield, a Connecticut city of 45,000 residents on the Massachusetts border whose economy Bigelow had dominated since 1914.

LEAD: ON the face of it, there is little common political ground between Singapore, with its resoundingly successful free-market economy, and Communist Vietnam, which seems only to grow more desperately poor. But new currents are flowing in Southeast Asia, and they cross in unexpected places.

LEAD: The Knicks played Bill Cartwright both alone and teamed with Patrick Ewing last night, but it mattered little. The 7-foot-1-inch Cartwright was the key as the Knicks trounced the Cleveland Cavaliers, 120-103, and extended their Madison Square Garden winning streak to seven games.

LEAD: An everyday player can compete in five areas: hit for average, hit for power, run, field and throw. Mays could do all five excellently. A lifetime .300 hitter, 660 home runs, a base-stealing threat at all times, he made great catches (see Vic Wertz, 1954 World Series) and great throws (see Billy Cox thrown out at home trying to score from third on a single to right-center field).

LEAD: A PROPOSAL to build a complex of condominium town houses with clubhouse, swimming pool and tennis courts has divided the South Shore community of Seaford and led to a split in the local civic association.

LEAD: If President Reagan is worried about the Federal deficit, he conceals it well. He is the man, after all, who has more than doubled the national debt in a mere seven years. Yet his imminent Budget Message, leaked last week, takes credit for the trivial deficit-reduction package worked out with Congress after the October crash.

LEAD: When the characters in John Hughes's ''She's Having a Baby'' catch a brief glimpse of the old ''Dick Van Dyke Show'' on television, the film sounds an amazingly nostalgic note. There, amid the sourness, petulance and misanthropy of Mr. Hughes's new comedy, are Rob and Laura Petrie, who led simple lives and fought over the silliest things.

LEAD: IT never fails: when it snows in unpredictably large proportions, my husband is always out of town and I'm left to do the dirty work. There is no consolation when I pick up the phone at 6 A.M. on a Tuesday and hear my teaching colleague say, ''School's closed today. Pass the word.'' She can well afford to be happy about it, because her husband will be there to shovel the driveway and revive the frozen automobile.

Indeed, it seemed that much of Boston had turned out for the culminating event of the project, initiated 10 years ago by E.

LEAD: I GAVE THE WOMAN A CHECK FOR $500, drove off in her '74 Datsun and left behind a whole life style. That was two years ago. Up to then, the only cars I had ever owned were Porsches. But as I wound the steep slopes of western Connecticut on my way home, my mind wasn't heavy with comparisons of hill power, or rack and pinions or swaybars.

LEAD: Roman fantasies, en-riched by architecture and mythology, dominate the 17 painted panels from the bedroom walls of an ancient country villa that have been restored and reinstalled at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. LEAD: BLACK History Month has rolled around again and, with it, exhibitions by black artists.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo made a surprise appearance today at a meeting of black and Hispanic elected officials and civil-rights leaders, and, in an apparent effort at compromise, proposed the creation of a special civil-rights unit in the State Attorney General's office.

LEAD: A free performance by music ensembles from Staten Island will mark the official opening Thursday of a visitors' and information center at the Staten Island Ferry terminal in lower Manhattan. LEAD: TORRENCE SEWARD, a seventh grader at Cloonan Middle School in Stamford, says he sees knitting as ''uniting two things, like you can unite two countries.''

LEAD: POSSIBLY the shortest spring and summer evening dresses in the recent Paris couture showings were the sequin-studded, printed silk styles by Per Spook. LEAD: Dr. Joseph Barnea, a natural resources expert for the United Nations and former chief economist for the Israeli Foreign Ministry, died Monday at his home in Queens. He was 77 years old.

LEAD: I envy Henry G. Brinton for writing the About Men essay I was hoping to write someday (''The Pastor's Problem,'' Jan. 17). I, too, work in a part of the world in which affluence is the way of life. I, too, find there is too much month left at the end of the money.

LEAD: FOR an intimate introduction to the San Francisco Bay Area's Painted Ladies, its Victorian houses, visitors can tour three of them widely varying in style and just a few blocks apart. A short trip across the bay to two of Oakland's architectural grand dames will complete a good survey of local Victoriana from 1860 to 1900.

LEAD: Minutes before a Philadelphia Orchestra rehearsal not long ago, Riccardo Muti, the music director, was lying down, his feet dangling over the arm of a dressing room couch at Carnegie Hall. He looked happy and relaxed. He cajoled an assistant about packing luggage for a trip, and chatted, one after the other, with the orchestra's general manager, Joseph Kluger, and its concertmaster, Norman Carol, about the ensemble's recent labor disputes.

LEAD: N.H.L. Canucks 6, Bruins 5: Doug Wickenheiser scored with 3 minutes 25 seconds remaining for the victory at Vancouver. The goal, Wickenheiser's fifth of the season and first since last Jan. 17, was set up by a centering pass by Dave Saunders. The victory, the Canucks' third in their last 11 games, snapped a six-game Boston winning streak.
