LEAD: AND so, at long last, after two years of preliminary skirmishing, strategizing, campaigning, fund raising, organizing, pontificating and poll-taking, the electorate, or at least a tiny sliver of it, has finally joined the labor of picking the two major parties' 1988 Presidential nominees.

LEAD: IF your bathtub is installed in a recess, that is, if the tub is surrounded by walls on three sides, creating a built-in appearance, one of the easiest ways to add a touch of elegance is to install bathtub shower doors in place of a shower curtain.

LEAD: The engagement of Susannah Fanshawe Dwight to James P. Prout has been announced by the future bride's parents, Margaret O. Bradley of Riverside, Conn., and George H. P. Dwight of New York. Mr. Prout is a son of Anne C. Prout of Cranford, N.J., and John Prout of New York. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: In college I took methedrine and read Chaucer. This was in 1968. During the day we sat in at Army induction centers, and at night we went to our boyfriends' apartments and took drugs and read Chaucer because there was a required Chaucer section on the senior English honors exam and we couldn't graduate with honors without it.

LEAD: IN 1980, the outplacement industry - which, simply put, is the business of counseling people who have lost their jobs - recorded $35 million in revenues, according to James H. Kennedy, publisher of Consultants News. By 1986, revenues had grown to $225 million, with the number of firms rising to 154 from 43.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Three people were killed when a northbound Conrail train collided with the car in which they were riding, the police said today.
LEAD: An article on Feb. 7 misidentified the bus line serving Roosevelt Island. It is Queens/Steinway Transit Corporation.

LEAD: The countries of the world should be divided into two classes, countries of immigrants and countries of emigres. Everybody knows that America - her might, her prosperity, her culture - has been created mainly, if not exclusively, by huddled masses yearning to breathe free. The culture of Russia, on the other hand, has been created, almost to the same extent, by her emigres, the wretched refuse of that ancient, pompous empire.

LEAD: THE Pentagon's successful ''Star Wars'' experiment last week vividly illustrates the growing gap in how East and West measure up on exotic anti-missile arms. As the United States pushes ahead with space spectaculars seen as vital to the perfection of orbiting battle stations, the Soviet Union is keeping a lower profile, seeming to concentrate on basic research confined to the laboratory.

LEAD: TWO weekends ago, Hani Al Hassan, a senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization, held a dinner party at his home in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Most of the guests were successful Palestinians working in the gulf region, and it became almost immediately obvious, in the heated, emotional exchange that ensued with the P.L.O.

LEAD: If there is anything in this city that is the target of more jokes than the city itself, it is City Hall. ''The world's most beautiful ugly building,'' a ''monument to corruption,'' an ''architectural abomination'' are among the many unflattering descriptions the building has earned.
LEAD: Senator Edward M. Kennedy has announced plans to introduce legislation that would encourage states to create a program of education and day care available to all 4-year-olds.

LEAD: The marriage of Alison Mead Husting, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene E. Husting of Locust Valley, L.I., and Cedric Christopher Janien, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cedric J. Janien of Chatham, Mass., and Boca Raton, Fla., took place yesterday at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley.

LEAD: THE Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck, as it so often does, provides a wonderful diversity of musical treats this week. Because many county youngsters are enjoying school holidays, children's programs fill the midday, midweek roster, starting tomorrow and Tuesday, when Puppetworks goes ''Around the World in 80 Days'' in what the troupe describes as ''a vivid and specially designed production'' of the Jules Verne classic.

LEAD: As he smiled and posed with Michael Mair of Italy, who was celebrating his 26th birthday today, Pirmin Zurbriggen stole a glance of the result board at the bottom of the men's downhill run, his smile slowly fading as he appeared a bit preoccupied.

LEAD: Eastchester, N.Y. $305,000 34 Tuckahoe Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, porch, fenced yard, walk to station; taxes $4,404. Mount Kisco, N.Y. $290,000 Crow Hill Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old frame Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, playroom, stone walls, 1 acre; taxes $4,343.

LEAD: Mantle was clearly superior to Mays, which is obvious at the first look at statistics. The two had identical lifetime slugging percentages, at .557, but Mantle's on-base percentage was higher, .420 to .383. Since these are the two most important offensive categories, Mantle already has him beat, but Mantle also had a higher stolen-base percentage, .80 to .77, and grounded into six fewer double plays per year than Mays.

LEAD: ON a small, grassy hill overlooking the ruins of Chinese Camp, an old mining settlement, stands St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic church. The tombstones in its graveyard bear the names of Irish and English immigrants who crossed the Atlantic in search of gold. But the most arresting monument to those who sought riches here is the lush canopy of trees that covers much of the town.

LEAD: The two million own-ers of camcorders probably expected that making their own video tapes with these camera-recorder combinations was just a matter of point and shoot. That, at any rate, is the impression fostered by advertisements that would have you believe that shooting video is as simple as taking snapshots.

LEAD: A FEW GOOD MEN FROM UNIVAC. By David E. Lundstrom. (MIT, $19.95.) This personal memoir, the latest volume in the MIT Press's History of Computing series, recalls the early days of the electronic computer industry, when machines with the capacity of today's miniature computers were ''a little larger than a single car garage.
LEAD: Workers removing posters from Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s campaign office in Manchester, N.H. Mr. Haig has quit the Republican Presidential race. (NYT/Jim Wilson)

LEAD: Mayor Koch's vociferous campaign against a state bill to increase pensions for retired city workers has drawn attention for the first time to a system that has been in operation for more than a decade.

LEAD: BANDITS, by Elmore Leonard. (Warner, $4.95.) An ex-con, an ex-cop and an ex-nun become involved with contras, Sandinistas and even a Miskito Indian in a plot to free a Nicaraguan woman from a leper colony in Louisiana. Despite this ''preposterous business,'' Walker Percy said here last year, Elmore Leonard ''knows what he's doing.

LEAD: On the fashionable north side of town, Spain's Socialists held their 31st Congress last month, planning how to maintain their overwhelming majority in Parliament, discussing sophisticated economic policies and paying homage to their charismatic leader, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez.
LEAD: Shall we begin by acknowl-edging that ''The Phantom of the Opera'' never did make sense?
LEAD: THE FAST MEN By Tom McNab. 345 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

LEAD: The musical and procrea-tive fecundity of the Bach family is legendary, but it is often assumed to have begun with the most celebrated Bach of all: Johann Sebastian. The fact is, however, that there were Bachs in the music business well before J. S. was so much as a tune in his parents' sketchbook.

LEAD: While the situation in the occupied territories continues to deteriorate, neither the Palestinians nor the Israelis can or will make the first genuine move toward reconciliation. Only strong action from Washington can end the violence.
LEAD: The Senate's two leading experts on immigration policy have agreed on a new bill that would make major changes in the system for deciding who can legally immigrate to the United States.

LEAD: The engagement of Vivianne Susan Filmer to Roger Leigh Anderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas W. Anderson of Rochester, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Filmer of Cary, N.C., and Bay Head, N.J. The couple plan to marry in May.
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 7 misstated the number of condominiums in Scrimshaw House now under construction in Yonkers. It will have 138 units.

LEAD: Since AIDS was recognized as a disease in the United States in 1981, it has appeared in three-quarters of the world's countries, about 160 nations in all, according to the World Health Organization.

LEAD: The first new apartment building on Riverside Drive in 35 years was designed to look 35 years old. Though the 21-story condominium now rising at 94th Street will not attempt to match the weathered appearance of the venerable structures to either side, it will use the same materials. An Indiana limestone base will give way to Norman brick.

LEAD: The engagement of Pamela Stacey Marcus to Jeffrey Allan Erksine, a son of Phyllis E. Small of New York and the late Victor Erskine, has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Dianne Wallace of New York and Alan J. Marcus of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: As a Brooklyn Dodger fan living in the Bronx I did my best for the Duke against the Say Hey Kid and the Mick. But now, looking back, I'd have to rate my man third behind Willie (number one) and Mickey (a close second). NORMAN KRASNE Mount Vernon, N.Y.

LEAD: THE PAPERCLIP CONSPIRACY The Hunt for the Nazi Scientists By Tom Bower. 309 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: Workmen are putting finishing touches on the new marble in the lobby of the turn-of-the-century Leonori, at the southeast corner of 63d and Madison Avenue, a building whose successive alterations document both the history of the multiple dwelling and of the Upper East Side.
LEAD: FAY, a murderous nurse, urges a widower, McLeavy, whose wife has been dead three days, to remarry at once, granting that a fortnight, perhaps, is ''a decent interval of mourning.''

LEAD: Boxers are not one of the groups known to be at heightened risk of contracting AIDS. Nevertheless, over the last year, British boxing authorities have screened foreign boxers for acquired immune deficiency syndrome, New Jersey authorities have mandated plastic gloves for all cornermen, and the medical advisory board to the New York State Athletic Commission has recommended that all boxers and ring personnel undergo tests for the virus.
LEAD: CAPTIVITY CAPTIVE By Rodney Hall. 214 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, asserting that British-style parliamentary democracy is not adequate for the country's long-term needs, is proposing a new electoral system in which voters in some constituencies will choose teams of legislators rather than single candidates.

LEAD: Q. Recently I moved into a house that has a sunroom with a slate floor. I suspect that the previous owners had kept pets in this room because there is a strong odor of urine, especially when the windows are closed. I scrubbed the floor with a strong household detergent and the odor is not as strong, but it is still there.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Cyril E. Rance of Hamilton, Bermuda, have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Lee Rance to Peter Francis Dunne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Dunne of Garden City, L.I. The couple plan to wed Sept. 24.
LEAD: WOODCUTTERS By Thomas Bernhard. Translated by David McLintock. 181 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

LEAD: As a former Connecticut pastor, I have struggled with the same concerns as Mr. Brinton, and he has my sympathy. However, in his concluding remarks, he obscures what is at issue by turning the problem in upon himself. A pastor's poverty or relative poverty is useful in biblical terms only if it has symbolic import: effectively positing the need for an otherwordly ethic in a too worldly society.

LEAD: THIS summer when J. Russell King of New York and his mother, Mary Ann King of Ardmore, Okla., fly to London on vacation, they will take different airlines and land at separate airports. Mrs. King will take Delta at no cost; her coupon was a Christmas gift from a son-in-law who travels in his work and had points to share.

LEAD: The Soviet Union, in an apparent hardening of its position at the Geneva arms talks, has asked the United States to agree to limit the number of sea-launched cruise missiles that are armed with conventional warheads, according to Administration officials.

LEAD: ''JEWELRY plays a greater role in today's world than it ever did in the past,'' Oppi Untracht observed a few years ago in the introduction to his comprehensive volume ''Jewelry: Concepts and Technology.''

LEAD: THE smallest and the largest piece on Friday's program of piano duos at Avery Fisher Hall was the Schubert F-minor Fantasy. It is the work a serious Schubertian longs to hear at such a concert, but almost dreads seeing there.

LEAD: Who was better, Mantle or Mays? The answer is ungrammatically obvious. Both of them. KEN MACKENZIE Guilford, Conn.

LEAD: Problems with the heat-resistant material that protects the nozzles of the space shuttle's booster rocket should be corrected before the next shuttle flight scheduled for August, according to an internal report being reviewed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
LEAD: To the Editor: I was surprised by the first-aid piece by Betsy Wade (Practical Traveler, Dec. 20) in which she recommended using tweezers or a needle to remove sea urchin spines from your skin.

LEAD: What ever hap-pened to melody in popular music? I'm not talking about tunes - hummable little ditties with short catch phrases - but a fluid, cohesive theme of at least 16 bars in which no musical phrase is repeated. Richard Rodgers's ''Some Enchanted Evening'' has such a melody. As it flows along, moving through rich, unforced chromatic harmonies, its indelibility can't be explained by the hammering home of a formula.

LEAD: Audiophiles wishing to exercise their egos and perform other salutary tasks can do so by adding an equalizer to their sound systems. These increasingly popular devices enable you to countermand von Karajan - or any other recorded conductor - in matters of tonal balance. How's that for self-assertiveness?

LEAD: Bring in another pot of tulips, daffodils, crocus or hyacinths from the coldframe or pit and force them into bloom indoors; keep the soil moist, but the pots cool until leaves form, then provide full sun when flower buds appear. Don't delay mailing orders to nurseries for new trees and shrubs, plants, seeds and supplies.

LEAD: New Yorkers are never long deprived of the chance to hear top-notch pianists perform, with at least two or three usually scheduled somewhere in town each week. The next several days, however, provide an especially fine opportunity to hear a range of established and up-and-coming young players, both as soloists with orchestra and in recital.

LEAD: A SMILING young couple pose above the caption ''They Found Each Other Through the Personal Ads,'' and each time I notice them, I wonder if they are merely some editor's fiction, extended from the fantasies reflected in the ads themselves.

LEAD: I was reading Linda Wells's article about Charles Palmer, ''Big Man in the Kitchen'' (Dec. 13). Mr. Palmer was making me feel right good about cooking in general and New York cooking in particular, until I ran up on his disparaging remark about one of the genuine delicacies of this world: catfish.

LEAD: A private organization asked the Government Friday to sharply restrict the use of a widely used intravenous sedative that the group says has been associated with 40 deaths in its two years of use.

LEAD: Sue Hubbell, a beekeeper and writer, and Frank Arne Sieverts, the spokesman for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, were married yesterday in Washington. The Rev. William A. Wendt, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Community of Hagar.

What Miss Scotto gave in response to these whoops and yells of approval was approximately what she always has.

LEAD: I SAW Byron Bay for the first time three years ago. I was driving north on the coastal highway from Sydney to Brisbane with my wife. The rain had stopped just beyond the town of Ballina, where the highway snakes inland toward the foothills of the northern coastal ranges. By the time we were west of Byron Bay, the iron-gray wedge of cloud had lifted to let the sun cast its warm, early evening light across the undulating grasslands to the flat brown marshes and pale dunes on the ocean's edge.

LEAD: FLOODED. The word brings to mind torrential downpours building to such awesome proportions that entire roads, submerged underwater, are temporarily lost from sight. That's a word picture that for many people comes to mind with the mention of the word.

LEAD: The Practical Traveler column on page 3 in some copies of the Travel section today misstates airline policy on frequent flier programs. Points cannot be shared among family members belonging to an airline's program, although the coupons awarded at fixed point levels can be.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''People hate to stand in line, and they especially hate standing in a banking line at lunchtime,'' said LeRoy M. Richey, explaining one of the reasons for The Bank of New York's new part-time teller program.

LEAD: October's market crash may have humbled some Masters of the Universe, as Tom Wolfe calls the movers and shakers in his recent New York novel, but not the owners of a brown Rolls-Royce Corniche convertible seen the other day on East 61st Street. Such a car sells for about $184,000, so a certain audacity emanates from the vanity license plate.

LEAD: A NASSAU COUNTY project to reserve land adjacent to Kaintuck Brook, a privately owned brook in Matinecock, for stream desilting and a detention area, has taken residents by surprise and has met with serious environmental concerns.
LEAD: The Soviet Union today blamed the United States for the ''military provocation'' in which two American Navy vessels and Soviet warships bumped in the Black Sea on Friday.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: IN the Georgia countryside north of Atlanta, in the town of Kennesaw, there's a piece of rustic property 50 acres or so in size. Tucked away among the trees on that property are a pond, a swimming pool, a tennis court - and a pitcher's mound. On that mound the past week has stood the man who owns the property, and Bruce Sutter wasn't standing on it just to survey his domain.
LEAD: JUST as a gypsy moth infestation that has plagued Connecticut since the late 1970's is moving out of the eastern part of the state, a new swarm seems to be moving into Fairfield County.

LEAD: Branchburg Township $144,000 59 Station Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; 2-car detached garage, patio, dining room; taxes $1,243. Livingston $435,000 12 Homestead Terrace 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old colonial; den, C/A, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $5,266.

LEAD: Clare Middleton Luce and Clifford Louis Abbey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Abbey of Sweet Home, Ore., plan to marry in April, the parents of the bride-to-be, Margarget H. Howe of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Peter P. Luce of Boulder, Colo., have announced.

LEAD: WHEN I became editor of a weekly newspaper in Bridgehampton last May, there was a letter on my desk from Norman Kean's office in New York congratulating me. I didn't know why this busy producer of ''Oh! Calcutta!'' and other plays was taking an interest in me or the paper.

LEAD: A COMMON ROOM: Essays 1954-1987. By Reynolds Price. (Atheneum, $23.95.) Most writers know something about their motives, though few are as impassioned - or as expansive - as Reynolds Price is in sharing them. Indeed, in many of these 57 essays by the acclaimed author of ''Kate Vaiden'' and other novels, the treacherous business of examining artistic intent - in his own writing as well as in others' - is managed with considerable grace.

LEAD: To the Editor: I appreciated the Dec. 27 ''Following the Sun'' feature with emphasis on the Brazil discoveries of Paraty and Sao Jose da Coroa Grande. I lived in Brazil for two and a half years and am familiar with both areas. They are ideal for the American who wishes to see parts of Brazil that the ordinary tourist would not see.
LEAD: Leon Goossens, an oboist who helped refine the instrument's potential and inspired composers to write music to showcase it, died Friday night at the age 90, his family said today.

LEAD: CAUTIOUS and keeping commitments may be the most used descriptions for Governor O'Neill's 1988-89 budget proposal. But conservation groups are calling the spending plan historic in its generosity.
LEAD: MONEY AND CLASS IN AMERICA Notes and Observations on Our Civil Religion. By Lewis H. Lapham. 244 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $18.95.

LEAD: A DECADE ago, I spent every summer Sunday on the beach and every winter Sunday searching for the perfect eggs Benedict at restaurant brunches. Those were the days of Long Island's brunch craze, when even the most unlikely restaurants offered these midday melanges.

LEAD: In a career spanning almost exactly the same seasons, Hank Aaron won twice as many r.b.i. titles and as many batting titles as Mantle, Mays and Snider combined. He accomplished this while winning as many home run titles as any of the celebrated triumvirate.
LEAD: An article on Jan. 17 about northern California oysters characterized oysters incorrectly. They are mollusks.

LEAD: Where Mays prevails is in mythology. He has been raised to a level where poets sing his heroics, where fathers brag to sons about having seen him. Mantle is frozen as a good ol' boy, fronting a saloon, buddy to Martin and Ford, running to fat in public.

LEAD: The young woman in Gdynia, on the Baltic coast, recounted how her father, a former close associate of Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, had left Poland with the rest of the family, complaining that there was no future.

LEAD: Black students occupying a University of Massachusetts building for the second day canceled a meeting this morning with the chancellor to discuss their demands that the school act against campus racism.

LEAD: A three-story brick building at 876 Jefferson Avenue, completed last month, offers the first six condominiums in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, beating out two other nearby projects for that distinction by a few months. But when Del Dellal, a partner in MFD Holding Ltd., purchased the vacant building at a city auction in 1986, he was rejected by several banks for financing and had to finance the $280,000 project himself.

LEAD: Bus drivers and mechanics overwhelmingly approved a contract proposal Friday night to end an 11-day strike that had left 90,000 daily riders without public transportation. The Queen City Metro transit system hoped to restore bus service by Sunday morning.
LEAD: The landmark Manhattan building that once housed the High School of the Performing Arts was destroyed in a five-alarm fire early yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''EXCUSE me, ma'am, do you know how to get to Carnegie Hall?''

LEAD: What do ''King Kong'' (1933), ''The Letter'' (1940) and ''Lost Horizon'' (1937) have in common besides quality? Three of the best Hollywood scores ever written, so snugly integrated they're easy to take for granted. Lend an ear this week.
LEAD: A suit against the magazine Soldier of Fortune, brought by the family of the victim of a hired killer, will be heard in Federal District Court here next week.

LEAD: At St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington, Kimberly Anne Timmons, a daughter of William E. Timmons of Washington and Jeane Lovegrove Stone of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., was married yesterday to Thomas Fenner Gibson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gibson Jr. of Indianapolis. The Rev. Francis Wade performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Mantle's injuries are legend, but Snider's were just as debilitating. Mays has to emerge as the best because his prime lasted longest. LEE DEJASU Rehoboth, Mass.

LEAD: WHEN Vice President Bush was asked the evening of the Iowa caucuses last week how his surprisingly poor third-place finish would affect his political fortunes in the New Hampshire primary day after tomorrow, he had a ready answer.
LEAD: Because James LeMoyne wrote at considerable length on Nicaragua in his article on Costa Rican President Oscar Arias, I am compelled to respond to two inaccuracies.
LEAD: The battle for the heart of Republican conservatives here has turned into a blood feud between Representative Jack F. Kemp of New York and Pat Robertson, the former television evangelist.

LEAD: Thomas M. Peters, a former Arizona state legislator who succeeded in several businesses and then turned his attention to charities for children, died Tuesday at the Venice (Fla.) Hospital. He was 99 years old.

LEAD: AFTER two months of rancorous debate, political backbiting and a dispute over who could vote, residents of this fast-growing town have resoundingly rejected a proposal to build a $1.25 million town hall.
LEAD: DAY after day, Bill Willoughby waits for the telephone to ring and the voice on the other end to offer him a new chance to play professional basketball.

LEAD: Q. Recently I moved into a house that has a sunroom with a slate floor. I suspect that the previous owners had kept pets in this room because there is a strong odor of urine, especially when the windows are closed. I scrubbed the floor with a strong household detergent and the odor is not as strong, but it is still there.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An eating club for Princeton University upperclassmen suspended the serving of alcoholic beverages this week after a 19-year-old student nearly drank himself to death at the club's annual initiation party.
LEAD: A DECADE ago, outplacement firms saw relatively few women. But as more women reach senior management posts, where outplacement counseling is a company-paid benefit, that is changing.

LEAD: The print, more than the painting, has been the chosen medium for political and social comment by artists. Traditionally, it's had a wider audience, and it's closer to the printed word. In recent years, though, we've been trained to view prints as more related to painting, alternate means for the artful expression of forms and colors.

LEAD: BY now we know with some certainty what to expect of the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Ring,'' the third installment of which was delivered Friday night with the premiere of ''Siegfried.'' As in the previous productions of this evolving cycle, the emphasis remained firmly on traditional Wagnerian staging.

LEAD: Shifting market conditions can move buildings in mysterious ways. Take the case of 110 East 55th Street, where the developer of a 19-story office project that has been sitting vacant since it opened half a year ago is pondering plans to convert it into a hotel.
LEAD: Congress resumes work on a complex trade bill next week, giving it high priority but confronting events pulling members in opposite directions.
LEAD: THE sprawling car plant stands abandoned, and outside the factory gate picketing workers cluster around an oil-drum fire, smoking and talking, as the police keep watch from a nearby van.

LEAD: WEARING a white hat with a brim as wide as his smile, a white scarf and a navy blue overcoat, Lyle Nelson carried the American flag yesterday as he led the United States team into McMahon Stadium for the opening ceremony of the XV Olympic Winter Games.
LEAD: EVEN before Oct. 19, the barrage of pink slips had begun on Wall Street, and the new year is expected to bring widespread dismissals on the Street and beyond.

LEAD: Jennifer Lynn Davis and Philip Michael Wilson, both members of the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater, plan to marry in May, the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. Eleanor Morin Davis and Dr. Harold L. Davis of New York have announced. Miss Davis studied at the Joffrey Ballet School in New York. Her fiance, a son of Mr.
LEAD: Derrick Chievous scored 26 points and Byron Irvin added 17 as Missouri held off a second-half comeback today and upset seventh-ranked Nevada-Las Vegas, 81-79.

LEAD: In 1937, F. Scott Fitzgerald was 40 years old and in need of quick cash. His best-known work, ''The Great Gatsby,'' was 12 years behind him; perhaps he sensed that death, then three years away, was closing in. In any case, Fitzgerald produced a short story that year, titled ''A Full Life,'' that was shot through with uncharacteristic black humor.

LEAD: Jacqueline Dejud will return to her native Panama this spring with a bachelor's degree in business and a desire to ''find work, to help my family, and to improve, as much as I can, my country as well.''

LEAD: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Bugaku'' is very peculiar. It often looks cliche-ridden, even corny. But the cliches turn into surprises, and even the corniest scene has a serious point. ''Bugaku'' was as fascinating as ever when the New York City Ballet danced it Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Cannell of New York and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Ann Cannell, to Rainer Gross, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Heinrich E. Gross of Cologne, West Germany.

LEAD: In the 1988 Presidential campaign, with its crowded field and surfeit of debates, about the last thing anyone expected was to have a deficit of candidates for a Republican debate three days before the New Hampshire primary.

LEAD: The Fish and Wildlife Service added 59 species to the list of endangered and threatened species last year, the second-highest number ever, the service has reported. The most ever added was 68, in 1979.

LEAD: William J. Ruane of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Elizabeth Arnold Ruane, to Michael Briggs Barrett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman K. Barrett of Berwyn, Pa. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: THEY are talking about going to college now, and some are even planning their careers.
LEAD: SLEIGH RIDE FESTIVAL

LEAD: THEY'RE KNOWN, TECHNICAL-ly, as ''tension membrane structures.'' But officials of World Expo 88, which opens in Brisbane, Australia, on April 30, call them ''sun sails,'' which seems appropriate; the theme of Expo 88 is, after all, ''Leisure in the Age of Technology.'' Made of a polyester fabric, the eight translucent canopies, each about 390 feet in diameter and together sheltering a ground area of close to 360,000 square feet, form the most striking architectural feature of the exposition site.

LEAD: Security Deposit Question: For several years we received interest on the security deposit for the apartment we rent. This year we received notification that the interest had been withheld due to the Interest and Dividend Tax Compliance Act of 1983. Can you tell me what this act is and why we did not get interest this year?

LEAD: The marriage of Constance Ann Ix, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander F. Ix Jr. of Spring Lake, N.J., and John's Island, Vero Beach, Fla., to Andrew Soren Pedersen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Pedersen of Cedar Grove, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

LEAD: 9 Flew Over the Osprey's Nest LOOKING like the American soldiers raising the flag at Iwo Jima, the nine East Hampton nature lovers struggled to raise a 20-foot-long telephone pole with an odd-shaped frame attached to the top.
LEAD: NEVER PASS THIS WAY AGAIN By Gene LePere. 296 pp. Bethesda, Md.: Adler & Adler. $17.95.
LEAD: Raw sewage was being pumped into Beverly Harbor at the rate of about 500,000 gallons an hour today because of a break in an underwater pipeline, officials said.

LEAD: Catherine Bates Mckenzie and Donald Campbell Bowman Jr., 1987 graduates of the University of Georgia School of Law, plan to marry in May. Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Mckenzie of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bowman of Columbus, Ga. The future bride's father is president of the Japan/Canada, Australasia/Pacific Group of Sterling Drug in New York.
LEAD: To avoid embarrassing questions, New Zealand marked Waitangi Day, its national day, this week with as little fanfare as possible.

LEAD: An investigation into the use of city money by a museum in Queens has ended without criminal charges, according to a spokeswoman for the Manhattan District Attorney's office, which conducted the inquiry.

LEAD: Some things are inexplicably magical. One is ''Goodnight Moon,'' the children's book by Margaret Wise Brown, wonderfully illustrated by Clement G. Hurd and brought back to mind by news of his recent death.

LEAD: Those who intend to buy a vacation home that would raise the total mortgage debt on a first and second home to more than $1 million, or are buying a primary residence needing more than $1 million in financing, will be limited by the Federal Government on the total loan amount eligible for tax deductions.
LEAD: TOO often, Trenton ''talks'' and the public does not hear.
LEAD: The Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration has cited the Portland office of the American Red Cross for not adequately protecting its employees from blood-borne diseases.

LEAD: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's 1992 re-election campaign is already under way - or, at least, fund raising for it is. The New York Republican has set up two finance committees, D'Amato in '92 and Friends of Senator D'Amato '92, that have so far raised $771,000, according to Arthur W. Jaspan, the Garden City, L.I., lawyer who is the D'Amato campaign treasurer.

LEAD: Announcement of the engagement of M. Michele Smith to Adam R. Blackwood has been made by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Leon G. Smith of Essex Falls, N.J. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: A newfound optimism is flowering amid the rugged tangle of shrub and desert in southwestern Zimbabwe.

LEAD: Older Drivers Question: I understand that Ireland has a limit of 70 years old on drivers renting cars. Are there such limitations in other European countries? - B. K., Ambler, Pa. - Answer: Drivers over age 70 can rent a car in Ireland. It is true that some auto rental companies there (not Ireland itself) set an age limit of 69 or 70, but the two largest agencies, which are both represented in the United States, do not.

Not surprisingly, the 25-year-old Princeon, N.J., international master was awarded the $100 Craig

LEAD: Two health physicists who complained about the safety of a nuclear reactor at the Georgia Institute of Technology have been dismissed by school officials, who said the moves were part of a program to improve safety and productivity.

LEAD: RECENT issues highlight major events of the past 50 years. Last November, the Arab nation released three stamps with a theme ''International Day of Solidarity with the Palestinian People.'' A previous set of three spread the message, ''Al-Quds (Jerusalem) is an Arab City.''

LEAD: FLYING Huey helicopters for the Jamaica Defense Forces might best be described as ''hours of tedium, moments of sheer terror,'' Dudley Stokes says, but steering a bobsled down a hillside lives up to his innermost need to ''let go.''

LEAD: After a campaign marked by a surprising level of anti-government protests, the cyclical ritual of Paraguay's ''democracy without Communism'' climaxes Sunday with the election of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner to an eighth presidential term.

LEAD: Two months ago, they took away Bob Froese's goal, thereby erasing his barely dry name from the record books. Shortly afterward, he had his regular spot in the Rangers' goaltending rotation revoked and since then his name has rarely been penciled into the lineup.

Kavesh of New York, have announced.

LEAD: PEPPERCORN GRILL in Hartford is just what the ravenous diner ordered. Slipping easily into the high-ceilinged storefront space formerly occupied by Panache, this sparkling new eatery has high-voltage visual impact. Its white walls hold etchings, paintings and bright neon sculptures counterpointed by red chairs and park benches and track lighting in a black ceiling.
LEAD: A five-year fund-raising campaign by Columbia University has raised $600 million, $200 million more than the original goal.

LEAD: With his father looking on, Maurice Williamson, son of John Williamson, the former guard for the Nets, set a Connecticut schoolboy record yesterday in New Haven when he scored 78 points as Wilbur Cross High beat Westbury (L.I.) High School, 108-92.
LEAD: Public television should ''restate and clarify the social dilemma and the political pickle.''

LEAD: President Francesco Cossiga tonight ordered Giovanni Goria, who resigned as Prime Minister on Wednesday, to again seek the confidence of a Parliament that has repeatedly defeated him. The President cited the need for Parliament to pass ''indispensable'' budget legislation.

LEAD: The answer is clearly defined by my recent issue of a baseball card collector's price digest which is the bible of the east coast. Mantle is worth $2,000+. Mays is worth $700+.

LEAD: IN 1936, when the Union Pacific Railroad began developing the mountain valleys around Ketchum, Idaho, into America's first alpine ski resort, engineers were given a daunting challenge: how to transport skiers to the top of the mountain, so they could then savor the thrill of rushing back down.

LEAD: A bill to ban sexual activity in about 200 city buildings as a means of fighting sexual harassment of female employees has drawn some ridicule, but the sponsor says the issue needs to be addressed.

LEAD: THE prison psychologist at the Edna Mahan (formerly Clinton) Correctional Facility for Women freely admits that he laughed when inmates told him a year ago that they intended to design a child-abuse-prevention program that would win a coveted grant from the New Jersey Children's Trust Fund.

Ms. Carroll, a mechanical engineer with General Motors Corporation in Tarrytown, N.Y., graduated from the Columbia University School of Engineering.

LEAD: It is still possible to hear a rooster crow at dawn or midnight in Puerto Vallarta, but one must listen carefully. The city is on the go almost nonstop, especially from now until Easter. Streets are jammed with cars, trucks and shoppers in the daytime. Restaurants and bars are open late; 10 P.M. is a respectable time for supper.

LEAD: An answer in the Q&A column on Jan. 17 gave an incorrect date for the Stefan Batory's last scheduled voyage. The ship, owned by Polish Ocean Lines, set sail in January for a Caribbean cruise, which ends in March.

LEAD: CAN ONE be realistic about the arts and still make money? Yes. The New Jersey Department of Labor's Division of Vocational Rehabilitation Services is a career-networking providing system that is designed to help the disabled find employment in the arts and promote the products of the division's clients.

LEAD: Few residents were impressed in January when the largest owner of this town's dormant power plant filed for bankruptcy protection. What caused a stir instead was the release of a 300-page report saying that the plant might be unsafe because of drug and alcohol abuse among workers and that the plant's management tried to hide the problem.

LEAD: For years, the 1,250-seat Stanford Theater, like so many movie palaces of the Art Deco era, has been unable to justify itself economically. Its future, some thought, was as a shopping mall.

LEAD: Billy Wilder is to receive the Irving G. Thalberg Award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Oscar night, April 11. The award honors a body of work that ''reflects a consistently high quality of motion picture production.''

LEAD: Peter Schiller's backhand goal with 7 minutes 1 second left to play lifted West Germany to a 2-1 upset over Czechoslovakia at the Saddledome today in the first athletic competition of the Winter Olympics.
LEAD: More than $2 billion worth of top-grade heroin bound for New York has been intercepted in what was believed to be the largest single seizure of the drug, the authorities said today.
LEAD: All this week, Japan's Parliament was brought to a standstill because an influential member rejected one of this country's most cherished social graces, an apology.

LEAD: In his article ''An AIDS Nightmare'' (Jan. 17), John B. Judis reported on the moving case of Jewel Foster Lyles, a pregnant woman with the AIDS virus who was murdered. Emergency workers cited their ''right to know'' whether they had been exposed to the virus and called for full use of the criminal law to punish those who intentionally try to transmit AIDS.

LEAD: ACCORDING to 15th- and 16th-century diaries, Valentines were not cards but people upon whom such elaborate gifts as jewelry were bestowed. Gradually the gifts became less expensive, and by the late 17th century, cards began to replace gifts, according to Christine Ermenc, a spokeswoman for the Connecticut Historical

LEAD: A guest of an Embassy Suites hotel under construction in Parsippany, N.J., will see more than trees and waterfalls when he leaves his room. Across the landscaped atrium, doors to all 273 other two-room suites will be visible beyond the circular walkways. The low-slung, 260,000 square foot building will rise only five stories but stretch the equivalent of three city blocks.
LEAD: TIMOTHY WEST receives about 12,000 complaints a year as head of the Complaint Center at the Department of Consumer Protection.

LEAD: Three singers will make their Metropolitan Opera debuts on Feb. 22 when Mussorgsky's opera ''Khovanshchina'' is performed for the first time since the 1985-86 season. The singers are Elizabeth Knighton, soprano; Stefania Toczyska, mezzo-soprano, and Timothy Noble, baritone. Others in the cast include Wieslaw Ochman, Denes Gulyas, Aage Haugland and Martti Talvela.
LEAD: CAMELS are wondrous creatures.

LEAD: PACK up winter worries. The season's woes melt away for one brief week in February. Lovers are celebrating today with flowers and candy; shoppers are reving up for Presidents' Day sales; travelers are heading to New Orleans for Mardi Gras, and serious eaters are in training for Chinese New Year feasts.

LEAD: ''JUST when one least expects it, the unexpected always happens.'' So observes Dr. Rance, an investigator ''from the mental branch of the government,'' who has come to check up on Dr. Prentice's private psychiatric clinic, a place where madness, according to Mrs. Prentice, is not cured but liberated and exploited.

LEAD: Televising an Olympic Games is only slighlty less complicated than staging one. ABC, which televised both the Winter and Summer Games in 1984, has moved 17 tractor trailers of equipment to Calgary and plans 90 or so hours of programming, beginning last Saturday through Feb. 28. Because of Calgary's Mountain Time zone location, most of ABC's coverage will be live.

LEAD: Guerrillas attacked a white farmer's house with rockets and firearms early today, then fled across the border into Zimbabwe, the Government said.

LEAD: MANY of us can recall, probably before the enthusiasm of youth gave way to the settled habits of middle age, playing rubber bridge or Chicago for most of the night and perhaps for longer periods. Some 40 years ago this writer played non-stop for 34 hours, in a tournament, a hotel bedroom, a train and a club, before succumbing to sleep.

LEAD: THE first time Robert R. Glauber saw room 1116 at the Federal Reserve building in New York, it depressed him. That day in early November the big room where he would spend the next two months had one chair in it, one desk and one telephone.
LEAD: JUNG A Biography. By Gerhard Wehr. Translated by David M. Weeks. Illustrated. 549 pp. Boston: Shambhala. $25.
LEAD: A Rutgers University freshman died early Friday morning after a fraternity party, and the chief investigator in the case said the party ''involved a serious amount of drinking.''

LEAD: Though Vice President Bush lost in Iowa last week, he scored an easy win in the race to get on the ballot for New York's April 19 primary. Unfortunately, it's a victory over democracy. New York's nit-picking election law forces Presidential candidates to spend inordinate time and money collecting petition signatures for delegates.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Louis Millman of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Millman, to Roger Conant Faxon, a son of Frances Parker Faxon of Concord, Mass., and the late William Faxon. The couple plan to marry May 1.

LEAD: RUBY SHANG, a modern-dance choreographer with many unusual ideas, has now come up with a theatrical work that features an unusually erotic central duet, a leading Butoh artist from Japan and a marriage of concepts that might normally appear incompatible.
LEAD: Mark Tillmon scored 19 points and Charles Smith added 17 today as Georgetown rallied twice for a 71-69 Big East Conference victory over Syracuse.

LEAD: HOW MANY SALAD BOWLS or toaster ovens or salt and pepper shakers does a just-married couple need? Usually, one is enough. To avoid receiving duplicates of such useful (and obvious) gifts, a growing number of couples are registering for china, crystal, silver and household objects at local department and gift stores.

LEAD: To the Editor: In many parts of the world where sea urchins and humans are apt to collide, ammonia is the antidote of choice. Betsy Wade might not have been aware of this since each community assumes ammonia is a local remedy and most do not have access to the bottled household variety, making the subject somewhat delicate for an

LEAD: Deborah Ann Haszko, a staff nurse at the primary medical clinic at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, and Nicholas Shulgach, the founder and president of Aplogica Inc., a computer research and development consulting company in Manhattan, plan to be married in June. Miss Haszko is a daughter of Mr.

LEAD: James Hargrove remembers the time he saw a robbery in progress in Manhattan. As a police officer, he wanted to jump out of his patrol car. As a black man in civilian clothes, carrying a weapon, he knew better.

LEAD: Some years ago, i was fascinated to learn that an ambitious British composer had chosen as a theme thoughts from Ludwig Wittgenstein's ''Tractatus Logico-philosophicus,'' one of the most brilliantly arcane works in the history of linguistics. For all I know, many musicians who were also professional philosophers took it into their repertories, but I never heard of it again.
LEAD: More than 80,300 acres on Cape Cod, nearly a third of its estimated land mass, is now protected from developers' bulldozers.
LEAD: IT was ''Meet the Teacher'' night in our district - an annual open house throughout the country, but in our very upscale junior high school, an event attended by a large percentage of parents.
LEAD: THE WEDDING CAKE WAS ORIGI-nally conceived as a table decoration.
LEAD: With the help of modern-day technology, a small band of exiles is piercing the censorship in Panama.

LEAD: AS CHAIRMAN and chief executive of the Allied Stores Corporation, Thomas M. Macioce spent much of his time in the company's Manhattan headquarters, meeting only occasionally with the chiefs of his 22 store divisions around the country. Austere and autocratic, Mr. Macioce kept a tight rein on operations from afar, handing down orders to the field through a layer of seven group executives.

LEAD: Somebody once de-fined literature as anything that was worth reading twice. On the same principle, you might say that any movie worth seeing twice qualifies as a classic - in which case, I am duty-bound to claim classic status for ''Moonstruck.'' Seeing it just after it had opened, and knowing nothing about it, I was enchanted.

LEAD: THE INCREDIBLE ESKIMO Life Among the Barren Land Eskimo. By Raymond de Coccola and Paul King. Photographs. Illustrations by James Houston. 435 pp. Surrey, B.C.: Hancock House Publishers. Paper, $14.95.
LEAD: IT HAS been estimated that 23 million people in the United States are illiterate and that 35 million others can barely read.

LEAD: GOTTA HAVE HEART Just in case the calendar failed to make its mark, today is Valentine's Day and some libraries are celebrating in noncaloric fashion, mostly saying it with music. For example, in Oyster Bay, at the library at 89 East Main Street, there's a concert at 3 P.M. of love songs and sentimental ditties, courtesy of Dayle, while down the road a bit, at the Manhasset Library, 30 Onderdonk Avenue, also at 3 P.M., the mezzo-soprano Susan Wagner, the soprano Teresa Arrigo and the tenor-baritone Ben Arrigo use tunes by Mozart, Brahms, Puccini, Gershwin and Rodgers and
LEAD: I have just read the indignant complaint of Benjamin J. Stein, an apparently honest man tilting with the windmills of greed, and I have to laugh (''Leveraged Buyouts: On the Level?'' Jan. 17).

LEAD: THE MORE THINGS CHANGE, the more they stay the same. Almost. The formal, traditional wedding is back, in many cases with unprecedented lavishness. Even second weddings are more festive today. But rather than following a standard script, more brides and grooms are putting their personal stamp on the wedding ceremony and reception.

LEAD: Jackie Joyner-Kersee jumped farther than ever tonight at the annual Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational track and field meet, far enough to claim an American record in the long jump, 23 feet 1/2 inch.
LEAD: After three consecutive losses to Big East Conference opponents, St. John's found a team it could beat yesterday. And, oh, how the Redmen beat Providence.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Officials of the Boy Scouts of America have voted to allow women in leadership positions, including scoutmaster, ending a male-only policy that has often been challenged in court, organization officials say.

LEAD: It seems to me that just because we do not understand how alcohol lowers the cardiac death rate is no reason not to recommend it. After all, it took over 200 years for us to understand how digoxin helps the heart. Furthermore, Dr. Bennett might have mentioned that there are several other epidemiologic studies that show that the overall death rate, cardiac as well as noncardiac, is reduced by moderate alcohol intake.
LEAD: Donald J. Trump was back on the witness stand here this week to explain to the State Casino Control Commission his maneuvering to buy total control of Resorts International Inc.

LEAD: A curiosity of world politics is that many problems arise from military perceptions yet military adversaries seldom talk to each other. Diplomats talk, often to discuss matters well understood only by the warriors. Warriors, somehow, seem to talk directly only when the shooting stops. All of which explains why there's something encouraging afoot between American and

LEAD: WOODEN ballot boxes sit on virtually every store counter and orange-colored posters are taped on the windows. All around town, the people of Kent are studying the calendar, consulting their private muses and digging into their pockets for dollar bills.

LEAD: A cruise missile launched by an Iraqi aircraft passed close to an American warship in the Persian Gulf on Saturday night before veering away to explode on the horizon, according to the Defense Department and press reports from the scene.
LEAD: Among military leaders who have seized power in Africa, Maj. Gen. Harrington Bantubonke Holomisa is something of an exception to established patterns.
LEAD: Once there was a little girl who had a crush on a little boy. He had blue eyes, brown hair and trouble pronouncing ''th.'' Never mind: she loved him.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Our desire to avoid ostracizing AIDS patients should not deter us from practicing appropriate public-health measures. Although the risk of transmitting AIDS by touching a contaminated arrowhead must be exceedingly low, not to seal it in plastic would have been foolhardy.

LEAD: WHEN rumors hit Wall Street in late November that Richard A. Daynard, professor of law at Northeastern University, was about to disclose something embarrassing to the cigarette industry, it was enough to send the stocks of tobacco companies down 4 percent.
LEAD: I JUST can't get over how the freshmen are responding to Dr. Gerald G. Jampolksy book ''Love Is Letting Go of Fear,'' again this semester.

LEAD: Beth Daniel, who is trying to end a slump of two-and-a-half years, matched par 72 today in the third round of the Sarasota Classic to take a two-stroke lead into the final 18 holes of the $225,000 L.P.G.A. tournament.

LEAD: At last, some straight talk about a highly ambiguous subject by a responsible commentator (Body and Mind: ''The Drink-a-Day Lore,'' by William Ira Bennett, Jan. 10)! The flaws in the various studies that seem to demonstrate ''protective'' value in one or two drinks a day are not so subtle that the interested public could not understand them.

LEAD: Nine people were injured Friday when a bus carrying 26 West Point cadets crashed into a jackknifed tractor-trailer on icy Interstate 81 near Avoca, the authorities reported. The truck was blocking the southbound lanes of the highway when the bus struck it, the authorities said.

LEAD: WHEN Bob Kussman drops in for lunch at Jay's Cafe, down the road from the Farm Credit Services branch he manages in Keytesville, Mo., the greetings are a good bit warmer these days, and fewer eyes avoid his.

LEAD: A BIG WHOOP-DE-DO WED-ding is like most gala occasions today. Everyone involved can dress in any number of ways and look just fine. But a wedding does impose a few fashion parameters, some traditional and others contemporary. One universal: The bride sets the tone; this is her day. She can be swathed in clouds of tulle and trailing a train.
LEAD: An article on Jan. 17 about Rio de Janeiro misstated the correct pronunciation for chope, the Portuguese word for beer. It is pronounced SHOW-pee.

LEAD: The only family that can disappoint you more than your own is a network executive's vision of a family. Television betrayed us when it gave us the perfect 1950's families in which every daughter was a princess and every son an honest and brave all-American boy. Our parents could never measure up to the kindness and patience we saw dispensed on television, and yet it seemed they should.

LEAD: Alfonso Valdes Cobian, an industrialist, banker, sportsman, politician and member of one of the most prominent families in Puerto Rico, died Monday in San Juan after suffering a heart attack two days earlier. He was 98 years old.

LEAD: Five years ago, the archi-tectural energy of Texas seemed concentrated in one city, and it was not Dallas. This old and, by Texas standards, staid city could barely compete with the brashness of Houston, where towers popped into the sky at a mind-boggling rate, each one, it seemed, more flamboyant than the last.
LEAD: When barricades went up at Dorcester District Court, not to keep prisoners in but to protect passers-by from falling masonry, few people noticed.

LEAD: WHEN the action of a play takes place in a remote area of the north of England, it is a good clue that the play is in the mystery thriller genre. Unfortunately, as is the case with the Arena Players current show, ''A Gift of Murder,'' the genre is not always mysterious or thrilling.
LEAD: WHEN the state's utilities called on customers last month to cut back on the use of electricity, Judi C. Friedman and Elaine T. Moreland were at a loss.
LEAD: Political action committees say they are increasingly resentful of greedy lawmakers, yet go along with their demands for contributions for fear of losing vital access in Congress.

LEAD: The long countdown for Calgary that began more than six years ago reached its climax today as Jeanne Sauve, the Governor General of Canada and Queen Elizabeth's representative, declared open the XV Olympic Winter Games.
LEAD: IN a blistering manifesto, Panama's military last week demanded that the United States Southern Command be expelled from its headquarters here.
LEAD: A Federal judge has set bail at $1 million for a defendant who has been imprisoned for 30 months without an opportunity to be released while awaiting trial in a Wells Fargo robbery.

LEAD: SOME states prohibit sex discrimination in automobile and health insurance - for which women have usually paid more than men. Last year, the Massachusetts Insurance Commissioner issued a regulation barring sex bias in all forms of insurance - including life, for which women have usually paid less.

LEAD: ''If we look back at history, always when there is a tendency toward improvement in our relations we see some military provocation.'' Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman. [ 1:5. ]

LEAD: Lured by out-of-date house prices and a twin set of superhighways, growing numbers of New York and New Jersey residents are settling into dozens of small northeastern Pennsylvania communities stretching from the old mill town of Easton to the heart of honeymoon land in the Pocono mountains.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: More than ever before, the voters of New Hampshire have it in their power when they cast their ballots Tuesday to drive many of the Presidential contenders from the race forthwith. The reason is money. All but a few of the candidates are broke or in debt, before even a single primary vote has been cast.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 30 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: The evidence is getting stronger that the AIDS virus first simmered in Africa before it exploded into a worldwide epidemic. But whether the AIDS virus is a relatively recent mutation or an ancient germ that has resided in some humans for tens of thousands of years is a mystery.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: A rather large bone of contention has been formally settled in the dog-eat-dog world of high culture. Over the objections of some people who will now be his subordinates, Kirk Varnedoe, a professor at New York University's Institute of Fine Art, was named last week to succeed William S. Rubin as director of painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art.

LEAD: Wendell S. Merick, a retired correspondent for U.S. News & World Report, died of chronic liver disease Thursday at his home in Bethesda, Md.. He was 60 years old. Mr. Merick was a correspondent with the United Press, now United Press International. He also worked for The Boston Traveler. He joined U.S.
LEAD: SIXTY parking spaces and a few signposts are all that stand in the way of new Amtrak rail service at Yonkers, according to Amtrak officials and Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko of Yonkers.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Mondale of Minneapolis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Jane Mondale, to Keith Van Horne, a son of Jean Van Horne of Clarendon Hills, Ill., and the late John Van Horne. The couple plan to marry in April.

LEAD: Richard A. Gephardt and Paul Simon clawed at each other today in a fight for second place in the New Hampshire Democratic primary next Tuesday. They were battling despite the fact that since 1952 no one has been elected President without coming in first in the New Hampshire primary.

LEAD: IT was when I was walking into the lobby of one of New York's finest old hotels that I realized the world isn't small after all. I had just returned from summer vacation. The distance between the remote Irish coastal village where we have a holiday cottage and this gilded and brocaded interior was so vast that they seemed separated not only by an ocean but also by centuries.

LEAD: THE State Senate will form a special panel to look into the problems of the elderly. Officials said they were acting in the wake of a report last week that documented employment, transportation, housing and other issues affecting the aged.
LEAD: After a speech in a packed auditorium at Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter the other night, Senator Bob Dole turned to questions from the audience.

LEAD: I have recently analyzed a sample of 76 management buyouts of public companies, each worth at least $50 million. Post-buyout financial data were available for 42 of these companies. Several surprising results emerged.
LEAD: Recent Sales

LEAD: Hoses snaking from a fire truck yesterday morning at the scene of a five-alarm blaze at First Avenue and 53d Street on the Brooklyn waterfront. Some 200 firefighters worked over four hours to bring the blaze under control. Four businesses were in the building, but there was apparently no one inside at the time of the fire.

LEAD: Like other Greek sculptures of standing women, or korai, this figure is frontal, her left leg slightly in front of the right. Her face is fleshy, ripe, her expression both attentive and aloof. Unlike Greek sculptures of standing males, she is clothed, but she seems both more naked and more secret than male figures nearby.

LEAD: WHEN my new husband and I moved to Putnam County into our first house, a 200-year-old Colonial, it wasn't two weeks before the predictions started coming true. ''You'll see,'' family and friends had told us, smiling kindly but, I thought, a little grimly. They were all homeowners, these Cassandras.
LEAD: THE first television series to be shot entirely in New Jersey will make its debut next month on WWOR-TV, Channel 9, and its formula - like its locale - will be unusual.

LEAD: In an effort to show that its transactions with Richard A. Gephardt's Presidential campaign were legitimate, a Washington bank furnished documents today detailing $1.4 million in loans it made to the campaign last year.

LEAD: The article on the declining number of Catholic priests [ ''As Catholic Rolls Rise, Priests Diversify,'' Jan. 17 ] presents graphically a challenge that the church on Long Island and throughout the world should be addressing realistically.

LEAD: NEW JERSEY lawmakers have stockpiled more than $3.3 million in political contributions from corporations, unions, special-interest groups and individuals in anticipation of the 1988 elections, with more than half of it for Senator Frank R. Lautenberg's campaign.

LEAD: The sight of Mantle limping to home plate, of Mantle dripping blood down the right leg or fruitlessly chasing Roger Maris elevated a generation as he carried a team. The human frailty of his fatal flaws made Mantle a mythical hero and made baseball accessible to 10-year-old boys who would marvel at the Joe Hardy in pinstripes and wait for next year when the Mick would play a full season without being injured.

LEAD: Q. Recently I moved into a house that has a sunroom with a slate floor. I suspect that the previous owners had kept pets in this room because there is a strong odor of urine, especially when the windows are closed. I scrubbed the floor with a strong household detergent and the odor is not as strong, but it is still there.

LEAD: In a 10th-floor apartment of the Albany Houses, a housing project in Brooklyn, two dogs howled and scratched, itching to get at whoever was knocking at the door.

LEAD: THE antiques shop window, just off the Grande Place in the French city of Nancy, was filled with ceramics from many regions of France, but one particular platter captured the eye. LEAD: For as long as apparently anyone along the Maine coast can remember, mussels have not been popular among many shellfish eaters.
LEAD: A correction in this section on Jan. 10 misidentified the translator of Octavio Paz's Dec. 20 review of ''Mexican Churches.'' He is Roberto Tejada.

LEAD: One crisp fall day, while admiring the flora and fauna in Riverside Park, I was stopped by a woman who announced that we had attended the same kindergarten. She said a few kind words about a book of mine, all the while looking at me with such great concern that I assumed someone had told her I had 10 days to live.

LEAD: A TEAM of Rutgers University biochemical engineers has charged that New York City has failed to clean up a toxic landfill that is leaching hazardous waste into Jamaica Bay, which empties into the Hudson-Raritan estuary, possibly imperiling North Jersey marine fisheries.

LEAD: SOME companies justify the higher expense of a laser printer on a strict bottom-line analysis. A laser costing $2,000 or more can be shared by several personal computers and cough out material quickly enough to keep everybody happy - none of the waiting in line that slower shared printers create. On a per-user basis, that can eliminate the price advantage of daisy wheels and dot matrix printers.

LEAD: LIKE most high school girls, Kimberly Allen's schoolday atire tends to the casual -jeans, a sweatshirt and sneakers. As a freshman, though, she puzzled her friends by occasionally turning up at Darien High School in a blazer and skirt or a dress.

LEAD: THE dollar's drop in the international currency market is boosting the cost of photography. Since the year began, companies as geographically far apart as E. Leitz in West Germany and Nikon in Japan have raised the list prices of their cameras, lenses and accessories. Given that the dollar's fall has been especially steep against the German mark and Japanese yen, and that Germany and
LEAD: MUCH of this week's musical activity is to be found on college campuses around the state.

LEAD: KYOKO TAKEZAWA, who made her New York recital debut Thursday night at the 92d Street Y, has a familiar biography, if a rather more distinguished one than most. Born in Japan, she won prizes for violinists there before coming to the Aspen Music Festival in 1985 to work with Dorothy Delay. She has continued her studies at the Juilliard School with Miss Delay and Masao
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Chancellor Franz Vranitzky of Austria said today that he might resign if the furor raging around President Kurt Waldheim continued to prevent his Government from dealing with other problems.
LEAD: Vice President Bush, who has seen his once overwhelming lead in New Hampshire evaporate in a matter of days, tonight issued a cry for help in his struggle to salvage his Presidential candidacy.

LEAD: MOST world-class athletes work at their sport all the time, tweaking and tuning their skills, even on days off. Sailors are among them, taking advantage of winter's downtime to keep the heat on. You don't have to be as compulsive as the best, but you can pick up a few hints from them - enough to give you a head start on the summer racing season.

LEAD: Joe Hammad's long white Mercedes, paid for by his chain of liquor stores back in California, climbed the steep ancient paths with the plodding power of the goatherds being nudged aside by the returning son.
LEAD: A Federal district judge has ruled that naturalized American citizens have the same rights as other Americans to security clearances that give them access to government secrets.

LEAD: Skiers representing the United States at the Olympics will have a long way to go to top the performance of a group of youngsters who represented this country at the world junior championships. They won one gold medal, two silvers and a bronze, and an informal point count put the team way ahead of any of the other nations competing.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: EVER since their season ended on a cold, blustery day in early October, the Yankees have been doing the things they do best. They dismissed a general manager, resurrected Billy Martin once more, added a potent bat to the lineup and tried desperately to shore up their typically vulnerable pitching.

LEAD: Lisa Jayne Oppenheim, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Oppenheim of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert David Schultz, a son of Mrs. David Schultz of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Schultz. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the Chieftans estate.

LEAD: One year after suspending most payments on its $113 billion foreign debt, Brazil has quietly abandoned its confrontational debt strategy and is now seeking to restore normal relations with its creditors as soon as possible.

LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers' troubles began in the second quarter today with the ejection of Charles Barkley; they ended with a 14-point final quarter. The combination paved the way for a 109-105 Net victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

LEAD: THE Winter Olympics have always generated a sense of grace, and not just the raw power of the Summer Games - from the stylized body movements of the speed skaters, to the hunched-down aerodynamic forms of the ski jumpers, to the fluid dance of the figure skaters. But ABC-TV has taken the Games to a new dimension: sensuality.
LEAD: ANYONE who has ever gone hunting or fishing far from his usual haunts knows that such expeditions are sometimes fruitless or even impossible without the services of a guide or outfitter.

LEAD: A hazardous gas leaked today for the third time since late January from an International Paper Company mill that has continued operating during a strike, and seven people were taken to hospitals, officials said.

LEAD: The marriage of Janet Carol Abrams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Abrams of Huntington, W.Va., to John Lewis Chalif, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour H. Chalif of New York and Garrison, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Vizcaya Museum in Miami. Justice Rosemary Barkett of the Supreme Court of Florida performed the ceremony.
LEAD: DAVE JOHNSON approaches his fifth and presumably final year as manager of the Mets this week with several constants in his mathematical mind.

LEAD: ''The state refuses to recognize most Monday holidays. We celebrate presidential birthdays the old-fashioned way -inconveniently.'' - Howard Mansfield of Hancock, N.H., on his state's contrariness. [ A13:5. ]

LEAD: Public libraries across the nation are increasingly being used, and librarians say abused, by parents who drop off their children for hours because day care is too expensive or unavailable.

LEAD: Broadway may be enjoying its best year of the decade, with blockbuster hits lighting up every available playhouse, but to hear the story told by Gerald Schoenfeld, the biggest name in the theater business, you would think this season represents nothing more than a temporary respite in the 60-year decline of the industry.
LEAD: Pat Robertson has taken to portraying himself as a victim of religious oppression because of what people call him. If he keeps it up, what they are apt to call him is a dissembler.

LEAD: Dan Jansen of the United States, whose sister died of leukemia early yesterday, fell and lost his bid for a gold medal in the 500-meter speed-skating event at the Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta. Jansen was the favorite in the event, which was won by Uwe-Jens Mey of East Germany in world-record time.

LEAD: Presidential candidates are airing more negative television advertising than ever before, and they are doing it earlier in the campaign.
LEAD: The contrast between the performances of Sebastian Coe and Doina Melinte was a sharp one.

LEAD: Police arresting a protester in Seoul. About 300 people took part in protest of what they said was Government suppression of labor movements and U.S. pressure to open South Korea's restricted markets.

LEAD: Even in the Civil War, being the 16th President of the United States may have been a very easy job in a way; Abraham Lincoln just had to be himself. But it's quite something else to live up to the myth of Abraham Lincoln in 1988 when you're really Harry Hahn.

LEAD: N.H.L. Capitals 5, Flames 4: Mike Gartner's second goal of the game 20 seconds into overtime gave Washington its victory over Calgary yesterday in Landover, Md. Mike Ridley sent a centering pass into the slot and Gartner beat Doug Dadswell, giving Washington its third straight victory.

LEAD: There is no shortage of memoirs and books by former intelligence officials. But when Graham Fuller retired from the Central Intelligence Agency, leaving his post as national intelligence officer for the Near East and South Asia, his first publication had nothing to do with cloaks, daggers or nasty deeds in back alleys.
LEAD: At Temple Isaiah in Los Angeles, Stacy Shaw Richmond and James David Wallman were married yesterday by Rabbi Robert Gahn.

LEAD: The University of Rhode Island's Thursday night fraternity parties have succumbed to the complaints of professors who teach Friday morning classes. The Interfraternity Council voted last week to halt the parties after professors complained that too many students were sleeping in class or cutting class the next day.

LEAD: THE Atlanta Ballet presented three new works Saturday night under the auspices of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, where the company from Georgia has been involved in a visiting residency program for five years.

LEAD: The Belt Parkway was closed to all traffic for about six hours yesterday in Brooklyn when pieces of concrete fell on the six-lane highway from an overpass at Flatbush Avenue, the police said. Traffic was backed up as far as the Van Wyck Expressway and Cropsey Avenue as the police detoured traffic around the overpass starting at 3:30 P.M.
LEAD: In the crowded bar car on the New Haven Line's 5:23 express train from Manhattan Friday night, commuters savored one last legal smoke and lamented the passing of an era.
LEAD: Judge Angelucci scored a 3 1/2-length victory today over Ferdinand, his stablemate and 1987 Horse of the Year, in winning the $269,000 San Antonio Handicap at Santa Anita.

LEAD: Franklin H. Kissner, a financier and collector of rare books, died Feb. 4 at New York Hospital after a fall and cerebral hemorrhage. He was 77 years old, with residences in Manhattan and in Bethlehem, Pa.

LEAD: Chad Hennings has always seemed just a bit out of place at the Air Force Academy, a school where the big men on campus tend to be wiry types with cool-eyed gazes dreaming of the day they will squeeze into the cockpits of jet fighters and leave contrails streaked across the sky.

LEAD: For the first major exhibition at the Musee d'Orsay, ''Van Gogh in Paris'' is a natural. With van Gogh, popular success is assured. LEAD: Senator Terry Sanford of North Carolina gave the traditional reading of George Washington's farewell address to a nearly empty Senate chamber today.

LEAD: As part of an effort to accommodate the homeless, President Reagan proposes adding 135,500 units to the nation's pool of Government-subsidized housing, a White House official said today.

LEAD: The paradoxes of President Reagan's budget policies have left a seven-year record that has puzzled some fiscal experts and upset liberal critics and conservative supporters alike.

LEAD: The bond market rally ran out of steam last week as more signs emerged that the economy was not as weak as some expected and that the Federal Reserve was not trying to push short-term rates lower.

LEAD: Margaret Parker Isaac, the manager of the Fourcade Gallery in Manhattan for 14 years until last October, died in an automobile accident on Dec. 19, just outside of Winchester, Va. She was 35 years old. Her 14 month-old daughter, Marina, survived the crash unharmed.
LEAD: Her desk is small, a table really, its grainy rosewood polished by her palms, the frayed bindings of dictionaries, the tissue-thin paper she fills with tiny ideograms.
LEAD: One of three brothers who were banned from school because they were infected with the AIDS virus has developed AIDS-related complex, but his doctor says he can remain active.

LEAD: Lincoln Center Theater and the Actors' Equity Association are negotiating a settlement in a dispute between the director of ''Sarafina!'' and an American actress who joined the Broadway cast.
LEAD: Early-February sales of new American-made cars and light trucks were up 2.8 percent from the comparable period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

LEAD: Coach Dave Peterson wore a long face after the United States hockey team wasted a 3-0 lead and suffered a 7-5 loss tonight to Czechoslovakia. But his first encounter with unhappiness at Calgary did not sway him from his strategy for the young Americans, whose enthusiasm for scoring goals often leaves them wanting on defense.

LEAD: IT is not every day that one celebrates an important millennium. It was in A.D. 988 that the Ukrainians formally accepted the church into their lives, and this 1,000 years of Christianity was marked by a festive, grandly scaled evening of music at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday. A big mixed chorus from Georgia - the Choral Guild of Atlanta - sang; members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra played, and there were five singers from the international opera scene.

LEAD: TRADITIONALLY employees have relied on year-end reports from the company for timely information about their benefits and how some, like 401(k) savings plans, have grown through the year. Or a worker may visit or phone the company's benefits office for answers.

LEAD: Bartlett H. Hayes Jr., an educator and art historian who was director for many years of the Addison Gallery of American Art at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., died of congestive heart failure on Sunday in Peterboro, N.H. He was 83 years old and had lived in Peterboro since 1985.

LEAD: A turbine blade from an Eastern Air Lines A-300 Airbus shattered on takeoff today and started a brush fire just outside the airport, but the twin-engine plane returned safely and no one was injured, officials said.

LEAD: Japan's trade surplus with the United States fell in January to $2.97 billion, the lowest level in two years, the Ministry of Finance reported today.
LEAD: An explosion today crippled a ferry that was expected to carry Palestinian deportees on a symbolic voyage to Israel, port officials and the Palestine Liberation Organization said.
LEAD: Opponents of a desegregation plan here will go to Washington to ''lay this open before the nation,'' an organizer said today.

LEAD: Two months after completing a 25-year jail sentence, Paraguay's longest-serving political prisoner remains under house arrest, with armed policemen stationed at his front gate to prevent him from receiving visitors.

LEAD: On the first day of a smoking ban on commuter railroads in the New York metropolitan region, a Long Island Rail Road passenger was arrested on charges of kicking and slapping two conductors after they told him to put out his cigarette.

LEAD: After a spirited auction involving eight publishers, Harper & Row has agreed to pay $130,000 for a new translation of a Chinese book of philosophy and religion written more than 2,000 years ago. The amount is one of the highest ever paid to a translator, and it is certainly the most for a work in the public domain that has already been translated into English dozens of times.

LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers said yesterday they would retire Julius Erving's number before an April 19 game against the Milwaukee Bucks.
