''If there was ever an athlete, or a man, deserving of this honor, it's certainly Julius Erving,'' said the 76ers' owner, Harold Katz.
LEAD: The most senior Tibetan religious figure in China has disputed official assertions that Chinese policemen did not shoot at demonstrating monks during a riot in Lhasa last October.

LEAD: Some undeniably chic fashions are also expected to be functional. But let's face it: they often aren't. Take jump suits. Forever being touted as the most contemporary, streamlined attire, they are, in fact, often a hindrance. Just try dealing with one in a jumbo jet's minuscule bathroom. Also, since a jump suit is cut in one piece, unless it is fitted perfectly, it tends to ride up.

Last year's shattering National Theater production of Arthur Miller's ''View From the Bridge,'' as acted by Michael Gambon and directed by Alan Ayckbourn, was no fluke.

LEAD: The majority leader of the State Senate called urged his colleagues today to scrap a plan to meet privately in the impeachment trial of Gov. Evan Mecham.

LEAD: The plight of lonely older people is among the main concerns of donors responding to the 76th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LEAD: A runoff election is to be held next week between a conservative and a Communist-backed businessman to determine who will succeed President Spyros Kyprianou, who lost his bid for a third five-year term.
LEAD: The National Park Service is going international. It has agreed to help India develop the Taj Mahal as a national cultural park.

LEAD: Because of a computer programming error in the tabulation of a New York Times/CBS News Poll on the Iowa caucuses, a news analysis on Feb. 10 incorrectly stated the percentages of Republican voters who listed ''moral values'' as a central concern. Sixty-eight percent of Pat Robertson's backers did so, not 70, and so did 19 percent of other Republicans, not 18.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Wind blew over a wall 30 feet high at a condominium complex under construction today, trapping 18 workers for about five minutes, the authorities said. Ten workers were injured, three of them seriously. Lieut. James Hagerty of the Franklin Fire Department said the workers were using long poles to raise the sheetrock-and-plywood wall when the wind caught it and if fell on top of them.

LEAD: The Israeli Army said today that it had opened an investigation into reports that its troops had buried four young Palestinians alive. It said that it had detained two soldiers and that it expected to detain others.
LEAD: After a week that would have tested any candidate, Senator Paul Simon of Illinois took a serene leap of faith today over polls and pundits, and landed on the side of optimism.

LEAD: Usually, it is nothing more than a nostalgic pastime, but occasionally a peek through the attic yields some forgotten heirloom. Mascagni's ''Iris'' may not quite be the priceless gem one dreams of finding tucked away among the dusty boxes of old and forgotten musical scores, but it is a far more satisfying discovery than most of the curios unearthed during recent years by operatic scavengers.
LEAD: The disk-shaped Milky Way galaxy is not flat, but instead resembles a warped phonograph record and is adorned with a delicate scalloped edge, new observations show.
LEAD: Some people mistake Officer Wayne Sato's koban for an instant photo-processing booth. At Officer Herman Jones's koban, tourists try to buy tickets for a cable car ride.
LEAD: Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that it was negotiating with several parties, including the Campeau Corporation, that are interested in buying all or part of it.

LEAD: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, announced yesterday that he was contributing $50,000 to help form a foundation to aid young victims of violent incidents. On Saturday, Tyson said he, his wife, the actress Robin Givens, and the promoter Don King visited Tawana Brawley, the student from Wappinger Falls, N.Y., who was the victim of a purported racial attack.
LEAD: The young man in wraparound sunglasses leaned toward a sponge ball microphone and intoned: ''Bonjour Afrique - bonjour africains.''

LEAD: Following are some questions from the New York City Taxi Driver Institute test. They were taken from the student workbook used in the course. 1. It's a slow summer night in New York and you haven't had many fares. Two men hail your taxi in front of the Port Authority Bus Terminal and tell you they need to be at Kennedy Airport in 30 minutes.
LEAD: Thrice weekly the Amtrak sleeper train clacks across the desert Southwest with its human cargo, a rolling collection of the neurotic, the phobic, the curious and the adventurous.

LEAD: Despite the deepening divisions in Austria and growing calls for his resignation, President Kurt Waldheim told his nation today that he would ''not retreat in the face of slanders, hateful demonstrations and wholesale condemnations.''

LEAD: BEFORE last week, Donald H. Straszheim, the chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, was predicting a period of uneven economic growth. But he now believes that a ''garden-variety recession'' will begin within the next 6 to 18 months, and he picks early 1989 as the likeliest starting point.
LEAD: Security Council

LEAD: Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the big Canadian real estate company, announced yesterday that it would pay $17.50 a share for up to 14 million additional shares, or 9.1 percent, of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation.

LEAD: Carlo De Benedetti, the Italian financier, formally began his bid today to take control of Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest company. But the company's shares climbed well above the offering price.

LEAD: Aided by nepotism and courtroom victories, Gene Gotti, a younger brother of John Gotti, is carving a niche for himself as an imposing figure in the Gambino organized-crime family, law-enforcement officials say.

LEAD: WHEN Jack Rehm was named president of the Meredith Corporation recently, many in the publishing industry thought that the 55-year-old executive was ideal for the job. He has been at Meredith for 26 years, nearly all his professional life, and if there is such a thing as the quintessential Meredith man, Mr.

LEAD: John Glenn, the astronaut, earned his political credentials as a Senator from Ohio before his try for the Presidency in 1984. Jack Kemp, the quarterback, paid his political dues as a member of the House from New York before offering himself for the Republican Presidential nomination this year.

LEAD: The smell of pervasive privilege and manipulation rises over Washington as one influence-peddling conviction follows another. In the next day or two, there'll be a chance to do something about it -if Senate Republicans will finally abandon their adamant opposition.

LEAD: People here have long been fond of saying that ''no one in Mexico has ever lost money betting on the dollar.'' But the latest downturn in this nation's six-year economic crisis has given a new and added cogency to that adage.

LEAD: THE American Composers Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon reminded us how much we in this country have to choose from and, in terms of quality, how precarious the choices can be. Sunday's program came in every size, shape and level of competence - from Matthias Kriesberg's complex and crowded ''Chronosymphonies'' to the unintentional Minimalism of Gordon Getty's ''Plump Jack.

LEAD: COMPANIES Pearson agreed to buy Addison-Wesley for $105 a share, or $283 million. Pearson, which owns The Financial Times, Madame Tussaud's wax museum and other properties, will become an international force in book publishing with this deal. [ Page D1. ] Federated Department Stores said it was negotiating with several parties that are interested in buying all or part of it.
LEAD: Focus on Newcomers

LEAD: Don Maloney of the Rangers celebrating after scoring against the Canadiens yesterday in the third period at the Garden. It was the Rangers' third goal in their first victory in over a week. Page A19. (NYT/Barton Silverman)

LEAD: Q. I was told as a child that you can tell how far away a thunderstorm is by counting the seconds between a lightning flash and the sound of thunder. Is this correct? If it is, why? A. Counting can be used as a roughly accurate guide, said Tom Ross, a meteorologist at the National Climatic Data Center in Asheville, N.C.
LEAD: Harold Wilson, the former British Prime Minister, used to say that two weeks is a lifetime in politics. He might have been talking about George Bush.

LEAD: Paul Schlichtman gazed at the 25 prospective taxicab drivers in a classroom in midtown Manhattan and opened the floor to questions. The drivers appeared suspicious. ''O.K., suppose you pick up a passenger,'' one said, finally, ''and he dies in the car?'' (''Call the morgue,'' said Mr. Schlichtman.) ''While you're looking at your map before the trip,'' asked another, ''can you turn the meter on?

LEAD: Jens Mueller of East Germany rode his luge down the 4,104-foot course at Canada Olympic Park in 46.367 seconds yesterday in the fourth and final heat for a two-day total of 3 minutes 5.548 seconds, nearly four-tenths of a second faster than Georg Hackl of West Germany at 3:05.916.

LEAD: When Soviet frigates bump U.S. warships, they set off public alarm. Yet if Friday's incident in the Black Sea is unsettling, it is also predictable, one episode in a longtime policy disagreement. More, it's manageable, a small piece of a complex relationship.
LEAD: Pearson P.L.C., the British conglomerate that owns The Financial Times, announced today that it had agreed to buy the Addison-Wesley Publishing Company for $283 million.

LEAD: THERE are laughs sprinkled through John Herman Shaner's ''After Crystal Night,'' but the play is not funny. Essentially it is a long harangue spoken in nine voices about the necessity of Jews' becoming aggressive, even violent, in the battle against anti-Semitism. In the production at the New Federal Theater the cast members make the most of the humor in the play, but the message overwhelms them.
LEAD: Lehman, the defending champion, trounced York, 87-62, last night as the 23d annual City University of New York tournament began.

LEAD: ''You can judge for yourselves whether your President is the young lieutenant - or even the distorted picture of this officer of the Wehrmacht - or whether your President is a man who, for decades of his life, worked for justice, tolerance and peace. I ask you to form your own judgment.''

LEAD: THE number of scientific articles and journals being published around the world has grown so large that it is starting to confuse researchers, overwhelm the quality-control systems of science, encourage fraud and distort the dissemination of important findings.

LEAD: Edward L. Rowny, special adviser to President Reagan on arms control, told a meeting of American scientists today that the Soviet Union was ''squandering time'' in its current disarmament negotiations with the United States and ''remains a brutal adversary.''

LEAD: In a dimly lit control room overlooking the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's rolling mill here, Joseph L. Voye pointed proudly to the bright computer screens, whose colorful charts and graphs detailed the thickness, smoothness and temperature of the steel sheets being molded below.
LEAD: MIDDLE-EAR infections, which plague millions of young children, are an inherited trait and have nothing to do with environment or access to medical care, a new study indicates.
LEAD: FIFTY-ONE HUNDREDTHS of a second. The blink of an eye. The slip of a ski in the snow. Too much time in the air after soaring off a bump. Not crouched low enough in a glide.
LEAD: The union representing 2,500 tugboatmen and barge workers in New York Harbor struck nine towing companies at 12:01 A.M. this morning following a breakdown of negotiations yesterday.

LEAD: The 19th annual Continental Open Tournament, held at the Hilton Hotel in Rye, N.Y., was won by Roman Dzindzichashvili. The New York grandmaster, who originally hailed from the Soviet Union, scored 5-1 to capture the $2,000 first prize in the six-round Swiss-system event.

LEAD: A NEW generation of drugs to treat depression is giving medical scientists a fresh view of the best strategies for coping with this severe and widespread mental disorder and important clues to its nature.

LEAD: The $2.7 billion nuclear aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln was christened and launched here Saturday. The 1,092-foot ship is the Navy's fifth Nimitz class nuclear-powered carrier. All have been built at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, where a sixth Nimitz carrier, the George Washington, is scheduled for completion in 1991.

LEAD: The line Saturday began forming outside the Cort Theater just before the box office opened for the matinee. It was sunny but cold, below freezing, with the wind gusting across 48th street making it feel like the mercury was stuck at zero.
LEAD: The fossil of a small bird has brought to light a previously unknown branch of the family tree of birds, paleontologists report.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation is easing its long-held opposition to publicly traded automobile dealers, a key executive said today. The development could spur stock offerings by some of the large multifranchise dealers that are beginning to dominate the retail car market.

LEAD: Bleak results from recent experiments indicate that the quest for a vaccine against AIDS will be even more difficult than many experts had imagined. The results also raise the possibility that current lines of vaccine research may be fruitless.

LEAD: Commercial real estate, a business ordinarily fraught with uncertainties, now seems even more risky. In New York, the collapse of the stock market on Oct. 19 has increased vacancies, lowered rents and raised fears of a local real estate recession. Elsewhere, a rapid pace of building from 1980 to 1985 has created cases of oversupply, particularly in the
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: For-Profit Radio in Africa

LEAD: The New Hampshire Presidential primary campaign, characterized by dazzling shifts in voter loyalties, ended today with personal invective, muddled forecasts and advice to Republicans from a venerable conservative hero.

LEAD: WHY is your flight delayed or canceled, and why is an airport so often a mess? ''Frontline'' provides some reasonable answers tonight: too many planes in too little airspace, a surfeit of passengers and not enough technology to control things. The PBS documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 P.M. and Channel 49 at 9 P

LEAD: When Ed Feldt's daughter Veronica announced she wanted to be a rock-and-roll star, Mr. Feldt had strong feelings. Veronica already had a good job driving a wholesale meat truck. Mr. Feldt, a meat man himself, had broken her in and helped her build her own route. She loved driving so much that she had taken a double course load at Smithtown High School West to graduate early and start on the truck.

LEAD: Merrill Pollack, a sculptor, writer and former editor of The Saturday Evening Post, died Sunday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Parkersburg, W.Va., after a short illness. He was 63 years old and lived in Grantsville. His family did not disclose the cause of death.

LEAD: Seeking to outmaneuver several Japanese competitors, the International Business Machines Corporation introduced an improved operating system for its largest computers yesterday. It said the system would be provided without charge to current owners of its most advanced mainframes.
LEAD: In the strongest language to date, China has described its relations with the United States as potentially unstable and attacked what it said was interference in its internal affairs.

LEAD: Some participants at the President's Day parade yesterday in Old Town in Alexandria, Va., dressed as World War II soldiers, while others performed a drill of the First Virginia Regiment of Revolutionary War days. (NYT/Paul Hosefros)

LEAD: When the minority students occupying a University of Massachusetts building here discovered that the brother of the chancellor was ill, they sent the chancellor a card this morning expressing their best wishes.

LEAD: Martin K. Speckter, a retired advertising executive known to lexicographers as the creator of the interrobang, a punctuation mark used to convey disbelief, died of bone cancer Sunday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Carlos Fuentes, the Mexican novelist and critic, is to receive the Medal of Honor for Literature from the National Arts Club, at 15 Gramercy Park South, at its 20th annual literary award dinner on Feb. 24.

LEAD: DRUGS that induce miscarriages may eventually replace traditional surgical abortions in the first three months of pregnancy, according to a World Health Organization official. In particular, a panel that recently evaluated international drug tests determined that a specific two-drug combination was safe and effective when used early in pregnancy.

LEAD: Horse Racing King's Swan Wins Stymie Handicap: King's Swan stalked pacesetting Wind Chill to the stretch yesterday, took the lead and went on to carry highweight of 126 pounds to a 4 1/2-length victory in the $169,200 Stymie Handicap for 3-year-olds and up. Wind Chill finished second in the five-horse field ahead of Feeling Gallant, Mr.
LEAD: 20th Century-Fox has paid Bruce Willis $5 million to star in a movie. For Hollywood, the result is equivalent to an earthquake. The map of movie-star salaries must now be redrawn.

LEAD: Austin Briggs-Hall, an actor who was a founder of the American Negro Theater and an authority on African history, died of heart failure Jan. 13 in Kings County Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

LEAD: James Diggs and Anthony Colon come from troubled and impoverished families, from neighborhoods where drugs offer the constant temptation of escape and quick money, and both have poor academic skills. It is easier to find the similarities in their lives than the differences that led James to return to school and Anthony to remain a dropout.

LEAD: Forty Niner and Notebook slugged it out for the length of the stretch at Gulfstream Park today before Forty Niner thrust out his nose at the wire to score the most courageous and important victory of his career.
LEAD: Not since the Depression of the 1930's did the nation's biggest banks perform as poorly as they did in 1987, a survey of their financial results indicates.

LEAD: More than a third of New York State's public-school children live in New York City. Yet the city receives less than a third of state aid to local schools. Fairness and necessity cry out for the gap to be closed.
LEAD: * CRI Inc., Rockville, Md., a worldwide financial services and investment company, appointed Yvonne S. Distenfeld senior vice president, general counsel.

LEAD: Not long ago, the President offered a lesson. ''Money,'' Mr. Reagan said, ''can never take the place of basics like . . . homework.'' Pedagogical poverty aside, a number of teachers here thought he did not go far enough. Homework is much more than old-fashioned drill, one of the basics; it is education's essence.

LEAD: In a bid to bolster its position as a business lender, the California First Bank said today that it had agreed to acquire the much larger Union Bank, a subsidiary of Standard Chartered P.L.C., for $750 million.

LEAD: Orlando Bosch, a symbol of anti-Castro militancy among Cuban exiles in the 1960's and 70's, returned from Venezuela today after his third acquittal on charges of planning an explosion aboard a Cuban jetliner in 1976 that killed 73 people.
LEAD: A Washington-based lobbying group has asked the Internal Revenue Service to investigate the Presidential campaign of the Rev. Jesse Jackson for the possibility of Federal tax law violations.
LEAD: The Agriculture Department today announced a major new program for encouraging private business to develop recreational facilities in national forests.

LEAD: John F. Lehman Jr., who was Secretary of the Navy in the first six years of the Reagan Administration, has been chosen for promotion to captain in the Naval Reserve, the service said today. Mr. Lehman, a naval flight officer who left the Government last April to pursue a career in investment banking, was selected for a captaincy along with more than 450 other commanders.

LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation on Wednesday will begin shipping its version of OS/2, the new operating system used on the PS/2 line of personal computers from the International Business Machines Corporation. Compaq, the leading vendor of I.B.M.-compatible machines, also said it would offer a 3.25-inch disk drive as an option for its portable computers, which until now have come with 5.25-inch drives.

LEAD: Vice President Bush soundly defeated Senator Bob Dole in the New Hampshire Republican primary today, keeping his Presidential candidacy alive after one of the most difficult weeks in his political life.
LEAD: The Campeau Corporation again sweetened its bid for Federated Department Stores Inc. yesterday. The offer was raised by $5 a share, to $66 in cash, or a total of $5.7 billion.

LEAD: EACH time employees place a call on the Federal Government's telephone system, they use technology put together a quarter-century ago and that has now become so outmoded and expensive to operate that it would be cheaper to place the calls on the public telephone system. LEAD: Every once in a while an athlete comes along who so outclasses the competition that he, or she, seems to be performing in a different event. That person has no real peer but himself; his only real contest is with his last performance. Torvill and Dean, who won an Olympic gold medal for ice dancing in 1984, are that kind of athlete.

LEAD: The Justice Department based one of its principal charges against President Kurt Waldheim of Austria on captured German documents that point to his involvement in the deportation of 488 Yugoslav civilians to slave labor camps in 1942, possibly making him an accessory to war crimes.

LEAD: Grey Advertising has reported an 18 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings. It said on Tuesday that net income had climbed to $2.74 million, or $2.06 a share, from $2.32 million, or $1.66 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 26 percent, to $98.1 million, from $77.8 million. For the year the agency reported that profit was up 13 percent, to $10.3 million, or $7.43 a share, from $9.1 million, or $6.60 a share.

The Florida Cabinet declared yesterday ''Red Barber Day'' in Florida, and a birthday party was held in the state capitol building.

LEAD: JACK JONES is a crafty saloon singer with a deeper feel for jazz and a more sophisticated sense of humor than such signature songs as ''The Impossible Dream'' and ''The Love Boat'' might lead one to believe. In the history of pop crooning, he stands as the stylistic link between Frank Sinatra and Barry Manilow, with stronger leanings toward the former.

Such waste! cried his critics, several of whom were politically motivated bureaucrats overseeing the Bavarian budget.
LEAD: Alain Savary, whose policies as Education Minister in 1984 provoked street protests, died today. He was 69 years old.
LEAD: By reducing costs, Japanese manufacturers remain competitive, even as the strong yen has made their goods more costly overseas. Page D1.
LEAD: Greg Bell made a 5-foot shot with one second remaining to give Tennessee a 72-70 upset over Kentucky tonight in a Southeastern Conference game.

LEAD: N.H.L. Whalers 4, Jets 3: Carey Wilson scored twice last night to help end a seven-game unbeaten streak by visiting Winnipeg. Wilson, who has 17 goals for the season, including 8 in 14 games since being acquired last Jan. 3, scored both his goals on deflections. His game-winner came at 7 minutes 46 seconds of the third period as Wilson, in the slot, tipped in a low shot from the left circle by Ron Francis.

LEAD: SEVEN seems to be a lucky number for avant-gutbucket jazz. Henry Threadgill's seven-member Sextett, the Microscopic Septet and now the seven-piece Jazz Passengers make jazz that's smart and witty and raucous. For all its unpredictable forms and modernist dissonances, the music comes across as boisterous fun.
LEAD: A report in the Business People column on Friday misstated new responsibilities of the broker/dealer division of Merrill Lynch & Company.

LEAD: IN his red-white-and-blue Olympic warm-up suit, Willie Gault was holding forth on his sudden presence on the United States bobsled team. But he's always a presence. Although best known as a wide receiver for the Chicago Bears, he organized and was the lead singer of their ''Super Bowl Shuffle'' rap video.

LEAD: MELVIN VAN PEEBLES - writer, film maker, producer, actor, songwriter, director, financial analyst - never does anything quite the way anyone else does. His style combines the straightforward and the theatrical.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company and unions representing its 32,500 workers reached a compromise Tuesday night intended to end a damaging 10-day strike. The tentative agreement, which workers will vote on Thursday, limits Ford's ability to introduce sweeping changes in work practices.

LEAD: The budget that President Reagan submits to Congress today is effectively his last. But he need not fret about his waning power. ''Art/ Artifact: African Art in Anthropology Collections,'' now at the Center for African Art, takes as its subject not so much African art per se, but the various ways Westerners have displayed it since the late 19th century.
LEAD: Brian Boitano and Brian Orser let the question of their Olympic supremacy linger on a bit tonight.

LEAD: Golf Couples Takes Lead: Fred Couples capped a nine-under-par 63 with a birdie-birdie-birdie finish yesterday to take the opening-round lead at the $650,000 Andy Williams Open in La Jolla, Calif. Couples, who lost the Phoenix Open in a playoff, birdied 10 of the 18 holes at the North course at the Torrey Pines Golf Club.

LEAD: ''MYSTERY!'' turns plummy tomorrow night. Chief Inspector Morse looks for a killer among Oxford's dons. The dons inhabit spacious, sunny offices amid turrets, spires and greens. Morse drinks ale, listens to Wagner, and solves difficult crossword puzzles in his bachelor apartment. There is not a handgun to be seen.

LEAD: Karl H. Steinbrenner, president of the Art Directors Club, announced the formation of the Art Directors Club Museum of Advertising and Communications Design. The club, which publishes an advertising and graphic design annual, also has a large television commercial archive. Those interested in donating historical material dealing with advertising, design and television to the nonprofit museum should write to the club, 250 Park Avenue South, New York 10003, or call 212-674-0500.

LEAD: Dan Jansen sliding on the ice after falling in the 1,000-meter speed skating event in Calgary, Alberta. It was his second fall in five days. Earlier, a top U.S. skier, Pam Fletcher, suffered a broken leg in practice. It was the 14th injury suffered by American skiers since last June. Page B9. (AP)

LEAD: Local residents were told months ago that many Olympic events, including hockey, speed skating, figure skating and curling, were sold out. They have become angry because there have been large blocks of empty seats at these events.

LEAD: In keeping with a bipartisan agreement reached last year, President Reagan today sent Congress a $1.09 trillion budget devoid of the ideological fervor that enabled a small band of committed conservatives to reorder Federal spending priorities in the last seven years.

LEAD: For most of the morning, the sun struggled in vain to break through the haze that stretched across the Florida sky. The day never fully warmed, but the pictures made it feel like spring anyway: children hanging over the dugout roof, players slowly filing into the clubhouse, uniforms being carefully unfolded.

LEAD: THE flourishing neighborhood between Union Square and the Flatiron district has spawned yet another stylish restaurant, Ristorante da Umberto. Owned by Umberto Assante and his wife, Kathleen, the three-month-old establishment specializes in the hearty cuisine of Florence. The high-ceilinged dining rooms are bright and tidy, with sponge-dappled amber walls and well-spaced tables.

LEAD: Nhe former California official appointed in 1986 to manage the ailing TMIC Insurance Company said yesterday that as early as May of that year he had argued that the company needed to be liquidated to contain its already large losses.

LEAD: STEVE GIANAKOS in his new paintings at the Barbara Toll Gallery comes on at first like a cartoonist. LEAD: THE next time someone tries to sell you a bridge in New York City, be sure to ask for a warranty. Officials say about half the city's bridges are rated in poor or fair condition, 31 have had to be at least partly closed off and 100 need to be replaced.
LEAD: FAMILY BUSINESS By Anna Murdoch. 592 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.
LEAD: To The Editor:
LEAD: The best Winter Olympic sport? The 12-yard dash between my TV and refrigerator! RICH STEINHAUS Bayside, Queens

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, center, and Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell, left, with President Mauno Koivisto in Helsinki. Mr. Shultz is to meet with Soviet leaders today in Moscow. Page 3. (AP)

LEAD: An article in the Sports section on Feb. 7 previewing Winter Olympic competition misidentified the current world hockey champion, and another article misidentified the 1984 winner of the Olympic bronze medal in hockey. Sweden is the world champion and won the bronze in the 1984 Games at Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.
LEAD: HOSPITALS are facing many new challenges, and, in many cases, they are meeting them with new administrators.
LEAD: To the Editor: I'd like to add to a Q. &A. answer on Medjugorje, the Yugoslav village that has become a popular place of religious pilgrimage.

LEAD: NADINE Starring Kim Basinger (in photo), Jeff Bridges (in photo), Rip Torn, Gwen Verdon, Glenne Headly and Jerry Stiller. Directed by Robert Benton. 1987. CBS/Fox Video. 82 minutes. $89.98. Rated PG.

LEAD: Mildred Seydell, a journalist who interviewed Mussolini and covered the Scopes trial, died today. She was 98 years old.
LEAD: Whatever hap-pened to Meyerbeer?
LEAD: ANTHILLS OF THE SAVANNAH By Chinua Achebe. 216 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $16.95.

LEAD: Rupert Murdoch and 10 unions agreed early yesterday on $22 million in concessions to save The New York Post, and hours later plans were under way to rejuvenate the paper and win back readers and advertisers who have defected in recent months.

LEAD: In a decision that could affect hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, a state appeals court has ruled that rent-stabilized apartments cannot be passed on to a live-in relative after the tenant named on the lease dies or moves out.

LEAD: THERE'S TOO MUCH record-breaking going on. You can't pick up a newspaper or turn on the television any more without discovering a half dozen incredibly uninteresting new records have been set overnight.

LEAD: Rene Char, called ''the greatest French poet of the 20th century'' by Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, died here Friday, according to the publishing company Gallimard. He was 80 years old and lived in Paris. Gallimard said Mr. Char died at the Val-de-Grace military hospital. No cause of death was given.

LEAD: Dr. Speros Vryonis Jr., an expert on the effect of Hellenism and Byzantine culture on Asia Minor and the Balkans, has been named the first director of the Onassis Center for Hellenic Studies at New York University.

LEAD: Because married couples increasingly need the incomes of both spouses to qualify for a mortgage, a problem can arise when an employer relocates one of the partners. The spouse of the transferred employee may take several months to find a suitable job in the new location and thus have the second income needed for the loan.

LEAD: From the moment I arrived in the emergency room of New York Hospital complaining of chest pains, I was treated by doctors, nurses and technicians with promptness, consideration and good humor. I don't know how you measure a good outcome like mine against the terrible misfortune of Libby Zion. But I do know that a fair analysis would not have focused on specific cases of negligence at one hospital without mentioning specific cases at any other hospitals.
LEAD: ON a trip to the Cape Verde Islands off West Africa, I met my great-grandaunt, Maria Nharita. She was a vivid reminder of my African ancestry. She lived in a hut.

LEAD: Lauri Jan Lowell, a daughter of Vivian Lowell of New York and Stanley H. Lowell of Scarsdale, N.Y., and New York, and Isaiah David Cooper plan to marry in June. The future bridegroom is a son of Florence Cooper of Middletown, N.Y., and the late Paul H. Cooper.
LEAD: THE CITADEL With Robert Donat (in photo), Rosalind Russell (in photo), Ralph Richardson and Rex Harrison. Directed by King Vidor. 1938. MGM/UA Home Video. 113 minutes. $24.95.
LEAD: A front-page article last Sunday about pressures faced by black police officers misidentified the department where Sgt. Donald Jackson works.

LEAD: SEVERAL days after Frank Lorenzo took control of Eastern Airlines in 1986, Charles E. Bryan, the head of the company's 13,000-member machinists union, sent him a welcoming telegram expressing interest in working together to strengthen the company.

LEAD: TO Morgan Kaolian, it is ''the best-kept secret in Fairfield County.'' Mr. Kaolian is referring to Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Stratford, of which he is the manager. Although it is within a half-hour's drive of anywhere in the county, the airport remains a little-known resource.
LEAD: THE ADVENTURES AND SUFFERINGS OF JOHN R. JEWITT, CAPTIVE OF MAQUINNA Illustrated by Hilary Stewart. 192 pp. Seattle: University of Washington Press. $29.95.
LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced new austerity measures today to accompany the jarring currency devaluation he decreed a week ago.

LEAD: FOR the last century, a ''royal and ancient game'' has been capturing a new land -winning the hearts of a new nation of ''duffers'' and ''pro's,'' threatening church attendance and nonplaying spouses.
LEAD: THE DOUGLAS LETTERS:
LEAD: SNOWED IN!
LEAD: To The Editor:

LEAD: THE longest lines at my friendly neighborhood film-processing lab aren't at the counter. They're over in the corner where the self-service printing machine sits. No matter that it may take 30 minutes to get to the front of the line, the appeal of while-you-wait prints is apparently too great to resist.

LEAD: THERE are many ways to fight the winter blahs, like flying to the Caribbean or to Tahiti, or livening up an outfit with a snappy hat or a flashy accessory. The latter solution may not be as relaxing as the others, but it's cheaper and will also cheer up other poor souls who can't get away from the land of icy gusts.

LEAD: Frances Ann Testa and Richard William Egan were married yesterday at Our Lady Queen of Peace Roman Catholic Church in Maywood, N.J., by the Rev. Stanley Kostrzomb. The bride, a daughter of Madeline Testa of Saddle River, N.J., and the late Florindo Testa, is the director of medical records at the Alexian Brothers Hospital in Elizabeth, N.J.

LEAD: If he were a head shorter, Maximo Blake said, he would have probably ended up in trouble with the law instead of working with the law-enforcement authorities to give young offenders fresh starts.

LEAD: After a year as a relief pitcher with the Boston Red Sox, Joe Sambito wants to make a new start with his original major league team, the Houston Astros. The Astros said that Sambito, who broke in with the club in 1976, would attend training camp as a nonroster player. . . . Leslie Frazier, a cornerback for the Chicago Bears during the 1985 season, when they won the Super Bowl, has been named the head football coach at Trinity College in Deerfield, Ill., when it fields its first football team since its 1887 founding.
LEAD: WHAT did the voters of New Hampshire and Iowa tell the American people?

LEAD: Take the sublime natural ingredients -the mountain, the sky, the wind and the snow - add the requisite dash of danger, and you have uncovered the classic dish of the Winter Olympic feast: downhill skiing. JACK PARL Bayside, Queens

LEAD: When two arms negotia-tors, the American Paul Nitze and the Russian Yuli Kvitsinsky, took a walk in the woods just outside of Geneva during the summer of 1982, they forged an original and provocative nuclear-weapons agreement. While it would later be rejected by their respective Governments, their proposal eventually ignited a groundswell of hope for what might still be achieved.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: TRADITIONS that we inherit sometimes lose their vitality and fall into disuse. Ideas have no claim on us if we haven't made them our own. Principles that become institutionalized in organizations often wind up as empty rules and regulations enforced by people who have given the word ''bureaucrat'' a bad name.

LEAD: Chicago! What a perilous, politically-blooded arena in which to revive ''Born Yesterday,'' Garson Kanin's 1945 play about governmental corruption in wartime Washington. Fixes and graft have long been a form of street theater in Chicago; most citizens' knowledge of municipal deals darker than the century-old bricks of the Steppenwolf Theater building lies as deep in memory as their childhood prayers.

LEAD: ''I owe Cartier-Bresson every-thing. I learned from him the supreme importance of geometry -the relationship of abstract shapes within a frame,'' says Marc Riboud. And it was Cartier-Bresson who inspired him with ''the idea of the 'decisive movement,' that instant seized on film which reveals a visual order in the chaos of reality.

LEAD: As the crippling war in Mozambique spills over into Zimbabwe, the Government of Executive President Robert G. Mugabe is increasingly faced with competing pressures over this country's military involvement in the conflict.

LEAD: Two years ago Leon B. Kellner, the United States Attorney here, took over the prosecution of several Miami police officers accused of drug trafficking and racketeering, This arrangement, requested by Janet Reno, the State Attorney for Dade County, evolved into a pattern under which virtually all local corruption cases here are going to the Federal courts for trial.

LEAD: Margaret D. Sulerzyski, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Sulerzyski of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Evan C. Jensen, the son of Margit Jensen of Monroe, N.Y., and the late Einer Jensen. The Rev. Johnnie Nystrom, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Terrace Restaurant in Manhattan. The bride, known as Peggy, is a vice president and the director of financial analysis and budgeting for Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York.

LEAD: WHEN President Reagan signed the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1986, he vowed to wage ''a national crusade against drugs, a sustained relentless effort to rid America of this scourge.'' Two years later, the supply of drugs on American streets is larger than ever, the enforcement effort suffers from lack of money, and officials in at least a dozen

LEAD: Joyful anticipation, tinged with perhaps a touch of anxiety, showed on the face of Judy Allison last Sunday as the final laps of the Daytona 500 unwound. Her husband, 50-year-old Bobby, and son, 26-year-old Davey, were leading the pack on the mad dash for the checkered flag.

LEAD: My choice is luge, perhaps because it is so unusual. To those who say that being a luger seems much too sedentary, isn't that a snap judgment? Actually participating seriously in this sport should rapidly dispel erroneous conclusions. THOMAS G. MORGANSEN Jackson Heights, Queens
LEAD: HAING NGOR A Cambodian Odyssey. By Haing Ngor with Roger Warner. Illustrated. 478 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95.
LEAD: Charles Smith scored 25 points, the final 10 on free throws, as Pitt outlasted Georgetown, 70-65, today in a physical Big East Conference game that ended with a brawl.
LEAD: WHAT makes a regional theater a viable artistic entity is its ability to reach out and challenge audiences with new, developing work.

LEAD: In his article, William Safire describes members of the upper class as ''those to the manor born.'' The original phrase, from ''Hamlet'' (Act I, Scene 4), contains, instead, the homophonous manner, and the connotation is quite different. When Hamlet says ''. . . though I am native here/ And to the manner born .
LEAD: GUNS AND BARBED WIRE A Child Survives the Holocaust. By Thomas Geve. Illustrated. 220 pp. Illinois: Academy Chicago. $18.95.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Liebowitz of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Terri Lynn Liebowitz, to Sanford K. Feld, the son of the late Edith Feld and the late Albert Feld of Sands Point, L.I. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: WEATHER permitting, this is a good season to prune dormant trees especially young apples and pears to strengthen them, but wait until after flowering to prune stone fruits such as peaches, nectarines and cherries. Grapevines are pruned any time this month and next. Arrange for tree pruning by arborists if shade or specimen trees have grown too thick and tall or have been weakened by ice or snow storms.
LEAD: Dr. Esther Oshiver Fisher, a retired marriage counselor, died of complications from Alzheimer's disease Feb. 13 at her home in Princeton, N.J. She was 77 years old.

Msgr. Francis Boyle performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New
LEAD: Japan, often accused of xenophobia and sometimes with justification, took a small step this week to make visitors from abroad feel a bit less alien.
LEAD: NATHAN SHANE licked his counting finger, scooped up a check and identification card from a rumpled, bent-over woman and began nimbly counting dollars.

LEAD: HAVING finally persuaded much of the public that the United States is on the verge of a heterosexual AIDS pandemic, health officials are suddenly reversing their prognosis. For months, a growing volume of statistics has been showing that HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, is not moving rapidly through the population after all.

LEAD: Surrounded by office towers, the six-story building at the northeast corner of 42d Street and Fifth Avenue gets barely a glance from passers-by. But empty buildings do not remain on prime corners indefinitely. Thus the future of 503 Fifth Avenue, built in 1860 and one of the oldest buildings on the avenue, does not seem bright.

LEAD: After five years of marriage, Ganga walked out on her husband the other day, announcing that she would no longer submit to his beatings. She then returned to her parents in another part of this northern Indian village.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH the budget President Reagan submitted last week formally projects that the Federal deficit will fall in each of the next five years, reaching a relatively negligible $23 billion in 1993, politicians and economists generally agree that the chances of this happening are practically zero.

LEAD: Judging by what's happening to too many athletes here, the XV Olympic Winter Games are in the wrong city. They should be in Great Falls, Mont. Sadly, almost incredibly, Dan Jansen, the American speed skater from West Allis, Wis., fell not only in the 500-meter sprint but also in the 1,000-meter sprint.

LEAD: ''Sheet music is a whole world,'' said Marianne Wurlitzer, a partner of Wurlitzer-Bruck, a New York firm specializing in antique musical instruments and musical material. ''You could do a history of the United States through sheet-music covers.''

LEAD: On Feb. 20, 1983, my 25-year-old daughter died at New York Hospital. I was convinced that her death was the result of gross negligence on the hospital's part, and sought a reasonable explanation. Instead of receiving sympathy and cooperation, I was stonewalled by administrators and doctors alike. Eventually, I felt

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar F. Czarra Jr. of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melanie Anne Czarra to Edward Stephen Panek Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Panek of Westfield, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: After more than eight years, Britain's artists, actors and writers show few signs of being won over by Margaret Thatcher. Some of their deep-seated animosity toward her recently surfaced publicly as a cultural debate. A few weeks ago The Sunday Telegraph ran a prominent article that asked the question: Why do the intelligentsia hate her so much?

LEAD: A baby born with only a brain stem whose body was kept alive to preserve his organs for transplant was removed from life support machines today after no suitable recipient could be found, officials said.
LEAD: It is a common conceit to de-scribe architecture in terms created for sound - there are buildings that are shrill, and others that are cacophonous.

LEAD: Q. I plan to remove the glass doors that now enclose our tub-shower. However, the metal runner on the bottom of these doors is apparently cemented onto the top of the tub rim with some kind of grout. I'm afraid that chipping and scraping might damage the finish on the tub. Is there any way you know of to remove this grout more easily?

LEAD: MOLIERE AT YALE REP Lewis J. Stadlen, a Tony Award nominee for his performance as Pangloss in the Broadway production of ''Candide'' in 1974, plays the title role in Moliere's ''Miser,'' which will run to March 12 at the Yale Repertory Theater.

LEAD: With Tucson expanding to mountain ranges on all but its south side, it seems only natural that its cultural growth would take shape in its heart rather than on its sleeve. In the last few years parts of the downtown area, largely abandoned by retail and business enterprises, have undergone a slow and somewhat hesitant rebirth.

LEAD: WHAT CAN A MAN do when the woman carrying the child they both deliberately created has a change of heart? What can a man do when the woman he loves wants an abortion and he passionately does not?
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Legislators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say that President Reagan's $1.09 trillion budget calls for too many sacrifices from the region's cities, but that the most improvement they expect is revisions for several key programs.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he and Soviet leaders would try to ''energize'' their sluggish negotiations on a strategic arms treaty when he holds talks in Moscow Sunday and Monday. But he cautioned against expecting any breakthroughs.
LEAD: Maria Walliser during downhill run of the women's combined. She is in second place, with the slalom to be run today. (Reuters)

LEAD: ''It's sort of like living with your husband. After a while it's not the same as it was in the beginning. Things happen, as most of us know. After any President serves eight years, you're ready for something fresh, for some new ideas.''
LEAD: MOST people avoid cemeteries. For years I have as well. With time in such short supply, who needs to pass it among those for whom time has run out?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Veronica Lee Fielding and William Charles Petzinger Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Petzinger of Toms River, N.J., plan to marry in April, the future bride's mother, Florence Fielding of South Toms River, N.J., has announced. Miss Fielding, also the daughter of the late Robert Fielding, is the manager of marketing in the news retrieval division of the Dow Jones Company in Princeton, N.J.
LEAD: At least 65 people were killed and some 10,000 were left homeless when a tropical storm struck Rio de Janeiro Friday night, the authorities said today.
LEAD: THE Nassau County Medical Center's recent decision to turn away all but the most acutely ill patients until it improves its nurse-to-patient ratio marks a drastic step for a hospital in crisis.

LEAD: When officials at GenCorp withdrew plans to build a corporate headquarters in Bath Township, nine miles northwest of downtown Akron, Ohio, in 1981, development prospects were uncertain for the 358-acre parcel near Interstate 77.
LEAD: RICHARD KENNEDY: Collected Stories. Illustrated by Marcia Sewell. 270 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95. (Ages 6 to 11)

LEAD: Seton Hall did not try to disguise its intentions against Boston College today. The Pirates wanted to work the ball inside to Mark Bryant, stop Dana Barros and earn a Big East Conference victory.

LEAD: Q. I plan to remove the glass doors that now enclose our tub-shower. However, the metal runner on the bottom of these doors is apparently cemented onto the top of the tub rim with some kind of grout. I'm afraid that chipping and scraping might damage the finish on the tub. Is there any way you know of to remove this grout more easily?

LEAD: WITH the help of 5 of her 12 children and a son-in-law, Maria Alfonsa Lopez braids rope in La Colonia Independencia, one of the western hill barrios of Tegucigalpa, Honduras. It is an occupation her family has pursued for generations.

LEAD: In this Island there is a Mountain of a vast Height all cover'd with woods and several small Hills which are naked, and enclose many Vales abounding in Rice . . . - Hendrick Hamel, 1668, ''The Description of the Kingdom of Corea''
LEAD: THIS IS TO REPORT the promotion to field-grade officer of a locution that had previously been a mere vogue word in the ranks.
LEAD: IF THE beginnings of Dada were ''disgust,'' as one of its leaders, Tristan Tzara, said, the beginnings of Surrealism might be called organized disgust.

LEAD: The engagement of Nancy Elizabeth Carey to Alan P. Goldberg has been announced by Miss Carey's father, Hugh L. Carey, the former New York Governor. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Goldberg of Swampscott, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: About 100,000 gallons of flammable toluene has spilled from a ruptured Sun Company pipeline into the Sandusky River near here, forcing the evacuation of about 5,000 people. Mayor Fred Singer said today that those evacuated Wednesday and Thursday would be allowed to return home.
LEAD: Quin Snyder scored 21 points, including 7 in overtime, as Duke came back twice to beat Kansas, 74-70, today.
LEAD: Bowdoin College has a message for all those who remember dormitory food as the worst they ever ate: It doesn't have to be bad.

LEAD: ON RAW DAYS LIKE THIS, with the wind whipping off a hide-brown Hudson and his containers slick with snow, Joseph Benedetto Jr. is numb to everything but the four levers at his finger tips and the greasy square of asphalt 50 feet beneath him. One distraction and whatever is in that 40-foot aluminum shipping crate he's lifting - shoes or whisky or computers - could slip out of his grasp and go crashing down on the men below.
LEAD: It is not every night that a goaltender comes away with a shutout, so Kelly Hrudey of the Islanders had something to celebrate tonight.

LEAD: After missing the team bus for Friday night's game in Philadelphia against the 76ers, then failing to report for tonight's 113-101 loss to the Seattle SuperSonics at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Orlando Woolridge, the Nets' high-scoring forward, finally contacted the team.

LEAD: The Big Easy Starring Dennis Quaid, Ellen Barkin, Ned Beatty, Ebbe Roe Smith, Marc Lawrence, John Goodman, Lisa Jane Persky, Charles Ludlam. Directed by Jim McBride. 1987. HBO Video. 100 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.

LEAD: THE official version was that, in a moving display of loyalty and enthusiasm, Paraguayans turned out en masse last Sunday to approve Gen. Alfredo Stroessner's eighth successive presidential term. No less predictably, opposition leaders, the Roman Catholic Church and foreign diplomats said the elections were too fraudulent to be taken seriously.

LEAD: IF you are looking for new ideas for winter desserts, consider dried fruits. They are at their best during the winter and are a fine alternative to expensive tropical or out-of-season fresh fruit. You can now get prunes, dried apple rings, apricots, pears, peaches and figs, mostly from California, good enough to eat straight from the package.
LEAD: The nation's armed forces are running short of a critical spare part: uniforms.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: With help from David Rockefeller and encouragement from the Polish authorities, a foundation has been set up in Poland to stimulate the lagging agriculture and food industries.

LEAD: IN the 1950's and early 60's, after the focus of jazz had shifted from swing to be-bop and before it was buried by the arrival of the Beatles, the guitarist Joe Puma and the bassist Knobby Totah were in the forefront of jazz activity. Mr. Puma played with Artie Shaw, Louis Bellson and Lee Konitz and was accompanist to Peggy Lee in the 50's and to Morgana King in the 60's.
LEAD: What's the best Winter Olympic sport? Contemplating spring training. FRED LANDES New York

LEAD: DR. Richard R. Green, who will become New York City's Schools Chancellor on March 1, is preparing for what is likely to be a brief honeymoon in an environment that has been notoriously unfriendly to outsiders. But he made it clear in an interview last week that without underestimating the difficulty of attempting to reform a system widely considered enormously resistant to change, he feels ready to take on any forces that might think of him as an easily manipulated newcomer.

LEAD: Some seasons, the Paris couture is everything it is supposed to be - and more. This spring is certainly one of those. The collections shown last month not only had plenty of clothes for the couture clientele to choose from, but, even more importantly, they were loaded with multiple messages for the fashion community at large.
LEAD: Apologizing for being late, Stuart Price of Manhattan sent $50 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, with the request that his contribution be used to help someone with AIDS.

LEAD: There are positive signs for the economy of Summit County. Akron's population of 227,000 has been stable over the past few years and unemployment among the county's 508,000 residents has dropped from its peak of 12.3 percent in 1983 to 7.5 percent last year.

LEAD: William Safire refers to the phrase ''jet set'' as having ''first appeared in print in 1951 to describe the fashion-conscious group that used jet aircraft to take them to the world's watering spots in passionate pursuit of pleasure'' (On Language: ''Ruling the Jet Set,'' Jan. 24).

LEAD: The decline in the earth's environmental health can be reversed, but only with a substantial investment by the rich nations, according to the 1988 State of the World report published by the Worldwatch Institute.

LEAD: Categories are conven-ient; they allow us to relate one thing to another, to set up connections between events that might otherwise (we fear) fly apart into a myriad of fragments in a mad, dissociated universe. So there's probably no harm in calling John Zorn's latest album, ''Spillane'' (Nonesuch 9-79172, all three formats), a pop record.
LEAD: THE GENERALS Ulysses S. Grant and Robert E. Lee. By Nancy Scott Anderson and Dwight Anderson. 523 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.
LEAD: A former teacher has filed a lawsuit charging Harvard Business School with denying her tenure because she is a woman and with discrimination in hiring and admissions.

LEAD: IN December, a computer enthusiast wreaked havoc at Lehigh University by programming a self-destruct code in personal computers on campus. The prank, which affected an estimated 200 people, was a sobering reminder that computer-dependent executives are vulnerable both to careless leaks and intentional sabotage.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The conservative attempt to equate the INF treaty with the Chamberlain-Hitler Munich agreement distorts the historical record (''The Right Against Reagan,'' by Hedrick Smith, Jan. 17).

LEAD: Demonstrators clashing with riot police after a rally yesterday in Seoul, South Korea. About 500 anti-Government demonstrators protested the proposed changes in rules for electing members of the National Assembly. Elections are scheduled for April.
LEAD: MAMA DAY By Gloria Naylor. 312 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $17.95.

LEAD: Downtown White Plains is getting something city officials have wanted for a long time - medium-priced condominiums in the midst of a half-dozen new, large office buildings near the railroad station.

LEAD: THE fight to remain open in a residential Woodmere community has become more than a zoning issue for the Life Center for Holocaust Studies. It is a matter of principle and recognition that the study of the Holocaust cannot be separated from the Jewish religion, according to Rabbi Benjamin Kamenetzky.

LEAD: At the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York, Alyse D. Gordon, the daughter of Philip Gordon of New York and the late Elizabeth P. Gordon, was married last night to Dr. Gary J. Ruth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Ruth of Auburn, Wash. Rabbi Saul Berman, assisted by Cantor Sherwood Goffin, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: I'm not tremendously educated in the art of figure skating, but I enjoy what I see. The beauty and physical efficiency of the competitors, the graceful and sophisticated movements, the poise, the confidence, the acrobatic ability that is exhibited is what provides for the most glamorous, yet most difficult of the winter sports events.

LEAD: Bridgestone Tire agreed to pay $1 billion for 75 percent of Firestone in what is believed to be the largest Japanese investment yet in an American manufacturer. Firestone is the nation's third-largest tire maker, with $2.6 billion of tire sales annually. But after the deal, its largest business will be 1,500 retail stores that sell tires and other automotive goods and services.
LEAD: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has attacked the Republican Presidential primary voting system in New York as ''onerous'' and ''a stain on the party.''

LEAD: Twenty years ago, when Gov. Tom McCall signed a bill declaring the uncluttered sands, high dunes and rocky shores of the 362-mile Oregon coast off limits to the claims of private property, some developers called it ''the communist manifesto.''

LEAD: The excellent article ''Incest Victims Get Sympathy but Little Help'' alerted the public to a serious social problem in Suffolk County but did not explain that in Nassau County we have developed an extensive range of services for victims.

LEAD: AS predictably as sunset burnishes the half-moon coves and secluded cays of the Bay Islands, off Honduras's Caribbean coast, visitors begin to wonder how long the islands can escape the kind of large-scale tourist development that has both benefited and blighted so many other tropical beauty spots.

LEAD: A MILLION DOLLAR yearly phone bill would send most companies into shock, but to Michael H. Wellner, president of the Kemwel Group in Harrison, it is an indication that business is good. LEAD: FREEDOM of speech. As an American I've come to take that for granted.

LEAD: THE big musical event of the week is the six-day series of lectures, discussions and concerts that Wesleyan University is devoting to the avant-garde composer John Cage, who has turned 75 years old.

LEAD: A Federal district judge in New York has temporarily barred the enforcement of new regulations that would prevent most family planning centers in the state from helping women to obtain abortions, a spokeswoman for the American Civil Liberties Union reported yesterday.

LEAD: BERLIOZ'S opera ''Beatrice and Benedict'' contains some of his most magical music, but with its rigorous demands for accomplished acting and singing and its musical complexity, it is rarely performed. Thus one welcomed Friday evening's production by the Juilliard American Opera Center, especially in the confines of the city's best opera facility, the Juilliard Theater.
