LEAD: Members of the President's AIDS commission said yesterday that they would strongly recommend greater use of neighborhood doctors and patients to test potential drug treatments for AIDS as a supplement to the government-sponsored tests at academic medical centers.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: When Dan Jansen fell, it was not from grace. Last week, hours before he was to compete in the first of two Olympic speed-skating events in which he had high hopes of winning medals, Jansen got word that his sister, Jane Jansen Beres, had died of leukemia. He was noticeably distraught as he started the 500-meter finals, and tumbled to the ice in the first turn.

LEAD: In the early days of World War II, the owners of many of the stately homes in this Washington suburb were asked to rent their spare rooms to help accomodate the influx of military and civilian workers into the capital.

LEAD: After starting slowly, players in salary arbitration finished with a flourish, winning two of the last three cases and five of the last eight. In the final decisions yesterday, Bob Boone of California and Mark Thurmond of Detroit won, and Tim Burke of Montreal lost.
LEAD: SENATOR KERRY. We had 11 new senators come in last time.
LEAD: The reputed leader of a Chicago-area white supremacist group called the Skinheads and five others were indicted today for attacking a woman and drawing a swastika on her wall with her blood.
LEAD: Adapted from ''Getting Better: Inside Alcoholics Anonymous,'' by Nan Robertson, to be published by William Morrow in April.

LEAD: More than a decade after the death of Marcel Pagnol, the international triumph of ''Jean de Florette'' and ''Manon des Sources'' introduced millions of people to Pagnol's Provence - as distinctive and enduring a terrain of the imagination as William Faulkner's Yoknapatawpha County. Contemporary audiences could be pardoned for believing that these picturesquely colored views of Yves Montand making mischief in the arid hills of the Midi - so scrupulously orchestrated by the director Claude Berri - were indeed the real thing.

LEAD: ''If the Iran-Iraq war does not come to an end officially in 1988, it will at least be practically over.'' This judgment, so contrary to the prevailing image of the war as a conflict without end, was expressed several weeks ago not by an armchair observer from afar but by Crown Prince Abdallah of Saudi Arabia, who had just completed a round of consultations about the war in the major Arab capitals followed by a summit meeting of Arab Gulf states.

LEAD: In a recurrent fantasy, I envision George Orwell reading a hi-fi catalogue. His gaunt gray face looks puzzled. The great champion of clarity and integrity in language - the man who skewered newspeak, cant and blather -frowns at the jargon of audio.

LEAD: IRMA THOMAS'S 47th birthday was celebrated during her early set Thursday at the Lone Star Cafe -much to the audience's, and apparently the singer's, surprise - when her fan club president brought a cake onstage. Although Ms. Thomas has been making records since 1958 and had a string of New Orleans rhythm-and-blues hits in the early 1960's, time has been on her side.

LEAD: Anita Wachter of Austria and the Swiss duo of Vreni Schneider and Brigitte Oertli positioned themselves as the skiers to beat for the gold medal in the women's combined competition in Mount Allan, Alberta.
LEAD: At least 34 people have been killed in 24 hours in bombings and ambushes by Sikh separatists in Punjab, news reports said today.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: OPPOSITION to a key aspect of a plan to revise certification standards for school principals is intensifying.

LEAD: BRYANT & COOPER in Roslyn is a steakhouse with a difference. Its dual personality will delight those who normally shun beef palaces. But fear not, the red meat gang will definitely not be shut out.

LEAD: Bay Shore $210,000 51 Bayview Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, fireplace, sunporch, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500. Brightwaters $212,000 347 North Windsor Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 70-year-old colonial; den, basement, fireplace, balcony; taxes $3,000.

LEAD: Dan Jansen said today that he planned to compete in two more international events this season. Jansen, 22 years old, spoke after the funeral for his sister, Jane Beres, 27, who died of leukemia last Sunday, hours before he competed in the men's 500-meter speed-skating race at the Olympics.

LEAD: Jay Anthony Gach, born in New York in 1953, has won first prize in the first Frederick P. Rose Competition of the Brooklyn Philharmonic for new orchestral works by American composers. Mr. Gach won a cash award of $10,000 and a performance of his score, ''Chant,'' during the orchestra's 1988-89 season.

LEAD: As Cyprus prepares for a presidential runoff election on Sunday, the result is far from clear, but the problem that will confront the winner is evident: how to revive efforts to reconcile and reunite the island's Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot communities.

LEAD: The Lower East Side is still home to some of the most creative rock-and-roll groups in the country. The area that fostered Blondie, Velvet Underground and Television supports groups that push rock forms to their limits. The music often winds its way in and around political lyrics; just as often, pop-styled songs with user-friendly melodies grab listeners' attention, only to hit them with odd-angled rhythms, subversive lyrics and crooked harmonies.

LEAD: Only ice hockey requires the molding of 18 to 20 individuals into a competitive team. Moreover, there is a uniqueness in the contrasting styles of play among the Europeans, Canadians and Americans. And the unpredictable nature of the Olympic ice-hockey tournament adds to the sport's premier status in the Winter Games.

LEAD: The ranking members of New York City's government are in an uproar, and have been for weeks. With the exception of Mayor Koch, they are angry, even shaken, by a formidable threat to their power.
LEAD: A MAXIM among woodworkers is that one can't have too many clamps.
LEAD: DUSK And Other Stories. By James Salter. 157 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $14.95.

LEAD: The Swiss bickered among themselves. The skiers, in general, complained about the wind and lack of snow. The ticket-holders arrived at this winter resort about 65 miles west of Calgary, not knowing whether they would see a race, much less which one. Still, nothing that happened during the first week of the Alpine events here at Mount Allan has caused as big a stir as Alberto Tomba of Italy is likely to when he begins competing Sunday.

LEAD: For the first time since Ronald Reagan became President more than seven years ago, the American public generally does not believe the nation's future will be better than its present or its past, according to a New York Times/ CBS News Poll.
LEAD: Shrinking banks and brokerage houses are creating a void in the downtown office market that stronger sectors of the Manhattan economy will offset only marginally in coming years.
LEAD: Whatever else this presidential campaign is, it is the first in which candidates, prominent supporters and even bit players are now fully wired for sound.
LEAD: High Tech's Next Twist

LEAD: ''The Return of the Hero'' is a group show that asks, then answers, the question: Does Lt. Col. Oliver North represent merely the tip of the iceberg when it comes to our current yearnings? Apparently. The 13 artists included - not all of them photographers, it should be said - seem to be in agreement that warrior-like appearance and behavior are definitely ''in'' in the late 80's.

LEAD: Tickets go on sale tomorrow at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street, for two screenings - on March 18 and 19 at 8 P.M. - of the film ''Koyaanisqatsi'' with live accompaniment by the Philip Glass Ensemble.

LEAD: What do Edward G. Robinson, Alec Guinness, Daryl Hannah and Dick Van Dyke have in common? Apart from being artists in the entertainment sense, they have also played artists in the artistic sense. And as Hollywood and the New York art world move closer together in the 1980's - with their star systems, the big prices and instant fame that awaits hot new discoveries - Hollywood has started to take the art world seriously (or humorously, as the case may be).

LEAD: The photographs, all in black and white and many very rare, have been mounted on illustration boards and arranged in neat piles on long tables, hundreds of photographs, waiting to be put up on the gallery walls of the Jewish Museum for the exhibition on Russian and Soviet Jewry opening Thursday. Looking up at me from one of the photographs is the dreamy-eyed face of the young Marc Chagall.

LEAD: YALE GLEE CLUB IN BERGEN The 100-voice Yale Glee Club will appear at the John Harms Center for the Performing Arts in Englewood Friday evening in a benefit for the Scholarship Fund of the Bergen County Yale Alumni Association.
LEAD: The South African Air Force struck two guerrilla bases in Angola today, after a bomb blast in South-West Africa on Friday that killed 18 people.

LEAD: Some legislators and citizens, and the states of Kansas and Pennsylvania, have brought a suit demanding that illegal aliens not be counted when Congress redistricts after the 1990 Census. They claim that undocumented aliens in states like New York and California will skew the results and perhaps cost their states a House seat.

LEAD: The marriage of Lorraine Adams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore V. Adams of Summit, N.J., to Michael Stanford, the son of Dr. Geoffrey Stanford of Dallas and Rosemary Stanford of Oxford, England, took place yesterday at the Americas Society in New York.

LEAD: In regard to the Jan. 10 article ''Incest Victims Get Sympathy but Little Help,'' I would like to say I agree with the statements that our current laws concerning the rights of abused children are considerably lacking in defending those rights.
LEAD: FYODOR DOSTOYEVSKY A Writer's Life. By Geir Kjetsaa. Translated by Siri Hustvedt and David McDuff. Illustrated. 437 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $24.95.

LEAD: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau will give three recitals of lieder - his first performances in the United States in eight years - at Carnegie Hall on March 22, 24 and 27. He will sing works by Schumann on the 22d, excerpts from Mahler's ''Knaben Wunderhorn'' on the 24th, and Hugo Wolf's ''Morike Lieder'' on the 27th, all with Hartmut
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Relations between Hungary and Rumania, neighbors and allies in the Warsaw Pact, have worsened to such a degree that they now speak to and about each other only in accusation.

LEAD: THE Trenton Civic Opera's production of ''The Sound of Music'' next Sunday will mark the culmination of months of work by dedicated amateurs, with one exception - the hairdresser and wig and hat designer.

LEAD: A former 24-pew Methodist church in Warwick, N.Y., is being converted into a 14,000-square-foot office building. While New York City has its cathedral of commerce - the gothic Woolworth Building - and its Limelight discotheque - once the Church of Holy Communion - the Orange County project is one of the rare altars-to-office conversions.

LEAD: Early in 1983, Jim Bunn, a new reporter for KPIX-TV here, finished writing his first AIDS report and knew the story was like none before. It had sex, death, medical intrigue, a host of complex social issues - not the least of which were civil rights and gay life styles - and, by definition, it was going to challenge every taboo known to television.

LEAD: THE VIZIER OF VULGARITY, the titan of terrible taste, the man whose 1972 movie ''Pink Flamingos'' is still disgusting 16 years later, stood - of all places - in front of a film festival audience and licked the rain of applause from his face.
LEAD: THE FOUNDING FORTUNES A New Anatomy of the Super-Rich Families in America. By Michael Patrick Allen. 438 pp. New York: Truman Talley Books/ E. P. Dutton. $22.50.

LEAD: >I USED to live on the third floor of an apartment building facing a row of town houses. When one of those houses changed hands, the new owners erected an oversized flagpole in the small yard beside their front steps. Every morning around seven, either the husband or the wife would emerge with a flag, attach it to the halyard and hoist it up, and every evening, not precisely at sunset but around that time, it was lowered and carefully folded away for the night.

LEAD: A jury has ruled that The Battle Creek Enquirer libeled a man in reporting that he was arrested in a rape investigation but not that he was never charged with the crime. The jury awarded him $1 million.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Julia Vitale Tyler, a daughter of Celia Vitale of Southbury, Conn., and Naples, Fla., and the late Alexander Vitale, was married yesterday to David Arnold Nufer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. D. George Nufer of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. John Halborg performed the ceremony.
LEAD: An elderly lady stepped up to a teller's window in the Chemical Bank branch at 86th and Columbus the other day. She unfolded scraps of paper, unearthed cards and finally asked for $200 in cash.

LEAD: Downhill skiing. Even those who haven't struggled to get on a chair lift, or stood at the top of the smallest slope and wondered, ''How am I going to get to the bottom?'' can appreciate the guts, skill, power and lunacy it takes to defy death and ski down an icy slope at speeds exceeding 80 miles per hour.
LEAD: On a raw winter morning near Skid Row, a dozen mothers on welfare listened to a story about a poor woman like them who once thought she had not a chance in the world.

LEAD: AMID conflicting calculations by officials over the cost of United States military operations in the Persian Gulf, it is clear that costs have risen and that little relief is in sight, despite the decision last week to reduce the naval force there slightly.
LEAD: THE United States Navy wants to impose a restricted zone across the entire width of the Thames River from Groton to Waterford, encompassing about 200 acres.

LEAD: IN October, a chief executive was horrified when his company's confidential boardroom deliberations hit the newspapers. He called in Corporate Loss Prevention Associates Ltd., whose technicians turned up a bug in the telephone switching equipment.

LEAD: The engagement of Liza Meltzer to John Durling Fixx, a son of Mary Durling Fixx of Oberlin, Ohio, and the late James F. Fixx, has been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Meltzer of Rochester, the parents of the bride-to-be. A July wedding is planned.
LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday with an article on the Stay in School Partnership Program misidentified the school where William Ford teaches. It is John Burroughs Junior High School in Yonkers.

LEAD: AFTER Amtrak's worst passenger train collision, in which 16 people were killed and 178 injured, John Riley, administrator of the Federal Railroad Administration, said he would seek comments from railroads on whether trains in the busy Northeast Corridor should have seat belts.

LEAD: Contending that the New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, ''is aligning himself with the culprits,'' lawyers for a black teen-ager who says she was kidnapped and sexually attacked by six white men broke off cooperation with Mr. Abrams yesterday.

LEAD: In Lebanon, where kidnapping is a cottage industry, the abduction last week of an American Marine, Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins, created more than the usual stir: Two apparently different groups of Islamic militants took credit for the kidnapping and a third Moslem militia undertook to rescue him.

LEAD: I STOOD before the courtyard of the great Buddhist monastery at Tengboche in Nepal; the festival of Mani-Rimdu was about to begin. First there were long blasts on the conch shells - an unearthly sound. Then a procession of monks dressed in robes of deep red, over tunics of yellow, apricot and orange, began to wind around the courtyard.

LEAD: ''Committed to Print'' at the Museum of Modern Art is an exhibition of ''social and political'' material - prints, posters, books and magazines that relate to concerns of today and yesterday in the United States. In almost all of them, the word ranks equal with the image. The general tone is defined by the museum as ''leftist or liberal,'' and for much of the way the word pulls the image along, the way horses pulled a covered wagon.

LEAD: DOROTHY (DOBBIE) R. NICHOLLS loves the insults her classes hurl at her on exam days. ''Nos morituri te salutamus,'' they shout. (We who are about to die, salute you) and ''Dux femina facti.'' (The woman is the leader of the deed.) Mrs. Nicholls is a teacher of Latin - the so-called dead language that this 43-year-old classics enthusiast has made the ''in'' language at Katonah's John Jay High School.

LEAD: Mario Vazquez Rana, the Mexican publisher who has owned United Press International since 1986, announced Friday that he had sold the right to operate the news service to an investment group associated with Financial News Network, a cable television service.

LEAD: Gabriel Garcia Marquez is about to publish ''Love in the Time of Cholera,'' a work he calls a novel of manners: the story of two people whose love, thwarted in their youth, finally flourishes when they are close to 80.

LEAD: In Guatemala, where thousands of people have died in political violence during the 1980's, human rights advocates have never been popular. So the creation last year of an independent agency empowered to denounce any and all abuses aroused considerable curiosity and even some hope.
LEAD: Demand Still Outpaces Room In Soviet Hotels

LEAD: THE shooting of a Merrill Lynch stockbroker by a distraught investor during the October market collapse sent shivers throughout corporate America. Fearful that violence could increase if the economy sours, a growing number of companies are hiring ''executive protection security personnel,'' or bodyguards, for top executives.

LEAD: RAISING YOUR JEWISH/CHRISTIAN CHILD: Wise Choices for Interfaith Parents. By Lee F. Gruzen. (Weber/Dodd, Mead, $16.95.) Lee Ferguson Gruzen is a Protestant married to Jordan Gruzen, a Jew. Like all parents in mixed marriages, they had some important choices to make regarding the religious training of their children.

LEAD: THE FASCINATION WITH FASHIONS PAT-terned after animal coats comes and goes. This winter, however, it arrived full force. Faux pelts have been spotted everywhere. From skirts to handbags to slipcovers, everything appeared to be more desirable if it had leopards' spots or tigers' stripes. These beasts' natural markings are carried out in complicated sequin embroideries; printed on silk, satin, denim or cotton, or stenciled on calfskin.

LEAD: CITRUS IS THE SAME IN French and English, conjuring up images of freshness, lightness and zesty flavor. The year-old restaurant named Citrus in Los Angeles blends French and American cuisines to produce lively and remarkably healthful dishes.

LEAD: THROUGHOUT the country, corporate chiefs are sounding paeans to American industry's rebound from the competitive doldrums. In speeches, published papers and annual reports, they note how they have cut the fat out of management layers and divested businesses that did not fit in with overall corporate strategy.

LEAD: MANY people say that young Japanese students went into engineering while ours thronged into law, that the products developed by one of these groups found eager buyers around the world while the product of the other found none.

LEAD: Richard Dotson sat quietly in front of his locker stall this morning, his attention drawn to a copy of the Yankee media guide that someone had handed to each of the players. Beside him sat Lee Guetterman, a pitcher of imposing physical proportions - he is 6 feet 8 inches - and not far away was Tim Stoddard, who is 6-7 and a former basketball player on North Carolina

LEAD: John Wayne Hearn, a convicted murderer whose classified advertisement in Soldier of Fortune magazine led to a suit against the publication, says most of the people who answered the ad were seeking help in crimes like bombings, assaults, jailbreaks and murders.

LEAD: IN SEARCH OF THE DARK AGES. By Michael Wood. (Facts on File, $22.95.) Michael Wood, author of ''In Search of the Trojan War,'' has now turned to slightly more modern times: the genesis of the English nation. He begins in A.D. 60, when Boadicea led her Celtic tribesmen in a doomed revolt against Roman rule, and ends a millennium later with William the Conqueror.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Rev. and Mrs. George A. Pera of Alexandria, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tracey Pera, to Peter David Sanders, a son of Prof. and Mrs. David S. Sanders of Claremont, Calif. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Because most theatrical movies made in any year are instantly disposable, without any aspirations beyond being amusing for a limited span of time, it's not easy to argue that movies are debased when they show up on television, reduced in size and clarity, in what is, in effect, their second run.

LEAD: AT the top of the game, those who are thought of as great bidders are rarely perceived to be great dummy players and vice versa. There is a psychological reason for this, which is unconnected with any absolute standard of performance.

LEAD: Emily Ritchie DuHamel and Montgomery C. Brower, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brock H. Brower of Princeton, N.J., plan to marry in June, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Notley Y. DuHamel Jr. of Montclair, N.J., and Sakonnet, R.I., have announced.

LEAD: When it comes down to Olympic tradition, the biathlon is the best Winter Olympic sport. Cross-country skiers swiftly stride through the woods, pushing the limits of physical endurance, then immediately gain absolute control of mind, body and emotion to prove their marksmanship, with the clock ticking in the background.
LEAD: Canada, which had scored six goals in its first three games, got seven in the first period today and clinched a medal-round berth with a 9-5 hockey victory over France.

LEAD: The Volubility of Tongue There have always been minimalists, people who distrust language, as if it had a will of its own and could trick us out of ourselves. This is Thomas Sprat, a 17th-century historian, quoted in ''One Culture: Essays in Science and Literature,'' edited by George Levine (University of
LEAD: Fifty-four economists told Congress today that raising the minimum wage would have little adverse effect on the economy.

LEAD: WHEN we visited our son when he was in college in Bogota 10 years ago, I asked with some embarrassment about drinking the water. He snorted and said the water at the Hilton was as safe as at home. Since his arrival there, he had not reported being ill, so I followed his lead. But when we traveled to San Andres Island, Colombia, he took one look at the tap in the hotel room there and said: ''Not this water.

LEAD: One thing New York City's government has never been accused of is being artistic. Colorful, maybe. But not artistic. Until now. In an effort to explain the current city government to an electorate that will be voting on changing it next November, the Charter Revision Commission has issued a whimsical poster that illustrates the city's vast bureauracy.

LEAD: ''The difference is that the limits are narrowing,'' a young, American-educated Salvadoran businessman said. ''The extremes, right and left, are being ruled out, as more and more people see they can't solve anything.''

LEAD: IT was billed as a battle of titans, but the 17,500 fans who jammed the Northlands Coliseum in Edmonton on Friday night didn't get to see much of the two high-scoring stars, Wayne Gretzky, the hometown favorite, and Mario Lemieux of the visiting Pittsburgh Penguins.

LEAD: A black teen-ager sentenced to death at the age of 15 was convicted today of murder in a retrial brought after the state Supreme Court overturned his original conviction by an all-white jury. The prosecutor said he would not seek the death penalty again.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Soft Breezes, Hard Water THEY prefer ''hard water'' to ''soft water,'' but not from the tap. Hard water means ice to a certain segment of Long Island's sailing population, and sailing on ice tops sailing on water any day, iceboaters contend.

LEAD: N.H.L. Red Wings Win Third Straight: Shawn Burr scored twice and Glen Hanlon stopped 23 shots yesterday as the Red Wings won their third straight game by beating the Chicago Blackhawks, 6-1, in Detroit. Burr's first goal, 10 minutes 50 seconds into the second period, increased Detroit's lead to 2-0.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Weiner of Sands Point, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Karen Lessall Weiner, to Charles A. Goss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Goss of Piscataway, N.J.

LEAD: It apparently takes more than a broken nose to stop Larry Bird. Two days after breaking his nose and leaving the game with only 13 points in a Celtic loss to the Denver Nuggets, Bird returned to the Boston lineup for a game against the Trail Blazers in Portland on Friday night, and as near as anyone could tell, the injury did not hamper his play.

LEAD: Stephanie Louise Kuehn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernd Percy Kuehn of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Westerly, R.I., was married in Purchase, N.Y., yesterday to Hans Christoph Vitzthum von Eckstadt 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vitzthum von Eckstadt 3d of New York; Jacksonville, Vt., and Bailleul, France. The Rev.
LEAD: With the performance of his life tonight, Brian Boitano won the Olympic gold medal in figure skating, the first gold won by the United States in the XV Olympic Winter Games.

LEAD: An impressive array of performances by women brightens the cable movie week. Joan Crawford, Ginger Rogers, Jennifer Jones, Sophia Loren and Glenda Jackson are all Oscar-winners. For dessert? A surprisingly vivacious stint by ice skater Sonja Henie.

LEAD: JOHN PIUS JR. was 13 years old on the night of April 20, 1979, when he was killed in one of the most shocking crimes in Long Island history. When his body was found the following afternoon, it was buried under a pile of logs and leaves in the woods near a Smithtown schoolyard with six rocks stuffed down his throat.

LEAD: ''MORE Than Just Something to Keep You Warm,'' the title of an exhibition of Afro-American folk art at the Bergen Museum of Art and Science, adds an affirmative twist to a black woman's modest appraisal of a quilt she had made.
LEAD: TO DWELL IN PEACE An Autobiography. By Daniel Berrigan. Illustrated. 356 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $19.95.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH most New Yorkers live in apartment buildings, the city's property tax system displays a curious political tilt against them and in favor the minority of city dwellers who own one-, two- or three-family homes.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 22 food establishments cited for violating the health code.
LEAD: NEWLY restructured, hungry and aggressive, I.B.M. is preparing a barrage of new products for its Personal System/2 line of microcomputers.

LEAD: JAPAN and megalopolis are synonymous in the minds of many travelers, but more Americans are discovering a Japan of mountain wilderness that is accessible to the adventurous visitor. Most itineraries emphasize visits to shrines, temples and sushi bars, so it can be startling to learn that you can go hiking in the Japanese Alps.
LEAD: The kidnappers of a United States Marine officer have apparently slipped him through a security net set up in southern Lebanon by United Nations forces and local Moslem Shiite militiamen.

LEAD: BOTH OF THE SMALL glass jars have colored filaments swirling through them; both are sold with little plastic paddles, one pink and the other green. One is Estee Lauder's Eyzone Repair Gel, the other is Revlon's Anti-Aging Firming Eye Gel.

LEAD: IT WAS a year ago this month that a Federal jury in Mobile, Ala., decided that when Ku Klux Klansmen commit violence, not only they - but the group to which they belong - can be held liable for damages.

LEAD: At Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in New York, Robin Marie Pugh was married yesterday to William George Filmyer Jr. by Msgr. Myles M. Bourke. Susannah Pomeroy Scannell and Elizabeth Cancian Rust were the maid and the matron of honor. Milton Webster Anderson was the best man.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The controversy over New York State's effort to establish a park, the Neversink River Unique Area, in the river's magnificently wild gorge in Sullivan County has entered a new phase. On Feb. 4, Thomas C. Jorling, commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation announced that his office would seek to accomplish that end by eminent-domain proceedings.

LEAD: MRS. CALIBAN, by Rachel Ingalls. (Laurel/Dell, $6.95.) An unhappy California housewife has an affair with a 6-foot-7-inch amphibian humanoid named Larry, who is fleeing from the law. In 1986, our reviewer, Michael Dorris, compared the novel to ''a strange conversation overheard on a bus: sketchy, incomplete, maddening, but totally unforgettable.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II's encyclical letter condemning the superpower rivalry is a highly personal document that reflects his Polish heritage and is characteristically both blunt and meditative, according to senior Vatican officials.

LEAD: Nouvelle Hampshire, The Washington Post called it, and the change can be seen in the old brick factory buildings in Manchester. Forlorn eight years ago, they now gleam with electronics businesses. Boutiques abound. Parking spots do not.

LEAD: Does the world offer a more beautiful sight than the crimson stare of a burglar alarm? Not to people who live by themselves, or with small children, or who are not named Rambo. There it is, the watchdog that doesn't have to be walked, ready to roar if anyone so much as tries to jimmy a window. If millions of
LEAD: YOU buy a frozen pizza in the supermarket. Should the food processor tell you in a prominent label whether you're getting real cheese?

LEAD: The engagement of Sandy Sevier Simmons to Geoffrey Porter Leonard, the son of James Leonard of New York and the late Georgine Leonard, has been made known by the future bride's mother, Mrs. John M. Simmons of Olympia, Wash. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: FOR 33 years the Senior Personnel Employment Council of Westchester has offered a no-fee employment service for workers older than 55. The first organization of its type in the nation, it has been replicated many times. The key ''plus'' that the council offers to workers is the absence of any discrimination because of age: employers list jobs with the full knowledge that we on the council deal only with workers 55 and older.

LEAD: Few Americans have suffered in such a curious manner from distorted public image as have those of Italian background. The prejudices have been less harsh than those affecting other groups, but no less demeaning. THE ITALIAN AMERICANS (Macmillan, $49.50), an account by Allon Schoener, a cultural historian, of Italian life in the United States in word and picture, is a more positive testimony to the nature and achievements of these remarkably vibrant people.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: IN the last 16 months, the University of Massachusetts at Amherst has endured just about the worst kind of publicity a college could get.

LEAD: Nine years ago, I graduated with the last class of the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing, one of the very few nursing schools for college graduates seeking a Bachelor of Science degree in nursing (''A Great Hospital in Crisis,'' by M. A. Farber and Lawrence K. Altman, Jan. 24).

LEAD: ''When I was a kid,'' the Balinese shadow puppeteer I Nyoman Sumandhi says, ''I loved to play with puppets - but not real ones, just a special kind of leaf. My father and my grandfather didn't let me play with their puppets, because we call the puppet a kind of sacred thing.''
LEAD: Following is a schedule of events: Saturday

LEAD: The engagement of Meryl Sali Justin to Michael Chertoff, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Gershon B. Chertoff of Elizabeth, N.J., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joshua I. Justin of New York, the future bride's parents. A June wedding is planned. Miss Justin, an associate in the New York law firm of Schoeman, Marsh, Updike & Welt, graduated from Harvard University and the Harvard Law School.
LEAD: To the Editor: It was gratifying to find, in C. L. Sulzberger's piece (Travel, Jan. 3), that newsmen still find Harry's New York Bar in Paris newsworthy.
LEAD: The government is sending message in tortilla packages to remind illegal aliens about the deadline to apply for immigration amnesty.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The day before their final exam, the students at this town's only university were cramming for the grueling, eight-hour test. Julie Eringis had been at it for hours, but she still worried that her cake doughnuts might turn out too greasy on the big day. Allan Gunn had studied 18 hours a day for the past week, but he was nervous too.
LEAD: Fee-Simple Condo

LEAD: Rural life may be a ''joke'' to Ed Koch and the suburbs a ''sterile'' place to dwell, but if the Mayor believes he's about to double the city income tax for commuters, he has another guess coming.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Pillar of North Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amie Michele Pillar, to Robert Alan Feldman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome O. Feldman of Merrick, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: After an uneasy political truce that lasted nearly 20 years, Canada has been thrust anew into a bitter dispute over its abortion laws.

LEAD: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, who accused Jim Bakker, the ousted PTL leader, of sexual misconduct, had no comment today on reports that the Assemblies of God church was investigating similar allegations against him.

LEAD: IF you think having a suit made in Hong Kong, where the tourist association's booklet on shopping and restaurants lists 142 tailoring establishments, is easy, think again. At least, if you have visions of a beautifully made, perfectly fitting suit with the construction, fit and hand-sewn touches that come only with custom work.

LEAD: AVON Products, makers of women's cosmetics, has been the largest taxpayer in the city of Rye for many years. Now more than 350 residents have organized in opposition to its expansion and are asking the city to block its plans for two office buildings.

LEAD: LIQUIDATION SALE IN SCARSDALE Boutique Elle in Scarsdale was the first of three stores of that name selling stylish Italian sportswear, cocktail and evening wear. The others are in Cedarhurst Center in Cedarhurst, L.I., and the Woodbury Common in Woodbury, L.I. LEAD: More than 300,000 Czechoslovak Catholics have signed an appeal to their Government to guarantee the Roman Catholic Church fundamental rights, after the church leader threw the weight of his authority behind the petition.

LEAD: The players politely considered the question, which promoted the notion that the game between the United States and West Germany on Sunday night would be hockey's version of World War II.

LEAD: Dancing is an exhausting profession, and one that leaves little time or resources for providing for an unforeseen problem. Sunday night the New York City Ballet closes its winter season at the New York State Theater with the Dancers' Emergency Fund Benefit. Instituted three years ago, the benefit raises money that is used to help resolve sudden crises in the lives of the dancers who bring the City Ballet repertory to life season after season.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Connick of New York have announced the engagement of their niece, Hilary Whittaker Curtis, to William George Hartman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Hartman Jr. of Northbrook, Ill. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: NEARBY RAFTING North American Whitewater Expeditions Inc., based in Hamden, Conn., offers what it believes is ''some of the best whitewater rafting in the East'' beginning in March and continuing through early May. An eight-mile stretch of the upper Housatonic River, starting at Bull's Bridge Gorge in western Connecticut, provides a course through rapids that drop 90 feet in the first mile, then rushes through steep chasms, over large waves and difficult ledge drops.

LEAD: AS a former member of a Board of Education on Long Island, I believe that the recent Supreme Court decision upholding control of student publications should be supported. I do not believe the decision to permit school boards and administrators to ban material deemed unsuited for publication is either a devastating blow to freedom of speech or ''the wrong civic lesson'' for teen-age students.

LEAD: The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council have taken a significant step toward imposing an arms embargo on Iran as part of their attempt to end the Persian Gulf war, according to diplomats involved in the negotiations.

LEAD: For the first time an American company has contracted to have the Soviet Union carry Western commercial payloads into orbit. The agreement is likely to spur similar moves by other companies, Federal officials said.

LEAD: When Scott Gregory and Suzanne Semanick won their second straight United States ice dancing title last month, they were operating at less than full strength. Because Gregory suffered a herniated disk last November, he could not lift his partner.
LEAD: In his State of the State address, Governor Kean tried to increase or shift the level of mediocrity from one school area to another.

LEAD: ON the New Haven line trains last week, grumbling was in the air where smoke had once been.
LEAD: Most people in the first coach car were trying to sleep in the wee hours this morning when the California Zephyr pulled into the small station here to pick up passengers.

LEAD: UNLIKE the man they are honoring, the music faculty at Wesleyan University has tried to leave nothing to chance.
LEAD: It was exciting to read about how Donald Perry has learned to traverse the jungle canopy to explore the secrets of the rain forest (''Secrets of the Rain Forest,'' by Erik Eckholm, Jan. 17).

LEAD: AS MORE than 100 demonstrators protested, ground was broken last week on Blanchard Street, in the city's Ironbound section, for Essex County's resource-recovery plant.
LEAD: If Mr. Prospector were a better sire of grass horses, this season's handicap racing in Florida would be much poorer, because Jade Hunter would be wintering in Europe.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. O'Neill of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagment of their daughter Kathryn Mary O'Neill to Nicholas C. Katz, the son of Carol Cambas of New York and Sanford M. Katz of New York and East Hampton, L.I.

LEAD: A reporter for The Boston Globe was ordered jailed for contempt of court after refusing to disclose the identities of confidential sources cited in a 1982 article about a former city official. Judge John P. Sullivan of Suffolk Superior Court said Thursday he would allow the reporter, Charles A. Radin, to remain free at least a week to appeal.

LEAD: To the Editor: William L. Tazewell's article, ''A Washington Outside the Beltway'' (Travel, Dec. 27), was read with delight at the recognition the Inn at Little Washington received. I, too, have been a guest there and thought of it as my little secret.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Freudenheim of Buffalo of the engagement of their daughter Julie R. Freudenheim to Spencer Greg Feldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Feldman of Patchogue, L.I. The couple plan to marry in May.
LEAD: AS the baby-boom generation grows older, more children are contributing to the support of their aging parents and looking to basic tax devices to reduce their costs.

LEAD: RAW-BONED, loose-limbed Mississippi blues - music so traditional it can sound avant-garde -twanged and strutted at the Triplex on Friday night, in a triple bill presented by the World Music Institute. Two of the oldest Mississippi styles and one of their wayward, electrified offspring filled the theater with sounds usually heard at barbecues, back porches and juke joints, defying the formality of a concert hall with down-home directness.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Zinsser Jr. of New York and West Cornwall, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mr. Zinsser's daughter Amanda Locke Zinsser to James Matthews Moffat, the son of Mrs. Daniel G. Quigley of Bedford, N.Y., and John Moffat of Cooperstown, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: A task force of 15 House Democrats representing liberal, moderate and conservative wings of the party has tentatively agreed on a $25 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels, according to Congressional aides. Jim Wright, the House Speaker, hopes to bring the proposal to the House floor for a vote on

LEAD: Two Emergency Medical Service ambulance workers face disciplinary action because they waited for sandwiches in a Bronx delicatessen before responding to a report that a man was suffering a heart attack in a church one block away, officials said yesterday.

To put a finer point on it, they are marking the 100th anniversary of the first game of golf reliably known to have been played on an
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN the 1950's, it was heralded as a paragon of construction technology. A shining and proud example of what highways could be, it was a masterful and much-anticipated artery for the enhanced exchange of interstate commerce and a promise of great things to come.

LEAD: James Patrick, who had the misfortune of playing many of the 60 humiliating minutes against the Devils the night before, sat with his head in his hands and his back, appropriately, against the wall.

LEAD: PURSUED BY THE CROOKED MAN. By Susan Trott. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) You've heard of novels based on the Bible, Greek myths or even Arthurian legend; this may be one of the first inspired by Mother Goose. But why not? The heroine, Miliana Bartha, who is possessed of ''three children, one husband, two lovers, and a woman friend,'' has an inspiration while scrubbing the floor one day.
LEAD: OSCAR WILDE By Richard Ellmann. Illustrated. 680 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.
LEAD: With 20 states and American Samoa holding Democratic primaries or caucuses on March 8, and 17 states having Republican contests, it sounds as if there will be 38 separate elections.

LEAD: FIVE members of the Nation of Islam (also known as the Black Muslims) are appealing a Federal District Court ruling that upheld the New Jersey prison system's right to prohibit them from praying together during recreation in the prison yard.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BEING known for a favorite defense is a two-way street. If you are really good with it, you will intimidate many an opponent and score victories against listless play. Yet no matter how good you are with it, it does point the opponent toward what he has to prepare when he comes up against you. And there are opponents who cannot be intimidated.

LEAD: The marriage of Pamela Jillson Phillips, the daughter of Patricia B. Phillips of Fairfield, Conn., and William A. Phillips of Greenwich, Conn., to Richard Bernard Noonan, a son of Robert W. Noonan of Osterville, Mass., and the late Frances E. Noonan, took place yesterday at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich.

LEAD: The engagement of Suzanne Ruth Herzberg to Brian J. Mayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Mayer of Fairfield, Conn., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Walter J. Herzberg of Fair Lawn, N.J., parents of the future bride. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: In a departure from longstanding Government policy, a Federal agency has bought five foreign automobiles for use in this country, prompting an outcry from political, industry and labor leaders.

LEAD: Housing affordability is at its highest level in over 10 years nationwide, but fewer purchases are being made by first-time buyers, a survey by the National Association of Realtors shows. It also indicates that those with incomes well over the median dominate the market.

LEAD: Relief services for about 260,000 Palestinian refugees in Lebanon will be cut to the minimum because the kidnapping of two employees of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency have raised fears over staff safety, the agency said today. The two employees - Jan Stening, 44 years old, of Sweden, and William Jorgensen, 58, of Norway - were kidnapped Feb.

LEAD: HIGHER gasoline taxes, rusting bridges, tainted water supplies, unending crusades to ''increase efficiency'' in government offices ''to better serve the public.'' All these result from our constant attempts to stretch government farther than its resources can reach.

LEAD: MARCEL DUCHAMP bestowed a moustache on a reproduction of the Mona Lisa in 1919. However, art about art didn't take root as an official policy until the 1950's when Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns began their careers parodying Abstract Expressionism and it was another two decades before photography followed suit.

LEAD: IN THE lobby of the McCarter Theatre here is a display of Fred Astaire accoutrements -a top hat, a straw hat, a white tie and all manner of cigarette holders - and photographs of his screen partners, mostly Judy Garland.
LEAD: WASHINGTON

LEAD: Bradford, Conn. $235,000 26 Riverside Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; landscaping, near river, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,274. Clinton, Conn. $142,000 10 Hurdbridge Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old Cape Cod; in-law apartment, pool, 0.50 acre; taxes $1,199.

LEAD: Ianis Kipours of the Soviet Union, aided by deteriorating track conditions that slowed Wolfgang Hoppe of East Germany, the defending gold medalist, jumped from fourth to first on the second run in the Olympic two-man bobsled today to set up what could be one of the biggest upsets with two heats remaining Sunday.

LEAD: Katherine Thayer Kreitler's engagement to Ronald Gray Hodge 2d, the son of Patricia Kues of Morehead City, N.C., and Ronald G. Hodge of Charlotte, N.C., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hobart C. Kreitler of Southport, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: On a side street in one of Philadelphia's poorest and meanest neighborhoods, there sits a vacant stone building that is about to be transformed into a residence for 25 homeless people. It might serve as a minor monument to the way in which a meddling Federal Government, in the view of governors and mayors, often frustrates local efforts to address many of the nation's urgent domestic ills.

LEAD: ''YEARS ago, security was at the bottom of the totem pole,'' said Michael Goodrich, general manager of Spectra Audio Research Inc., which makes electronic security devices. Now, he went on, executives are quietly investing in bodyguards, bulletproof vests, automatic vehicle locators to trace a missing car and other high-tech gear.

LEAD: The Super Maine, a huge hot air balloon, rose 50 feet over frozen Sebago Lake several times today, carrying as many as 60 people at a time, though it was firmly tied to the ground. The designers, builders and supporters of the 210-foot-high, 168-foot-wide balloon simply wanted to make a balloon larger than the Virgin Atlantic Flier, which crossed the Atlantic last summer.

LEAD: Alaska Ferries Question: I am told there are ferries from Seattle to Alaska that stop at ports in the way cruise ships do. Are there sleeping accommodations? Where do you write for information? - H. C., Hauppauge, L.I. Answer: A ferry service called Alaska Marine Highway operates year-round between Seattle and Skagway, Alaska.
LEAD: It was around the midpoint in three days of talks to save The New York Post, late Thursday evening, and all seemed well on the surface.
LEAD: TO BE AN ISRAELI THESE DAYS IS, for many of us, to live with the sense that our world has begun to crumble, that our deepest beliefs and most cherished dreams are being shattered.
LEAD: St. John's lost for the second time in three days last night, this time to a surprising DePaul team.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BEHIND PALACE DOORS, THE PRINCE OF Wales sometimes refers to journalists as ''creeps and bloody hacks.'' In the past, such outbursts have greeted aides' suggestions that he hold private, off-the-record meetings with British editors in an attempt to get them to pay more attention to his speeches and less to his troubled marriage.

LEAD: Taking a cue from anxious developers, Leonard D'Andrea stirred some flash into the strategy for selling his home in Stamford, Conn. Besides posting a competitive price on the two-bedroom condominium, he is offering to pay the buyer's $160-a-month maintenance fee for six months.
LEAD: As large new construction projects move forward on Broadway in the Times Square area, the main unanswered question, amid all the concern over design and scale, is who will occupy the buildings.
LEAD: NEW LONDON LANDMARKS, a nonprofit preservation group, has begun a program to provide owners of the city's many older homes and other buildings with advice on rehabilitation and restoration.
LEAD: MY FIRST LOVES By Ivan Klima. Translated by Ewald Osers. 164 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.
LEAD: CASTAWAYS The Penikese Island Experiment. By George Cadwalader. 193 pp. Chelsea, Vt.: Chelsea Green Publishing Company. $17.95.

LEAD: Guy Blundon is not one to waste a waterfront. Of the 16 apartments that compose the Davenport Slip condominium he is developing with his partner, Lenard Thylan, 12 will have stepped terraces and sliding glass walls facing New Rochelle Creek. The four other apartments will have dockside views. The creek, a stubby estuary off Long Island Sound in the New Rochelle, N.Y., is lined with marinas, making for lively viewing.

LEAD: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Katrin Kai Naelapaa, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Heino Naelapaa of Mexico City and Dallas, was married yesterday to Douglas Bartlett MacLaury, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. MacLaury of Titusville, N.J. The Rev. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A traveling swindler comes to town. What he sells to the rural folk isn't worth much, but the power of suggestion runs rampant. From apparent fraud emerges surprising results - love, happiness and success. As an operagoer's ''who am I?'' quiz, this one isn't very difficult: Donizetti's ''Elixir of Love.
LEAD: More than any of the other United States speed skaters, Eric Flaim has been hailed as a potential ''Eric Heiden of the future.'' And tonight, his future almost arrived.

LEAD: Deregulation aside, the folks in Washington still insist that a product labeled ''apple juice'' have something in it that came from apples. Federal prosecutors charged that for several years, executives at the Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation deliberately ignored such standards and sold as pure apple juice intended for babies a concoction derived mainly from beet sugar and sugar cane syrup.

LEAD: In the pantheon of American heroes there is no more appealing figure than Charles Ives, the iconoclastic Yankee insurance man and spare-time composer who, though supposedly unaware of avant-garde developments in European music, anticipated many innovations credited to Debussy, Mahler, Scriabin, Stravinsky, Schoenberg and Hindemith.

LEAD: George Balanchine was a complex man of firm convictions and deep contradictions. Like many Russian emigres, he had a love-hate relationship with his native land and he could not abide the Communist regime. Yet, he enthusiastically accepted its invitation to visit the Soviet Union twice and show off the fruit of his 60-year artistic endeavor abroad - the masterworks he had choreographed and the fabulous company, the New York City Ballet, that he had created and molded.
LEAD: HOUSE TOURS

LEAD: Governor Cuomo has, surprisingly soon, stopped pushing to restructure New York City's Board of Education. He thinks that current tensions between the Legislature and Mayor Koch make this an inopportune time to press for giving the Mayor control of the central school board.

LEAD: The police have detained at least seven opposition leaders, apparently in an effort to prevent the outlawed trade union Solidarity from convening a meeting this weekend, opposition spokesmen said today.
LEAD: An item in the Record Notes column in Arts and Leisure on Feb. 7 incorrectly characterized New World Records. It is a nonprofit organization, not a commercial company.

LEAD: DRIVING along the paved road to Kah-Nee-Ta Lodge at noon on Sundays from May to September, visitors are likely to be caught in a parade of cars, vans and pickups holding American Indian families that have come to dance. Watching them arrive and settle themselves may be the best introduction to the pleasures of this Indian-owned resort on the Warm Springs Reservation about 60 miles northeast of Bend,
LEAD: A Mexican family living in Leicester has won a three-year fight to stay in the United States.

LEAD: Q. I plan to remove the glass doors that now enclose our tub-shower. However, the metal runner on the bottom of these doors is apparently cemented onto the top of the tub rim with some kind of grout. I'm afraid that chipping and scraping might damage the finish on the tub. Is there any way you know of to remove this grout more easily?

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: WHEN Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrives in Moscow today for talks, he will be carrying an agenda with an unusually heavy emphasis on regional disputes, most notably Afghanistan, the Iran-Iraq war and the Arab-Israeli conflict. And he is likely to find Soviet leaders sharing his eagerness to accomplish something in these areas.

LEAD: DURING a trip to Tokyo in 1956, Britten twice attended a Noh play, and saw in its static, austere forms a solemn, graceful poetry. ''Sumidagawa,'' the story of a madwoman who had lost her child, struck the composer for the slowness of its action, the combination of speaking, singing and chanting, and the quiet, mystical intensity that sustained the piece, presented both times with no conductor guiding the ensemble of players and musicians.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: What was supposed to be a day in which the United States scored a breakthrough in the biathlon was instead another bitter disappointment. Josh Thompson left the starting line in this test of endurance and marksmanship, envisioning an Olympic medal, only to cross the finish with tears in his eyes, a victim of his own expectations.

LEAD: The engagement of Julia Anne Kosasky to William Lane Hallisey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hallisey of Riverside, Calif., has been made known by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Harold J. Kosasky of Chestnut Hill and Falmouth, Mass. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: Two weeks before my scheduled participation in the Olympics, perhaps the ultimate dream of every athlete, I was abruptly awoken. I discovered I was being replaced on the United States bobsled team by a well-known professional football player, Willie Gault of the Chicago Bears.

LEAD: SOMETIMES it seems as if everyone is wearing them. Braces are in, especially if you are 11 years old and attending junior high school. There it is de rigueur to flash a metallic smile. You can make your peace with not eating bagels and with spending time in the orthodontist's office, where, periodically, the doctor tightens your wires and decorates your mouth with rubber bands.

LEAD: YOU needn't be a parent to enjoy back-to-school events next weekend, because several of our county colleges and conservatories have scheduled concerts of high promise. The first is on Thursday, when the resident Sarah Lawrence Woodwind Quintet offers music by Telemann, Danzi, Barber and Francaix at its 8 P.M.

LEAD: THE MYSTERY AT THE HEART of the yachting world's raging controversy is scheduled for unveiling March 27, when Michael Fay, a New Zealand investment banker, is to launch the boat with which he'll compete for the America's Cup in September. The $3 million yacht is being built (above) near Auckland by Marten Marine Ltd.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Albert M. Moss of Huntington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Martha Moss to Dr. David DiBenedetto, a son of Mrs. Joseph DiBenedetto of Belmont, Mass., and the late Mr. DiBenedetto. Miss Moss expects to graduate in May from the Boston University School of Medicine.

LEAD: WHEN the New Jersey Highway Authority, operator of the Garden State Parkway, features Frank Sinatra, Liza Minelli or Bruce Springsteen at its Arts Center in Holmdel, the S.R.O. sign goes up weeks before the performances.
LEAD: In a world of triple axels, double toe loops, death spirals and sit spins, clocks and yardsticks have no place.

LEAD: THERE is an Austrian saying that seemed to sum up the mood here as the bitter dispute over Kurt Waldheim increasingly battered and divided his small nation: ''Better a horrible end than horror without end.''

Yet Jonathan Haas - who plays with the New York Chamber Symphony, at the Aspen Festival, and with a number of smaller groups around New York - has persisted, and surrounded by colleagues, he gave a recital at the 92d Street Y on

LEAD: Highland Park $212,000 135 Amherst Street 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; finished basement, 2-zone heating, patio, fenced yard; taxes $2,738. Howell $207,000 25 Rimwood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, year-old colonial; deck, w/w carpeting, pool; taxes $2,751.

LEAD: Brian Boitano winning a gold medal in the men's figure-skating competition in the Olympic Winter Games last night in Calgary, Alberta. Brian Orser of Canada took second place in the event. Eric Flaim won a silver medal for the United States in the men's 1,500-meter speed-skating race. Section 5. (Reuters)

LEAD: The 150-year-old Blue Riband, a trans-Atlantic speed title claimed two years ago by a powerboat team from Britain, is expected to generate two more multimillion-dollar record attempts this June.
LEAD: Clinton B. F. Brill, a civil engineer, architect and former chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority, died of a heart attack Feb. 9 at his home in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 94 years old.

LEAD: Individual physicians, or even New York Hospital, should not be blamed for the deaths of Andy Warhol and Libby Zion. The system failed these patients, and the system must be changed. When interns, fresh out of medical school, are forced to work for 36 hours without sleep and are left alone at night in charge of 30 or 40 seriously ill patients, deaths that should be avoidable will occur.
LEAD: What victory?
LEAD: A QUICK and delicious passage to India can be made enjoyably at a modest storefront restaurant named Bonani in Stamford.

LEAD: AS a ski resort, Copper Mountain is a natural. A ''nearly perfect ski mountain,'' wrote the United States Forest Service in 1969, adding, ''If there ever was a mountain that had terrain created for skiing, it would be Copper Mountain.''

LEAD: FROM Bayberry Avenue in the courthouse-complex country of Garden City, the long, low building across the iced front lawn could have been any Long Island school. The visitor watched buses arriving to discharge small passengers for a day of what might be, elsewhere, such minor miracles as spelling a word correctly or grasping one more of the arcane mysteries of arithmetic, or the like.
LEAD: OF all America's possessions, none has appeared more content with the relationship, at least in recent years, than the Virgin Islands. But there are signs of change.

LEAD: Secretary of State Shultz had the idea years ago of improving the ''quality of life'' of Palestinians under Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza. By that he meant easing Israel's restrictions on their lives and commerce, building a degree of mutual confidence.
LEAD: Roger Clemens of the Red Sox, recipient of the Cy Young Award the last two seasons, loosening up yesterday in Winter Haven, Fla. (AP)

LEAD: Israeli security forces shot and killed two Palestinians, one of them a 12-year-old boy, in another day of protests today. The shootings raised the death toll to at least 61 Palestinians in the 10 weeks of what Arabs are calling ''the uprising.''

LEAD: THE DARK PATH TO THE RIVER. By Joanne Leedom-Ackerman. (Saybrook/Norton, $19.95.) Joanne Leedom-Ackerman's first novel is a densely plotted, dialogue-filled story that reads like commercial fiction yet examines unconventional territory. Frequently shifting points of view, the book focuses on the fates of two American friends and former newspaper colleagues who are united in their interest in a small, unnamed African country on the brink of revolution.

LEAD: Yesterday's agreement between Rupert Murdoch and the unions at The New York Post sets the stage for another attempt to do what newspaper professionals have long said cannot be done: turn a long-term profit at The Post.

LEAD: To the Editor: Thank you for the informative article by Ross Terrill on his visit to the Liangshan Yi Autonomous Region in China (Travel, Dec. 20). However, I take exception to a couple of comments the author seems to have accepted at face value from Han Chinese informants.
LEAD: In response to Kim Jenkins's Jan. 31 Opinion Page article ''First Amendment: Is It Just for Adults?'':
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: William J. Dempsey, former counsel of the Federal Communications Commission and a communications lawyer, died of heart failure Tuesday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 81 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH it still has a number of stops to make before it arrives June 7, the Presidential political bandwagon is heading toward New Jersey. And the way things are going in both major parties, New Jersey voters could play an important role in picking the nominees.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An article in The Times Magazine on Jan. 10 about Nicaragua's leader, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, misstated the date of a secret meeting at which the Sandinistas sought to take control of the provisional legislature by adding members. It was May 2, 1980.

LEAD: THOUGH voting in the Presidential primary contest is just beginning, the candidates' scramble has long been under way. But members of Congress also have long been engaged in the enterprise that will preoccupy most of them until Election Day - campaigning for re-election and the election of others in their own party.
LEAD: For Dr. Becky McCarthy, it was an ordinary day in the life of a country veterinarian, quite different from the dramatic emergencies depicted by James Herriot in his books and television shows.

LEAD: A smoky fire in a crew car aboard the Amtrak system's California Zephyr killed a crew member and injured 16 people early today, officials said. Passengers said they had received no warning of any danger and had been given no help in getting off the train.
LEAD: QUESTION. Who's hard to beat - on both sides.

LEAD: The authors purport to examine problems at New York Hospital by focusing on a few celebrated cases, but their own statistics do not support their allegations. If the hospital admits roughly 40,000 patients a year, and 109 complaints have been registered in the last three years (with only 29 percent of those apparently justified), greater than 99 percent of the cases are handled without significant incident.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: SOME say multinational corporations threaten the economic and political independence of developing countries and represent one of the greatest obstacles to development. Others find progress in the third world inconceivable without companies operating on an international scale. Multinationals, they say, transfer technologies, as well as exemplary standards for production safety, the environment and social responsibility.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''Gifts of Gear and Gadgets'' (Practical Traveler, Nov. 22) by Betsy Wade contains information about the type of binoculars to buy, but there are no specifics on manufacturers, magnification, field, etc. The price is given as being in the ''several hundred dollar'' range.

LEAD: The State House of Representatives here has given preliminary approval to a mandatory sex education program that would separate birth-control classes by sex and prohibit discussion of homosexuality except in negative terms.
LEAD: ''Blunt force injuries'' inflicted in a struggle with the police contributed to a Brooklyn man's death in police custody last month, the New York Medical Examiner's office has said.

LEAD: OBVIOUSLY, A LONGSTANDING conflict like that between the Israelis and the Palestinians can be resolved any number of ways - particularly when one side has the power to impose a settlement on the other. The question here, however, is not about a so-called ''agreement'' that one side forces the other to accept, but a true, lasting settlement that elicits a reasonable degree of consent from both.
LEAD: MUCH DEPENDS ON DINNER The Extraordinary History and Mythology, Allure and Obsessions, Perils and Taboos, of an Ordinary Meal. By Margaret Visser. 351 pp. New York: Grove Press. $19.95.

LEAD: 'Everyone deserves the opportunity to make an independent assessment of reality - and make a critical evaluation as well. In this situation the ideals and values of socialism can be established not by implantation but by the free will of an individual mind. '
LEAD: ''What would you like to hear?''

LEAD: ''BLOOD BROTHERS'' at the Downtown Cabaret Theater has the earmarks of a double event. Here is the American premiere of a 1983 award-winning, long-running -and downbeat - British musical that can alienate and attract audiences, and what a bold step this is for a theater noted for unthreatening, familiar fare!
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: At the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y., Anna Tobey Petite, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Clinton Petite of Bronxville, was married yesterday to Thomas Greeff Lee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Lee of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. C. Carter Via performed the ceremony.
LEAD: The CBS television affiliate in the Washington area mistakenly began its ''Face The Nation'' broadcast today with last week's preview of the New Hampshire primary.

LEAD: Two more Palestinian protesters were slain today in demonstrations called to protest the visit of Secretary of State George P. Shultz, while other Palestinians were seeking permission from the Palestine Liberation Organization to meet with Mr. Shultz during his stay here this week.

LEAD: With seconds to go in his freestyle program Saturday night, Brian Boitano let the world know exactly how he felt about his performance. His smile seemed to stretch from one side of the Saddledome to the other; his fists were clenched at his heart in triumphant joy.
LEAD: Babbitt's Little Problem

LEAD: Justice Antonin Scalia says one thing has disappointed him since he joined the Supreme Court in 1986: the absence of give and take among the Court's members when they meet in conference to discuss and vote in cases they have heard.
LEAD: The negative double, developed as part of the Roth-Stone system 40 years ago, was a major step forward in bidding theory and has been adopted by almost all serious players around the world.

LEAD: An Amtrak official disagreed today with state officials on the cause of a fire in a crew car on Amtrak's California Zephyr that killed one man, and he defended the crew's handling of the emergency.

LEAD: In the end, all of its youth, enthusiasm and infatuation with goal scoring wasn't enough as the United States Olympic hockey team was convincingly knocked from medal contention by a sturdy contingent from West Germany.
LEAD: It was quiet yesterday outside The New York Post building in lower Manhattan. Inside, about two dozen reporters and editors gathered in a ritual of relief.

LEAD: A senior United States official said Saturday that little progress had been made in negotiations to open the Japanese construction market to foreign companies. Japan allows only companies with construction experience here to bid on new projects, and the restriction has become a major trade issue between the nations.

LEAD: Orlando Woolridge, the high-scoring Nets' forward whose whereabouts were unknown to the team for more than 24 hours, will meet with team officials today and might participate in the morning workout, the Nets said yesterday.
LEAD: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, who last year condemned a fellow television evangelist, Jim Bakker, as ''a cancer on the body of Christ,'' today confessed to sins of his own and begged to be forgiven.
LEAD: Some United Nations operations in southern Lebanon have been curtailed sharply since the kidnapping of a United States Marine officer and other United Nations personnel this month.

LEAD: Robert S. Strauss has told his partners at Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld that he expects to be named chairman of the National Economic Commission. There is talk that Mr. Strauss, a former Democratic national chairman who was United States Trade Representative in the Carter Administration, will have a

LEAD: By issuance of his 20,000-word, personally written encyclical, ''The Social Concerns of the Church,'' Pope John Paul II risks becoming known as the foremost political-moral relativist of our time.

LEAD: A 61-year-old doorman was shot in the back, and a woman was then robbed of jewelry valued at $15,000 in the elevator of an apartment building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the police said.
LEAD: Isabel Bishop, a painter and printmaker, died of Parkinson's disease Friday at her home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 85 years old.

LEAD: With America's appetite for imports slowing and West Germany's reluctance to stimulate its economy growing, European policy makers are desperately seeking ways to break the continent's long cycle of torpid growth.

LEAD: When Jade Hunter held off Cryptoclearance by a length in the Donn Handicap Jan. 30, the runner-up's backers began looking forward to the prospect of a rematch in the Gulfstream Park Handicap. The latter race would be a furlong farther, and Cryptoclearance would surely get up in time.

LEAD: Earl Morse, a food industry executive, art collector and former chairman of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, died after a long illness Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: An article Sunday about a New York State appeals court decision that the right to a rent-stabilized apartment is not automatically passed on to a relative incorrectly identified the court and the territory covered by the ruling. The ruling was made by the First Department of the Appellate Term of the State Supreme Court,and while it is expected to establish a precedent for the entire city, it is binding only in Manhattan and the Bronx.

LEAD: At Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., Wendy Ann Miller, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice H. Miller of Lawrence, L.I., was married yesterday to Paul Scott Lurrie, a son of Eileen Lurrie of Glen Oaks, Queens, and the late Lawrence Lurrie. Rabbis Morris Friedman and Gilbert Klaperman and Cantor Marcus

LEAD: Barely a decade after the video cassette recorder began its relentless march into America's living rooms, a new type of home library - filled with dozens, or even hundreds, of videotapes - is rapidly emerging.
LEAD: John Johnson was suspended indefinitely from the University of Viginia basketball team Saturday after failing a drug test, the university announced.

LEAD: With the hard bargaining past and a rescue package for The New York Post in place, only a few details remained yesterday for the completion of Rupert Murdoch's $37.6 million sale of the newspaper to the real-estate developer Peter S. Kalikow.

LEAD: The essence of Mario Biaggi, said Peter Fata, a Bronx resident, is not in the legal trouble that has brought him to the brink of expulsion by his colleagues in the House of Representatives.

LEAD: A brain-dead baby boy was taken off life-support machines Saturday after no recipients could be found for his organs, but another baby, also born without a brain stem, was on a respirator today in hopes of saving her organs for transplant.

LEAD: New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority seems intent on making life harder for countless New Yorkers who wouldn't think of boarding a subway car without a newspaper or magazine in hand.

LEAD: An off-duty police officer was shot in Brooklyn early yesterday when he intervened in a dispute, the police said. The officer suffered minor wounds when a passer-by, trying to help, shot him accidentally.

LEAD: In the era of movie cassette rentals and closet-sized theaters, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has lavished Oscar nominations on the biggest, widest, tallest movies of the year. Epics like ''The Last Emperor,'' ''The Untouchables'' and ''Empire of the Sun'' are marvelous. But where does

LEAD: Despite coming to the University of North Carolina campus as the topranked team in the nation, the Temple Owls knew they had something to prove. Critics had pointed to their schedule, which had included only two ranked opponents, as an unreliable indication of the Owls' strength.

LEAD: According to an axiom making the rounds in Haiti, for at least the next hundred years, each time a president takes office Haitians will be thrown into an anxious fit trying to divine if the new regime will be as tyrannical as the reign of Francois (Papa Doc) Duvalier, whose family controlled the country for three decades.

LEAD: For most of the morning, as it poured rain outside, Jack Clark lay quietly on his back in the trainers' room at Fort Lauderdale Stadium and read the Sunday newspaper. He wore a Yankee cap pushed back off his forehead, and he seemed genuinely oblivious to both the attention that was being paid to his right ankle and the small horde of reporters that waited patiently near his dressing stall in the crowded clubhouse.

LEAD: THROWING MUSES have unlearned just about everything rock songwriters take for granted. The four-member band from Boston, which performed Thursday at Drums, rejects concise melodies, conventional chord sequences, naturalistic singing, narrative lyrics and just about anything else that might suggest symmetry or surface clarity.
LEAD: There must be something about Californian governors to make them such fans of the line-item veto.

LEAD: Peter J. Robotti, longtime owner of Le Chateau Richelieu, a French and Continental restaurant on the East Side of Manhattan, died after a brief illness at his home on Thursday. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Soviet President, Andrei A. Gromyko, reports in his forthcoming memoirs that Mao Zedong sought Soviet cooperation in 1958 for a plan to lure United States troops into the interior of China, then attack them with Soviet nuclear weapons.

LEAD: Dr. Leah P. Gruss, a radiology resident at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, and Dr. Joel H. Spielman, an orthopedic surgery resident at the Montefiore Medical Center, were married yesterday. Rabbi Samuel Orenstein performed the ceremony at the New York Hilton.

LEAD: Karl Friesen, the West German goalie, stopping a shot by Stephen Leach of the United States last night in Calgary, Alberta. The Germans' 4-1 victory advanced them to the medal round of the tournament and ended American hopes for a medal. SportsMonday, page C1. (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)
LEAD: Pity Brian Leetch. His dream snuffed out in Calgary, he now gets to join a nightmare in full progress.

LEAD: The American Council of Learned Societies and the Soviet Theater Union have established the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Commission on Theater and Dance Studies, a group that is to study theater and dance history, theory, criticism and practice.
LEAD: From the air as he tours San Antonio in a helicopter, Henry G. Cisneros envisions a new city unfolding below him.
LEAD: About 100 motorists drove to the state capital yesterday to protest high auto insurance rates and demand that lawmakers address the problem.

LEAD: After 40 years, Congress is moving toward the final step on an international convention against genocide. The Senate gave its approval to the treaty in 1986, and it only remains for Congress to pass implementing legislation to amend the criminal code.
LEAD: WHEN Jackie Joyner-Kersee was growing up in East St. Louis, Ill., she made the mistake one night of losing track of the time.
LEAD: Judging by corporate loan demand at banks across the nation, the nation's economy remains strong, if spotty, with many smaller businesses particularly robust.
LEAD: For the second time in a year, the execution-style slaying of a New York City police detective is being relived in a Queens court.

LEAD: A two-day tribute to the author James Baldwin - comprising screenings, interviews and a jazz performance - is to be held on Feb. 29 and March 1 by New York University. The writer died in December. On Feb. 29, a daylong screening of films featuring appearances by Mr. Baldwin or adaptations of his works will begin at 9 A.M.
