LEAD: Teamsters union members reported to work at Pan American World Airways yesterday despite the expiration of a strike deadline and a breakdown in contract talks. But a union representative threatened to strike the airline ''at whatever time will hurt them most.''

LEAD: When Dave Johnson speaks, his voice has an instant effect on a stranger. It is clear and crisp, almost perfect. If it is a voice that sounds familiar to the ear, it's because most sports fans have heard Johnson's utterances before.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: George Bush, the cowboy, came out tonight in this flat, dusty town north of San Antonio.

LEAD: Under pressure from its Arab backers, the Palestine Liberation Organization has withdrawn its threat to revive attacks on Israelis outside Israel and the occupied territories, according to Cairo-based diplomats and Palestinian officials.
LEAD: The De Gustibus column in The Living Section on Wednesday misidentified the owners of Le Bernardin in New York. The restaurateurs are Gilbert and Maguy Le Coze.

LEAD: The International Olympic Committee announced today that Jaroslaw Morawiecki, Poland's best hockey player, has been banned from these Olympics after testing positive for steroids. It was the first penalty for drug use at the XV Olympic Winter Games.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The festivities at the traditional pre-Lenten carnival here recently seemed more subdued than usual, and no one needed to ask why. ''There's not a cent for dancing in the streets or any other fun,'' one newspaper complained on its front page.

LEAD: At first glance, it seemed that the long arm of the European Community had reached Remi Guinebault and Philippe Follet on their 300 acres amid the verdant flatlands between the Yonne and Loire rivers.

LEAD: Track and Field Remigino Takes 800-Meter: Mike Remigino, a freshman at Manhattan College and son of a former Jasper, Lindy Remigino, the 1952 Olympic 100-meter gold medalist, captured the 800-meter run in 1 minute 54.04 seconds yesterday at the Reebok/Metropolitan Athletics Congress indoor championships at West Point, N.Y.
LEAD: ''I do not plan in any way to whitewash my sin. I do not call it a mistake, a mendacity. I call it a sin.'' The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, television evangelist [ A1:1. ]
LEAD: Two years after the triumph of ''people power'' in the Philippines, the future of democracy in the ''Pearl of the Orient Sea'' still hangs in the balance.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A judge said Friday that he would rule March 7 on the Union Carbide Corporation's appeal of a court order that it pay $270 million in interim relief to victims of the Bhopal gas leak.

LEAD: If the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan can perform the kind of magic at the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company's tire plants that it has performed at its own plant here, one thing appears certain: The American tire business will become even more competitive.

LEAD: STATE treasurers are closely watching a recent lawsuit against the State of New York that could decide who can lay claim to abandoned property that rests in the hands of scores of businesses and banks.
LEAD: A new coalition of French and Belgian shareholders in Societe Generale de Belgique is forming to thwart the raid of Carlo de Benedetti, according to analysts who follow the company.

LEAD: IN the University of Calgary bookstore, the end of the line was over among the shelves with the Greek and Latin classics. Eventually the autograph seekers wound through the aisles to a Russian classic. No, not Tolstoy or Solzhenitsyn, not even a book in hard cover or paperback.

LEAD: Lawyers for Boston University have asked a judge to order Coretta Scott King to release tapes of conversations between her husband, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and others recorded secretly by Federal investigators.

LEAD: John A. Mulheren, the arbitrager arrested last Thursday on charges of illegal weapons possession, spent the weekend in a county jail in New Jersey and will seek to be hospitalized this week, according to people familiar with his case.

LEAD: Mookie Wilson, the ''other'' center fielder on the Mets and the man most likely to be traded by the Mets, conceded today that ''there are a lot of things worse in the world than sitting on the bench in New York.''

LEAD: For gym rats, extended periods of time away from basketball can be excruciating. John Hillin is a gym rat, and last year he was faced with 170 consecutive days without any contact with the game. Hillin refused to accept this fate.

Jimmy Swaggart. ''My heart has been deeply saddened by the news of the past few days,'' said Mr.

LEAD: Bill Rudy heading into the sugar bush with empty pails to collect the sap of maple trees at Lenoir Preserve in Yonkers. Holes are drilled into the trees, and the clear liquid tapped is boiled down to a rich, golden syrup. It takes 35 to 50 gallons of sap to make a gallon of syrup. (NYT/Suzanne DeChillo)
LEAD: Everywhere he traveled this weekend, from San Francisco to Los Angeles to Las Vegas to the nation's capital, Albert Gore Jr. was asked about Garry Trudeau.
LEAD: The Federal Railroad Administrator has criticized Congress for failing to improve rail safety in the year since 16 people died in an Amtrak crash in Maryland.
LEAD: Mayor Koch says he is ending his campaign to boycott Manhattan movie houses that charge a $7 admission. He said he was giving it up because of a lack of support from moviegoers.

LEAD: If there is one gold medalist in Calgary during the Winter Olympics who differs from all others, it is Vadim Pisarev of the Soviet Union. The 23-year-old Mr. Pisarev has won his unusually large collection of gold medals at international ballet competitions - in 1986 in Jackson, Miss.; in 1985 in Moscow; in 1984 in Helsinki and Paris.
LEAD: For 21 years, John Artis says, he has been the neglected ''other guy'' in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz made human rights a major theme of his first day of talks in Moscow today, meeting with leading rights campaigners and devoting most of his morning discussions with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to the topic.

LEAD: One or more industries seem to have taken advantage of a fuel spill last month and dumped their own chemicals into the Ohio River, chemicals that are more dangerous pollutants than the fuel that spilled, water quality experts say.

LEAD: ''TELEVISION,'' the eight-part series that examines the medium and all its wondrous effects, looks tonight at television news. In 40 years, it has moved from simple illustrated lectures to global instant replay. Where will it go next? ''Point of View,'' the fifth part in the series, doesn't say, but it does express a cautionary note.

LEAD: Several district attorneys in New York State are expressing concern about Governor Cuomo's proposal to set up a civil-rights unit in the State Attorney General's office, fearing that the new unit might take over bias investigations they originate.

LEAD: A fairly heavy calendar of Treasury financings are scheduled for this week, including today's sale of three- month and six-month bills. On Wednesday, $8.75 billion in two-year notes will be auctioned, followed on Thursday with a regular monthly sale of five-year notes totaling $7.25 billion.
LEAD: JANE FONDA is dressed in tights and she smiles. ''Set those shoulders on fire,'' she cries, waving her arms energetically. ''Make it burn.''
LEAD: THERE is a moment in victory, or defeat, when your face tells the story. Writers spend their cash advances wearing out typewriter ribbons to try to capture that instant.
LEAD: The Nassau County Medical Center, criticized by the State Health Department for the quality of its patient care, has received full, three-year accreditation.
LEAD: Many taxpayers, including residents of New York State, will discover in this filing season that their state returns have undergone revisions almost as major as those on their Federal returns.
LEAD: A millionaire businessman who had the backing of the powerful Communist Party defeated a conservative opponent to become President of Cyprus in a runoff election held today.

LEAD: First there was the Los Angeles Ballet, and now there is the Ballet of Los Angeles. John Clifford has begun anew. In 1973, Mr. Clifford - at that time, a dancer and choreographer with the New York City Ballet - returned to his native Los Angeles to found the Los Angeles Ballet, which he directed until 1985, when economic troubles closed it down.

LEAD: REPEATEDLY ambushed over the past 75 years, neither Romanticism nor the Romantic symphony orchestra have been that easy to kill off. Lowell Liebermann, for example, is only 27 years old, but he has already composed a big symphonic work interesting enough to be featured at the Juilliard Symphony's concert at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night.

LEAD: The one area of black resistance that the South African Government has been unable to break under its nationwide state of emergency is a 20-month-old rent boycott by blacks in Soweto, South Africa's largest black township.
LEAD: The Devils created plenty of chances this afternoon and played with enough intensity, but they were denied by a hot goaltender and one of the better teams in the league.

LEAD: Congress has spent hours debating airline safety, train safety, highway safey, but it has yet to tackle what have been called the most dangerous and unregulated crafts of them all: commercial fishing vessels.
LEAD: RISA JAROSLOW is a performer of great though quiet eloquence. And that gift was evident in two pieces presented by Risa Jaroslow and Dancers on Friday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater.

LEAD: In a major art-world job switch, John Wilmerding, the deputy director of the National Gallery of Art and a leading figure in the study and exhibition of American art, has been appointed to a new, fully endowed professorship at Princeton University and will become a visiting curator at the Metropolitan Museum of

LEAD: A French fishing boat hit a mine in the English Channel today and sank when the mine exploded, but all four crew members were rescued, the coastal authorities said. An official at the search and rescue headquarters in Cherbourg said the trawler hit the mine early this morning about 30 miles north of the Normandy coast.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo has turned down a request to meet today with two clergymen to discuss the case of a black Dutchess County teen-ager who says she was abducted and attacked by six white men, a spokesman for the Governor said yesterday.

LEAD: FOR nearly a half century, John Cage has been picking away with his perceptive, gentle wit at the conventions of the serious music scene. LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said Friday that it would distribute $635 million to its United States employees in what it said was the largest profit-sharing payout ever made by an American company.

LEAD: Starting Saturday, life will change for the 24 million residents of California. Almost daily, they will receive pointed reminders about the chemical risks of the good life of the 20th century in the nation's largest state.

LEAD: THE Washington Square Repertory Dance Company accurately called its Friday night program ''Dances From the Home Front: Choreography With American Themes, Music and Images.'' Unfortunately, despite its strong subject matter, each item on this concert at the University Theater of New York University was deficient in some way.

LEAD: Varig Airlines of Brazil, the Brink's security company, a local cargo concern and the federal police are still referring to the ''loss'' of two bags containing $8 million. They were being shipped from the Federal Reserve Bank in New York to Buenos Aires this month.
LEAD: The final two heats of the two-man bobsled were postponed midway through today's racing because of deteriorating track conditions aggravated by wind-blown sand.

LEAD: The Southland Corporation has agreed to sell its Dairies Group to Morningstar Foods Inc. for an undisclosed amount. Morningstar, an affiliate of the Houston-based investment firm of Duncan, Cook & Company, will buy 10 regional dairies throughout the United States, along with 25 plants and distribution points.

LEAD: The acknowledgment of moral lapses yesterday by the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart was only the latest in a series of scandals among television evangelists in recent years that have rocked their supporters, depressing donations and creating public distrust.

LEAD: An enormous hulk of a man, Brian Dennehy is probably better known for such stereotypically macho movie roles as the sheriff who made the grave error of jailing Rambo in ''First Blood'' and television parts like Buffalo Bill Cody than for classics of the stage.
LEAD: The Supreme Court has long been shrouded in secrecy and inaccessibility, hindering public understanding of its role while perhaps enhancing its mystique.
LEAD: * Charcuterie Tour Eiffel, which sells pates and delicatessen meats to supermarkets and specialty stores, to Image Concepts, Paramus, N.J.
LEAD: NOW that waterfowling has ended throughout the nation, including the bonus seasons for scaup and Canada geese in some portions of the Northeast, only a handful of hunters are abroad.
LEAD: The Spanish Government has agreed to open formal peace talks with the radical Basque group that has waged a violent campaign for autonomy in northern Spain.

LEAD: The parents of Jim Bakker, the former president of the PTL television ministry, have applied for unemployment benefits after being dismissed from their jobs as greeters at PTL's Heritage USA religious theme park. Raleigh Bakker and his wife, Furnia, both 81 years old, still live at the resort. PTL, which is involved in Federal bankruptcy proceedings, has cut 1,800 jobs since 1985, a spokeswoman said.

LEAD: The Department of Energy has ordered a further reduction in the power level of its last remaining plutonium-producing reactor in an effort to assure that the reactor operated within the capacity of its emergency cooling system, a departmental official said tonight.

LEAD: The marriage of Gena Cohen, an associate at the Washington law firm of Arent, Fox, Kintner, Plotkin & Kahn, and Robert Jeffrey Moses, an associate at the law firm of Epstein, Becker & Green in Washington, took place yesterday. Rabbi Avis Miller officiated at the Arts Club in Washington.

LEAD: Continuing a consolidation phase after the sharp declines registered in January, interest rates are likely to move in a relatively narrow range for the next week or so, credit market analysts said. But they added that a further drop in yields seemed quite probable before the quarter ends.

LEAD: Rick Tocchet scored three goals for the first time in his National Hockey League career today to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

From the tattered bag he drew a picture of his son James. Mr. Watkins has 19 children, but it is
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Without the black church, the civil rights movement would have been impossible. So would the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign, which has its base there.

LEAD: Peter O. Price, who has spent much of his life in such successful and lustrous enterprises as Princeton University, Time Inc. and Avenue magazine, will bear much of the burden of attempting to turn around The New York Post, widely acknowledged to be the grittiest and most vulnerable newspaper in New York City.

LEAD: In the wake of Saturday's game-ending, bench-clearing brawl between Georgetown and Pittsburgh, Dave Gavitt, the commissioner of the Big East Conference, has called a special meeting of the league's executive committee. The purpose of the meeting, which will be held today or tomorrow, is to formulate tough, uniform policies for controlling fights and punishing those players who participate in them.

LEAD: The golf purist who remains loyal to persimmon wood may cringe at what technology has wrought: a solid-plastic club head. There is no wood, metal or graphite in the mix. The head has the color and sheen of the inside of an oyster shell.
LEAD: H. David Bright, who was instrumental in reviving the National Education Corporation, was named chairman of the nation's largest network of vocational schools last week.

LEAD: It is early on a Saturday morning on Bergenline Avenue, the main commercial strip here, but moving about is already difficult. Amid throngs of shoppers, merchants are setting out goods, cars are double-parked and children are skipping down the sidewalk.

LEAD: Last July, Richard Shaw watched the National Hot Rod Association Summernational drag races in Old Bridge, N.J., from the grandstands. Earlier this month, the 30-year-old fashion industry executive had a different perspective on the action at the Winternational event at Pomona, Calif. Shaw watched it from behind the canopy of an 800-horsepower gas dragster, as he became the first winner in a new race series that permits drivers to rent rides rather than entering their own cars.

LEAD: Every night, each homeless person who arrives at a shelter a few blocks south of downtown is asked to give his name and Social Security number. And every night, the list is turned over to the police, who try to match names on it with those on arrest warrants.
LEAD: Young & Rubicam, San Francisco, will no doubt be toasting its 10th anniversary this month with glasses of prune juice.

LEAD: This was supposed to be the Mount Rushmore of Alpine skiing, where Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland and Alberto Tomba of Italy would etch their profiles in the Olympic snow. But since Zurbriggen won the downhill last Monday with a spectacular run down Mount Allan, he and others among the world's more renowned male and female skiers have found the slick, icy slopes to be unforgiving.

LEAD: ONE of the oldest anti-gold arguments used by monetarists, those who would sever any link between bullion and paper money, is that gold is a ''sterile investment.'' Why? Because gold does not yield interest or dividends; its value is largely dependent on investor concerns about other assets.

LEAD: Allegheny International Inc., the maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances and Northern electric blankets, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code during the weekend.

LEAD: The S.D.R. may rise again. The Special Drawing Right is a form of money, but not the kind that people use to buy a loaf of bread. Consumers have never seen one. LEAD: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, opened every game with the same move: king's pawn to E4. Then he slowly circled the children who had packed the gymnasium. He stared intently at each board for about 10 seconds, made a move and went on to the next.

LEAD: ORPHEUS brought a strongly played, well-conceived concert to Carnegie Hall Saturday night. The American chamber orchestra, which operates with rotating concertmasters and without conductors, used Haydn's F minor Symphony, ''La Passione,'' to start and ended with the ''Short Symphony'' by Aaron Copland.

LEAD: Less than a year after introducing their newest personal computer line, the PS/2, officials at the International Business Machines Corporation are now planning an overhaul of the line that will distance the company from advancing clone makers. LEAD: MITSUKO UCHIDA'S elegant Mozart recordings scarcely prepare us for the headlong passion she brought to Chopin at the Frick Collection on Sunday Afternoon. Miss Uchida's broad rubato in the first movement and a fury in the second that stretched both the music and her excellent technique to their limits.

LEAD: ANDREA GROVER, who lives in West Orange, N.J., is adding a dining room to her home and redoing her kitchen so that she can have dinner parties more comfortably. That makes her something of an anomaly among her friends, who rarely entertain guests at dinner.
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 3 today that coastal states own or may have some rights to all the lands affected by the ebb and flow of the tides, including land miles from the ocean.

LEAD: Something modest, but potentially momentous, occurred during Secretary of State Shultz's visit to Moscow this week. The United States and the Soviet Union seemed in position, perhaps for the first time, to make as much progress on regional disputes and human rights issues as on arms control.
LEAD: The pressure on American Standard Inc. tightened yesterday as the Black & Decker Corporation raised its takeover bid to $68 a share, or $2.1 billion.

LEAD: George O. Pratt, the director of the Alley Pond Environmental Center in Douglaston, Queens, standing near the charred ruins of a century-old windmill that was destroyed in a fire Monday night. Investigators suspect arson in the fire. The windmill was built on Arleigh Road in Queens and was moved in 1986 to the environmental center in an effort to prevent its demolition.

LEAD: ORANGE juice may be the American breakfast beverage of choice, and grapefruit is certainly the dieter's delight, but when it comes to cooking with citrus fruits, as a nation we lack imagination.
LEAD: PURIM is one of the most joyful of Jewish holidays, and it is also a time of tomfoolery.

LEAD: The Army will dispose of its aging stockpile of chemical weapons by burning them in closed incinerators to be built at the eight sites where the chemicals are now stored, a top official said today.

LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr. said today in Norfolk, Va., where two new aircraft carriers are being constructed, that he was the only Democratic Presidential candidate who was in favor of building the carriers.

LEAD: DEVELOPING a taste for one food or another may depend on the context in which that food is eaten. I know several baseball buffs who consider a hot dog with sauerkraut absolutely vital at a game. And yet these same people look on a platter of sauerkraut, using the pickled vegetable as the focal point of a main course, with something that borders on contempt.
LEAD: President Reagan today chose a veteran Capitol Hill infighter, William L. Ball 3d, to step into a simmering dispute over Pentagon budget cuts as his new Secretary of the Navy.

LEAD: The Knicks committed 26 turnovers last night. Earlier in the season that would have spelled almost certain defeat. But these are different Knicks. They still do not have any player they can count on to give them a big game, but they have learned to cover up for their errors with outstanding defense and they have learned to win consistently on their home court.

LEAD: Ketchum Advertising/Pittsburgh has gained the business of the Equitable Gas Company, a utility, that formerly was handled by George Hill & Company of Pittsburgh. It is expected to bill about $1.5 million.

LEAD: Oliver G. Swan, a literary agent whose career spanned almost 40 years, died of pneumonia yesterday at Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 83 years old. Among the authors he represented were Conrad Richter, Richard Wright, Morris West, Alex Hailey and the estate of Henry James.

LEAD: Three leading carriers -American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and United Air Lines -plan to increase their lowest discount fares by $10 per round trip, effective March 2. The seasonal adjustment comes at a time when traffic usually strengthens after a period of weakness at the beginning of the year.

Iraq, desperate for funds to finance its conflict with Iran, begins shipping its oil across Turkey and Jordan and negotiating with Turkey, Jordan and Saudi Arabia for rights to build permanent pipelines.

LEAD: It took only a little more than an hour yesterday for a jury in Minneapolis to acquit Tommy Kramer, the Minnesota Vikings' quarterback, of a drunken-driving charge. Kramer was arrested last July 24 after leaving a restaurant in Bloomington, a Minneapolis suburb. Three police officers testified that Kramer's car was weaving on the road and that, after he was stopped, he had trouble with a balance test and reciting the alphabet.

LEAD: The fourth TV commercial in Nike's ''Revolution in Motion'' campaign featuring the Beatles song ''Revolution'' began last night, just as a spokesman for the shoe company earlier in the day had said it would.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Roh Tae Woo, who transformed himself from co-conspirator in a military coup to avowed champion of democracy, assumed the presidency today in South Korea's first peaceful transfer of power in four decades as an independent nation.

LEAD: Many House Democrats are so disgusted with Reagan Administration policy toward Nicaragua that they'd simply stop all aid to the contras. But that's bad policy and bad politics. LEAD: N.B.A. Celtics 113, Trail Blazers 112: Larry Bird scored 16 of his 44 points in the fourth quarter last night. The victory was the Celtics' second in six days over the Trail Blazers and brought their home-court record to 21-3. The Celtics overcame a 100-88 deficit with eight minutes remaining.

LEAD: The City of Baytown, banking that City Hall may be sitting on a pool of oil, is looking in its own backyard for more income. The City Council voted Tuesday to approve a plan for Trace Oil and Gas to drill a well 5,000 to 6,000 feet deep near the entrance to the 30-acre wooded City Hall complex. The city would receive a 20 percent royalty on any petroleum uncovered under the agreement.

LEAD: The Supreme Court, in an 8-to-0 ruling today, broadly reaffirmed and extended its rules protecting criticism of public figures as free speech, even if the criticism is ''outrageous'' and offensive.

LEAD: SEMYON FRIDMAN, a Soviet-born cellist who won first prize at the 1987 Concert Artists Guild International New York Competition, made an impressive New York debut Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. LEAD: Clement Chen Jr., the first architect to participate in a joint international venture in China, died Friday. He was 58 years old.

LEAD: A Finance Ministry committee today approved a report calling for tougher laws against insider trading on Japan's stock markets, where traders say information about companies is frequently leaked to investors.

LEAD: President Reagan said tonight that the United States had ''intimations'' that outside agitators were partly responsible for inciting the violent clashes between Palestinians and Israeli security forces in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

LEAD: A coalition of stockholders siding with Societe Generale de Belgique in its takeover battle with Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian financier, declared today that it had ''firm commitments'' for 52 percent of the company's shares.

LEAD: NEVER underestimate the power of wishful thinking. Before these Winter Games ever began, some southerners at heart prayed for a Chinook wind to warm up the Alberta prairie.

LEAD: The Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of a rent control law in San Jose, Calif., in an opinion suggesting that challenges to rent controls are unlikely to succeed except when particular landlords can show they have been denied a fair return.

LEAD: Be-cause Representative Mario Biaggi is involved in litigation, the House ethics committee has decided to delay intro-ducing a resolution caling for his ex-pulsion, according to a statement re-leased today.

LEAD: A mentally ill young man who shot himself in the head in a suicide attempt suffered a brain injury that apparently eliminated his phobia of germs and his obsession with washing his hands, doctors say.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THERE'S a public-service announcement on national television in which a teary-eyed girl flinches as she hears her parents call her stupid and clumsy. A few seconds later a young boy smiles proudly as his parents tell him what a good job he's done. The message is clear. Children learn who they are by how we label them.
LEAD: * American Greeting Corp. filed $100 million of notes due in 1993 through Goldman, Sachs.
